Billy Costigan(Leonardo Di Caprio) is chosen to go undercover and then commits a crime in order to establish credibility with the mobsters and infiltrates the criminal underworld. Departed then becomes a cat and mouse game with each side being aware of the others existence but knowing the actual identity.

The cast is magnificent, with Jack, Leonardo, Matt, plus Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen, and Alec Baldwin, it is an allstar lineup. The problem is both the two and a half hour running time and closing fifteen minutes so bad that it's laughable. It's as if Moe, Larry and Curley from the three stooges took over from Scorcese to complete the project. Best Picture; no way, it should have been Pan's Labyrinth, a masterpiece from Guillermo Del Toro. The academy blew it, big time.

title: Climax....................
review: Climax is the part where the story lacks for me........i mean the idea to make this film was great...the film is kind of grasping in the starting....it catches speed with time...the cast was good....but still the main aspect of the film was not properly made. Story is not so weak but the end makes it look dull....All in all a good movie to watch but still u will be disappointed to see the end which is confined to a small period where people just shoot each other i mean this was not an end expected.............not so thrilling and the duration the film is like 2 and a half hours that makes it more dull a film with such a long duration with a small climax puts a negative impact on the audience.....Don't waste your time on this one.....:p

title: Film Class
review: Martin Scorsese is an impeccable director and this film shines the brightest out of all of his works. The actors chosen for the particular roles, Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, and Jack Nicholson, were perfect because throughout the film the audience began getting emotionally attached to the characters and choosing sides. The plot was full of twists and turns that kept the audience on their feet and made them think about all events that were happening. Throughout the movie, it is as if the viewers are actually on the streets of Boston, amidst all that is going on regarding the police, the criminals, and the "rats" or informants, both good and bad. he star-studded cast adds to the excitement and progression throughout. This film is a classic that will leave the audience stunned with each turn of events and leave them wanting more than Scorsese gives them.

title: Great stuff
review: It was nice to see "The Departed" again today after a long absence. Basic plot: Leo D. plays a Massahusets state cop who goes undercover to ferret out murderous mobster Frank Costello (Nicholson with a hairdo crazier than in The Shining). Back at police HQ, Matt Damon as a detective in Costello's pay helps keep Costello one jump ahead of the cops at all times. Damon also is trying to figure out which of Costello's minions is an undercover cop. Martin Sheen, Mark Wahlberg and Alec Badlwin all have substantial parts in this gritty and very violent crime drama, loosely based on a real gangster of the period (and who has since surfaced after going into hiding decades ago). This is a white knuckle and sometime depressing drama with typical Scorsese flourishes throughout. Which means if you like Scorsese, you'll like this picture.

title: A riveting classic with a top notch cast and crew
review:
– will entertain today, tomorrow and 20 years from now – the dialogue believable, filming and editing, score, costumes, directing --- there is absolutely nothing about this film not to love – but when you put together a cast and crew like this you have every reason to expect a film that will endure the test of time and this absolutely does – beginning to middle to end – no sagging or losing the audience --- and God I love Wahlberg – lol -- one of my personal top 50 films of all time.

Nicholson is his normal psycho self, Baldwin shines, Wahlberg is in one of his finest hours here, Matt Damon shows his versatility - just fabulous acting and directing. Grips you from the opening monologue to the end --

title: Another Scorsese masterpiece
review:
This movie is just excellent. Martin Scorsese always makes the best movies with an amazing cast and this movie is no exception. Every actor does such a bang up job that it makes this movie so real and intense. The only reason I did not give it a 10 was because i was not a big fan of the ending other then that though "perfection"

This movie is about 2 cops who are undercover in the irish mafia. Though as the movie progresses bledshed causes suspisions about the two undercover men and moles are sent out to discover their actual identities

This movie is one of Scorseses best easily. Very good story line, script, direction and acting. Everybody in this movie does a very, very good job. If you like crime dramas and Scorsese GOO WATCH THIS NOW. once again it is a perfect movie I just didn't like the ending soooo 9/10

title: Matt Damon is outstanding
review:
This is a classy bit of film making with some cracking performances. Matt Dillon's portrayal of slimy faux-cop Colin is brilliant, probably the best I've seen from him. He alone makes this film worth watching, and I've watched it 4-5 times and intend to do so again.

Dillon's adversary is faux-hood DiCaprio, sweating his way through a stressful career stint as scary arch-villain Nicholson's sidekick. Throw in a little Sheen and Wahlberg, mix with Baldwin and Winstone, and you have one enthralling movie. For glamour fans there's the delicious Vera Farminga, throwing a cherry on top of the fabulously convoluted plot.

No matter that the story is full of holes and nonsensical, contrived situations. The appeal of this film is gritty, real-life relationships and dilemma. You can smell the fear and taste the blood, thanks to a director and cast who really know what they're doing.

Quite why Damon's performance has gone largely unacknowledged whilst almost everyone else involved with the film has collected awards, is puzzling me. Playing such a complex and shifty character with great depth and understanding is apparently not enough - it seems you have to shout, wave your hands and make funny faces to win awards.

Well done Matt Damon, in my books yours is one of the all-time great performances, and I'd give you an Oscar.

title: Cracking movie.......
review:
The Departed (2006) | My Rating ☛ 7.5/10 151 min - Crime | Mystery | Thriller

First of all I shouldn't have watched Infernal Affairs..coz..I was able to predict everything that was going to happen. Now the question is which one is better? Well, both movies were just awesome however i liked Infernal Affairs little bit then Departed. May b I saw it first. But hats off to these four guys; Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Mark Wahlberg and Jack Nicholson. It was fun to watch Mark Wahlberg he was angry throughout the movie and the dialogues were awesome. All in all a superb movie!!!

title: Good..but not his best by a long shot
review:
Had no idea this film existed if I'm honest, as soon as I turned it on however, a whole host of stars came on screen, Alec Baldwin, Leo Dicaprio, Jack Nicholson, Ray Winston, Matt Damon and more who I simply can't put a name to a face of.

There was a pretty shaky start to the whole thing, changing from characters point of view at one time to anothernot sure if this was the intention or because I missed the first 4 or 5 minutes. I was getting the feeling that it was just going to be a star studded routine film about cops and the bad guys, only with a heapload of actors and violence to keep me entertained, I turned out to be wrong though

A fair few one liners lightened the mood in the dingy and slow moving areasthe rapid changes between characters to different conversations with no transition was rather mind boggling at times.

Midway through I was thinking the plot was a pretty predictable ordeal, only hoping for something out of the ordinarytrue to Damon and Dicaprio to happen and blow me away. Seeing that I was able to foresee everything that was going to happen at this point the film seemed to be nothing special.

Then the film began to have a kick, it got me more interested in what was happening, and surprisingly I wasn't able to predict every moment, the action started to share it's role with making me think about what was going on.

Seeing as The Departed is a 2 and a half hour film, there was only one point during the film I became tired of, this feeling rapidly went away and was able to continue watching what would happen with an eager excitement.

Drawing to an end I was not sure as to what could happen, I had an idea but this was way off, it was a twist and a good one at that. At first this twist seemed to almost completely ruin the film for me until about 5 minutes or so later it all fit into place and I was able to say I thoroughly enjoyed what Scorsese had done with the end of the film.

title: A golden effort from a legendary director
review:
Martin Scorsese has always been known as A legendary director. With masterpieces like 'Raging Bull', 'Good fellas', 'Taxi Driver', and 'Casino', Scorsese never fails to at the very least impress. This film proves that Scorsese is brilliant at doing what he does best.

The Departed is an infuriation of excellence. Watching it is like watching exploding fireworks in the sky. The film captures an unseen, brutal part of Boston, showing it in an undeniably intensifying way. It's filled with excellent performances, outstanding direction, and a great screenplay.

This thriller is filled with jarringly flawless performances. Leonardo DiCaprio and Matt Damon's on-screen 'battle' is suspenseful. You can actually feel yourself rooting for one of them. DiCaprio is furious and exuberant, while Damon is smart and curious. Jack Nicholson makes for a charismatic star in this film. His performance is certainly worthwhile freakish. Lastly, Mark Wahlberg is hilarious. I really haven't seen a better performance from him. Other actors including Martin Sheen, Alec Baldwin, and Vera Farmiga are decent.

Scorsese may not have ventured into this theme so much, apart from Goodfellas, but it mostly seems so. The different camera angles and intelligent shots are dazzling. Inclusive to some overdone foul language and blood/gore, it eventually pays off. I'm definitely counting this film as a worthy Scorsese brilliancy.

It's not easy to write scripts, but this film has an engrossing one. From the start to end, the film is entertaining enough to keep on going. It has a highly suspenseful and sometimes abrupt climax, but otherwise, no problem.

Overall, there's really not enough to justify this achievement. It may not come to the likes of people not familiar with substance material, but it's a must-see for any Scorsese fan. A star-studded cast, worthy direction, and 'exciting' screenplay back up as proof.

title: A great movie with an all-star cast and an intriguing plot line, The Departed has very few flaws.
review:
Storyline

The plot line that the departed follows is sort of cat and mouse type set up. It is the story of two rats, one who is loyal to the Massachusetts state police and the other to Boston Irish crime leader Frank Costello. Billy Costigan is the man who is a good and some what honest cop who Queenan and Dignam are prejudice of because of his family history. While Colin Sullivan who looked up to Costello as a sort of father figure in his youth is the mole inside the state police. Both scramble to find the identity of the other while billy's superiors use him to gather evidence against Costello, while Costello is using Sullivan to keep the state police from gathering evidence against him.

The Good

The irony to the plot line creates an interesting concept to follow. The man who would become the undercover officer the police needed and who could be potentially essential to bringing down Costello is at first quickly rejected from becoming a regular state trooper, while the man who is an informant for Costello is quickly accepted. The twin story lines creates a good effect on the viewer by allowing both stories to unfold around the characters with their paths crossing. Another excellent aspect of The Departed is the characters, the characters have a lot of depth so much so that they seem like they could all exist, from the criminal Costello to the humble cop Captain Queenan. This movie has a large amount of incredible actor some considered to be the best around, with Leonardo DiCaprio, Jack Nicholson, Matt Damon, Mark Wahlberg, and Martin Sheen topping the list. This movie entertains you through its entirety until it comes to an unexpected and satisfying conclusion.

The Bad

Some have said this movie is over done when compared to the original Infernal Affairs. This could seem confusing to some who don't follow it closely because of the two different characters it follows almost an equal amount of time.

and The Conclusion

This movie can entertain almost anyone, with a great storyline and a fantastic cast. Thats why the departed gets a 9/10 from me.

title: return of the Scorsese movie is not great. but its good.
review: Here it is. The Scorsese's movie i've been waiting for. THe Departed. I love Scorsese and his brilliant work and his movies and i was so excited to see this movie. I was so confident that i was going to love this movie. And I actually loved it, but it wasn't what i expected it to be. But this was Leonardo Dicaprio's best role. Jack Nicholson was good and so was Matt Damon. But Mark Whalberg was a cussing machine. Well, that was the problem with this movie: The cussing. There is like 2 or 1 F bombs in every 2 sentences and it got really annoying. Why so many F Bombs??? Although the story was fantastic. But it's just not what i pictured it would be like. Some scenes really bored me too and i didn't really need to know about it. The Actions were OK. But people who like action packed movies such as The Matrix or The Bourne Series are gonna get bored and hate this movie. This is my movie rating. Story: 9/10 Picture/Scenes: 8/10 Character: 9/10 Overall: 8.5/10 BUt i decided to rate it a 8 or a 9 because There is not .5's in IMDb. Thank you and this was just my Opinion.

title: Best since Goodfellas...
review:
I have lost count of the number of times this film has been recommended to me. Consequently I bought the DVD some time ago but never got round to watching it until now. It is a remake of a 2002 Hong Kong film titled Infernal Affairs which was a big hit over there. It deals with crime and police corruption in Boston, and I must admit to those that recommended it to me, it's pretty damn good! More of my thoughts later, here's a brief summary first (summary haters take big Joey for a ride while I write the next paragraph But don't let me catch you readin' it!!!).

State Detective, Billy Costigan, is from the South side of town; he has no family to speak of and so is targeted by Cpt. Queenan and Staff Sgt. Dignam who run undercover operations. They persuade him to get in with crime boss, Frank Costello, who they suspect is selling technology to the Chinese, amongst many other crimes. Little do they know that Costello has an inside man on the police task force, Colin Sullivan. Now Sullivan is not able to get the name of the undercover operative in Costello's gang, but tips him off whenever the cops are getting near. After a while the cops become suspicious that Costello has an inside man amongst their ranks and start up an investigation to find out who the rat is. Cpt. Ellerby appoints Sullivan to lead the investigation. Add to this the fact that Costigan is slowly losing his mind the longer it goes on and has to see a police psychiatrist, Madolyn, who just happens to be Sullivan's girlfriend. With both sides slowly closing in on the insiders a tense and shocking climax is in the offing.

I must say I really enjoyed this film up to a point. That point is the ending, I would have done it differently, but then who am I to argue with a man like Scorsese? A great script by William Monahan really brought out some great performances. First up I thought Leonardo DiCaprio was outstanding as Billy Costigan, Matt Damon totally made me forget the Bourne films as Colin Sullivan and, of course, Jack Nicholson was great, as ever, as Frank Costello. Also on the role of honour are; Mark Wahlberg as Staff Sgt. Dignam and Martin Sheen as Cpt. Queenan. Honourable mentions go to; Ray Winstone as Mr. French (Costello's top henchman), Vera Farmiga as Madolyn, Anthony Anderson as Brown (a cop) and Alec Baldwin as Cpt. Ellerby.

A really engrossing film with just enough twists and turns to keep the audience enthralled without confusing too much. A great script and some really great performances only add to the enjoyment factor. I've already said I have a slight problem with the ending, but it is still a tremendous film and one I don't hesitate to very highly recommend.

My score: 9.3/10

title: The Departed-Ida Allen
review:
Ida Allen HUMN246 F2WW Assignment 5-5 Film Review The Departed

The Departed is an American film based on the 2002 film called Internal Affairs. The Departed takes place in Boston, Massachusetts. The film is centered on crime and deceit. One of the main characters Frank Costello played by the legendary Jack Nicholson is quite the crime leader. He trains and plants Matt Damon's character Colin as an informant at the Massachusetts State police Department. At the same time, the police get wind of some wrong doing and plant their own undercover assignee Leo DiCaprio's character Billy. The Departed is quite the layered film. It is deep and serious through out. It takes more than one viewing in my opinion to fully understand and appreciate the wonderful actors and the stories they tell.

Legendary director Martin Scorsese has been mentioned as one of the most legendary directors of the decade. He really met his match on this film. It is so intricate and detailed that even he said on an entertainment show that he had more to tell than he could truly fit into a respectable time allowance. The theme of The Departed gets down to basics about cops and robbers. It shows the audience about the good guys and the bad guys and shows that sometimes they even pretend to be on the other side when they need to. The central concern in the film is based upon crime and catching the bad guy. The theme mainly focuses on plot and character.

Thematic ideas are truly important when reviewing a film. The plot points of The Departed have so many thematic elements intertwined into it that one has to pull each string of information from it to understand the full picture. For example, the plot involves two trained cadets who are both trying to uncover crime in the same work place of the police department. Both Billy and Colin are working as double agents with the overall goal of catching Costello. The thematic element of character comes into play strongly in this portion of the plot. The characters in the film have very detailed roles and truly make the movie. The Departed is clever, cunning, and meticulous.

There are many undercover scenes where Billy and Colin give incredible performances. The scenes are tense and nerve racking and place you at the edge of your seat. The viewer feels nervous about either Colin or Billy getting caught by Costello. Both sides worry about getting their cover blown, but yet suspect that they are being watched by someone else.

In all reality, they are. Both Colin and Billy are watching the same criminal and one another. The plot thickens when Vera Farmiga's character psychiatrist Dr. Madolyn Madden is involved with both undercover agents. She is the stations psychiatrist and Colin begins seeing her and then Billy also begins a romance with her after meting with her for his probation. This woman could blow both men's cover at the drop of a hat. They refer to the other as a rat. Colin and Billy give stunning performances in this film and left me hoping for a sequel. They provide such a believing performance of their characters and really convince the audience that the good guy, bad guy story line is real.

Techniques used during The Departed really added relevance to the film overall. For example, the lighting in the film was right on the money. A scene where Costello was discussing his crime activities with Colin was often captured in low lighting. This gave me the feel of hidden danger and secrecy. In addition, a scene where Billy was investigating Costello and Colin was often portrayed in natural or low light. This felt surreal and authentic. This provided me with the belief that these characters were real and the film was not just a film, but a real occurrence.

Another example of a technique in the film is camera angle. In a scene where Mark Walhberg who plays Staff Sergeant Sean Dignam who is second in command of the undercover unit and is on a mission to figure out exactly what Colin and Billy is up to makes the audience feel as though they are on the street as well. The angle he is captured when yelling at Colin made me nervous and feels on edge for him. The angle was shot close up and was bona fide.

The theme of The Departed is not a singled out one. There is one other film that comes to mind with the character and plot portrayal of crime and undercover moles in the police department which is Goodfellas. This film is also based upon crime and robbery. The film places direct reference on the theme of character and plot. The main characters Henry Hill and Jimmy Conway take part in a robbery that was in completion of two other gangsters who also have their bids on the crime. The film was quite complex and involved around the characters and the plot.

In conclusion, The Departed has a theme related to character that many can relate to. Costello acted as a father figure to both undercover agents. The main point of theme is identity of the good guy and bad guy. The identity of both agents keep the audience intrigued and the thought of Costello realizing who they are are just captivating. Throughout the movie, Scorsese proved that remakes of earlier films can be as good as the first version and that suspense and thrill are his main ingredients to this film.

References Scorsese, M. (2006). The Departed. Warner Bros. Retrieved October 28, 2010 courtesy Blockbuster rentals.

title: Familiar And Overlong But Exciting Undercover Cop Thriller With Fantastic Ensemble
review:
Desperate to bring down local kingpin Frank Costello, the Boston Police Department convinces a newly graduated officer with a chequered past to go undercover and join Frank's mob. However, Frank has his own agents working for the good guys ...

This fast-moving crime melodrama is pretty good fun but for me it's overly familiar Scorsese territory, with its wiseguys, stoolies, religious backdrop, failed romance and general male identity crises. It was a big hit for him, both financially and perhaps more importantly in that he finally won an Oscar after five nominations. But take it from me - most of those previous nominations were for better movies, and some of his best work wasn't even nominated (Taxi Driver, The King Of Comedy). Don't get me wrong though, there's a lot to enjoy in this flick and in some ways it is quite different - there's much more of a focus on plotting and intrigue, there's Crazy Jack doing his inimitable thing and the big ensemble of heavyweights are all clearly enjoying themselves (Wahlberg wins the Joe Pesci gratuitous swearing award). I liked Damon best as the increasingly confused Judas with a lucky streak a mile wide, and the plot has lots of interesting little quirks, such as the inference that Costigan (and not Sullivan) is the father of Madolyn's child. It goes for the standard Hamlet ending, but in an unexpected way and the final shot of the rat is an amusing metaphor. I've never been particularly enamoured of Scorsese's constant fascination with the link between machismo and male identity - I guess it's an Italian-American thing - but when the picture gets into more universal territory, like the scene in the restaurant where Frank is starting to crack under the pressure of knowing there's a traitor in his midst, it starts to come alive. The movie has an unusual history - it's based on the excellent 2002 Cantonese flick Mou Gaan Dou, aka Internal Affairs (and not to be confused with the 1990 Mike Figgis film of the same name). Aren't the Academy Awards strange ? When Scorsese makes a courageous and deeply personal piece like The Last Temptation Of Christ he loses (to Barry Levinson), but when he does a (slightly inferior) remake of a pulp fiction Hong Kong action flick he wins. Hey, maybe there's a rat in the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

title: Disappointed at theater, but after a second watch, changed my mind
review: I was pretty disappointed with the movie when had watched it at theater for the first time (had difficulty in following the movie especially, found it too fast paced etc.) it was just a good movie, but months later, I watched it on DVD again and changed my mind almost completely. There is everything that a cop movie could include. Of course, this is not the best Scorsese film or my favorite Scorsese film, it is Taxi Driver, but a great movie. And people compare it with the original Asian version (they don't have to do), then they say hard things about this movie. I was disappointed not because of only one reason, but the most problematic thing in the movie was editing, the movie is one of the most exhausting movies ever made, if you ask me. It is like there is no break even to breathe, no break between the events, so a too exhausting experience like he first half of Bourne Ultimatum. The events run, run and run, any kind of method is not used. I don't like the movies has such editing, because you cannot assimilate things. As for the plot, despite this is not an original work, a new version, the story is brainwave, in other words, it is brilliantly written, it adapts 'the idea' almost excellently. I see The Departed as a crime epic, yes it is an epic, not like American Gangster which is pretty good, but usual. The actors. Matt Damon is one of my favorite actors, but the point is that may be because of his persona, may be because of Bourne trilogy, himself (and his character) is one of the factors that make the movie very good. Damon excellently reflects his character's two face. And his unbelievable actions throughout the movie. Jack Nicholson is one of my favorite actors too, but his acting is not overrated, great performance. In addition, his colorful, but at the same time maniac character, Costello is not likable, but very interesting and colorful. I am proud of Alec Baldwin and Mark Wahlberg. Yes sometimes such things happen, a man comes and exhibits an unexpected and excellent performance. I don't like Mark Wahlberg honestly, but in this movie, he goes beyond himself. He is so funny and so serious also, his character. The battle of words scene between Dignam and Ellerby is the peak of Martin Scorsese movies, you know, in Martin Scorsese movies, characters are ribald and as I know, Casino was a record in terms of strong language. The scene was very funny and a bit shocking and makes a reference to Scorsese movies I believe. The best part of the movie, that deserves being in cinema anthology, starts when everything turns into a mess. Orders, coincidences and bad luck. I don't know why, but to witness the greatness of the movie, just watch this scene. It was one of the reasons that made me changed my mind. I don't know the disappointment reasons of other people, but it should not related to the script, acting or direction (except exhausting story telling), because this is a very well written, acted and directed movie with some bitter twists. The success of it comes from the details mostly and its complexity in the story. The movie has flaws, but not little flaws. For example the love triangle is so far fetched and unrealistic. They encounter at home, then have sex. There is an envelope matter which is weird. However, we can interpret it as silliness of Costigan. By the way, almost all the people around me complain about the ending. I have not any problem with the ending. What is the name of the movie? Plus, no uninteresting or dull character. Now it is time for Di Caprio. He raises his bar too. The situations he is in and his relationship with Costello are very exciting, very engrossing, but sometimes harsh and sad. Scorsese should have won the best director Oscar absolutely by The Taxi Driver first, but this is not a movie which I would complain or bother so that he won it by this.

title: Very much worth the credit it received!
review:
You don't have to be a New England fan to love this movie. The scenery is authentic Southy Boston. The story is phenomenal. I am personally very impatient and can barely sit through an episode of Friends or Sex and the City, but the two and a half hours of this movie passed by in no time.

If you like movies similar as Goodfellas then this one will top it. A strong story that keeps you focused to the screen for a long time and you will watch it again.

The story is about two graduate Mass. State troopers. One of them is deemed so intelligent, he is offered an under cover position to uncover Castello's mob network in South Boston. The other one is a rat in the State police revealing information to Castello's organization.

Definitely worth making it to the IMDb top 250.

title: Excellent Rip-Off
review:
It is a wonderful movie, I really enjoyed watching, but it kind of makes me mad that it won 4 Oscars only because Scorsese "americanised" the story of infernal affairs. Of course Scorsese changed a lot. There's is some improvement. For Example : In Infernal Affairs every time somebody gets shot they play music, so the scene gets more "emotional". But I loved those silent killings at the end of TD. Then character development is a bit different. TD concentrates on relationship, whereas Infernal Affairs concentrates on the two mules and the way they become part of their environment. I think that this aspect is portrayed better in Infernal Affairs.

The rooftop scene - In Infernal Affairs the rooftop scene is much cooler, much more intelligent. On the other hand, it is good that Scorsese changed it, because it wouldn't fit to the concept of the movie.

title: Scorsese is the master
review:
I don't think I have to read every comment here to say what I have to say about this movie: it is the work of a master and that will make it always worth watching.

The very first time I saw a Martin Scorsese film, it was 'Mean Streets' and it gave me an anxiety attack. I thought I wouldn't be able to cope with all the adrenaline making me sit on the edge of my seat throughout that movie. Little did I know that any movie of the crime-suspense genre by Scorsese would make me feel this way and I had better get used to it.

Spielberg should bow and scrape every time he sees the master. And any actor with a brain would crawl through broken glass to get to work on a Scorsese picture.

The fact that this was a remake of a great Chinese film invites comparisons between the two. I think I will wait a good long while before I see the Chinese film and I will probably love it as much but with distance and time between the two stories.

Mark Wahlberg was blessed to get the role that he did in this film. He had to do little except act the part of tough native Bostonian. His somewhat important part in the story didn't really shock or amaze. He got recognition for his role simply by being involved in this wonderful production.

Can Martin Scorsese tell a story better than anyone on the effin planet or what? Can he recognize a humdinger of a story when he sees one better then any effin director alive today or what? Can he dig the diamonds out of the effin coal while working in effin politically correct effin Hollywood or what? Sorry, just still feeling the effin spirit of the effin movie's effin language, that's all.

There's a haze of dread that hangs over every scene like pollution. Does that come from the viewer's intuition or does the director, with the writers, the camera man or the lighting guy, put it there?

In almost every scene, there's the new lethal weapon (call it Lethal weapon XXVI): the cell phone. Every time one rings in someone's pocket on screen, you want to stand up and scream, 'Don't answer it!' The cell phone is the new character, deserving separate billing, getting 'offed' (thrown in water) or marked with blood (literally).

As in all crime plots, the black character is marked - you know he is going to get whacked, it's just a question of when.

Matt Damon and Leonardo di Caprio give equally powerful performances but Leo is the lucky guy who has the audience rooting for him. They look a bit alike and this cannot be an accident. They look like they SHOULD be related. In real life, in the non-screen world, Whitey Bulger and Billy Bulger are brothers and have been living a drama based in Boston that also pits good against evil (brothers, Whitey is a mobster on the lam, Billy was the president of the University of Massachusetts, both Irish, both Bostonian). There's a fabulous irony that somewhere, Whitey Bulger probably owns this DVD and watches it in a setting not unlike some of the film sets.

There has been talk that Costello, the Nicholson character, was loosely based on Whitey Bulger. That isn't important. The good/evil conflict is, and it is very Bulger family - like. Kudos to the screenwriter, William Monahan, who has more than a little knowledge of the Bulgers, having written a book about them, and knows how to write one quotable line after another. Bang, pow, wham! They just keep coming, making your wish you could carry those lines around in your pocket. 'I'm the guy who does his job. You must be the other guy.' Alec Baldwin and Leo have best lines - the dialogue just comes from them, as if they went home at night and wrote the lines themselves -but Nicholson has his share, too.

Nicholson is great but he plays, who else, the Irish American version of Jack Nicholson. Great nonetheless.

The dark scenes with the soundtrack of the slammin bangin Dropkick Murphy's music: everything is harmonious in this movie as long as we are in bars, alleys and dark, hidden places.

I have the tiniest criticsm of one plot point in the movie: who cares if your identity is erased from a computer? As everyone who ever has touched a computer knows by now, everything lost can be found again!

I also want to thank the Academy for recognizing this picture - what's with all the other crap coming out of Hollywood these days, anyway?

title: Scorcese Imitating Scorcese?
review: When I put the fact that Scorcese directed this flick against the finished product, I was left scratching my head. Scorcese has always had the goods where gangster films are concerned. But, I have to say I'm now inclined to think that there WAS a time when you could go to see a Scorcese movie and know you were getting first class. You never had to worry. THE DEPARTED may have killed that notion...at least for the time being. I went straight out and bought the double disc edition with the movie script booklet purely based in the fact that Scorcese directed it. (Note: in FIRST run of the DVD in Australia, released February 14 2007, the second disc's special features don't match those advertised on the box cover - there are fewer on the disc itself than printed on the back. This is a print error that Warner Brothers have since acknowledged and will be rectified in future prints.) It is not a bad film by any stretch; it's still very entertaining, however, the actors didn't quite reach the level of authenticity I would have expected - especially since the cast is a bevy of Hollywood's A-List male actors. Jack Nicholson is a brilliant performer - he always brings an intensity to any role he plays. And he did this here, occasionally throwing in that jagged edge of insanity he is famous for. However, I just couldn't believe him as a mob leader specifically. Matt Damon - always been a favourite of mine. But what's going on, mate? Here we see him attempting to achieve the persona of a sly, corrupt cop in the way he THOUGHT it should be played, rather than actually becoming the role. In a number of his roles, he has come across as somewhat conscious of how he is delivering the character, and this was no exception. For me he didn't quite fit the role. Mark Wahlberg's sharp mouthed, a-hole cop was almost unnecessary. I couldn't piece him into the picture; the film could have easily survived without this role, regardless of the fact that he was required to round out the plot in the final scene. But, his angle on character delivery was too forced and exaggerated, and in placing him into the full context of the story, his existence was more a hindrance than a help. The only really solid performance here was Leonardo DiCaprio. And this is something I never thought I'd admit to. I have never been a fan. However, in this film, he has proved beyond a shadow of a doubt that he is a main player. Overall, THE DEPARTED didn't quite showcase the legendary capabilities of Scorcese as a director. And for this reason, the final product looks more like a film made by a lesser known director trying to IMITATE Scorcese's style, but doesn't fully achieve the equivalent. Thus, we don't see the full potential of what we know to be a brilliant cast. The flow of the movie is left somewhat disjointed and scattered, making it difficult for the audience to fully submit to the plot and the experience. And this is a pity since you really need to pay attention to the plot to catch the wave and stay with it. However, it is entertaining. Most people will probably enjoy it - if not for the juiciness of a violent gangster flick then certainly for the cast. Still very worth the watch if you love Scorcese.

title: Best Crime Drama of the Decade
review: I haven't been so blown away by a film in a long time and this immediately got put on my favorite movies list. I've seen comments left by other users who are fans of Infernal Affairs which is the film The Departed is based on. They bashed this movie saying it was "too americanized" or "the characters were ruined" but i feel differently. The original movie Infernal Affairs was good, but I can't say I liked it as much as The Departed. Many things highlight this movie such as a diverse group of characters and personalities, a VERY strong cast, excellent acting by all cast members, and a plot that took my breath away. The moment I walked out of the movie theater I said to myself "that one's gonna win Best Picture" and it did. Enjoy this milestone of a film and remember it for years to come.

title: Oscar????
review: Best movie i have seen this year ,so ,i reckon it is probably justified as the best picture. But yea its a great story with some great performances,similar to Crash really,but for an Oscar as best Pic don't you think it should be more than just a good story. Now i'm confusing myself,i suppose the purpose of this web site is too recommend a movie and avoid anyone watching the dross they produce nowadays ,so that in itself ,i will conclude that The Departed is a very well recommended movie which we enjoyed immensely.........but is it an Oscar winning. !!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Of course Jack Nicholson puts in another quirky performance that we expect of him and i am never disappointed with Jacks name in the credits.Martin Scorcesse once points fun in the direction of the criminal and organised crime,sometimes i think that it glamorises ,but hey its a movie.Thought the sex scene was a tad unnecessary,but no real overuse of bad language.great really enjoyed.

title: The Departed Has Left 314 Wash Street
review: lots of bodies, should be this films title. Scorsese is at his best doing movies where the villain is more fun than the main characters. Nicholson shines in this film. His glowing hallow around Nicholson makes moderate performances by the other actors playing mob guys look excellent. Tony Sirrico and Gandolfini (Sopranos) act as if they are mobsters, the guys in this film "not so much". In fact in a couple of scenes they looked bored in the background. Scorsese doesn't spend much time worrying about his background players and it shows. Many scenes where an extra actor could add something to the scene. They Bump On A Log. I believe it is an east coast acting theme that believes heroes, major characters, should only be the ones on camera. I did not like Snakes On A Plane however, the director had a moving grooving set, with lots to look at both foreground and background. I found Martin Sheen, Baldwin, and Wahlberg's performances trumped Damon's performance by a long shot. Di Caprio stole this movie. He was unrelenting, viciously psychopathic and yet tender at times. The best scene is in the porno theater when he is listening. He did not take the easy way out by just sitting there, no Di Caprio outdid both Nicholson and Damon in a scene where he's just sitting there. Wahlberg, plays his character, as a vicious jerk, which seems overplayed. However, Scorsese, plays the viewer for the fool when he, the unemployed cop, kills a rat in the end. Excellent film because Di Caprio, Sheen and Wahlberg tugged out Oscar Winning Performances from what can be played as a mobster movie. Nicholson was a perverted mobster which I felt did not do the character justice and Damon adequately weaselly did an OK job.

title: A Film for all movie lovers
review:
In the film The Departed directed by Martin Scorsese audience viewers will get to experience an action packed film, filled with internal character turmoil, played by some of the best "A" list actors Hollywood has ever seen. The three main characters, Billy Costigan played by Leonardo Decaprio, Colin Sullivan played by Matt Damon, and Frank Costello played by Jack Nicholson are all facing a moral and ethical dilemma. Throughout the film the audience will see how each character contemplates doing what is morally right, or sticking to their alliances with other characters in the film.

In the opening scene of the movie we are shown how Colin's allegiance to Frank Costello, played by Jack Nicholson, is developed. Colin is a young child sitting isolated in a deli. Frank comes in to collect "taxes" from the deli owner. After causing a commotion with the deli owner, Frank makes the owner give young Colin milk and bread, because Frank knows that Colin does not have a good family life. Fast Forward into time and Colin is now working his way through the Boston Police Department to work as a mole for Frank Costello. Simultaneously as Colin is going through the ranks we are introduced to Billy who is working through the ranks for good intentions, to change the perception of his family's name.

The director, Martin Scorsese uses a variety of film techniques to portray the underlying mystery and suspense in the film. Scorsese uses a lot of low-key lighting to create an almost depressing atmosphere in most of the action scenes. The audience can almost predict when something bad is going to happen. Scorsese also uses high angle shots to diminish Billy's worth within the police department, while low angle shots are used to make Collin appear more respected. This style of directing can also be seen in Orson Wells film Citizen Kane.

The Departed is a film that all movie viewers will love, whether you're looking for a love story, an action flick, or a suspense thriller. Viewers will be on the edge of their seat from the start of the movie all the way up through the end of the movie. As the characters develop, and the plot thickens, viewers can't help but to hope that good will overcome evil.

title: Wow...
review:
This movie was AWESOME! Matt Damon did good, Leonardo Dicaprio did great, Jack Nicholson did awesome, but being that he was barely even there, Mark Wahlberg did the BEST! This drama film almost turned into comedy every time he spoke.

The film held an excellent story line leaving you waiting for more till the very, very end and yet leaves you wanting more. It's a who did, when, what? kind of movie that leaves the audience at the edge of their seats to puzzle piece ever thing together.

I'd definitely keep this movie in my collection to watch again, and again. Leo is hot, so why wouldn't I? Can't get any better action this this. I'd put 3 thumbs up if I had an extra, but I guess till then, I'll give two thumbs up to the sky!

title: To our fatefully departed
review: I just finish watching The Departed for the second time, and although I rarely ever write a review here at IMDb I felt compelled to put my thoughts into words and share them. I believe TD is an excellent film. Seeing Leonardo grow into himself an play an amazing believable character as an rat with a conscience is amazing, good on him. Nicholson is amazing like always, trowing coke at hoos !!!! jajajajaj great ! Even good ol Marky Mark plays a deep caracther ... you hate him at the beginning but at the end he delivers .... 10 point to MM. And last mr. Damon is alright, I don't really like him that much so the fact that he plays the real f... at goes very well, good on mr Martin for a tremendous job, or should I say in a common term in these section... a tour de force !

title: Brilliant...but be very awake, bright eyed and bushy tailed!!
review:
It goes without saying that this is another piece of Scorcese excellence, however I made the idiotic mistake of watching it when I was tired and probably should have been in bed. A big mistake - you'll want to watch this when you're totally focused and enthusiastic, otherwise you'll have trouble piecing it all together and following the plot. I won't go into the story on this one; instead I'll give rundown of the actors' performances - and this is something anybody considering watching this flick will want to know given the celebrated A-List cast assembled. I have never been a fan of Leonardo DiCaprio. (His performance in "The Basketball Diaries" was flawless. Other than that, he's been very ordinary). However, after watching "The Departed" I had to humble myself and admit that his delivery in this flick was nothing short of brilliant! He and Jack Nicholson carried this film, if no one else. And, in a way, this is a shame when you compare it to the other somewhat bland performances by the other cast. This is what upsets the movie and makes it seem disjointed, thus becoming a distracting factor in an otherwise brilliant film. Jack Nicholson doesn't seem to need to make any effort in his acting technique - he pulls it off each time. His performance is incredibly focused and well timed, with that trademark edge of demented deviance he brings to almost all his characters. I've ALWAYS been a Matt Damon fan. However - and I hate to admit it - but his performance here was almost wooden. I don't think it was a role he fully submitted to. Again, like a small handful of his other performances, he was playing 'Matt Damon'. You can detect a touch of self-consciousness in his delivery. However, this won't deter a lot of Damon's fans. Mark Wahlberg's arrogant cop was just passable, however I could see a touch of his 'Dirk Diggler' from "Boogie Nights" in the way he delivered his dialogue. In a documentary from the accompanying Special Features disc, he mentions that he was playing the type of cop who used to arrest him when he himself was a teen. And this seems to be precisely what he does: he imitates someone else, rather than putting his own interpretation on the role. A pity, since Wahlberg is actually a great actor. In a relatively small role, Alec Baldwin is actually outstanding. This might be the role which may reprise his career after all! Martin Sheen - do I need to comment? This guy is brilliant no matter what he does. A very focused performance.

All in all, this film is incredibly well done, in true Scorcese style. A few continuity errors and audio overdubs/lip-synch changes are present, however, once immersed in the entertainment, viewers will be happy to dismiss these. (Or, perhaps, those who know and expect perfection from Scorsese may be somewhat shocked by these minor, yet mildly distracting errors.) Still highly recommended to any Scorcese fan or fans of the cast. Definitely worth the two and a half hours.

SPOILER: A lot of the film's bung-ups have been mentioned already in full list, however one that I haven't yet seen is the audio overdub of Matt Damon's voice when he is asking his informants over the phone what fell off the building. His actually asks what fell off the 'roof', however the audio says, 'building'. The second time he asks the same question, both his mouth and audio deliver 'roof'.

title: Another voice comparing the two
review:
I managed to see both "Infernal Affairs" (hereafter "Mou gaan dou") and "The Departed" in one sitting and would like to compare them. To start, I would give them the same rating (8) and praise them equally. But the strengths are uneven.

What follows is TOTAL SPOILER and meant only for others who have seen both.

* Religion In Mou gaan dou, the mob boss Sam is religious. He indirectly attributes his success to his faith and ties in the disciples through a ritual of loyalty. He rules by this ingrained sense of loyalty and is never portrayed as fearful. In Departed, mob boss Frank rules entirely through fear, violence and intimidation. He caps this off with utter contempt for the Church. Who would stay loyal to a guy like that?

* Class The Departed's greatest strength is in the in-depth analysis of the class conflict in New England's Irish community. References to "lace-curtains" and "shanties" is an allusion to long-standing symbolism of this conflict. This was a compelling introduction to the characters that Mou gaan dou left out, and went very far to explaining their motivations.

* Language The language in Mou gaan dou is richly oblique ("At least I am not afraid to let the sun shine on me" says Yan toward the end.) and only occasionally rough. The language in Departed is relentlessly coarse and filled with coarse metaphors, puns and references. The language in each fits with the consistent tone of the acting. The two main spooks are cool in Mou gaan dou, and nearly hysterical in Departed.

* Overall The Departed's beginning was utterly brilliant, far outclassing Mou Gaan Dou. But the high level of violence in Departed wore thin on me. By the time of the big bust, I felt that Mou gaan dou leaped ahead in crafting a complex drama that was not just another shoot-em-up. The cat-and-mouse chase between the spooks was FAR more compelling in Mou gaan dou, and the last scene in Departed proved that not even Scorcese can avoid the demands to give 'em a happy ending.

title: The seamy side of the Megalopolis of the northeast USA
review:
I rented this DVD in March 2007 after in won 2007 Oscars awards in Film Editing, Writing, Directing, and Best Picture. I watched it twice, with numerous "Replay" and "Slow" the second time.

Yes, I recommend renting the DVD of "The Departed".

To me it shows a realistic portrayal of the seamy side of the Megalopolis of the northeast USA. My father was raised in working-class Boston, and his description of the collaboration between corrupt police and organized crime matches what is shown in this film.

Unlike the majority of American films, this is realistic. It shows how life in the traditional cities near Boston interacts with small-time criminals. In many parts of the USA, like new suburbs of the Sunbelt, mafioso tactics like shown in this film do not reach down to working class citizens.

As shown by the Oscar awards bestowed by the entertainment industry, this film is an extraordinary achievement in the cinematic arts. My own time spent living in working-class neighborhoods of the old parts of NYC and Chicago shows this film has taking a boring scenario and spiced it up by showing the seamy background. This means understanding the complex dynamics of the denizens of countless neighborhood bars that function as restaurants and public meeting spaces. Guys like me are reluctant to enter these "pubs" because of the alleged fights that occur within, as shown in The Departed.

It shows the positive side of the patronage for those families who do owe allegiance to local crime bosses.

title: flick watch
review:

title: Some "Gaffes" are NOT Gaffes
review:
There seem to be a few over zealous "reviewers" who got a BIT confused by this films DELIBERATE non-linear and labyrinthian narrative. The "confusion" over the address where Di Caprio and sheen "renedevous clandestinely"(144 being quoted over a phone as 114)IS DELIBERATE...and is revealed to be a major plot twist MOMENTS LATER IN THE FILM.

Likewise, the "gaffe" of our seeing the childhood photo of Vera Farmigia being moved into Matt Damon's apartment only to see it moments later in the film back in HER apartment AS SHE begins to pack TO MOVE TO DAMON's PLACE IS DELIBERATE...and reveals that she has been involved with Damon and Di Caprio SIMULTANEOUSLY (the subtlety may have been an effort to give conviction to what could have been read as a corny "coincidence" (and was called such by many critics...).

I suggest a reviewing on DVD...THERE ARE A FEW NITPICKING ANACHRONISMS...but have SOME respect for the director's narrative chops!

title: Nicholson
review: Jack dominates the film. He is so completely in charge every time we see him that the scene where he is killed seems a bit unreal. Wouldn't he have understood that the only reason this cop would have to keep him around would be that he knew something important? However quibbles aside this is a good, not great movie. It isn't close to Goodfellas or Godfather but it does tell a story, the acting is excellent and for the most part character motivation is on course. The psychiatrist is played as well as possible although she is the weak link and could have easily been omitted. If she was to be left in it would have been nice to see why she would act as she did. Worth seeing for Nicholson's performance.

title: Unforeseen Tragedy
review:
"The Departed" is captivating movie-making. "The Departed" is not the year's Best Picture; although it seems destined for the Oscar gold. Director Martin Scorcese generates powerful and compelling performances from Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Mark Wahlberg, and Jack Nicholson. Writer William Monahan's story is based on the screenplay for "Infernal Affairs" by Alan Mak and Felix Chong. "The Departed" starts off great and has a stunning Act 2. However, Act 3 is horrible in the sense that the movie suddenly turns stupid, and then desperately and unconvincingly ties up loose ends. I think Martin Scorcese wants to demonstrate that along with his preoccupation with the darker side of humanity, he also has a sense of cinematic justice. This is a feeble attempt at best.

The going in premise is an intriguing look into intertwined cultures from the perspective of cultural moles. Colin Sullivan is a smart sharp kid in Boston, virtually raised by Irish Mafia kingpin Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson). Colin (Matt Damon) becomes a Boston Police cadet and quickly rises through the ranks of the Boston Police Department. Sgt. Colin Sullivan remains beholding to Frank. Colin becomes a key player in a federal task force that infiltrates the Boston Irish Mafia. On the polar opposite, Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio) is a bright police cadet with questionable family ties which does not bode well for his career as a police officer. We witness Billy burying his dead mother. Billy's late father was a man of honor, an Airport worker who refused to join Frank Costello. Billy strikes a deal with Boston Police Capt. Queenan (Martin Sheen) and Detective Dignam (Mark Wahlberg) to go rogue undercover and disavowing any ties to the Department. Billy's job is to get in with Frank. Along the way Colin romances police staff psychiatrist Madolyn (Vera Farmiga). Farmiga has the thankless job of essentially portraying a plot device, as charming as she is.

The performances in "The Departed" are amazing. For that acknowledge Scorcese. Leonardo DiCaprio has grown into a powerful leading actorhe commands the screen. He is edgy and dangerous. It is puzzling that Matt Damon did not receive more acclaim for his role as insider Colin. Damon balances a slick soullessness and believable consuming desperation. Jack Nicholson as Frank displays unrecognizable restraint in a compelling performance. Ultimately, the script fails the movie. During an early scene in the movie Billy (DiCaprio) quotes Nathaniel Hawthorne. Detective Dignam (Wahlberg) makes the snide remark that he was expecting him to quote Shakespeare. Ironically, "The Departed" is not great tragedy. It is not Shakespeare. Unfortunately, it seemly intended to be so. This in itself is tragic, given the promise of the story's premise and the superb cast. My friend Chuck said that "The Departed" would have been great if it ended before devolving into senseless violence. His comment is brilliant and insightful. There is neither great catharsis nor any grand noble act in the end to redeem "The Departed". What we are left with is a harried mess. And that is truly a tragedy.

title: A well crafted film
review: I have watched it once and will do it again! It is a very well done movie. If the whole story doesn't shock you, the ending will. The plot is set very well. I would say that it has a bit of different types of movies - comedy, theatrical, drama, crime - all in one. The performances were very enthusiastic, every actor played their best. Bringing all of those well known actors together - Jack Nicholson, Leo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, and Mark Wahlberg - in one film, is the icing on the cake. If it wasn't set up the way it was, I would consider it to fall in the lines of a "chic flick" - only for the actors in it. Most of them are still what most ladies would consider to be the "ladies man". The entire movie is so spectacular that I would definitely recommend this movie to others, and I definitely look forward to seeing the sequel (if they make one).

title: A Masterpiece Except for several Scorsesesque flaws.
review:
Seriously Director Martin Scorsese finally delivers a mind blowing, crowd pleasing, genuine Hollywood heavyweight. And his long-time loyalists can't be more thankful. Credit begins with a brilliantly complex screenplay adapted from the 2002 Chinese film "Infernal Affairs." As Scorsese testifies, "It was the first picture I made with a plot." It seems like that is exactly what the people were waiting for, as the opening weekend gross of $26.8 million obliterated all other Scorsese releases. And regardless of its many shortcomings*, Marty certainly reassures us all that he is still the master of modern mortality with a riveting final half-hour of elegant and exciting violence that is right on par with the 'Baptism/Murder' crescendo in "The Godfather Part I"-- when Michael Corleone finishes all of the family's unfinished business. With "The Departed," it seems that Marty also finishes some business of his own.

*First, realize a few things: that this film takes place in a fantasized contemporary world, that Jack Nicholson can't help but act extremely ridiculous, and of course, that Marty Scorsese is a highly stylized director the musical selections, the over-lighting, the frequent and casual violence, and the excessive story exposition and once all of this is understood, or more importantly, accepted (asking too much?), then you can really begin to have fun with this movie.

Now, coping with Nicholson's absurd over-performance is probably an issue on to its own How much better might this movie have been had DeNiro played Frank Costello, rather than the attention starved Jumpin' Jack, who seemed like he was just horsing around until he got to the Lakers game later that night (i.e. playing with a dildo in a porno theater)? See Born Critic for more on that

http://borncritic.blogspot.com/2006/10/departed.html

On the other hand, the rest of the cast displays career acting performances, most notably Leo DiCaprio, who brings an amazing raw energy and intensity to his roles, balancing both the physical and psychological demands of his complex character, and was only beat out for a Best Actor nod by himself in "Blood Diamond."

http://manwithavan.blogspot.com/

title: A Masterpiece of the Millennium
review:
Having to admit that I was skeptical that Martin Scorsese can pull up a new great movie like he did in the past 3 decades (Mean Streats, Raging Bull, Goodfellas and Casino to name a few) especially being ignored by the Oscar committee for over 40 years of great work!!!, I was skeptical in the beginning of the quality of this movie. Yet Having the Legendary director with full star cast including Jack Nicholson, Leonardo DiCaprio, Martin Sheen, Alec Baldwin, Matt Damon and Mark Wahlberg who could miss a movie like that?!!! I have to admit that I spent some of the finest 150+ Mins in my life watching this magnificent movie.

I have to be honest that I would never have thought that it would be half as good as it was. Me being a person who watched thousands of movies in my life there is a little room for surprises to me but I was SHOCKED.

This movie will be held in the movies hall of fame to be one of the wittiest , brilliantly acted and directed movies of all time. Not a single minute of boredom in over two and half hours of brilliance. This movie just cracked its way in my Top 10 List ever. There are no words that describe the script smoothness and slickness throughout the whole movie. Leornard Di Caprio have entered in a new dimension in his acting skills and now he is not the boy with pretty face , no this Guy can on par to the greatest actors alive now. Nothing short of brilliant. No need to mention Jack Nicholson because he is the master who never really misses , Alec Baldwin, Matt Damon and Mark Wahlberg probably have done the roles of their lives. I haven't mentioned Vera Farmiga as she is pushing her way into stardom with the act she did in this movie.

Throughout the movie you will feel no one is really acting and it's the real thing you are watching. Excellent camera control and flashbacks that really don't interrupt the movie flow but just gives you a glimpse of the background of every character.

If you don't like Scorsese or DiCaprio or any of the great film cast or you being offended by violence or profane language, I Still advise you to push yourself to watch this movie because it's like an experience which you will never forget. For the younger audience who haven't watched the Great movies like Godfather , Goodfellas , Pulp Fiction, etc.. you will probably believe that this is the Best Movie you have seen in your life. Go watch it, enjoy it, buy it on DVD, Tell your kids about it and pass it on to your grand children . It'S UNMISSABLE!!

And Yes Folks this is better than Goodfellas , Raging Bull and Mean Streets combined. No offense To De Niro cause he is still my favorite actor ever. Long live Scorsese!!!

title: The Question, Part 1
review:
Remember when I said "Match Point" moved fast? Well, "The Departed" moves faster; so much faster that the name of the film appears after the movie has begun developing the plot and it would have been the same if it appeared at anytime. Characters speak without pauses, throwing intelligent lines from time to time; the music is too loud and it never seems to stop. Every time I paid attention the loud music was in the back; as if the montage of the first scene was still running.

It's fine, but I was thinking about the beginning of "Goodfellas" and how much I loved the speech he gives; gentle and slowPaused. Here, Jack Nicholson gives a wonderful opening speech but it goes so fast that if you close your eyes you miss its essence. The same goes for some talks between Vera Farmiga and Leonardo DiCaprio and between Matt Damon and Alec Baldwin that lie between the best little scenes of the movie.

I didn't watch the original piece in which William Monahan based his script, but Monahan still doesn't convince me. There's a lack of seriousness to his work and he'll get an Oscar for it. However, when his "Kingdom of Heaven" was short of words, this screenplay has words to spare. I probably miss the days of "Taxi Driver", when Bob drove through the streets and there was no need for words to express his feelings.

Here we encounter the great Martin Scorsese in a rush, as his movie of course. The pictures of Scorsese I've watched made me understand he was a calm and observing director, with a lot of messages to give in each film and a lot of importance to give to the screenplay. "The Departed" doesn't instantly find messages, but the screenplay rushes; and Scorsese doesn't stay behind. With his ability, Marty followed his characters rapidly, moving constantly his camera; whether in a chase scene or in a chat inside of an office where the close ups are instantaneous and the frames show a character by the second. In addition, he still found the time of creating new and interesting filming shots that go along with the film's rhythm.

That "The Departed" is far from being Scorsese's best picture is a fact; but it's probably the best he's done this decade. And that's enough to get him an Oscar before he starts desperately trying for one and goes back to make films without a burden or a personal pressure; because he won't give up the crusade for an award he simply deserves.

As I said, a part of me wants the old Bob back, but as the years go by, Leo is kind of growing on me. I mean, he'll never be my favorite actor or anything similar; but his performance is the finest of "The Departed" cast. I look back at his retarded kid in "What's Eating Gilbert Grape" and I think to myself that when DiCaprio isn't on the main focus (because it's where he's always been), he can hand in some great portrayals.

And what an ensemble! I mean, Scorsese can get big names that are among the biggest talents. Don't even mention Jack Nicholson, who's not in the run for the big awards because we are rewarded when we watch him on screen; it's his present to us. Mark Wahblberg, an actor I've always liked, could have gotten recognition for a couple of films where he outshined the leads some time ago; but is perfect here in a role that was definitely for an older person. If we say older persons we find the fabulous portrayal of Ray Winstone and two underrated performances of Martin Sheen and Alec Baldwin (what a year he had). What was even more underrated was Matt Damon's incredible turn as Collin Sullivan, the second in line after DiCpario's performance in the movie and easily his best labor since "The Talented Mr. Ripley".

Is anyone sure if Vera Farmiga has nothing to do with the Arquette family? She looks a lot likeAnyway, she's a good actress. I refuse to talk about Anthony Anderson, but the question remains: "Is 'The Departed' the Best Picture Oscar of the year?".

title: Even an All-star cast cant save this piece....
review: I just saw this movie earlier tonight and all I can say is: what a disappointment! I was expecting a Scorsese masterpiece, instead I get this crap! This movie is long, disjointed, and fails to capture the viewers attention. What does everybody see in this crap? It has the feel of a movie that was written by multiple people, edited to death by numerous individuals. Somehow they cant come up with a comprehensible story. Its a shame because this movie could have been real tight. Poor martin sheen is more like a confused grandfather figure than any sort of important police official. There are tons of things that happen throughout the movie that are never explained and make no sense. This is no Godfather... hell, it ain't even up the standard of carlitos way. Shame on you Scorsese!

title: A Crime thriller that will have you dropping your Rs by the end
review: My brother and i saw the Departd about a month ago, but were not sure that it would much different than the Boondock Saints. We left the theater in absolute awe, as the movie was just that good. I would not recommend this movie to anyone with a weak stomach, or is easily offended by graphic language. Being from the Boston Area, this film was a must see for me. If you are a fan of any action movie, such as the Boondock Saints, or Fight Club, this movie id most definitely a must see. If you are Irish, or are from Boston, you really need to see this movie. Be prepared however, it is on the longer side... somewhere around 3 hours. Overall i think this gets a perfect 10 stars, and I can't Wait until i get to see it again

title: You think you know everything, but you will be on the edge of your seat anyway.
review:
I can't remember the last time I watched a movie that could keep me so engrossed from start to finish. This movie is a reminder why Martin Scorsese is a director's director. There no point in this movie that says formula. It is original and packed with incredible acting. This is by far Matt Damon's best performance. I generally like his movies, but I always saw him as one of those actors that looked like they were acting. He sank himself into this part and deserves recognition for great acting. Scorsese knows how to bring out the best in his actors because even the legendary Jack Nicholson out performs himself.

A superb film

title: Language
review: The movie is good, but I am curious to know why the writers have to resort to so much bad language. Many great movies have been made without inundating the audience with senseless cursing every other word. In reality the "F-bomb" was dropped, on average, every thirty seconds. I would think that the "writers" could try to convey their message by using more powerful writing. It's too bad. I can't really recommend this movie because the foul language is the only thing thing that stuck in my head instead of a good story. It's no wonder people today speak in such a disrespectful manner. It's all that Hollywood throws at them.

title: some good performances, but full of problems
review:
I know no one is going to read this, but this move irritated me so much that I have to blow off steam.

I was looking forward to seeing this movie, but I was completely disappointed by the inadequate screenplay, the distracting casting, and Scorsese's weak choices. The story is full of holes. A very few examples: a big deal is made about a letter which is then forgotten, and characters do things that don't make sense (would you warn a known murderer that you're on to him, and then agree to meet him in a deserted warehouse? Why not just go to his superior with all your evidence?).

The character of Madolyn (why the bizarre spelling?) was completely frustrating. As usual for a big American film, there are dozens of featured male characters and only one woman (other than a few minor roles), so she has to serve as the love interest for both of the main actors. Yet nothing comes of this "love triangle", so why include it? Supposedly Madolyn was really happy with Colin, yet she has sex with Billy who, inexplicably, seems to know no other women. Rather than deepening my feelings about the characters, this situation just puzzled me, and made me think that Madolyn was a pretty bad psychologist. Actually, I got the impression Scorsese was hedging his bets with the Madolyn character--she adds so little to the plot that she could easily have been cut.

There are some good performances in the movie, particularly Jack Nicholson's and Martin Sheen's, but I felt that Scorsese cast people he likes and not necessarily actors who were right for the roles. Obviously, Mark Wahlberg's performance has its fans, but he didn't convince me at all as a foul-mouthed tough guy, with his baby-face and floppy hair. Leonardo DiCaprio did a good acting job, but he's too physically slight to be really believable as a gang strongarm. Martin Sheen was the only one who managed to disappear into his part. (Though I didn't believe for a second that a no-nonsense guy like Queenan, as Sheen played him, would have stood for all that lip from Dignam.)

There are some bits that really made me wonder about Scorsese's own beliefs. Both the gang characters and the police make sexist remarks, which they probably would in real life, but the women around them don't get any lines to respond, so the comments are left to stand. Scorsese seems to be on the side of Billy when he beats a guy senseless for saying that his drink is girly, as if that were the only appropriate response to such an insult. Possibly that's not what Scorsese meant at all--he may have just been trying to show how far Billy would go to play his assigned role--but what are we to make of the fact that an Asian man is accidentally killed in the course of the story, and then never mentioned again, as if the murder doesn't "count"? Racism? Or did Scorsese forget about that, the way he forgot about the letter?

I've read a lot on IMDb about how much of the movie was lifted from "Infernal Affairs". I haven't seen that film, but I was appalled to see how Scorsese ripped off a famous scene in "The Third Man". (At the funeral.) He also apparently paid "homage" to Howard Hawks by stealing his use of "X's" from "Scarface". (I didn't notice that myself, but several people on IMDb have mentioned it.) I think someone needs to teach Scorsese the difference between affectionately referencing someone else's work, and just taking from it because you haven't thought of anything as good yourself. I'm really angry at him for making sure that now, whenever I see that powerful scene in "The Third Man", I'm going to think of a movie that I mainly disliked. And what was the deal with that ridiculous last shot of the rat? How could a supposedly great filmmaker give in to such an obvious, heavyhanded choice?

I think Scorsese has it in him to make a better film.

title: One of the best movies i've ever seen, just be warned, very violent
review:
Its about 2:20 in the morning and i honestly have nothing better to do right now than to write a movie review. so, here goes. i saw the Departed about a week after its theatrical release. I knew it was going to at least be good. it wasn't good. it was possibly one of the best movies i've ever seen. that being said, if you can't stomach incredibly brutal violence, then don't watch it, because believe me, as much as i like a violent flick here and there, even i left the theater feeling like i had been hit with a baseball bat.

The story is very riveting with good twists, yet one doesn't have to pay attention to every minor detail and look for symbolism left and right to find out whats going on. DiCaprio's performance i thought was absolutely fantastic, hes definitely one of the best actors out there today. Whalberg is hilarious in his few scenes and of course does the ultimate justice in the end of the movie (watch and you'll know what i mean). The soundtrack fit the movie perfectly, from Gimme Shelter, through I'm Shipping Up to Boston, Nobody But Me, Thief's Theme, all the songs fit every scene perfectly. Scorsese never fails to amaze me, and i've only seen four of his films.

The movie to me is an 11 out of 10 (unfortunately, thats not possible). Definitely watch it, but if you don't like violence, steer clear.

title: Honestly !!
review: If this movie makes a win at the Oscars then this entire business is becoming disgustingly lost for art or entertainment. This movie was predictable, story was lost for reality or credibility, characters were shallow and of course, the violence was too much for nothing. Only couple of scenes were really worth it in the entire two hours. The only real good performance was by Alec Baldwin !!. Leo really is getting better but the voice doesn't help much. Somehow every leo character in black leather and a white T brings to mind one of my teenage stretched pin ups of Brad Pitt the resemblance scary. Anyway, really guys come on the violence was made so easy and with such a star stud cast everyone will vote for guns as a house hold consumable. Good luck cleaning zero self minded people after this. Anyway.. glad i didn't pay a penny to see this movie if you can do the same by all means do it. Thank God most of these good actors already proved they can act before this movie.

title: Scorsese deserves an Oscar for this film
review: Like most of us, when news comes from Hollywood that an American filmmaker is doing a remake of a foreign film, my stomach cringes at the fact (i.e. The Grudge, The Ring). However, imagine my sheer excitement when I learned that Martin Scorsese was attached to direct one of the best HK crime films I've seen: 'Infernal Affairs'. Usually, I'm not optimistic about a remake but I had to make an exception. Anyways, the film succeeds in matching up to the original, reminding me why idolize Scorsese in the first place. Scorsese, with the help of a solid and interesting screenplay by William Monahan (Kingdom of Heaven), crafts a story of deception and tragedy set in one of America's most celebrated but equally infamous cities. Casting is everything in a film and The Departed is no different. Leonardo DiCaprio gives one his best performances as Billy Costigan, the undercover cop sent to infiltrate Frank Costello's (Jack Nicholson) crime syndicate. I totally bought DiCaprio as the man who was trying to distance himself from his family's dark past. His struggle in leading a life of deception is very chaotic and thrilling. He deserved an Oscar nod for this role (I haven't seen Blood Diamond yet). Matt Damon, as he demonstrated in the Bourne films, showed a darker side as Colin Sullivan, Costello's rat in the Boston State Police. I sound a bit biased, but I think Damon should have gotten at least a Golden Glode nod for the film. Jack Nicholson is Jack Nicholson. His casting was key in the success of this film as he provided some of the most comical and sinister scenes of the film. It is a crying shame that this is the only film Nicholson has made with Scorsese so far. Alec Baldwin is great as Capt. Ellerby, even though he has very little screen time. However, the performance that caught me by surprise the most is that of Mark Wahlberg as Sgt. Dignam. He is very convincing as a no nonsense cop with a chip on his shoulders. His disdain for Damon's character is very genuine and it makes what transpires very chilling and justifiable. Overall, this film is at the top of my film list for 2006. If you haven't seen The Departed yet, please do. It is an unforgettable experience. Also, will the Academy please give Scorsese the Oscar come March?!?

title: Oscar nods
review: How in the heck does Mark Wahlberg get a best supporting actor nomination and Di Caprio get nothing. The Oscars have truly become the least credible movie award, and yet they maintain their glamor. WHY???? Also why does it seem that an actor with two wonderful performances in one movie year only get one Oscar nomination?? How many times are actors and actresses get nominations for a performance that was only half as good as another performance in the same year? An example is Sean Penn winning best actor for Mystic River when his performance was much better in 21 grams. Anyway this is just my rant because I like Di Caprio and he deserves at least an nomination for his performance in this movie, especially since he was a supporting character. I guess the Oscars have a lot of trouble deciding who is the main character in a movie where there is no main character only supporting characters.
