It saddens me that the best performance 'I have seen' all year didn't even get a nomination.

title: Full review
review: Martin Scorsese's remake of the Hong Kong thriller INFERNAL AFFAIRS (2002) is a thrilling return to form, a psychological gangster film whose diabolically convoluted premise follows two men living double lives, their manufactured identities sustained by a web of lies that simultaneously keeps them alive and strangles their souls. Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon) and Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio) grew up in the same tough South Boston neighborhood, each in the shadow of Irish mob boss Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson, only rarely lapsing into "Here's Johnny!" mannerisms). But while Costello took the orphaned Colin under his wing, schooling him in the ruthless, bottom-feeding code of the streets, Billy was sheltered from Costello's pervasive corrupting influence by his father, the one law-abiding member of a mobbed-up family. Both entered the Massachusetts State Police academy, and each enters an elite division of the force: Colin, the very image of a bright, incorruptible cop, joins the Special Investigations Unit, which is mandated to bring down Costello's empire by any means necessary. Colin ostensibly reports to Captain Ellerby (Alec Baldwin), but is in fact Costello's inside man, keeping his mentor apprised of every move the police make. While still a cadet, Billy is tapped by avuncular Captain Queenan (Martin Sheen) and foulmouthed Southie Sergeant Dignam (Mark Wahlberg) to work in an ultra-secretive undercover division. Billy's chief qualification is his family's criminal history, particularly his late Uncle Jackie's close relationship with Costello; after Queenan and Dignam arrange his expulsion from the academy and a stint in jail, Billy is perfectly positioned to worm his way into Costello's organization and feed information to the police. The two moles soon become aware of each other's existence, but neither knows the other's identity or that they're connected by therapist Madolyn Madden (Vera Farmiga), who's dating Colin and counseling Billy as a condition of his parole. Hidden behind their masks and under ever-escalating pressure to root out the traitor within their respective organizations, Colin and Billy both begin to crumble. William Monahan's screenplay hews remarkably closely to Alan Mak and Felix Chong's convoluted original (though their names are buried in the end credits), but Scorsese makes it his own, from the vivid pop soundtrack to the seething paranoia and spasms of brutal violence. The cast is uniformly excellent, with Ray Winstone a standout as Mr. French, Costello's red right hand.

title: Not Scorsese's best, but it is one of his top 5 best.
review:
The Departed is in my opinion one Scorsese's top 5 films, with Taxi Driver and Goodfellas ranking 1 and 2 respectively. it was sad to find out so many great performances were snubbed by the AMPAS people, but still we have another great crime thriller from the man whom has brought crime and suspense to the big screen with great success.

Scorsese is one of the best filmmakers of our time and I know he has another Taxi Driver in him somewhere, but in the mean time this film will easily keep you smiling from ear to ear as it is filled with all of Martin's classic trademarks, and awesome performances from this top notch cast.

Now as I said it is not his best as it doesn't have the intensity of his other films, but it comes damn close, and I am eager to see what ole martin has cooking next.

title: thumbs up for the director, thumbs down for the writer of the adaptation
review: The goodness of the film and the director doesn't need me to emphasize any more. Just want to look down upon the writer of the adaptation screenplay. The movie is recently banned in China, which make me to watch the movie again. Because when the first time I saw it, I was pretty much enjoying the movie as an art, the Chinese government sequence didn't really bother me though, as a Chinese, I felt uncomfortable with it. When I watch it again last night, I was very angry about how they portraited the Chinese government though I can even tolerate the stupidity of the Chinese gangsters. I just don't understand why they took the excellence of the original Chinese story and set up some unnecessary plots to humiliate the Chinese government and Chinese in general. It is a shame and dishonorable. It is just not right.

title: Departed has left the building, stratospherically
review:
The world is divided into two; those who believe Scorcese has been victimised and deliberately ignored in the Oscar stakes and those who think he's trying a little tooooo hard to worm his way into the Oscar Academy's graces. Okay, so TAXI DRIVER (9/10) could've won but it was also against NETWORK (9/10) and the eventual winner ROCKY (9/10). And who could forget the incredible KING OF COMEDY(10/10) with Bob De Niro playing the wanna be standup Rupert Pupkin with Jerry Lewis playing the straight man.

Yes, with his last two films, you watched them and go "so what?" GANGS(6/10) was almost camp in some of its violence with the cartoonish Daniel Day Lewis , while THE AVIATOR (6/10) made one look on in horror at Leo De caprio's miscasting. And made you wonder what the hell he saw in Leo apart from his pretty blue eyes? He's back. This is gangster opera. Ebbing and flowing through a sometimes complex film with more crosses( and double ones) than a Lourdes shrine. And put any TITANIC (6/10) misconceptions to rest; this film shows Leo can act. He plays an undercover cop, Billy Costigan, who goes so deep that he finds it hard to come back. An emotional tour de force, and force majeur. Makes me look forward to seeing BLOOD DIAMOND in the coming year.

The basic premise is of undercover infiltrations into the violent ganglands of Boston; not the first natural milieu for the genre you'd think of, in this most mayflower of cities. Jack Nicholson plays a crime boss who does it as much for the love of the game as for the profit it brings. Matt Damon is an ambitious cop with plans for the future which take him outside of the force. But his past won't free him and he knows it. An at times unbearably tense film, it gripped me throughout.

Great support by Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen, alec Balwin, Ray Winstone and the not so insignifcant love interest Vera Farmiga.

And expect to see Marty up on the stage come February 25th, with his cheeks shining with tears and Jack in the front row, slow clapping him up with his trademarked grin.

title: A rip-off of "infernal Affairs". An excellent movie nevertheless.
review: "The Departed" is a remake of a 2002 Chinese film entitled "Infernal Affairs". The main and almost only difference is the exceptional heavy-weight Hollywood cast that has been thrown into Scorsese's version. DiCaprio's performance is excellent (as always), but Matt Damon's somehow falls short of his usual standard. The character played by Nicholson has a bigger and more eccentric role in this version as compared to the Chinese version, which does not come as a surprise considering that it is Jack doing his thing in his own way. Nevertheless, this time Nicholson does not steal the film like he's done in previous times. Considering all the big names in the cast, and if I could go back in time and change something about this film, it would be the choice of Damon as the mole in the police dept. I think that role required either a different approach or an actor with more personality so that the public could identify more with the character, like in the case of DiCaprio's. After all, the whole point of the movie is the tension created by the possibility that either one of those two characters is going to be caught. The film is excellent but I can't give more than 8 out of 10 to it considering that in some scenes it is a frame-by-frame rip-off of "Infernal Affairs". If you can watch any of the two versions at any given time, I would recommend to watch the original version first because In my opinion it comes across as the most honest of the two.

title: Great!
review:
Scorsese is one of my favorite directors, at least he has certainly made a few of my favorite movies. And seeing how he keeps the quality of his work so constantly high is astonishing. And not only that, i would rate this as his finest movie this decade. While i did enjoy "Gangs of New York" and "The Aviator" (both are fine movies in my opinion) this is still a lot closer to the masterpieces of Scorseses previous career.

I have always considered the American way of taking foreign movies and making a new version rather silly. I don't know whether they do it because they can't stand reading subtitles or if there are other reasons. Generally the new versions are also inferior which makes it an even less understandable practice. Here though we have the opposite. While i feel that "Infernal Affairs" is certainly an interesting movie, and a quality film to boot, i still feel that "The Departed" is a vast improvement.

What i was perhaps most impressed by when i watched this movie was the way that Scorsese brought the best out of the entire ensemble. Matt Damon, Leonardo DiCaprio and Mark Wahlberg are far from my favorite actors but they are all as good as i have seen them here. Damon usually has something stiff and almost detached about him that i don't like, but here he seems a lot more relaxed and really flows into his character. Jack Nicholson on the other hand is one of my favorites, and he is absolutely magnificent in "The Departed". He makes one of those appearances where he just dominates every scene that he's in, and unlike many other great actors who have been in the game for a long time, he never seems to relax and turn on the autopilot.

Of course in a thriller the story has to be interesting too, a great ensemble is not enough. And i think that "The Departed" delivers there as well. While it is perhaps maybe 20 minutes longer than i would have liked, it never becomes painfully so. A few twists along the way are also bound to keep most people guessing.

After watching "Gangs of New York" and "The Aviator" i felt afraid that Scorsese might never reach the peaks of his earlier career, and therefore would never receive the Oscar that should have been his a long time ago. But "The Departed" gives me hope since this is yet another memorable and simply great movie. Very recommended! 8/10.

title: better than expected
review:
I expected just another big star ensemble piece from this movie. I knew it would be well made and directed. I was confident of the cinematography and sound.

I was pleasantly surprised by how good it was and weeks later upon reflection I agree that this is one of the better gangster films made.

Regardless of what people say Nicholson does a great job as a gangster. The people who think he is too much of a caricature should get out more.

The cops in this movie are all excellently acted. The script is great and interesting and is a great portrayal of the characters. And most importantly there is that something special that permeates the whole feature.

Anyone who likes a good gangster flick will get this, so will the Scorsese fans and film illiterati.

If you are heading to the video store this week and haven't seen it yet - just get it.

title: Outstanding...until the end
review:
WARNING CONTAINS SPOILERS I was at the edge of my seat, feeling sentiment for all characters, until everyone died in the end (almost everyone). The acting was incredible all around from main to minor roles. The screenplay was excellent. The plot was very dynamic. After reading several reviews, I was unsure why many comments compared the movie to Internal Affairs. In Internal Affairs, Garcia's character knew the entire movie that Richard Gere was the crooked cop. In this movie, DiCaprio had no idea who the was the crooked cop. The movie seemed to me more like Donny Brosco. DiCaprio's character experienced the same anxiety as Johnny Depp, both as undercover police officers inside the mob. The different angle for Departed, was that the mafia had an inside man penetrating the police.

Half way through the movie I thought to myself that was one of the best movies I have ever seen. Then everyone in the end got shot in the head...in succession. It became so ridiculous during the elevator scene, laughter rang out through out the theater, and my wife shouted, "This is stupid." There could have been several better endings, either the "good guys" or "bad guys" winning. Such as Damon killing DiCaprio, and then Wahlburg finding the tape recordings on his desk. Something to leave you thinking, rather than the simple ending: kill everyone.

Despite the ending, a wonderful movie worth watching at least twice. It ranks among the great mafia movies after Godfather I, Good Fellas, Casino, and Donnie Brasco.

title: Twisted corruption... talented cast
review: Wow... what a cast. Everyone in this movie brings it. The talent pool here is so deep the story lines could stink and the movie still may have a change to be good. Thankfully, this movie keeps you guessing as to possible outcomes until the end. Casting Bostonians like Wahlberg and Damon doesn't hurt either. No fake accents and attitudes make things more believable. The violence in this movie is grotesquely real. Gun shots wounds and brain matter are everywhere. The movie has very nice tension due to the undercover work and the havoc that plays on the life of an officer. Try to get past the violence and sit back and watch good actors do their thing in this movie... and by all means keep the kids away from this one.

title: Brilliant movie, excellent acting performance.
review:
This movie was by far on the best last year.

The main cast is excellent. Nicholson and Di Caprio have more complex roles than Damon and Wahlberg. But the 4 of them fit perfectly into the movie. The acting is just wow, ... and the story is actually quite simple in it's complexity. You can very easily see yourself in any of the main roles and "feel" what you would do in his/her shoes.

The introduction was a bit on the fast side but you easily keep up after 5 minutes.

There are parts in it when things happen so fast that you're still trying to "work" out what you just saw the next thing happens that makes you forget the first one. After walking out of the cinema that evening we were all still thinking about the movie for 20 minutes without talking to each other.

title: Hokey ending
review: Martin Scorcese is a cult film-maker like Woody Allen. Notwithstanding this, he has made good movies ("Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore", "Cape Fear") same as Allen has ("The Sleeper"). But both in the long run have generally ended up making neurotic movies of compulsive characters. The ending of "The Departed" was hokey. Seeing it made me long for Alec Baldwin's character to shoot up Mark Wahlberg's. And then for Martin Scorcese (in cameo) to do in Alec Baldwin's. And finally for the audience to stone Scorcese's screen image to a pulp! Alas! Martin missed doing an all-time classic ending! The movie did well at the box office and at video rentals due to the cult following but also (more importantly?) due to the talented cast.

title: Hope and Faith is restored in the medium
review: Way to go, Marty! (as if I know the man). Aftering seeing a glut of really cruddy films recently (Deja p.u.) I am so happy to have come across this one. Really makes one wonder why Bruckheimer and all this SFX people even go there anymore. Here is a story that runs and works because of character, not because some jackass can blow up a car or CGI some scene out of the ether. Wahlberg and Baldwin are amazing. And let's talk a bit about Ray Winstone -- he really is amazing. Next year, depending on material, could be his break out year. He's something to behold. Let's just hope he doesn't go the way of his fellow country man Gary Oldman (remember when he was astonishingly good?) Highly recommend this film....

title: There Are The Few Exceptions Of A Remake Surpassing The Original Film, But This Is One Of Them. Just Too Good To Be True, A Scorsese Comeback
review:
Most people are like myself and when they hear of Hollywood remaking another masterpiece from the other side of the globe they will shudder and feel that it can be disrespectful to the original source. Not in the case of Marin Scorsese's The Departed, where he's back on form with what will no doubt be the best film by the end of 2006. When you hear that a master like Scorsese is going to direct a film like The Departed you suddenly get overwhelmed with the knowledge that you know it will be something special. The Departed is based on an Asian cop Vs criminal film named Infernal Affairs that since 2002 has managed to spawn 2 sequels and now the remake The Departed.

When a director like Scorsese gets on a project like The Departed you know that you're in for a treat and with its wonderful cast you're going to be hard done not be impressed. There is a certain responsibility The Departed has and that's the fact it has to be respectful to Infernal Affairs and no steal the film's original premise. It has to keep the original story, but remember to make it individual and unique. So The Departed pays respect to Infernal Affairs while adding the needed significant changes and that's where The Departed succeeds.

Whether you hate remakes or not all goes out the window because the film becomes a unique piece of work that only Scorsese could have done. Many other directors would have felt inclined to stay close to the tight knitted story, but Scorsese adds many changes and development so that he can make the work his own.

My favourite aspect of the film is the intense proportion of skill in the acting from the entire cast of greats. The acting is the most dominant part of the film and you become so absorbed by the characters that you'll forget about the film's two and a half hour running time. Every single actor and actress has a personality and a certain technique to their character which helps you come to understand them better. The enhanced range of styles and wonderful capabilities everyone shows just how much time and effort was put into the film. The cast includes the likes of Leonardo DiCaprio who's performance is in fact the best of his career and also the best the performance the film has to offer, he truly succeeds at holding the film together. You've also got other excellent performances from Jack Nicholson, Matt Damon, Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen and the gritty performance from Ray Winstone.

Mixing crime and drama perfectly the film sets out to be a modern masterpiece of the cop Vs criminal genre. The technique used to tell the story is brilliant and smoothly paced; it's a distinctive style that has a trademark stamped all over it. The original soundtrack is one that perfect suits the scenes it accompanies and the stark direction captures the crime perfectly. There are many powerful moments to accompany the film and it is at times quite heartfelt. From start to finish you become gripped to the intelligent and intense plot line. There's also a psychological element to the film and moral subtext to the characters, which is terrific.

In the end The Departed does become a better film than Infernal Affairs and this owed to the original otherwise The Departed would have been a lost case. One of the best films of the last few years, a must see for anybody interested in film and for the sheer entertainment value this film has to offer.

title: Another Scorscese Masterpiece ...
review: Well what can one say about Martin Scorscese, everything he touches turns to Gold and so is the recent masterpiece. For sure the best movie I have seen this year. The thing with Scorscese is you give him any story and he will direct it in a way that it appeals and leaves an impression. Even weak storyline("Gangs of Newyork") are turned into directional masterpieces. This one however does have a potent script, and the acting by all the players is definitely good. I have always believed in giving credit to the director for Good or Bad acting. He is the captain of the ship and can work his crew around guidelines he so wishes. I am pretty confident he can even make Tom Cruise act better, and if you can do that, you're good... and Martin Scorscese definitely is. The departed is A Must See !!

title: Acotrs play "de" "part" successfully in "The Departed"
review: There is no doubt that Martin Scorsese's instant classic mobster flick "The Departed" has not been left for dead. Not only has it received lauded critical success, but it also has been a box office monster. OK, I am going to rat and tell you what the film is all about. Leonardo Dicaprio stars as Billy Costigan, a novice cop who goes undercover and poses as a henchman to Boston Mafia Guru Frank Costello played by an unknown actor named Jack Nicholson. Kidding! I was just Jacking you off! Eventually, these 'Costo" brothers' pseudo-relation will cost them a great deal and not much is saved. Dicaprio continues to demonstrate that he is a true aviator in the world of acting and that his pretty face is not always in the clouds. He was impressive as Costigan, his character is likable and made you want to advise him "Billy, Don't Be A Hero" so his life will not be endangered. What can you say about Jack? Nicholson's Costello routine was wicked, wily, and wonderful. Ummmmm I smell a rat! That would have to be Matt Damon who was astounding as police rat Colin Sullivan. Damon was a little damon in this part , but the talented Mr. Damon has effectively played wicked before. I also dirkly digged Mark Wahlberg's performance as the callous Sgt. Dignam. I guess you can't take the dig out of Wahlberg's movie characters. All the aforementioned are worthy of Oscar noms. Acting vets Alec Baldwin, Martin Sheen, and Ray Winstone also gave "The Departed" a will to incorporate an outstanding acting ensemble. The only character which I thought was lifeless in "The Departed" was Madolyn (played by Vera Farmiga), the lone principal female character of the film bared no momentous contribution. Before I depart, I must mention that the iconic Marty Scorsese makes a triumphant return to the genre which made him a film director legend. Hopefully for his sake, he will not also be classified as a Susan Lucci legend by losing out on another Best Director Oscar. His nom is in the bag already. OK, I am departing now but don't you depart from ratting on to "The Departed". ***** Excellent

title: My faith in Oscar-nominated-anything will die if DiCaprio is not nominated...
review: Wow. Let me say that I've seen this movie 3 times in the theater already, and that is something I've never done before. The acting in this movie blows me away! Even Jack Nicholson is great (playing Jack)... and I never had any respect for Leonardo DiCaprio until I saw this movie (probably because I hated Titanic). If this isn't nominated for best picture, best actor, director, etc, I will never put any stock into what is an Oscar-winning *anything* again. This movie keeps you on the edge of your seat... you kinda know what's going to happen, but not how, or when; and the ending was excellent as well! ********* S P O I L E R below ********* >> I'm kinda thinking the baby was Billy Costigan's and not Collin Sullivan's. I like a few loose ends; things to chew on and think about after you're done watching a movie only makes the experience that much more enjoyable! <<

title: wicked
review: Just simply brilliant, looking at the quotes just cracks me up again. The acting was great. Scorscese just seems to get the best out of actors. good to see J.N. back in a bad guy part. Dicaprio was great too. Even though he's a pretty-boy, he's way talented. I really grew to hate Damon through out the movie, so he did a good job i reckon :p. Even Walberg managed to make me laugh. especially when talking to Baldwin about his wife and mom, ha ha. The cast was just great, and all performed at their best. Love it, just loved it. Length of the movie was pretty good, shouldn't have been longer. 'ne thing i didn't really get was the importance of the therapist chick. And why they didn't pick someone else for it. But besides that, it was all good.

title: A Belated Response - Moral Ambiguity
review:
The Departed, is one of the better movies I have seen by Martin Scorcece, with Leonardo DiCaprio as a replacement for Robert De Niro, and with Jack Nicholson at his evil best, when you watch him on screen you realize that acting for him seems the most natural thing to do, nothing seems too difficult, everything comes easily, although it would interesting to see if he is able to play characters that are simple and straightforward, instead of people who seem to keep the company of the devil.

The movie is slow and methodical, where characters talk to each other and the story is allowed to develop for audiences to absorb and understand. But judgment is still out on Leonardo, he seems to express emotion and has screen presence, however this role does not have much range, it is limited in its scope, so one cannot really get an idea of his abilities, I maybe wrong for I have not seen some of his earlier movies. But I do not think he is the heir apparent, yet, to a Robert De Niro or an Al Pacino. I did find the female lead Vera Farmiga, fascinating, her performance was very good, and the relationship that develops between Madolyn and Billy Costigan, has a lot of chemistry and charisma, it is unfortunate that the director decided to leave it unresolved or to explain what happened to Madolyn, it would have been interesting. I did find Matt Damon's performance interesting, although a little wooden, because he is unable to express conflict very well.

As the movie reaches its final dramatic conclusions and resolutions, one is left with a feeling of incompleteness and irresolution and so one leaves the theater with a sense of Moral Ambiguity and a lot of unanswered questions. Although this is a pretty accurate depictions of the real world, with its sense of chaos, greed, corruption and violence, where the question is not one of good or bad or right or wrong, but one where an individual is measured in degrees of immorality.

One always hopes however, that in the world of fiction, we get to see our Moral and Ethical Dilemmas resolved with a clear distinction made between good and evil, right and wrong. At least that is why many of us in the Audience flock the theaters, although in much less numbers than before. Hoping to catch a glimpse of our hero's fight the forces of evil, with all their might and the advances in technology, sometime single handily but often with trusted Sancho at their side, triumphing in the end, and sometimes winning the heart of the most beautiful woman of them all and some of us in the Audience. But Art or what's left of it, demands that we stay true to life and to the story as conceived of by its creators.

Although our director does make significant and subtle attempts to take a moral stand, even our arch enemy, by the end begins to show hints of a conflict, a softening of the soul in his relationship with Billy, or in expressing compassion for the fate of the Frank Costello's lady friend. On the other hand, by the end, the director is unable to suppress his fascination with the Mechanical and Technical aspects of the enactment of the Violent Cinematic Death Scene, although Brutally Honest and Tragic, with a Visual Sense of Appeal, it seems empty and hollow if it somehow becomes disassociated with the story, as certain important or meaningful characters seem to disappear and one is left with a sense of loss at their sudden end or disappearance.

title: Superb direction,awesome story...worth watchin again and again...
review: I watched this highly anticipated movie last night on DVD...dint know what to expect because of 4 of the top people in movie....after watching this movie one gets the feeling why every movie has to end...so it ended but believe me...this movie gave me the best 150 mins of 2006....really gripping from start till the end and in the MIDDLE you just cant believe that this is really happening....leonardo di caprio has a change look in this character and will be much appreciated from his other roles...same goes for matt damon and mark wahlberg....and not to forget the great Jack nicholson....how he blends in with every one else and easily tell you how he is the best....i think this movie will be the best movie of 2006 winning at least 4-5 Oscars....HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.....PEACE....

title: Martin Scorsese meets Guy Ritchie and Boondock Saints ... spectacular!
review:
Wow ... first off ... wow. I just got home from seeing this film not an hour ago and still I'm struggling to describe this movie with words more descriptive than ... wow. I'd first like to point out that I'm not a Scorsese fanatic who will instantly love anything he puts on the screen (as I am with some directors) I've seen only two of his films the Aviator which I liked and Gangs of New York which I did not. I'm also not a fan of Leonardo DiCaprio however I don't mind him when hes working under a good director.

My first thoughts after seeing this film were "its the great film-making of Martin Scorsese with a complicated twist laden plot line of Guy Ritchie (Snatch and Lock stock and two Smoking Barrels) set in the backdrop of Boondock Saints and Goodwill Hunting (Boston)". This movie although very unapologetically violent is, funny (something I was not at all expecting) the dialog as well as the situations are so funny that many times in the theatre I was hysteric with laughter, very loudly and in the theatre I might add and I was not the only one its not very often that an audience in a theatre is so captured by a film that you can hear its collective uninhibited reactions to every funny line or plot twist but that was the case with this film.

The story itself is brilliant very very interesting. The Massachusetts State Police and the Irish mob both have moles deep in the other organization and let the mole hunts begin! The two sides are a negative and positive for one another and the mirroring and reflection that goes on between them is phenomenal.

The acting was superb everyone was excellent the great cast of this film performed to its full potential. My favorites Matt Damon, Jack Nicholson, and Martin Sheen were all at their best Matt Damon in particular was outstanding. Even Mark Wahlberg and Alec Baldwin who I'm usually relatively indifferent to gave wonderful performances and yes even Leonardo DiCaprio was extremely good.

The music (something I notice very much in films) was exceptional there was music playing nearly the entire film and created the perfect atmosphere for every moment of the film. The piece that was most notable for me was "I'm shipping up to Boston" by the Dropkick Murphies. Ever since I've listened to them I've thought I would love to see them used in a film and with the exception of Boondock Saints this is the perfect film for them.

A warning to some as I mentioned before this film is unapologetically very violent and certainly requires one to have a stomach for that sort of thing.

All in all this is an extraordinary film I haven't been this excited about a film since I saw Munich several weeks ago. Enjoy!

title: Whether you think Infernal affairs or the Departed was better depends on which you watched first, and whether you are fluent in the languages.
review:
I watched Infernal Affairs when it came out. I thought it was a really good movie, with an original plot, and great actors. I watched the Departed a few days ago. I think to appreciate each film, despite some people saying that the language barrier doesn't matter, I think its a major component. Some people applaud The Departed in that Scorcese portrays the American setting really well. Well I can't appreciate that because I'm not from there.

ALSO a big part of appreciating the movie is letting the plot unfold without knowing what will happen. I watched Infernal Affairs first, so naturally when I saw a lot of the plot and even minor details copied from the original, it raised an eyebrow and hindered the flow of the movie. A lot of things, like the plastered arm and envelope with the crossed out spelling.

Another thing I like in Infernal Affairs over The Departed is that it has more contrast in emotion. There are moments of comic relief by the "Sor Keung" character, and, for example, DiCaprio's character in Infernal Affairs isn't yelling and punching people the whole time. The Departed has a bit too much violence and swearing to my liking, even if that is an accurate portrayal of what people were in that setting.

To be honest, the biggest determining factors in people's preference of the movie is which you watched first, and which language you are more comfortable with. I watched Infernal Affairs first, and though I'm fluent in both English and Cantonese, I appreciate the cultural background of the Hong Kong version more. All in all, I can't really judge which movie is better than the other because I'll probably be biased, but I certainly enjoyed watching Infernal Affairs more.

title: so cool!!!1
review: I couldn't believe it. The coolest scenes I have ever seen, I mean, did Leo Di CaPrio ever act as well as this? His acting blew my face off, and Matt Damon as well. His best performances since Team America World police- MATT DAMOooN! The scenes come fast and furious to the nail-biting extreme. Nevermind the original, this remake deserves all the Oscars Academy can throw. And Jack Nicholson. What a hero. He makes the screen light up with his brazen cheek. He's so rude, yet ultimate intimidating. terrifying!!! what a movie. 10 out of 10! A barrow roll, encore! Bring on the remake of the original sequel, can it get any better? I love it.

title: The ExceptionalFellas: finally the Scorcese/DiCaprio partnership lives up to all expectations
review:
When the fellowship between Scorcese and DiCaprio seemed to be on way to confirm it as a shot on water, here they come up with The Departed. Gone are the unsuccessful historical themes of Gangs of New York and The Aviator, in which the director seemed so comfortable as a crasher in a party, and comes back the universe of organized crime, that he dominates perfectly; vanishes the catalysts leads, and brings up the original and more balanced division of forces between the characters; above all, there isn't here that desperate need for approval - of the Academy, his pairs, of the industry and the public - that were present in his two previous projects with his favourite actor. Scorcese is back to his comfort zone. Which, in his case, means the return to the extreme emotions and the cinema of high combustion of Goodfellas and Casino, that until this new enterprise were considered the last big moments of his curriculum.

Adapted such and which of Infernal Affairs, a Hong Kong crime movie, The Departed treats on the opposing trajectories, but symmetrical, of Billy Costigan (DiCaprio) and Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon). Both have family connections with the Boston Irish mafia, and both distinguish themselves as cadets in the police academy. Colin, however, is there by orders of Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson), the godfather of the local banditry, with the purpose of making a career in the law and therefore facilitate the business of his organization. Billy, whose father apparently was the only honest man in the family, is recruited for the inverse task: commit a crime, get kicked out of the police force and forge his passage to the other side of the balcony, captivating next to Costello. For his protection, only two of his superiors, interpreted by Martin Sheen and Mark Wahlberg, know his true identity. And, the more the two plans, Billy's and Colin's, uncurl themselves, the clearer it gets to both organizations (the criminal and the police) that they have a rat in the house - and the more it intensifies the hunt for them.

As an example of another icon of the new yorker cinema, Woody Allen, which in Match Point gained new breath when transposing his habitual themes to London, Scorcese appears rejuvenated in this change to Boston. In contrary to Allen, however, that went to film in England because it was there that the money for it came from, the unexpected decision of Scorcese served to at least one good practical reason. A plot such as of The Departed would stumble on innumerable logical obstacles if taken place into the rigid hierarchy of the Italian families of the New York mafia. Now the style more, let's say, personalized - and, therefore, highly inflammable - of the irishans of Boston fits perfectly to this story of two voluble agents, that act based on improvisation and in the shortest elapsed time of action and reaction, with no information to map beforehand a path to walk on. Billy and Collin are thus, more then anything, actors, and their different dramatic styles - calculated and good-tempered in the case of Collin, that is climbing up in meteoric speed in politics, defensive and reactive in the case of Billy, the dude that joined the gang last - are the keypoints of the film.

Another indication that Scorcese appears to be back to his good times is this: the way that the characters exists here in full form, and not as counterfeits as in Gangs of New York. The dialogues of The Departed are torrents of obscenities and insults - but torrents meticulously modulated according to the temper of the person that pronounces them, specially brilliant in the case of Mark Wahlberg (no, this is not a typo). In other times, Scorcese would have chosen other heavy metal actors used to impose themselves by their weight in the scenes, such as his old favourites Robert DeNiro and Joe Pesci. Here, starting with Jack Nicholson, first time with the director, all the cast is lighter and agile - and in all of it, from one point to the other, the interpretations are exceptional. Even so, there is no doubt that this is a Leonardo DiCaprio movie. Apathic in Gangs of New York and dislocated in The Aviator, he here reencounters his plummet (and, no less important, his ability to involve the audience) in a role much harder then the previous two. His Billy Conaghan is burdened by simultaneous wishes of survival and self-destruction, and by fantasies of failure and victory in impossible circumstances. And is, above all, very young and very lonely, in what finally appears to be a good use of the personal repertory of the actor.

title: No such thing as a small role for a good actor
review: This is a really, really good story. I urge women who really don't like violent movies, but whose guys do, to go for this one. The story is outstanding with more twists and turns than a cut snake. The actors are all excellent. Even the small roles are attention grabbing. Mark Walberg, that guy just gets better with every film he makes. This is a mature role, and he plays it to the hilt. Matt Damon, too nice, too cute, and never looking older than 22, finally ages a bit, and almost plays a nasty, the twist being that he got the role within a role because he is a nice guy, too complicated. Leo DeC gets a role worthy of his talents, Let's hope it teaches him to stamp on his agents' toes when they offer him romantic leads. The only woman is unknown and totally real. The whole thing is just mesmerizing for what? 2, nearly 3 hours. Scorsese on top of his form. Da guy is a genius or what? See the Chinese version. Lau and what's his name are exact Chinese counterparts for Leo and Matt. Carole

title: An exquisite film...
review:
When walking into the theater, I had low expectations for this film. However, this film made me see a side of myself I had never seen before. The brutality of the movie was indeed sickening, but was all in necessity to make the movie what it is.

My friends and I had mixed reviews. Two of them thought the film was horrible and came out of the theater with headaches, while my other friend and I found the film a great one...one that would rock the ages.

The music played in the background throughout the movie shifts from suspenseful to an Irish punk rock. This keeps the movie upbeat and really keeps the action going.

Jack Nicholoson does an excellent job along with the rest of the cast. If you can stand the brutality, you will enjoy the film.

title: Marty's back, in fine form.
review:
After several years of toiling away in good (but not great) historical dramas and biopics, it's fantastic to see Scorcese return to his roots with this gritty, tough, tense gangster flick.

And it's almost as if he never left. "The Departed" is a textbook example of how to craft a practically flawless thriller - these guys set the scene early on, and keep ratcheting the tension tighter and tighter, all the way till the end.

Scorcese is at the top of his game - his sure-footed direction of his actors and beautifully operatic staging work wonders within the cops-and-mobsters world of the Boston underground.

Marty's got good source material here as well. Monahan's script is easily a front-runner for the Oscars this year. His characters are complicated, conflicted, and utterly fascinating. "The Departed" has more twists than a Russian contortionist, and Monahan will keep you guessing, right up until the final minutes of the film.

The cast is nothing short of brilliant as well - leads DiCaprio and Damon hit career-high notes in varied but intense performances, and the supporting cast of Mark Wahlberg, Alec Baldwin, and Martin Sheen all take to their characters with relish. And that's saying nothing of the sheer joy that the audience gets watching Jack Nicholson really, really let himself go. Which is saying something.

Fast-paced, bloody, tough and demanding, "The Departed" will grab you by the throat and keep squeezing until the credits.

title: A shocking remake
review:
How can this movie be rated so highly when it has very little originality? Infernal Affairs (I tried to name the original movie in Asian and they said it was a spelling mistake) was far superior.. but some people do not relate to Asian movies because they are in the closet racists.

8.5/10... what's wrong with you people? Even if you were unaware of the original made only 4 years ago and the fact nothing has changed in the movie except ethnicity... it was not that good... and the Irish input ha ha

Soon they will be remaking Oldboy :(

Is nothing sacred?

title: Good, but could have been great. . .
review:
This movie had almost all the elements of a really, really, great film. The acting was absolutely superb. The direction and cinematography were excellent. The music was well chosen and orchestrated. Most importantly, however, the story had a bit too many holes and questions.

I found myself too many times during the movie -- and in processing it later -- not making any sense out of some parts and happenings. I don't want to give anything away, but for all of those who tout this as Scorcese's best work (not by a long shot - perhaps could have been, though), go back and think about the last 20-30 minutes and see if you think it all makes sense. For a two and a half hour movie they certainly wrapped it up all nice and neatly in a pretty short period of time. Oh, and the last minute and a half is possibly the worst part of all.

BUT, all of that aside, it's a great ride and perfectly acted by Damon, Nicholson and especially DiCaprio. Alec Baldwin and Martin Sheen are good too. Personally, I think Marky-Mark is a bit annoying and over the top, but he's OK.

See it. Be entertained by it. But stop there.

title: Martin Scorsese nearly got it.
review: I'll give credit where credit is due. If any one could have pulled this movie off, it was Scorsese. I have been a fan of "Infernal Affairs" since I first saw it 4 years ago. I have always been a fan of Asian films such as "Friend" and "Shiri" and when I went to see "The Departed" I was not aware this was a remake. After the first 30 minutes, I realized what it was. The cast put together was most superb and the acting had me entrhalled. I noted that many of the emotions in the movie held true, yet many of the subtleties did not. I must admit, knowing what was going to happen, other than the end, did not hold me in suspense. Watching the cast pull the movie off did. DiCaprio has had his best role yet. Better than "Catch Me If You Can." SEE THIS MOVIE. BUT SEE THE ORIGINAL TOO. Both stand on their own as excellent movies. Now to remake "FRIEND"

title: Watch Infernal Affairs
review:
I was eager to see how the Americans would remake Infernal Affairs. Based on other American remakes of Asian films, however, my hopes were not high. Even so, I was hoping that I might be pleasantly surprised.

I was wrong. Almost everything about The Departed was a direct copy of Infernal Affairs. The plot, which although more drawn out, was pretty much identical. They even stole bits from the original script. Now, this wouldn't be so bad if they'd acknowledged and paid respect to their source, but they had said that this was not a remake of Infernal Affairs, rather, they merely took inspiration from the Hong Kong thriller. Furthermore, none of Martin Scorcese, Jack Nicholson or William Monahan (the screenwriter) had even seen the original. Is it laziness or arrogance? Knowing Hollywood, it's probably both.

The film, being a carbon copy of Infernal Affairs, adds pretty much nothing to the original film, but somehow manages to take away instead. The violence often moves to the forefront of the drama and subtracts from the character development. Furthermore, it appears that the ending to this is some kind of hybrid of the original and alternative ending to Infernal Affairs, which unfortunately, negates the whole point of the film.

The stupid love triangle involving Matt Damon, Leonardo DiCaprio and Vera Farmiga is pointless and typical Hollywood nonsense that does not add to the tension like it was probably supposed to.

Admittedly, the acting on the whole is good. Jack Nicholson is outstanding as the mob boss (a marked improvement on the original, in fact). Matt Damon shines as a mob mole placed inside the police department. His character has also been changed slightly (one of the very few differences between this and the original) and Damon does well to make it work. Leonardo DiCaprio is competent, which is more than can be said about his usual performances, but seems miscast and is outclassed by Tony Leung in Infernal Affairs.

On its own, The Departed is not a bad film. Unfortunately, it was preceded by a much better version of the same story, upon which The Departed stubbornly refuses to acknowledge its dependence. All this leads me to summarise this film in three words: Watch Infernal Affairs.

title: Fantastic moviebut the ending has dragged it down
review:
Overall this is a really great movie. Acting, storytelling, characters development The Departed got a lot of good stuffs that gave this movie such a high score at this website.

I believe most people can tell all the good parts about this movie from other people's comment, and personally I agree with most of them. Therefore I will just focus on the part that I have different comments with most other people.

Yes I have seen the original before, and I might be a little bit biased here, but for me everything is nicely done in this movie except the ending. Of course there are different styles for directors, so some scenes might be more effective than the original, some might not. But I found the ending for The Departed especially lacks of depth. Where I am not just simply comparing the ending with the original. I am just commenting on the ending of The Departed by itself.

Seriously, the ending feels like a comedy, it kind of ruined everything that this movie has tried to development in the first 2 hours. It feels like "okay the movie has to end now so let's just blow everybody's heads off".

When people began to get shot in the head near the end, most people in the theater began to laugh out really really badly. It is just too sudden and has no emotion. Bang! Bang! Bang!, okay now they are all dead and we don't really care. The only sentence I wanted to say to my friend when I was walking out of the theater was the sentence that they have abused during the entire movie: "what the xxxx".

In conclusion, I think The Departed is a great movie before it reaches the end. The ending really has disappointed me a lot, and that's why I only give it 5/10.

title: life is brutish and short and we should be grateful for any illusion of peace we can muster
review:
Martin Scorsese is a brilliant filmmaker and all his films are must sees. When he's plumbing the depths of his bad guy obsession his films can be simultaneously riveting and repulsive. The Departed qualifies on all counts, must see, riveting and repulsive. DiCaprio is Scorsese's new DeNiro and he is the centerpiece of the latest Scorsese descent into death. Cormac McCarthy says any writer unwilling to deal with death isn't serious. If this is so then McCarthy is as serious as any writer has ever been. His latest, The Road, deals with nearly everyone's death in a post-apocalyptic world of cannibalism and ash. Not far removed from McCarthy's world of dead people is Scorsese's world of people fixing to be dead. No happy endings (no surprise), awful lot of brains blown out, and an awesome display of acting from DiCaprio. You have to wonder where the anguish and anger he shows us in his interview with Wahlberg and Sheen come from. Watching Vera Farmiga as police shrink watch her boyfriend Matt Damon talk to Nicholson on his cell made us want to see much more of her.

Scorsese seems to have a visceral hatred of snitches. Rats abound in The Departed and we have trouble telling the difference between the good and bad guys at first. They all end up bad guys by the time all the blood is let. Scorsese works hard to make us sympathize with DiCaprio's character and if we can see past the anger and beatings administered by him we do care more for him than anyone. I couldn't tell if Nicholson's charm was innate or Scorsese's manipulation but we shouldn't like the head bad guy, right? Even when he does his rat impersonation? Right? Maybe Martin is talking to us about honor, about being true, about the damnation visited upon the liar. Or maybe he's just saying the world is an ugly and violent place, life is brutish and short and we should be grateful for any illusion of peace we can muster.

title: What a Twist!
review: I really enjoyed this movie, not like any cop drama I've seen lately. When Sheen took a dive, I thought Wow, a movie with the nuts to kill off the commissioner. After Wahlberg takes a leave of absence, and pretty much everyone but Damon is still alive, I felt they spent a little too much time setting up the final kill. As soon as Damon was alone in his hallway, and the old lady jerked her dog away !! rotfl, I don't know who couldn't have seen it coming. I just wanted some answers from the OTHER RAT that saves Damon from DiCaprio in the elevator! Where did he come from? And that raises the question, who did Wahlberg actually work for? I think the ending fit the style of the movie, being mysterious the whole way through. They still could've added, what? 20 seconds of film to tie it up with a few metaphors and receive the full 10 stars from myself.

title: Less Than Impressive
review:
This film rollicked right along with decent acting and an intriguing plot and then, all of a sudden, it ended with a series of abrupt murders hastily filmed as if Scorsese's backers had tapped him on the shoulder and said "you're over budget fella, wrap it up, now." Clever, imaginative, striking, interesting - not this movie's ending.

But major kudos to DiCaprio for an acting tour de force - his was a splendidly executed portrait of bottled dynamite with a conscience. I was sorry Scorsese's budget clipped the role short, along with all the other characters heaved unceremoniously into the morgue's dumpster as the quickest, dirtiest, cheapest way to tie up all the story's threads.

Much more satisfying in this genre of "mole tasked to find the mole" is Kenneth Fearing's "The Big Clock." Now THERE'S an imaginative tale, well told, and without a big pile of corpses at the end.

Mentioned countless times already, but here're my two cents to help bring the total in the jar to serious money: FAR too much gratuitous obscenity larded dialogue - it's WHAT'S said that gives dialogue its punch, not how many times the F word can get shoehorned in between the preposition and the period.

title: One Of The Greatest Movies
review: Everybody with any interest in movies, must see this masterpiece of Martin Scorsese. From the beginning to the end this movie shows nothing but quality and perfection. The story is absolutely great and all the actors show their A-game. This movie will be remembered by anybody giving time to watch it, and you should. It is a breakthrough in movie history. Every second in this movie is exciting and the acting is mindblowing, Leonardo DiCaprio deserves an Award for his performance. He shows that he can play any role, and he does it to perfection. If you haven't seen this movie, you better do it, you will be disappointed if you don't.

title: Best Film of the Year
review: Wow! Best Film this year. Scorsese has matched a terrific cast and a great story and pieced together a masterpiece. In the deluge of mush touring American theaters in 2006 appeared this diamond. Matt Damon and Leonardo DiCaprio are outstanding in the leading roles. The best performance of their careers. Jack Nicholson should win the Oscar for his role as an Irish godfather. The supporting cast of Alec Baldwin, Martin Sheen, Ray Winstone and Mark Wahlberg were excellent. Vera Farmiga is terrific as a psychiatrist torn between the "nice guy" and the "bad boy". Be warned, like any Scorsese film, violence is explicit and disturbing.

title: The best
review:
Simply the best movie I have seen in the last 5 years

If Mr Scorsese does not get an Oscar for this, then there must definitely be a conspiracy going on in Tinseltown, also Leo DiCaprio should get one for best Actor and Jack for best supporting actor.

I think the special effects were stunning too, the sound of the Pistol going off next to the lift at the end sounded real.

This is about the best I have seen Leo perform in a Movie, I didn't know he had that much talent, However one downfall for me was the interplay and banter between Alec Baldwin and Marky Mark at the beginning, I thought it was over the top.

This does not in any way detract from the overall quality of the movie its the quickest 2 and a half hours I have ever spent watching a movie.

title: It really deserves a spot among the best crime flicks.
review:
I heard this film is allegedly a remake of a Hong Kong film called Mou gaan dou, which I sadly haven't seen before this one. That fact takes off a lot of the originality that The Departed would have poses if it hadn't been a remake. So I'll try to take that in consideration. But since it's a Scorsese flick I spent a little more time comparing it to his (still) better crime-drama, Goodfellas. In my opinion, just because of the pure chronology, considering that Goodfellas was made about sixteen years before The Departed, that alone makes it a more original piece of the crime world.

Let's face it. The crime genre is by now a pretty well investigated universe. I'm not thinking just about films, but tens of TV series as well. So in sense of originality, The Departed does come a little short. However, the cast, the performances and the entire realization of the project are quite a different story.

These are probably DiCaprio's and Damon's toughest roles yet. I've read one review of the film in the papers so far, and the critic described them as 'eternal boys', that just couldn't fully pull it off. But I think he was wrong, because the film doesn't rely that much on their brutality. Instead we really get a view into an intense struggle on two opposite fronts. I think most of the beauty of the film lies within Costigan's and Sullivan's insecurity and unawareness of who's who in this game. It kind of feels like good old fashioned voyeurism, since we are the ones that see it all from a bird's-eye view. And along with the story, the characters just get more and more corrupt.

I would say that this one does deserve a good spot on the chart of best crime films in recent years. The only problem I see in it is that it doesn't appear to be that quite fresh. Like I've said the crime genre is already very well worked and tested. But if you take all the attributes into account I think it's very worthy to spend two and a half hours of time on it.

........ +4/5 ........

title: It is a record of the f-word abuse
review: OK not really a record, but it looks at a good attempt. Words cannot describe this movie, I absolutely hated it. first of all because it is so vulgar, understand me well, I do not care if you use the F word or similar, like: "what the F-word do you think you are doing" or "die F-word die". But in every sentence it becomes unrealistic and very irritating. Lets say a conversation like: Hey extended F-word What the F-word do you think you are F-word doing? Shut the F-word up Cs I will F-word do What I F-word Like. Let's say in anger or fear you use terms of abuse, this adds to the realism of a movie, if you use them in every sentence you are just looking for an excuse to use them. Get My point? If you do not care or even like this in a movie, fare enough I suggest you watch it you will have the time of you're life. But in reality no one communicates with each other in this way certainly not police officers, Not that I ever have been to the US, but in Europe this is certainly not the case. I can only hope they respect each other as much in the US. But besides these vulgarities the movie has many shortcomings in my book. In the first hour the storyline was swift, that is in a bad way. At one time you are at the this point and suddenly somewhere else and then again somewhere else. The scenes do not connect well. There is a lack of storyline in the beginning which makes it strange to watch, as if you are watching different movies of 2 minutes. My guess is the movie was too long and was edited in a bad way too make it shorter. Besides 2 actors look too much alike, some people might have trouble keeping them apart in the beginning. The movie however does become a little better in the end, too late to save this movie, but still better than nothing. I actually started to feel some tension, but them came the many twists at the end, as if they wanted it to end in a certain way, I do not want to spoil it for you so I will not tell the ending, but you will know what I am talking about when you have seen the movie. All in all a bad movie which could have been very good if the director was not looking to use the F-word so much and the storyline connected a lot better than it did.

title: Watch with lesser expectations
review:
Very mild spoilers.

This is the first time I've caught a Scorsese movie in theater, that too a non-biographically styled modern one remade from 'Infernal Affairs' (which I haven't seen yet).

'When I was your age they used to say you could become cops or criminals. What I'm saying to you is this... When your facing a loaded gun, what's the difference?' the Frank Costello's pretty much summarizes the movie.

There were 2 unusual things which was'nt a part in the previous Scorsese movies I've seen (Casino, Goodfellas, Aviator): 1. The movie had a contemporary setting (few years back is contemporary too ;) ), and I did quite miss the antique settings in this movie, especially the soundtracks.

2. It had a feminine key character, the rest of them (except Sharon Stone in Casino, who probably would'nt give you the feel that there was a female character) appeared in roles that were'nt important to the plot.

Being a remake, I would'nt delve into the plot although it was one the strong point. The screenplay and dialogues were typical Scorsese sprinkled with dry humour, guns and loads of blood spatters. Jackie boy, Leo, Mark Wahlberg were the ones who stealed the show. Like Reuben says in Oceans 11 'What am i saying. You guys are pros, the best' :) The only source of disappointment was Matt Damon, he still looked kind rookie-ish. I could'nt make out if was scared or not from his facial expressions (which his role required him to do). Maybe thats why Marty assigned him to be Sullivan and (thankfully) not Costigan. Leo on the other hand had lots of scenes to his credit: his first meeting with the counsellor, a couple of scenes after Queenan dies are some i can think of.

Overall, I would'nt place this movie in the 'Best of Scorsese', but certainly recommend all mafia movie lovers to watch it (with lesser expectations).

title: Martin Scorcese's Badfellas
review:
Cops who are robbers. Robbers who are cops. And a hip hop star synonymous with exposed underpants who steals the show.

A welcome return to form for the premier gangster movie-maker, Martin Scorcese bats one outa the park with *The Departed*. Ferociously funny, doggedly compelling, a *tour de force* of gritty production, tightly-wound storyline, sneeringly salty language and flame-throwing acting chops. And there's Leo and Matt and Martin and Alec and Marky Mark. And Jack. All so deliciously at the top of their game that the word Oscar is bandied about this movie as profligately as it is around Sesame Street's resident Grouch. Deservedly so.

Jack Nicholson is Irish mafia kingpin, Frank Costello, who opens the movie cultivating the trust of a young street kid, who grows to be Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon), a Massachusetts Police Officer whose loyalties lie not with law enforcement, but with his mentor, Costello. Concurrently, Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio), a former street thug who passes his academy training with flying colors, and who also applies to the Massachusetts P.D., is rejected on the grounds that you can take the thug out of the street, but not vice versa, and is "invited" instead to go deep undercover within Costello's mafia. Confronting Police Captain Queenan (Martin Sheen), being forced to relive his checkered past, though DiCaprio mines incredible emotive shadings, that scene is definitively stolen by Mark Wahlberg, as the Cynicism juggernaut, Detective Dignam. With this film, Wahlberg comes into his own as an Actor; though his scenes are short, they are as cuttingly sweet as limes and salt rubbed into paper-cut wounds.

*The Departed* quickly establishes its triangle of the gangster (Costello), his mole in the police (Sullivan), and the police mole in his outfit (Costigan)  and then sits back and lets the plot twist, as each faction tries to untwist its knickers and weed out their respective moles.

Right hand man to Costello is Mr. French (Ray Winstone, almost unrecognizable under heavy beard and faux-Boston accent  given away by his customary élan, i.e. as tender and subtle as a crucifix nail). Under Captain Queenan is Ellerby (Alec Baldwin, in another of this movie's smallish roles that is eaten alive by its actor  Baldwin gives Wahlberg a run for his money as comic relief scene-stealer). Amongst the battle-scarred veterans, Scorcese chose wisely to insert a "new" beautiful face as female lead - Vera Farmiga, as police psychoanalyst, Madolyn, who moves in with Sullivan and then begins an affair with Costigan (nice!), setting up a tangential triangle which might have obscured the larger criminal drama in a lesser director's hands, but otherwise only served to verify that old saw, "chicks dig bad guys."

Sullivan is a policeman, sure, but as a mole for Costello he is inherently a Bad Guy  whether Madolyn knows this or not, she is drawn to his duplicity and callousness. Costigan, though also a cop, is so deep undercover that the street is rubbing off on him in ways that make Madolyn's pants-suit pants moist - once again, no medals for figuring why she prescribes him "private therapy."

*The Departed* is unmistakably Scorcese, with all the classic Scorcese stamps; his characteristic camera moves, angles and smash-cutting; foreboding or calming source music juxtaposed over contrary visuals, and pulling a depth of performance from his actors that must take them places in their heads they never want to visit again without an attorney.

Selling Leo as a hard case in Scorcese's *Gangs of New York* was mildly obtuse; here, in their third collaboration, DiCaprio is steaming with mental muscle, street smarts and a spring-wound temper that turbo-charges his screen presence like no other role he has ever attacked. Not only might it be one of *his* best performances on film, the same can be said of Nicholson, whose conniving and ruthless Costello seems always to be on the verge of either welcoming you as a brother or snapping your spine and appending a pun.

Re-made from a recent Hong Kong movie *Mou gaan dou* (*Infernal Affairs*, 2002) (written by Felix Chong and Siu Fai Mak and directed by Mak and Wai Keung Lau), it is a slight annoyance that Scorcese would insult his audience by performing that patronizing surgical act of re-rendering foreign art for the Great American Unwashed; on the other hand, *The Departed* (screenplayed by William Monahan) stands extremely tall on its own merit, not exuding that alarmist *stanque* of "remake" (*Oliver Twist*) or worse, "bad remake" (*Fun with Dick and Jane*) or worse still, "pointless remake" (*Psycho*).

Whereas Scorcese's *Goodfellas* showed us the world through the eyes of only bad fellas, *The Departed* slews its camera over the wrong AND the right side of the law, graying the line between honor and justice and law and order with its complex layers of hypocrisy. Among thieves, among cops alike, we see honor and duplicity and lawlessness and order.

The worlds are exactly the same. But the chicks dig the bad guys.

(Movie Maniacs, visit: poffysmoviemania.com)

title: Scorsese's back
review: without a doubt Scorsese's best film since "goodfellas".Set in Boston its a brilliant story of good cop,bad cop, and the mob. Leonardo Dicapio is riverting as a good cop who has to go to jail in order to be undercover going after a notorious mobster Costello(Nicholson). The only people that know about it are the 2 officers that ordered it, Mark Whalberg and Martin Sheen. Matt Damon is the seemingly good cop,but is bad. He knows Nicholson he does everything to keep Nicholson from getting arrested. But Nicholson discovers there's a rat in his mob. Matt Damon is with a shrink, who cheats with Dicaprio,she discovers what's going on with Damon. Jack Nicholson is amazing as a very vicious mobster. Dicaprio finds out that someone on the force is helping out Nicholson. Then they both meet, Damon and Dicaprio. Then Dicaprio finds out its Damon who's protecting Nicholson. Sheen gets killed by Nicholson's mob, they throw him from the balcony,Dicaprio feels bad,because Sheen was protecting him. .Brilliantly paced,artistic,very bloody and an amazing cast.

title: Scorcese is Back at It
review: The Departed marks Martin Scorcese's return to more-familiar territory after forays into period pictures. This film does not rank with his very best work but easily is among the best films of 2006. Leo DiCaprio, Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen and Alec Baldwin turn in fine performances; Matt Damon does a good job essentially playing a variation of the same character he played in Syriana, only bigger and broader here. Scorcese almost but not quite reins in Jack Nicholson; perhaps if DeNiro had played Frank Costello as originally planned, the film would have gained at least another star from me. My main objections to the movie are its sloppiness (see the Continuity page for many, many examples) and lack of authenticity. Despite the location settings, it was really shot primarily in New York and that takes away from its efforts to depict the Boston cops and crime scene. Mystic River did a much more accurate job of that. And still, it's nice to have Scorcese back making a picture where his talents can really shine through -- humor, gore, profanity. and moments of real emotion.

title: Nice, but overrated
review: The Departed's storyline is promising, the cast top notch and the names behind the film impressive. Yet the film does not quite meet the expectations I had of it. Somehow the characters never really grasped me, I felt no more sympathy for the good guys than the bad, and frankly, Nicholson sort of disappointed me. I just didn't believe him in this top criminal role, and the majority of his goons just were too flat and stereotype to lift this mobster flick above the average level, where films like the Godfather (the entire trilogy), Goodfellas et cetera seriously surpass that. Maybe it's a matter of a bit too much of everything, too little of one thing in particular. Good ingredients don't necessarily make a gourmet meal. The high rating in the top 250 surprises me, not often I feel so different about a flick's rating. Anyway, worth watching anyway, but don't expect too much.

title: Scorsese is GreaT.
review: The movie is awesome. Great Movie. First credit goes to Felix Chong and Siu Fai Mak for writing an excellent screenplay. This is a complicated story to tell on screen. I don't think anyone can beat Martin Scorsese in Directing after seeing this movie. He deserves an Oscar for best director for this movie hands down. Cinematography was superb. Acting performances were great. Scorsese's favorite Leo DiCaprio displayed another acting masterpiece. Matt Damon and Mark Whalberg too. Although I thought that Jack Nicholson was not in his best especially in the scene where he suspects Leo while sitting in the restaurant. Although Leo and Martin have done tremendous work in the past, they've been nominated too for Oscars but the time has come that both artistes get their well deserved Oscars for this movie.

title: Vastly disappointed at Director Martin.... felt it could had been done better
review:
I went into the cinema with high expectations on this film because of two reasons:

big cast w/ renown director and a Hollywood budget production. I am so sorry but in my personal opinion INfernal affairs in terms of plot was defo miles ahead of The Departed and here is how I would explain it, the major fault was the failure to display the characters inner struggle at the mental level:

1) excessive use of foul language to an unnecessary level... a level that actually hindered me from understanding what the actors were trying to say off their lines.

2) Felt that the director struggled to find a rhythm for the film, and tried too hard to fit in original scenes into this one, e.g. the cast-breaking scene when Leo D had his hand smacked on the table. golf practice scene.

Being inspired and plagiarism are two diff things in which unfortunately this film belongs to the 2nd CAT.

3) I don't see the core elements shining thru as much as IA, the contrast between good and evil despite a mis-match of physical identities. the contrast between the good vs. bad group is not presented strongly enough.

e.g. how they got young version of Matt Damon to pledge loyalty to the crimelord.......surely any kid wont understand what it meant when the crimelord helps him the 1st time literally for nothing... seemed like Jack Nicholson decided to be Santa that day and walked into the grocery to make sure the kid receives food/things under his name and practically not items from HIS shop but a poor food shop owner who had been harassed for protection fees just 3 mins ago.

4)the killing scenes?? supposedly a battle of wits, now it;s become random killing occasions. I cant see a trace of premeditation here, even the killing of Nicholson by Matt D was made to look as a total accident (i.e killed him out of self defense) From a viewers point of view I was thinking... Oh! just another one down, it kinda became a laugh at the end when 3 person where consecutively shot dead outside the lift........ and us poor viewers totally had NO clue what the motifs were at all.

OH not to mention that the death of Martin Sheen was so awkward!! deliberately slowing down his fall from the building... geez it nearly did made me think that it was a doll.

5) whats up with the Chinese crime org trading with the Irish gang? cant even speak cantonese properly...nor did he sound cruel. I really dun know how the crew picked their cast, esp knowing that a cantonese audience will be watching this film.

6) apparently bits and pieces of the plot were transferred to TD which for a person like me who had seen IA before found it stale, unoriginal and most importantly bored.

This film had failed to convince me to view a story with a similar backbone from another perspective. Because of a fragmented plot line, I can only give it a 5 at most. However I think Leo D's performance was a breakthrough and he deserves praise for that. Jack Nicholson also played the crimelord well... cruelty without an expression of fear or guilt, perfect. The psychiatrist role was also pretty good...playing justice for the both of these moles, although I would prefer if Vera played the wife of the crimelord cos she seemed to be witty and sly at times.

I bet Martin was prob sticking with his goodfellas blueprint and decided that women in mobster films should always be the dumb blonde.

title: Nothing good
review: Great cast for a police story. That's all, good news end here. I can't see one single reason to go to see this movie. A police story must always be accurate and likely. This is not. I don't want to bother you with details (and if you are going to see it anyway, of course you don't want to know them before going), but believe me. It's not likely because of an endless series of incorrect details. Finally the end is an unannounced non-sense, it could make sense if it were a farce, but it's not, it would be a police story, simply a bad police story! Martin Scorsese is a great director. Anyway he has directed some bad movies. This is his worst!

title: Woot, great film
review: Really enjoyed watching this one. DiCaprio was absolutely superb, he got the role down to a T, Damon was clinical and found him a bit 2 dimensional, I thought they could have shown a bit more of his vulnerabilities to be honest. Marky Mark, was good, but could have had a bit more depth other than verbal fisticuffs. Nickleson in parts was brilliant, you could really feel the malevolence. Ray Winstone, ignoring the accent had the best exiting scene for a long time, very good. The film meandered in parts and could have done with losing 30 mins, I never got bored tho and not having seen Infernal Affairs before was caught out by the ending. Will look forward to watching this again when it's out on DVD. Props to Scorsese, back on top.

review:
Totally copied from 'Infernal Affairs' vol. 1 (a HK Movie) watch 'Infernal Affairs' vol.1 first!! much better than 'The departed' anyone here knows Andy Lau??

i give 4!

title: A Work of Bloody Genius...One of 2006's Best
review:
For as much as I fancy myself a connoisseur of cinema, I have never been too heavily interested in auteurs like Hitchcock, Kubrick, and Scorsese--granted, they have made some films I've enjoyed, but on the whole, I lack the (seemingly mandatory) obsessive critical enthusiasm for their works overall. But "The Departed" (a surprising remake of a Japanese original) is the type of film that might finally inspire me to peer into Scorsese's extensive backcatalog.

"The Departed," in addition to telling a story that's deceptively simple on first glance, but brilliantly twisted with complication as it progresses, also succeeds in assembling a cast at the tops of their respective games. The film actually deserves its biggest accolade for convincing me (finally) that Leonardo DiCaprio is capable of playing an adult role without a hint of the sappy, sentimental "Titanic" baggage that's long stigmatized him in my eyes (when his undercover agent roughs up two hoods in a convenience store, we buy it completely). Similarly, Matt Damon--who's often seemed like a pretty-boy recycling the same character--has a fine turn as a cop who's corrupt to the bone, whose long-standing relationship with Jack Nicholson's Bostonian mob kingpin only drags him further down. Parallels to "The Score"--the 2001 heist flick that united Robert De Niro, Marlon Brando, and Edward Norton--are not out of place, but "The Departed" is more than a cinematic stunt revolving around a twist ending while the actors show their chops; there is a sincere, wrenching intrigue and dramatic force propelling this ride. Scorsese's implications--as we've seen in "GoodFellas" and "Taxi Driver"--are shattering, and "The Departed" is no exception.

While the plot is intricate and I probably couldn't spoil it even if I tried, it is only a tiny part of the bigger picture. Scorsese's film might be the best fictionalized portrait of corruption among civil servants since 1997's "L.A. Confidential," and the double- and triple-crosses perpetrated by DiCaprio, Damon, and Nicholson interweave beautifully. While the script has its contrivances--a romantic interlude between DiCaprio and Damon's girlfriend (Vera Farmiga)--Scorsese not only makes us feel that something is truly at stake all the time, but is not afraid to align our sympathies with his corrupt characters at any given time. "The Departed"'s constantly spinning moral compass--and the coordinates it settles upon--is one of the film's major attractions, because it keeps predictability at a minimum.

At two and half hours, "The Departed" is a tightly-paced crime thriller that maintains such strong momentum that its minuscule caveats are easily forgivable. In addition to the wonderful interplay between the three leads, Alec Baldwin, Martin Sheen, and Mark Wahlberg also turn in strong supporting work. This is a surprising, enthralling film...one of the year's best.

title: The best crime drama of the decade!!
review: I had the chance to see this movie at PVR and was awestruck by its fantastic narration. Especially, the inter-cuts in the movie are so well done in the movie that u don't feel jarred or confused... superb! And even though DiCaprio and Matt Damon had pivotal roles, not to mention Jack, it was a treat to watch & listen to Mark Wahlberg whenever he appears on screen! And man, last 15 minutes really blew me off! I haven't seen much of Martin's movies, the last one I remember watching is The Aviator, which didn't impress me much, even though I liked it somewhat. But with this movie, I can I had become a fan of Martin and would like to watch his previous titles like... Good Fellas,Raging Bull, Caper Fear etc. I am eagerly awaiting for the release of DVD of The Departed which, unfortunately to this part of the world, will come a little late...

title: Just short of a classic
review:
Martin Scorsese has created another great film that will join "Casino" and "Goodfellas" (two of his earlier films) in the American mobster canon. However, this film isn't quite as good as Scorsese's earlier contributions. In fact, it doesn't really improve on "Infernal Affairs," the film it is based on - it merely Americanizes the story.

The script is excellent for the most part. The dialogue is funny, quirky and effective. The actors do a great job (although the accents falter occasionally).
