Jack Nicholson is hilarious and believably crazy, although, admittedly, he is somewhat typecast as the character he plays in this film and seems to rely on standard grimaces and deranged smiles.

Mark Wahlberg's character is strangely lovable, even though he plays a cop with very few redeeming qualities.

Matt Damon and Leonardo DiCaprio convince us that they are, respectively, moles in the police force and an organized crime racket.

Alec Baldwin's supporting role is also very entertaining.

One thing that bothered me was the subtle and not-so-subtle product placement, which, in my opinion, took away from the film (Halls and Dell are two prominent examples). While many argue that we should just accept product placement as a fact of life, I believe that directors have the choice to sell out or not and should resist the urge to make more money while compromising the visual and ethical integrity of their films.

If you have not seen the original film (Infernal Affairs), you'll probably love this movie. If you have, you'll still like it. If you enjoy repartee coupled with violence (something only mobster movies seem to be able to satisfactorily provide), you'll be in for a treat. And, you might have a taste for some Halls mints when you leave the theater...

7 out of 10

title: Lacks suspense & action
review:
The Departed provided a well explained background of the characters that very well patched up the story gaps that Infernal Affairs had. It connected both the Rat & Mole in so many ways that they are not aware of.

It could have been a perfect 10 if it surpassed or at least lived up to the action that Infernal Affairs had, it lacked suspense. In the first meet-up scene with the Chinese men, it lacked tension and on the scened where Martin Sheene was going to meet Leo at the to 344 Washington, it felt dead. The way Mr. Sheene feel from the roof top was uneventful, "how did he exactly fell of that way?". Another is when Matt Damon & Leo meet up on the roof top... where's the struggle in there???? It didn't even had any action! Though it answered a lot of questions to the story gaps Infernal Affairs had, it did not provide the tension & action it had. It was good, but could have been better.

title: Excellent mix of black comedy, drama, and action
review:
This is quite possibly Martin Scorcese's best picture since "Goodfellas." It may surpass "Goodfellas," in fact. There is an excellent mix of drama, black comedy, and action. It is made even better with excellent writing, direction by Scorcese, and acting by its leads.

We begin the movie with a monologue by Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson), the crime lord of Boston, Massachusetts. It then shows young Colin Sullivan and how he begins a relationship with Costello doing odd jobs. When older Colin (Matt Damon) becomes a police officer, Costello has a new informant in the State Police.

Enter the mind of Billy Costigan (Leo DiCaprio), a young undercover cop infiltrating the Boston Mob for the State Police. With a family history of criminals, Billy has an easy time fitting in with Costello's crew. He uses paroxysms of violence to show that he can defend himself and that he is not to be pushed around.

When moles are believed to be in the State Police and the Boston Mob, Captain William Queenan (Martin Sheen) and Costello are on the lookout for suspicious behavior among their "allies." With both Sullivan and Costigan getting paranoid, the movie goes deeper into the BPD and the criminal underworld. Great supporting performances from Ray Winstone and Mark Wahlberg make "The Departed" a real treat to watch.

10/10

title: Absolutely Amazing
review: Going into this film i expected it to be really good but i came out thinking so much more. First of all Scorsese did a brilliant job of directing the film. The storyline was fantastic and was really gripping. All the four leading actors did an excellent job, Jack Nicholson obviously nailing the part rather predictably. But the real surprise amazing performance came from Leonardo Di Caprio. He gave the best performance in the film and made Matt Damon look left standing alone even though he gave a good performance. Mark Wahlberg gave a good performance but his was more comical than as dramatic as the others. But he suited the role perfectly i think. If this film doesn't win Best Picture and Director i don't know whats wrong with the world. I think Di Caprio will get a nomination for lead actor and i think Nicholson will get a supporting nomination. All in all the best film of 2006 undoubtedly.

title: kindda disappointed
review:
just finished the watching of TD around 10 mins ago, well, i have almost the same opinion like many guys who already have seen the TD and the original version have given. Kindda disappointed.

Basically, TD is a good movie if we r not comparin it 2 the original 1. When I first heard this remake movie is going 2 be stared by Dic&Matt, I was holding a lot of expectation. Unfortunately,it doesn't work out that way as i expected.

I don't like the performance of the both in comparison 2 Tony& Andy. I personally think Dic's performance is bit superficial, his eyes and acting oozed out 2 much fear. Lookin back tony's performance, it's more complex and dramatic intense.

Well, as 1 fellow said, in this year filled with lame movies, it's still a good thing to watch a movie as TD. And 1 more tip, don't watch the original version before u watch it.

title: Awesome!
review:
Okay, I'm not a huge Scorsese fan and entered the theater having possible thoughts that this film was another cop and criminals film. It is a cop and criminals film, but done in a very rare feat of movie-making that blew me away! The film is based off of a previous film made in China that explores both sides of the law through the eyes of two men. both of them are moles who are in deep, seeking out information for the other. Billy Costigan (Leo Dicaprio) plays a hot-headed cop who hasn't graduated the academy yet. he is assigned to go undercover as a henchmen for a ruthless gangster named Costello (Jack Nicholson).

Meanwhile, Costello has a mole inside the police department, Det. Sullivan (Matton Damon) who is ambitious and who worked his way quickly through the department to get a high position in the police force. As the story progresses, both sides of the law learn they're being watched and leads to a very violent and shocking conclusion.

The acting was top-notched and believable. I'm not much of a Leo fan, but he was flat out excellent and deserves some recognition in the Oscars. Nicholson was pretty much himself with his charm, wicked humor, and psychotic facial expressions. i don't need to mention the rest of the cast, for they were all equally as great, despite the fact that Alec Baldwin stole the show a bit.

the story was in-depth and ad a lot of character development, as well as twist and turns and occasional plot holes that were meant to be. The film-making was excellent, especially with the use of old rock'n'roll music such as Pinkfloud and the Rolling stones, the editing was tastefully done, as well as the cinematography, and the pace of the film flew by, feeling like a ninety minute movie versus a two and a half hour film! Despite all of this, I have to say that this film is not for everyone. especially for those who are squeamish to blood, for there is plenty of graphic blood spray, which never really bothers me, but made me gasp and say "Oh my GoD!" in a few scenes, and there was boat load of swearing that was as bad, if not worse than Bad Boys II.

nonetheless, I loved this film, and I think it is the best film of the year, and as well as Scorsese's best film. It was awesome. It had offbeat, and sick humor, action, acting, story, fast-paced, and above all shock value. there is no doubt that this film should get some Oscars!

**** out of **** If you are a Scorsese film (which I now am because of this film), and can handle a great deal of violence and swearing, it's for you!

title: The Departed By: Rick Radman of Radman_Art
review:
The Departed By: Rick Radman of Radman_Art

Awesome! I absolutely loved this movie. In a decade of bad movies I can barely believe a movie like this was released. Martin Scorsese is a genius, we should cherish this man and honor him before he leaves us like Stanley Kubrick. Like myself and thousands of other artists that never get to create to their full potential. They are ignored by a industry that has completely lost touch with it's audience . But I know the way things are going, the people that hate will stay on the top of the hill destroying all that is TRUE entertainment. "All we need is love", The Beatles.

My dad was a cop in Connecticut all his life and his friends where my friends. Life is cheap back east. I thought in that sense this movie was accurate. That is why I love the west. We are kind out here. This is our world. You have to live here to see what I mean. Don't get me wrong I am from Middletown, Connecticut for as long as I live. My family's family is from there amen. If you want to know why I do not move back there or even visit. Then please contact my sister and two brothers and ask them. Although family sticks together they also (like the movie) turn against each other at the spire of the moment.

I loved absolutely every thing about this move. Except.

Who's brilliant idea was it to make Jack Nicholson the stud? A man at his age he isn't performing any thing remotely similar to the stud he is made out to be in the move. It kind of makes me sick to think of such a thing. Other than that his performance was perfect. It was so cool to see him play a bad guy again. Like in the movie Batman as the joker. It was a thing of beauty. Like I said before, we will not know how much we appreciate someone like this until they are gone.

Oh and how about Alec Baldwin? I just could not hold it in during the conversation at the putting range I began laughing and so did the couple behind me. This is the man at work in such perfect form. It felt like the last scene in "True Grit".

I only hope for more cool movies like this. I think the movie industry makes it's mark like rock music in the 60's and 70's. This past decade of compromise is a mark against us all.

title: they all laughed, but it isn't funny.
review: People says this movie is great, wonderful, perfect... but what about the final? When I went to the cinema last week, the departed was just coming out and the seats were quite full. And when at last Di Caprio (I liked his performance very much) comes down from the flat... )who has already seen the departed know what scene I mean) well, all the people around me started laughing. Furthermore the first 2 hour are full with violence, vulgar language, raunchy scenes, and I can accepted them, but only if they have a sense! "You're makin' nonsense at all, mate" Jack Sparrow'd say. I'm Italian but I don't understand the Italian Scorsese: why everything is so sad? Is that his personal meaning of justice? why all that violence? nothing and nobody explains it. Here in my country people use to be kind and gentle and the violence is never free.I would have enjoyed much more an happily-ever-after ending.

title: Scorsese in familiar territory: guerrilla warfare in the urban jungle. Terrific acting except for Nicholson's lazy turn
review:
Martin Scorsese returns to the milieu he knows best: guerrilla warfare in the urban jungle, only this time the setting is south Boston ("Southy"), not New York City, and it's Irish ghetto dwellers, not Italians, that claim his attention. All of which is vaguely amusing in light of the fact that Departed is a remake of a 2002 Hong Kong crime flick, "Infernal Affairs," adapted from the original script by William Monahan, a Boston Irishman himself.

The plot line is as reminiscent of John LeCarre as of Mario Puzo. It's all about spying. The Boston city police suspect that Southy gang lord Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson) has planted a mole inside their criminal division. At the same time, Costello's people have been tipped that the police covert crime unit might be running a spy, an undercover agent who has infiltrated their gang. In fact, both rumors are true, as we learn early on. But wait a minute. Things aren't THAT simple: there seems to be a spy behind every other lamppost in this shoot 'em up thriller. And Scorsese pays all due respect to the Hong Kong provenance of this story by liberally splashing blood and knuckle sandwiches around like holy water.

Scorsese has also gathered a fabulous cast, and for the most part he orchestrates their turns to great effect. Matt Damon (playing Colin Sullivan) and Leo DiCaprio (as Billy Costigan) are the principal spies, and both sizzle: they're tough as shoe leather, quick as tigers. This is the best work I've seen from DiCaprio in ages: he's maturing, he's bulked up, he's convincingly tough yet just vulnerable enough to be intriguing, as well. Scorsese makes more than sufficient amends here for miscasting him as Howard Hughes in "The Aviator."

Another wonderful surprise is Mark Wahlberg's strong work as the garbage mouth, in-your-face Sergeant Dignam, aide de camp to the chief of the undercover unit and Costigan's leader, Oliver Queenan, who is more than ably played by Martin Sheen. And that's not all. Alec Baldwin also shines as Ellerby, chief of the crime unit, Damon's boss. Then there is Brit bad guy extraordinaire, Ray Winstone, never more menacing than he is here as "Mr. French," Costello's right hand man.

That leaves us with only a couple of less admirable turns to confront, one of which, I regret to report, is presented by Jack Nicholson, who sleepwalks through this film playing the role of, yes, himself, Jack Nicholson. We get the shambling gait that has attended his increasing corpulence in recent years. The rolling up of the eyes, the arching of the brows, the acid toss off comments, the devilish, naughty little smirks that can explode into either a violent attack or a hearty guffaw.

But it's all old hat: Prêt-à-Porter, off-the-shelf, stock Nicholson. And for that reason I find his turn here distracting, like, how did this aging, frumpy, lovable Hollywood actor become enmeshed in a taut crime storyhe better watch out, he could get hurt. He doesn't need a hip fracture at his age. I defended Nicholson in "About Schmidt," when a number of critics said he was too big a star to play such a character role, i.e., too much Jack, not enough Schmidt. But I can't defend him here. Come on, Jack! You can do better. Start surprising us, for Heaven's sakes. Earn your money. Be a dog that is willing to learn new tricks.

However canned his performance is, you can never accuse Nicholson of offering a weak turn, but you can sure indict Vera Farmiga on this charge. Her Madolyn is a psychiatrist who ends up having professional and unprofessional contacts with both young spies, Sullivan and Costigan. The screenplay demands that she face a hopeless fate: as a lover, she is ambiguous and lacks passion; and as a shrink, her sense of boundary issues approaches that of an amoeba. As the lone woman among this pack of seriously felonious cops and crooks, she all but disappears. If I were Ms. Farmiga, I would replace my current agent within the next 30 minutes, before he steers me into another suicidal casting blunder.

This rough and tumble gangster stuff is done in the stylish, grand Scorsese manner; he's at his best directing entertainments like this one (think of "Mean Streets" and "Goodfellas"). And if the moral point seems to be that there isn't much difference between cops and criminals, why that's hardly news. For years psychological researchers have demonstrated such an affinity in the personality makeup of these two groups of adversaries. Like any good Hong Kong crime movie, this one may not teach us anything we don't know already, or transport us to any new destination, but it's sure a thrilling ride. My grades: 8.5/10 (A-) (Seen on 11/02/06)

title: Excellent actors, brilliant idea, smart beginning...
review:
... but perhaps I was expecting too much after all that?

FOR The theme of the film was very interesting, and the editing was very good. Especially the beginning, I said, was extremely credible and I appreciated a lot the depiction of the complexity of real life in a police department and the difficulties ordinary policemen may face in their job. I truly valued the characters and the acting of Leonardo DiCaprio (Costigan), Matt Damon (Sullivan) Mark Wahlberg (Dignam) and Martin Sheen (Queenan).

AGAINST I consider Jack Nicholson (Costello) has become the parody of himself. Moreover, there was a confrontation between Leonardo DiCaprio/Billy Costigan and Jack Nicholson/Frank Costello which made me literally burst laughing out loud in the cinema. The lines were absurd!

And I'm afraid Europeans don't enjoy butcheries either, as at the end of the film everybody in the cinema was laughing.

Vote: 7/10

title: Great Movie! Leonardo has changed my perspective of him.
review: I have to say the entire cast in this movie were all shining. However after being such a Leonardo DiCaprio hater, he was the one who I truly took notice. Long gone is the baby faced actor trying to be a man.. He has completely shed that persona, and I only hope he continues to amaze the movie going public with more creative and assertive roles. Jack Nicholson was his normal greatness. Matt Damon, Alec Baldwin, Martin Sheen, and Mark Wahlberg added weight, depth and dimension to the film, without their characters overpowering the each other. Martin Scorsese was able to tell a story with directness and no overkill. This movie deserves an Oscar for Best Director! Hats off to Martin Scorsese!!!

title: The departed: Wouldn't let u parted till end....
review: Its the movie you will remember and would buy another ticket for. Such lavish sets, competent screen play and photography. Excellent direction. but whats most aspiring is the casting and their performances. Every character fits in his own. May b its the commitment of director or actor whatever. They have given their best. Especially LeoNardo DaCApriciao and Nicholson. MAy be its climax is not much happening but the performances make it masterpiece of MArtin Scorsese. I would be glad to see this movie roll on Oscars red carpet..So go and enjoy the movie. U watch yourself and decide. Don't go by critics opinion.

title: Scorcese scores with 'The Departed'
review: Okay ... if this one doesn't win at the Oscars 2007,screw the AMPAS ! The movie is a real tour dé force; without a shadow of doubt Scorsese's best after 'The Last Temptation of Christ'.Perfect in every which way ,be it the ensemble cast of Hollywood's best (Nicholson,Damon) or the sheer pace of the movie (believe me this movie is actually edge of the seat stuff ,no exaggerations whatsoever) or the plot (though its a remake of the Hong Kong cult flick 'Internal Affairs' ) or the timing (including the intermission!) or the deliciously sexy Vera Farmiga (including her steamy interlude with Leo) ,the movie is prodigiously handled by 'Marty' Scorsese (arguably one of the best Directors after Kubrick).And the biggest surprise was Leo... yep this actor has come of age with this role.You can see shades of potential fulfilled after he wowed audiences with his '93 performance in 'What's eating Gilbert Grape' as an autistic savant kid.It's probably the effect of Scorsese having continued faith in this actor after he cast him in 'Gangs of New York' and 'Aviator'. And the soundtrack is gripping to say the least complementing the action on screen brilliantly (most Pink Floyd aficionados shall agree) .Surely ,Martin Scorsese is the best Director to not have won the Oscar..let's see if that changes next year! Enough said! Watch this flick ... your satisfaction is guaranteed!

title: Americans love movies made by American
review:
It makes no sense to argue which one is better, the departed or inferno affairs. Obviously most amercians would say the departed is way much better and rated it high score, but this is not the opinion by most of the Asian friends I know. So far as I know, all my friends from asia felt "disappointed" after seen this one... And also it doesn't mean IA better than TD.

You even think the music in TD is much better than IA, because you guys listen to this kind of music ever before you could walk. But the songs in IA seems to be more moving and consistent with the plot from an asians' point of view. BTW: is the music in TD by pink floyd? can anyone confirm? The most disappointing change in TD, I think, is that the police undercover just wanted money at the very end. In IA, as a contrast, the police undercover wanted nothing but "to be a cop", and he got what he wanted after he died, which was the beauty of this film.

Anyway, no offense. Just different tastes based on different cultures. Your story happened in church, and our story happened in temple. Stop arguing church is so much better than temple, or otherwise.

title: Departed - viewed & comment -
review:
"Departed"

I must give this movie a strong rating of 5!

The acting was most impressive by everyone. Damon did an exceptionally wonderful job with his character in this movie.

Nicholson was his same rare self and played it well. As could only be expected by a man with senior experience and talent.

However, anything beyond the talented acting in this movie is not at all impressive. The storyline was a bit on the weak side. The added humor placed within this movie did add to its finished result, but these were on the most part quite slim and far few to say the least.

The movie seemed to go on way too long for the story at hand. It reached a point where I was saying when will this end?

I must give this movie a rating of a strong 5 only with the consideration the acting was indeed well expressed.

~Angel~

title: Makes other movies look bad
review: The thing with Scorsese films is that each time you watch one of his movies, you pick up something new. I loved this movie, entertaining and so well acted, and fun - funny to say in a movie where most of the major (SPOILER!!!) characters are killed off, but the fun is in watching people like Nicholson, DiCaprio, Damon, Baldwin and Walhberg in the same flick at the top of their game. Everyone was excellent but kudos esp. to DiCaprio - mesmerizing and heartbreaking. Recommend highly but don't go if your taste runs to the typical Hollywood pap.It requires the viewer to think; the storyline may appear simple but there are so many sub-layers to the characters and their relationships. An added plus is the soundtrack, not just the usual Rolling Stone songs that Scorsese loves but also the original instrumental music.

title: Killer Looks, Naked Ambition
review:
Big Marty Scorsese is back baby and he's better than ever. After seeing this gem, there wasn't enough voltage in the world to electroshock me back into coherence.

The story is riveting mainly thanks to the ingenuity of the premise of having two characters deep undercover and trying to track each other down. You know the edge of your seat? If not, you will by the end of this pulsating thriller.

The ensemble cast is A-MA-ZING! Nicholson can start writing his Oscar acceptance speech now because he's in career best form as local mafia kingpin Frank Costello. Equally impressive are twin hotstuffs Leo Di Caprio and Marky Wahlberg who simply smolder in any scene they share.

What more is there to say? Bring on the sequel, The Arrived!!! (cue the cringe)

title: Infernally good
review:
First things first  if you've not seen it, see Infernal Affairs (just the first one  no real need for the sequels). It doesn't matter if you see it before or after The Departed, but you should see it all the same. It is not quite the same film (with, for me, the biggest difference being in the interpretation of Damon's character) and is excellent.

So, that out of the way, The Departed: what a great film! A top, top, top flight cast, with a top director and a top idea  as a cynic, for me it was set up to be a turkey, but luckily they got it right. Scorsese's pacing and control are spot on, Nicholson seethes and explodes as only Jack can, Damon is cold and controlled, Alec Baldwin (world's greatest actor, according to Kim Jong Il) is superbly fat and sweaty, Wahlberg is intense and dislikeable (in a good way) and Di Caprio gives, maybe, his best performance since What's Eating Gilbert Grape? managing to convey the desperation and isolation that Costigan was feeling without resorting to melodrama.

It is a long film but never drags and, despite having already seen Infernal Affairs first, still felt fresh and gripped me to the end. This is quality cinema, of a style that you don't get much of these days (that's right kids  no wire work or chicks doing kung-fu) and deserves to be seen and applauded.

title: According to my expectations..and a little more
review:
I saw the movie couple of times. I go to see a movie more than once very rarely and the main reason is to keep the first impression mostly 'untouched'. This time things were different, not only that I wasn't scared of damage the good feelings that the film left me with after the first seeing, but the desire of doing it again made me think of it even with more delight. I really liked it obviously. First I was attracted by the way it climbed in the IMDb Top 250. I keep my eye on this chart and in the last months I haven't seen such a fast going up-to-the-top . After 'Heat' and 'Mystic River' I don't remember to have been moved that way by a movie in that genre from the latest years.

If I have to be honest, the only thing that bothered me was that DiCaprio is playing the main character. After 'Titanic' I thought nothing can make me go and see him playing again. Well, that's the funniest part - exactly he and his acting are to be thanked for making me see this movie again...and again if you ask me. Sooner or later I think he and Martin Scorsese will have their own Oscar statuettes at home. At the end - why not this time?...

title: a possible goof
review:
maybe a SPOILER

I am not sure how it works in America, but usually they will have to shoot blanks at a funeral. I just do not see the guard of honor using live ammunition. At least that's what other countries practice.

At the funeral in the movie, we see two consequent shots without reloading - which is hard to achieve with blanks, due to the lack of retraction of the loading mechanism. The gases fired are not enough to reload the weapon without a bullet of some sort.

Correct me if I'm wrong.

What is the usual practice in US in this case?

title: Too many cooks spoil the broth....kick them out of the editing room
review:
I was watching 'The Departed' and marvelled at how gorgeous movies can look, sound and be scripted today with imperfections. It doesn't matter why, but it does matter when one of my considered best directors may allow insiders/outsiders have a say or a bit of a fiddle in the editing room, which I think has happened in this instant. Life is compromise. I may be wrong.

This is an immediate response after a nights sleep - DiCaprio, Wahlberg, Baldwin, Damon and O'Hara immediately fill the screen with ongoing possibilities. I'd like to think this is because Scorsese let them move. Maybe they do it themselves...

Nicholson, Sheen and Winstone et al, all these actors have achieved in their own right, yet increasingly seem to be playing themselves without anyone saying,'excuse me...didn't you do this in your last five to ten movies.....?' Maybe its time directors/actors used their well-honed skills to move on? A braver push and shove! Jack must be mentioned because caricatures are as visible in cinema as they are on the canvas. He's having fun and there is a weary laugh right down to the rat on the railing at the end and I'm not sure if there was an intended tip of the hat to Scarface, but, its not worth a nod as its been done by Pacino excellently.It gets harder to surprise -i'll squash a fly and lick it off my hand or wave an exaggerated artificial penis (ahoy young man) in an underground theatre at my informer, stand in some squalid hole in the wall bar with blood-soaked butcher arms..........It got a bit silly. Jack or his director made it a bit embarrassing.

No problem with intelligent violence & sex.......... but less is more.

title: Solid return to the crime drama for Martin Scorsese
review:
An American remake of the Infernal Affairs trilogy from Hong Kong.

Story is essentially the same: a powerful mobster wins the attention and soon the loyalty of a young boy who later joins the local police force and gives him critical information to help the gangster carry out his underworld operation. Meanwhile, the cops send in their own undercover man to find who sends them critical information from within the crime lord's empire. Soon, paths become dangerously close as both cop and criminal know that someone is out to expose their real identity.

One of the world's finest directors once again works with a powerhouse cast to deliver a powerful film. Nearly epic in tone and riveting with its great performances for its admittedly lengthy runtime, but you'll hardly notice that. This is also one of the rare times where remake measures up to the original, mainly in that Scorsese pull no sucker punches or cheap shots. He controls the characters, sensationalism, and critically, the violence and steers them out of Hollywood cliché. The film has literally non-stop profanity/offensive remarks and brutal scenes of violence, but it is all convincing when shown next to the two-faced nature of undercover work. Nothing happens just to show off a slick location or gun-play, but all measures up to what crime drama fans have been waiting to see from Scorsese since he made "Casino" a decade earlier.

The film does end slightly abruptly and the scenes seem to jump a bit towards the end. The lengthy duration of the seems to the have caused Scorsese to speed things up there in order to reach the conclusion, but overall this great stuff. Jack Nicholson has never looked so evil and a film has rarely been so dark in parts and funny in others, so depressing in certain scenes and uplifting in others. And the best thing is, most of these scenes ring true.

Even if you have seen the original (and will be able to predict major story turns) this is still a film worth watching in how its core has been placed in America.

However, the biggest strike against the film, and Scorsese at Oscar time, will probably be the poignancy of the film. Scorsese is more than likely to once again square off against Clint Eastwood who directed the great, and POIGNANT "Flags of our Fathers." This film lacks that punch in that it deals with issues that don't affect everyone, but war reaches an entire nation as you have, inevitably seen in recent years. Though this still ranks as one this year's best. 8/10

Rated R for strong violence and profanity

title: Not as good as the HK original
review: If you thought that was good go see Infernal Affairs. It's in Cantonese but they have subtitles! The original is better then The Departed and I didn't see Infernal Affairs in theaters so that must say something. Maybe its just that Andy Lau is so hot hot hot who knows... They have to get the right to rip of plots don't they? I hope so because if not that would be totally lame. I wish that they would have given some hint in it to the director of Infernal Affairs. If hes not getting a chunk of money from it then Martin whats his face should have at least gave some credit to the director of Infernal Affairs. Leo Dicaprio did a good job portraying the good guy, I hope when the DVD comes out that they have alternate endings, since the original did. I'm just going to leave it at that I suggest you go rent Infernal Affairs (blockbuster has it) if ya liked The Departed.

title: synopsis
review: I suppose I was a little harsh in ranking The Departed a 7 out of 10 but whenever I watch a Martin Scorcese film I expect to see a great movie. I guess that's what happens when he's directed hits such as Goodfellas and Casino. Still, The Departed was an action-packed film that left me shocked (in a good way) as I left the theatre. The plot centers around Colin Sullivan (played by Matt Damon) as a crooked police officer from Boston and Billy Costigan (Leonardo Dicaprio) as an undercover cop posing as a gangster in Frank Costello's (Jack Nicholson) gang. Basically, Costigan is recruited by Officers Dignam (Mark Wahlberg) and Queenan (Martin Sheen) to become a mole within the Frank Costello crime operation. His work as a mole is totally clandestine with only Dignam and Queenan having any knowledge about his mission (to gather evidence to arrest Costello). Subsequently, Costello suspects that there's a spy on his crew and asks Sullivan, using his police power, to find out who the mole is. Unfortunately, for Sullivan, he doesn't have access to the records of undercover police officers and therefore has no knowledge of Costigan. To complicate the matter further, it is suspected that there is a mole within the police department and Sullivan is assigned to investigate such claims. Without giving away too many plot details, the rest of the film centers on Sullivan desperately trying to find the mole on Costello's crew while Costigan does the same for the police department. In general, the film was filled with much of what has made past Scorcese films so good, great acting, a solid plot, and a lot of action/bloodshed. In particular, I thought Matt Damon stole the show with a great (Oscar worthy?) performance as the suave yet cold Colin Sullivan. Also, Mark Walhberg was great in a supporting role as the bellicose Officer Dignam. Overall, I felt this was a great movie but still a tier (albeit a small one) below Scorese classics such as Goodfellas and Casino.

title: Very good movie carried by story and acting
review:
This is very good movie paying the nine odd dollars for a ticket in the theater is worth it. Would be a phenomenal movie is it wasn't for a few things.

A certain brown envelope is never explained and was probably in some deleted scene. The ending goes so quick it is hard to process everything almost like they knew it was too long of a movie and just had to end it. Ending isn't bad just not up to par with the rest of the movie. Lastly the role of the female psychiatrist/love interest is not done well and I found myself annoyed with how she was portrayed and didn't find her part very believable.

All of these problems aren't very big ones that ruin the movie, more like annoyances. I give the movie 8 out 10 on IMDb or on the more traditional movie rating system a 3 1/2 stars out of 4.

title: leave your breath at home...
review:
...cause u won't be needing it during "THE DEPARTED". well, maybe during intermission...

"THE DEPARTED" is the name of the world's newest roller-coaster,it may not be the scariest but it surly is the fastest. u don't SEE "THE DEPARTED", u RUN with it. the movie is so fast, there's something going on all the time and u have to take turns with your friends at who blinks just so u won't miss anything...

high expectations in movies are a curse cos most of the time u get disappointed. this is not the case...

where to begin? i saw "infernal affairs" like 1 year ago, i liked it but... something was missing, i couldn't quite put my finger on it, now i know what it was...Scorsese, Martin Scorsese:

those empty lines are not a mistake, i really am speechless... the man just keeps 'em coming like bullets from a tommy-gun... nothing to say, he just keeps setting higher standards for himself and just when u thought "crime movies" are a thing of the past he comes and delivers this beauty...

the acting in the movie is truly fantastic. mark walberg is both hilarious and frightening as a fast-talking, tough and yet caring detective. the same goes for Alec Baldwin who plays a small but great part. martin sheen might get nominee for his great role also.

as for the three "big guns"? well, Dicaprio keeps surprising me, he was fantastic. truly. Matt Damon was the only one that maybe, maybe was a bit less than great... he gets an "-a"... and jack? well, jack is jack...

and the best for last: William Monahan, Siu Fai Mak & Felix Chong. for writing us a film the pantheon of cinema simply had to have...

go. see it. now.

title: The Departed and Infernal Affairs (Chinese version) comparison
review:
Like a lot of other American films that's of the same genre, this one is filled with shooting, fighting, and killing. To some of us, this film is fairly original; just how the film is in detail, there are plenty of reviews already. However, to anyone that understands Chinese, or anyone who's interested in the original version of this film, I strongly advise you to watch Infernal Affairs (yes infernal, not internal) 1 (2002), 2 (2003), and 3 (2003) (Wu Jian Dao / Mou Gaan Dou). While I would say both the American and Chinese versions of the film are great. The Chinese version offers a greater detail of character development, there is a lot more layers complex that requires viewers to really pay attention to the movie to enjoy it fully. On the other hand, the American version follows the more American trend of such genre, story is completely flattened and simpler in comparison, with less attention to character details, and a lot more action. Since the American version of this film is considered an action film, I would say the Chinese version is a film of art. Depending on personal taste, some would prefer one over the other. If you want to enjoy a good o' American action film with plenty of "blowing things up" to keep you on the edge of your seats, The Departed is for you. If you enjoy the finer details and story of films that hooks you into the movie, then Infernal Affairs are the better choices. Either way, I suggest you watch both versions, and personally, the Chinese version is more my flavor.

Oh, by the way, to avoid too much confusion: Infernal Affairs 1 is The Departed, 2 and 3 are prequel and sequel that goes into more details to complete the whole story (forgot which one's prequel, which one's sequel)

title: Well done
review:
A well done movie, but one too many dead heads in blood puddles. The acting was great and the plot satisfyingly complicated except for the ending. ** How did the guy who killed Colin know he was the rat. ** Why didn't Madolyn turn Colin in? ** Why didn't Colin kill Madolyn so she couldn't turn him in?

Vera Farmiga (Madolyn) was especially likable. She looks like a real person rather than the typical beauty queen which most directors choose for their lead female roles.

Overall the 2 and 1/2 hours went fast. I would recommend this movie with reservations for the violence.

title: Scorcese Is Back Where He Belongs
review:
Last night, I sat in a dark theater, thrilled to see the words, "Warner Bros. Pictures Presents" come onto the screen. I have been a Scorcese fan for as long as I can remember, but this was the first time I had ever witnessed one of his brilliant films on the big screen.

For starters, let me say that this is the best film that I have seen this year, and I find it sad that it comes so late. There have been no films that have really blown me away this year, and it's already October.

But it was worth the wait. I was blown away by the cast members' performances, especially those of Leonardo DiCaprio and Matt Damon. Martin Sheen and Alec Baldwin are fantastic in their roles as Oliver Queenan and Ellerby, respectively. Jack Nicholson plays Frank Costello the only way Jack Nicholson could play a villain, violent, vulgar and insane. And under Martin Scorcese's direction, he becomes the incarnation of evil.

The plot is a basic cops-and-robbers tale that makes itself complex, gripping and amazing all at the same time. Frank Costello (Nicholson) is the one man you don't want to meet if you ever find yourself visiting Boston. He's flashy and dangerous, and keeps all together apparently, as he's never been caught for his illegal activity. And there's reason for that: He has a mole working as a police officer in the State Police (a "Statie" in Boston street slang). The young man who tips Costello off is Colin Sullivan (Damon), who was just a kid when he began working for Costello.

Of course, there has to be a good cop. That's where Billy Costigan (DiCaprio) comes in. He has the task of going undercover as a member of Costello's crew.

And so begins the intensity of "The Departed." I can not give away any of the plot because it is just too good. Mark Wahlberg and Vera Farmiga also deliver solid performances. Martin Scorcese is back where he belongs directing gangster movies, and it shows: The film is packed with Scorcesean violence, heavy profanity and unbelievabely intense scenes. It's gripping, depressing and beautiful. It's the best film of 2006.

title: Reading my review below is a window to my soul.
review:
I like puppies. I will say it again so everybody knows I am serious about this. I like puppies. I will go to the highest mountain and yell it if I have to. I've lost friends over this fact. OK, so now that this issue is out of the way. Let's talk movies. OK, I saw Departments the other day. I will not bore you with all my inner thoughts on this bad boy, I will just say I give it 7 out of 10 stars.

Last night, Charles Brown's Thanksgiving was on. You are right, I did watch it. However, I will confess that I kept it muted all the way through except for the parts when Snoopy was on the screen. Please e-mail me if you know the answer to this question: How old is Snoopy? I mean, if he is a puppy that is awesome, and I love him. However, if he is not a puppy, I will never allow his name to be mentioned in my dorm room ever again.

title: The man has done it again
review:
The man has done it again. If there is any director who is the undisputed master of the crime genre, it is Martin Scorsese hands down. Not because his films are campy examples of the genre, and not because they take and break the rules. What makes Scorsese's crime movies, and The Departed as a particular standout example, is how incredibly matter-of-fact they are. Frank Costello isn't a caricature. Jack Nicholson plays him with much intensity, but he never, ever treads Vito Corleone or Marcellus Wallace territory. Costello is just a man who happens to be a foul-mouthed gangster  no more, no less. Costigan is just a young man who is extremely confused about loyalty. Sullivan is just a young man who stands by his loyalty but gets dragged down by his weaknesses. Dignam is a man who compensates for his lacking physical stature with fierce determination. Queenan is a wise father figure. The point of this breakdown is to emphasize that all of these are characters. They never become caricatures, exaggerations, and depictions. They all exist in all three dimensions, round as a billiard ball. As with his previous films, Scorsese never needs to emphasize the setting. Sure, since it is a contemporary film he doesn't need to indulge in period details. But the whole Boston setting is extremely well executed in that Scorsese never emphasizes it. It simply is. It is in this sense that Scorsese is so successful in his film-making. Because he doesn't indulge himself in excessive details. His focus is entirely on his storytelling. And this focus pays off greatly.

The plot is thick as a brick. The initial concept of a police mole in the mob and a mob mole in the police department, both of which pretty much need to find themselves, is fascinating and brilliant. But there is so much more than the simple premise. The film is rich with paradoxical details and mind-bending deadlocks. The dynamics, parallels, and general unfolding of events are as rich as they are fascinating. And as the film reaches its unforeseeable climax, we see what all the anticipation was for.

From a technical standpoint, Scorsese utilizes a style reminiscent of Taxi Driver. It isn't exactly minimalist, but it is certainly gritty and down to earth. There is no fancy lighting, no elaborate sets or costumes. Everything is extremely realistic and down to earth. Scorsese also expertly uses music in the film, both pop songs and Howard Shore's original score, NEVER to emphasize or warp the audience but simply as a setting. If there are two technical aspects that must be emphasized, it is the cinematography and the editing. Scorsese has always been known as a master of the camera, and what makes him such a master isn't being a show-off, but in his restraint. The camera angles and movements are brilliant and dazzling, without taking front stage. It all serves the story. The editing by Thelma Schoonmaker, longtime Scorsese collaborator, is definitely the most amazing technical aspect of the film. It blew my mind. I seriously can't think of any director that can better string together a series of shots in a more meaningful and expert way. The editing in this film should win awards. It's just incredible.

But utilizing the film medium is just part of Scorsese's brilliance. He is also a notoriously good director of actors. And with an all-star cast most other directors would kill to get, Scorsese already has a great starting point from which his actors can take the dive and start bouncing. And bounce they do. Every performance builds on and off the other performances. Nobody ever overplays anyone else, it's an extremely expert use of an ensemble. This movie further supports the claim that that the Academy should desperately include a "best ensemble cast performance" category in the Oscars. Nicholson dominates the film; Sheen and Baldwin, the other veterans, expertly deliver fantastic supporting performances. But the real stunners are the younger cast members. DiCaprio was incredible and came across as extremely convincing and very intense as a gritty street character. Then again, Scorsese definitely knows how to direct the man - I still think his performance in The Aviator deserved the Oscar. Mark Wahlberg, a very hit-and-miss actor, is definitely in the hit territory - his aggressive police lieutenant character is expertly, expertly played. But the real standout is Matt Damon. I knew this guy could act - just see Good Will Hunting or The Talented Mr. Ripley for proof. But at THIS caliber? I had no idea he had it in him. The intensity, the drama, the accent - Damon nails it all. He deserves more recognition as a talent and less as a crowd-drawing name as he does today.

I resent calling this a "return to form" for Scorsese, because I personally found his last film, The Aviator, to be just as brilliant as Scorsese's other masterpieces. But this is definitely another entry in one of the most masterful filmographies of any director working today. It's great to see that Scorsese, like fellow director Steven Spielberg and quite unlike fellow directors Brian DePalma and George Lucas, remains a strong and consistent directorial force, and hasn't at all lost his touch. He's still a master of his craft, and does his thing better than anyone else.

title: Weak, bloated remake
review: A major disappointment for people hoping for a sharp, original take on a great film. Scorsese and company add nothing new except trivial subplots and extra characters to service their need for mass market digestibility. Do we really need an improbable romantic triangle involving the two male leads? The Mark Wahlberg character is a superfluous addition whose only purpose is the provide a tied-up-with-a-bow ending. The original is edgy and tense and contains a deeper moral sense of good versus evil. It also has real acting in it. Nicholson overplays every scene and, of course, has to do his crazy devil thing. In the original, Andy Lau actually achieves some depth as the icy, distant, morally vacant wolf in sheep's clothing. In "The Departed", the same character, played by Matt Damon, is portrayed as engaging and charming, making his evil completely inorganic. Tony Leung in the original delivers the best performance of anyone in either film. In the remake, DiCaprio, in the same role, is stiff and artificial, as is most of "The Departed". Too bad, if you saw the remake first, but check it out if you want to see tense, nervy, original film-making of the quality Scorsese used to make.

title: In the shadow of the trilogy...
review:
I'd give this seven stars out of ten. Why? Simply because the Infernal Affairs trilogy eclipses it. Why remake a film which is superb as it is? The plot of this film follows that of Infernal Affairs closely- however, the ending seems a little different. The film basically attempts to walk in its daddy's footsteps. I suppose, though, that if you don't understand Cantonese and dislike subtitles, you're better off watching this movie rather than the original. Pardon my use of a cliché: nothing beats the original. This film isn't very 'special' or 'original', in the sense that it's all been done before...

This film, however, is well worth seeing. The acting was good, 'good' meaning nothing special, but nothing too mediocre either. Famous names add some star spangle to the movie. Leonardo DiCaprio's acting lives up to (if not, surpasses) that of his Asian counterpart, Edison Chen, from IA; but then again, it cannot be denied that Chen's acting was far from admirable. At least both actors are fairly attractive- they both give the film a little 'zing'. Flimic techniques are geared for thrilling viewing. Those who are game for a fast-paced, action-packed movie with a clever plot will find themselves drooling over The Departed.

Watch this movie for a bit of excitement. It's best viewed in a cinema- surround sound and all that.

Don't watch Infernal Affairs until you've seen this movie. Otherwise, you'll find yourself sitting through The Departed, thinking to yourself the entire time; "What was the point of a remake...?!"

title: Brilliant Scorcese Movie
review:
Martin Scorcese returns to the top of his form with this one. This is a movie that will undoubtedly be spoken of as one of Scorcese's all-time best in years to come. He's done the street-level mob story more than once in the past, but the Boston setting (very well represented) and the absolutely stellar cast insure that this movie never threatens to become "Mean Streets III".

The entire cast is wonderful, including Leonardo DiCaprio, who is in no way outclassed by the legendary actors he's surrounded by. Matt Damon and Mark Wahlberg insure that there are authentic Boston accents, and most of the accents in the movie are pretty good (possibly a first for a Hollywood production set in Boston).

It's also worth noting that this may well be the most tightly-plotted Scorcese movie I've ever seen. While his previous mob movies have been more character-based, the action in this one crackles from start to finish, but never overwhelms the well-drawn characters.

In summation, a masterpiece, and one I can't wait to see again.

title: Extreme Disappointment
review:
I can only say one thing, with this all star line up including the director I expected to be overwhelmed. I wasn't. The movie is below average in every sense. This movie without, mainly, Nicholson and the rest of the line up would have been a terrible waste of time. The story is fully depreciated and the ending is just trying to put a spin on things.

Of course the direction is outstanding but Scorsese is whipping a dying horse.

This is definitely not the movie I expected. It is not even entertaining to say the least.

title: Better than expected
review:
I went into this movie with a lot of people already telling me it was a must-see. Never a good start. I had the expectation that it would be another gangster movie with lots of violence but essentially the same story. I was wrong. This is a break out on the gangster theme and set in Boston, instead of the typical New York scene. I figured the cast would dilute the story, but again I was wrong. The cast made the movie. Kudos to the casting director.

Best scene in the movie is the cell phone scene b/n Damon and DiCaprio. Similar to the scene in Heat, where Pacino and DeNiro meet for the first time.

Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed it and would see it again. A couple of holes near the end, but the studio hacks probably cut it down b/c of the lengthy timing already. Its OK, it justifies buying the director's cut on DVD in a year.

title: undeveloped
review:
I was really expecting this movie and had high hopes for it. I've never been fan of Scorsese, he always seemed like a guy who trying too hard. If only he would relax and not make movies just because of the golden statue.

Unfortunately I was pretty disappointed with The Departed. It had bad pacing, worse editing, was way too short for such detailed story - constant jumping from one event to completely another, too many characters undeveloped (especially Sullivan). What kind of relationship do Sullivan and Frank actually have? Can you just shoot somebody after a lifetime of companionship?

It reminds me of movies about superheroes. Those most likely fail when taking themselves too serious. The Departed is just trying too hard to be cool gangster movie with tough guys with f***ed-up personalities.

Altogether, the idea is good but unfortunately Scorsese fails to deliver the whole package. Also, I didn't find DiCaprio to be Oscar material... he frighteningly screams in all his movies anyway.

title: Very well put together, but ultimately pointless?
review: This is undoubtedly a very well made film. It has a gritty realism in style, dialogue and acting. The main protagonists are clearly great actors doing a great job. There is also plenty of action - some of it pretty messy (this isn't a film for people who can't stand the sight of blood!). So why the low score? For me the film fails as there is no real character development. As a result, you never really build any empathy with any of the characters. Ultimately, you don't really care who "wins" or "loses" - pretty much all the characters come across as amoral. So you can sit back and admire the technical competence of all involved, though you won't feel involved yourself...

title: if the comparison with original is necessary
review:
Alrite, I finally drag myself to watch this. My reluctance, of course, is because i think the original is a very good movie that has decent plot and good deal of emotion heavy moments, plus I am never a big fan of Scorsese's works and i really did not think it could top the original.

It turns out i was right, but I had to applaud for this movie. Afterall, it is Scorsese, one is not going to get those beautiful songs play at the background when someone die. It's bleak and cold, and it is a movie of its own.

The only problems i have with this film is Sullivan and the ending. I think the screen writer must be out his mind to make such a complicated character in the original degrade into a stereotypical villain. In IA, Andy Lau is deep, evil, but in the same time, in constant struggle to find his self image. Sullivan is really just lame. I also think the ending lacks the tragic feeling in the original, but hey!, it is exactly Scorsese's style and i respect that.

One other disappointment is leaving out the subtle kind of understanding between the two main characters make the film's depth a bit shallower. After all, the best scene in the original is the one at the audio store where Tony Cheung and Andy Lau first met. Departed just made the line between black and white too clear.

Nevertheless, it is still a great film. DiCaprio deserve nomination for his performance, and even though i am in doubt Scorsese will actually receive one academy award next year, I think this is a better shot compare to GoNY and Aviator. Wellz, i guess i will just make a suggestion for people who watch this film but not the original, grab it. It's the same plot essentially but very different style, and both highly enjoyable

title: OK Movie
review: I think it was rather too long and the female connection ,Damons girlfriend and De Caprio's counsellor was unnecessary. It didn't do anything for the plot. Overall though very good, even if sometimes the soundtrack did not always capture the mood of each scene. Nicholson as always is very good. Martin Sheen is OK Mark Wahlberg is excellent ,very Funny Alec Baldwin comes across as a dumb ass. Leonardo de Caprios Best Movie ,no Doubt. Scorsese's best for long time ,but somehow he doesn't always hit it off. RayWinstone is always excellent ,showing how he can be a villain in the USA as well. At 149 minutes a little too long.

title: Could have cut an hour out
review:
I have no Idea why this has been getting such great reviews. Granted, if Scorcese had carried on like he did in the first 40 minutes of the movie, this could have been brilliant, but I think he's getting slow in his old age.

At about halfway through this movie you'll see what I mean. Suddenly there is too much going on at once and it turns into a stupid "everybody suspects everybody else" cop drama with ridiculous plot twists to boot. The last 20 mins are totally stupid and unnecessary, so I would walk out before they start.

Other than that, it's not all bad. Leo and Jack Nickolson put in some stellar performances and the soundtrack is pretty good. Still, only a 5/10

title: slightly overrated
review:
All in all, this was indeed a good film. Certainly better than 90% of the garbage out right now. But it was not in the same league as Goodfellas, Taxi Driver, Mean Streets, Age of Innocence, Kundun, Casino, Raging Bull. It had a lot of over-acting (Nicholson) and none of the camera directing and scene construction that made the previously mentioned Scorcese movies so great. Those movies were rich in every sense that a director can enhance a movie that already has a good script and a good cast. Scorcese constantly reminded you that it was a "Scorcese" film.

It perhaps is in the same league as Gangs of New York and Aviator. Well paced, well acted, and well written, but not as significantly crafted.

When I heard that this film was supposed to be Scorcese's return as "Scorcese," I guess I expected too much.

title: Another Blockbuster Hit
review: I thought this movie was great. It had action and suspense and your were kept guessing throughout the entire film. You never expected what happened next. The chemistry on set was excellent and Jack Nicholson gave an outstanding performance as always, think of when he did the Shining, you loved and hated him. The movie also had great one liners. You will be on the edge of your seat wanting more. Marc Wahlberg and Leonardo DiCaprio were also excellent. Leo gave an other performance worthy of his in the Titantic and Gangs of New York. The only problem I had with the movie is I thought it was a little long. Definitely A Must See!!!!!!!

title: Very well done BUT...
review: I would agree with most everyone that this movie was well done, had great acting, interesting characters and all that. BUT...for some reason when I walked out of the theater the movie failed to resonate with me at all. To me movies are supposed to provoke conversation or stir up feelings but while watching this I never felt sad, afraid, angry or really anything at all. Me and my friends who saw it hardly talked about it afterward. Being well crafted doesn't make a movie great. This one certainly will garner Oscar nominations in many categories but honestly I don't think I'll even remember it 5 years from now.

title: Good, but Scorsese's least personal film
review:
In this, Martin Scorsese's least personal film to date, the director's typically freighted acts of ritualized violence are pared down to a simple, brutal efficiency. Gone is Travis Bickle's spiritually cathartic massacre of a compound full of pimps and dopers or Jake La Motta's masochistic bloody atonement versus Sugar Ray Robinson. The one-shot kills depicted here, shocking in their suddenness, are accompanied by the same splatter of brain fragment across pristine surface time and again. In their depersonalized sameness, these acts achieve something of a perfect uniformity to the dehumanized world in which they occur, where life is cheap and identity cheaper, each man an interchangeable cog in a bottomless existential chain game of cops and robbers. Yet this dedication to meaningless chaos saps the scenario of some of its complexity, particularly noticeable in Scorsese's relative lack of attention to moral and spiritual consequence, the rich exploration of which have solidified his legacy as a serious artist.

So, what is at stake? Unlike in his best work, the answer is found in dismissed and belittled subjects. The disdainful treatment of the clergy provides a window into his methods, as he gives neither counterpoint nor context to an early scene in which two priests are accosted and verbally humiliated by a gang lord played by Jack Nicholson. The scene is treated as a blackly humorous anecdote, but the degrading treatment found here and elsewhere in the film, of a profession to which he's mostly shown unique respect throughout his oeuvre (the fact that he nearly became a priest cannot be ignored), suggests that he's in accord with Costello's coarse assessment. This denial of complexity turns up frequentlyincluding an incredibly poor final shot, the selection of which frankly puts his judgment in questionand suggests that what's truly at stake is commercial viability.

If Scorsese's presentation borders on the reductive, the film is given ample weight and complexity through several fine performances and its crackerjack premise: Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio), an undercover cop trying to earn his stripes, moves up a Boston gangster's (Nicholson) food chain as Nicholson's surrogate son and lieutenant (Matt Damon) infiltrates the city police department. Both moles appear at first to be sympathetic, good men. But as Costigan clings tighter to the fragments of his true identity Damon begins to relish the freedom of his adopted one, eventually resorting to irredeemable measures to protect it. The story provocatively suggests that Costigan is a better cop as a criminal and Damon a more effective instrument for evil as a protected agent, a sly insinuation that the methods and conventions of the police and the underworld are not so dissimilar.

Scorsese, to his credit, crafts many fine suspense sequences. The film is at its best when Costigan and Damon are pressed to work at cross-purposes on the same task, as in a drug deal between Costello and some Japanese buyers, when the imperiled moles clandestinely use cell phones to send signals to their respective teams. This scene, and two deeply upsetting deaths, fulfills the promise of the scenario, propelling it to near-greatness. The fact that it falls short may be attributable to Scorsese's indulgence of Nicholson's worst impulses, playing a multifaceted character as a dime-store Mephistopheles, thereby softening the story's profound emotional impact and coarsening its tone. As affecting as DiCaprio and Damon are, Nicholson plays it from the outside, relying on tired gamesmanship to undermine the narrative austerity. Just as Nicholson's failure to understand age-appropriateness paints him as an old man trying vainly to be a kid again, Scorsese's comparatively grown-up attempts at striking the right balance between the sacred and the profane are infinitely preferable to this stab at postmodern chic.

title: Geeks ONLY! Blooper in the Sub-plot involving the microprocessors
review:
The microprocessors used in the film sub-plot (during the $1million exchange with the Chinese gang) is the kind of chip used as a washing machine part!

I work for ST as an Author and spotted the device. The STMicroelectronics processor that is used to form the sub-plot of the movie (shown about 30 minutes in) is an ST9 based 16-bit MCU, the ST92F150JDVxxx. It's the kind of chip used as a washing machine part by Candy and Hoover! Hardly a "TOP SECRET" Mil-Standard missile guidance system device! And hardly worth a $millionUS for a case full! The Chinese gang could contact "Big Jim" our marketing guy in Roussett and have 100,000 chips shipped out for less than a 1million$. Mind you it wouldn't help the films plot very much! Good business for Jack Nicholson's gangster! And good product placement for ST!

title: Scorsese has done it again!
review:
Director Martin Scorsese has done it again. In the 70s through 90s he was the mastermind behind the films Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore, Raging Bull, The Last Temptation of Christ the epic Kundun and the great Goodfellas. In the last 5 years he's spent time directing, Gangs of New York, The Aviator and now - The Departed. Scorsese is the kind of director; character actors rush, hope and pray for an opportunity to work with. Watch any film in his extensive filmography and you will understand in an instant.

The Departed is a story about two informants in the Massachusetts State Police department who work for and against the Boston mafia. The film includes a laundry list of supporting actors. They include Mark Wahlberg, Ray Winstone, and Martin Sheen but it leads with Matt Damon, Jack Nicholson and my man Leonardo DiCaprio.

Damon performs another solid role as the mob mole working in a special task force inside the state police. Nicholson plays "himself" as the dangerous Irish mob boss but he has finally re-invented himself into a dangerous, believable and refreshing character - imagine that. Then we have DiCaprio, one of the best male actors on from the left-coast. Scorsese starred him in "Gangs," trusted him to play the mysterious Howard Hughes in the "Aviator" and has him sneak around inside Nicholson's mob in this thriller. Dicaprio is completely convincing as he moves in circles, unable to trust anyone.

Departed places you in the middle of a world filled with murder and much aggression, all necessary to convey this intense story. The film is easily followed but full of credible twists and turns. Scorsese introduces a new character that should be given a Best Supporting nod if only it had a heart. He has taken our modern day convenience, the cell phone and turned it into a character never before seen on screen.

As with any mob film, there is plenty violence but don't let that deter you from seeing one of the best films this year.

title: "The Departed" NOT the Best Scorcese Movie Ever!
review:
Contrary to what some of the Scorcese devotees have posted here, this is not his best movie! "GoodFellas" was much better! And why is it that "epic" dramas always have to be so long? Have we become so programmed as a movie-watching society that we won't take your movie seriously unless it's two and a half hours long? In my opinion, there was way too much padding in this movie. It could easily have been cut down to less than two hours, and would have been vastly improved.

I haven't seen "Infernal Affairs" so I won't comment on comparisons between the two, but I hope that the Academy doesn't think that remaking someone else's movie (even if it's well done) is worthy of an Oscar! I think that the "best of the best" should be original ideas (although I'm well aware of the fact that there are few "original" ideas left in Hollywood).

That having been said, I thought "The Departed" was a good movie, but not great. I thought most of the performances were good, if not particularly memorable (although Alec Baldwin was hilarious!). I thought that for the most part, the principles pretty much play their parts about the same in most of their movies. And will Leonardo DiCaprio EVER look like he's older than sixteen!? On to the ending...from reading other postings, it sounds like it's a pretty straight redux of Infernal Affairs' ending, but I don't think a "gritty" crime drama should have the audience laughing with increasing volume as each character goes down with a shot to the head!

title: Good plot, acting, cinematography+ horrible ending=OK movie
review:
Good plot, acting, cinematography+ horrible ending=OK movie

I don't understand how this movie has an 8.1 rating.

I think people are forgetting that a good movie has to be a complete package. Plot got really complex and instead of even trying to attempt an ending, just kill everyone and roll credits.

Went from a 10 movie to a 1 movie in the last fifteen minutes, so I am giving it a 5.

Another problem is that with the all star cast...you are constantly reminded you are watching a movie, and this can make it tough to get into it. I don't know how Ocean's 11 did it, but I feel like they did a much better job handling so many talented actors.

title: WTF no Jack & lesbo sex!
review: Read in the New York Post how their was a sex scene in this movie with Jack to girls one with a strap on all going at it. This was not in the movie. Anyone else read that artical. I noticed a couple other quick edits in the end to like when the chick answers the phone and says who the "hell" is this but her lips mouthed, Who the F*CK is this. I really did enjoy this film a lot, but somethings seemed rushed to me. Are they trying to boost DVD sales by having these deleted scenes in it? When i go see a movie it really pisses me off in 3 months when it comes out on DVD with all this extra stuff in it. If thats the case why go to the theaters why not just wait for the damn thing to come out on DVD

title: Excellent Movie, Spectacular Performances By an All-Star Cast
review:
The Departed is an an excellent film that is a remake of a Hong Kong blockbuster titled Infernal Affairs. I had previously seen Infernal Affairs and it was a pleasant surprise to see how closely The Departed tracked the original script. My memory is a bit fuzzy, but I definitely recognized several conversations that were lifted directly from the Hong Kong original.

WARNING: PLOT SPOILER BEINGS HERE

Despite the clearly demonstrated desire to stay true to the highly successful original, there were certain plot modifications made with an American audience in mind. Among them is the fate of Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon's character) at the end of the movie. Other than adding a little additional color, and brief moments of humor, the desire for some "positive" closure appears to be the sole reason for the inclusion of Sgt. Dignam (Mark Wahlberg's character), a character who was not in the original movie.

What really struck me towards the end of the film was the necessity of Billy Costigan's (Leonardo DiCaprio) death. I'm not a Leonardo DiCaprio fan, but I was quite surprised and impressed with how convincingly he played his character. There was a certain point where I realized that in the absence of some cheap trick by the scriptwriter, there was no way for Costigan to live happily ever after. The closest they could have come to a Hollywood ending would have been to have Dignam come in and somehow vouch for Costigan; fortunately it was not with this in mind that he was included in the script.

The one thing this remake was unable to capture was the strong father-son relationship between Costigan and Capt. Queenan. That relationship added a lot to Infernal Affairs and made the latter's death all the more affecting.

title: Boom mic and BAD photoshop work
review:
Okay, great movie. Scorcese never lets you down, nor will this cast, and I almost had an anxiety attack I was so caught up in it.

BUT.... Two weird, lazy technical errors:

1. In the first scene at the State Police Boardroom: The scene opens with a wide shot of the busy room, and i swear to you, I SAW THE FRIGGIN' BOOM MICROPHONE. There it was hanging down from above the center of the frame.

2. Check out some of the photoshop work in this film. Whenever they show that picture of the female lead/psychiatrist as a kid, it looks like CRAP!

*Of course, there are also many continuity flaws...but a lot of people have mentioned that.

Still a great film.

title: One of Scorcese' Finest Films!!!!
review:
Wellwhat can I say about the latest film from Martin Scorsese? Is it a prestigious thriller/drama film up their with the likes of The Godfather, Goodfellas and Reservoir Dogs? Or is it a flop, a flimsy lifeless film which lacks the depth and perception that most crime/thriller films happily entail? From what I have seen from this film, The Departed is Definitely NOT the latter of the two.

I could start with the acting, but I think I'll leave that till a bit later. The first feature of the film that struck me significantly was the setting of a modern day Boston. Scorcese has succeeded in depicting such an underrated city in its dark and sinister form. If there were another definition for the words 'realism' and 'effect', the backdrop of Boston in The Departed would certainly be featured. Each scene is strikingly detailed down to the point of even adding effect to a fly on the wall. The backdrop of the meeting place for Costello's (Nicholson) gang in addition to the Massachusetts State Police Headquarters fits in appropriately with the overall theme that the film is expressing to its viewers.

In order to make a good film, fine actors must be featured in it. I have already selected at least three of the cast members who should vie to win, or at least be nominated for, an Oscar for next year. For Best Actor, Jack Nicholson's portrayal of powerful kingpin Frank Costello is nothing short of exceptional. Nicholson succumbs to his trademark smirk and charisma that is strongly evident in many films that he has had the honor of starring in. The Departed shows that Nicholson has not lost his talent with his old age. Costello, with all his power and influence over his gang in Inner Boston, is a pivotal character in the film, endeavoring to use his power to his advantage.

My second choice for Best Supporting Actor would normally be very difficult to choose for this film. Both Matt Damon and Leonardo DiCaprio have certainly seized their chosen roles and have presented them in convincing awe. If I could only choose one, it would have to be DiCaprio's portrayal of undercover cop Frank Costigan. A live wire in the police who dropped out of the Academy, he is rectified of his prison sentence and wrongdoing and is recruited to go undercover to investigate and weasel out Costello and his henchman. Costigan himself is a confused and unstable man who's vast presence on screen involves compassion and resilience for his aura. Scorcese has really revived DiCaprio's career through his recent films and he is heading back up the food chain of the hostile and unwelcoming list of current great Hollywood actors.

The third and final person who is worth a Nomination is Vera Farmiga who played Dr. Madolyn Madden, Sargent Colin Sullivan's (Damon) girlfriend and shrink who serves Costigan during his stint as an undercover cop. Farmiga strongly portrays the female lead in a style that portrays her unawareness of the situation that is being faced in the film. She is a pivotal character in the plot of the film and her presence on screen is somewhat invigorating. She deserves a nomination for Best Supporting Actress at a minimum.

With the utterly convincing plot and setting, the superb acting by such an ensemble cast, and the superb twist at the end, all describe the sheer excellence that The Departed contains. The only problem I had with the film was its length. At 151 minutes, you just wished at times that the film would come to its fantastic and long awaited end.

This deserves to be Film of the Year and I'm being very generous in giving it a high rating.

title: Another Great Film from a Great Director!
review:
Just as it was becoming painfully clear that 2006 was one of the worst years for movies in recent memory, along comes a masterpiece like 'The Departed' to freshen things up a bit. This should come as no surprise, however, when one takes a look at the credentials of the film's director: Martin Scorsese. Scorsese is arguably the greatest living filmmaker whose films tend to center on themes dealing with violence, masculinity, and urban alienation. Films like 'Taxi Driver', 'Raging Bull', and 'Goodfellas' are among his best work and have represented American cinema at its very best.

After a series of period pieces, such as 'Gangs of New York' and 'The Aviator', Scorsese takes a change of pace with 'The Departed' and goes back to the urban alleys and streets that have been the setting for many of his films. Many fans will no doubt find this to be a welcome 'return to form' for Scorsese, although this is hardly a fair assessment of the director's body of work.

Although the plot has a somewhat labyrinthine structure, the basic premise of 'The Departed' centers around two moles, or 'rats', both of whom are employed by the Boston State Police Department and the Irish mafia. Jack Nicholson, in one of the best performances of his career, plays the notorious mob boss, Frank Costello, who has many friends in high places protecting his every move. Frank is the kind of man who rules his Boston turf with an iron fist, but is capable of mercy and generosity when it suits him. He values loyalty above all else, and if "you'll scratch his back, then he'll scratch yours."

Leonardo DiCaprio plays Billy Costigan, a young thug who works his way into the Boston State Police Deparartment and gets a little more than he bargained for: he gets assigned to work undercover as a 'mole' in Frank Costello's gang. The other mole is played by Matt Damon, who also works for the Boston Police but is secretly helping Costello every step of the way.

The brilliance of 'The Departed' lies in its wild energy and fast-paced storytelling. Tight editing and controlled camera-work move the story along at a quick pace while the twists and turns of the plot will leave you on the edge of your seat. Another charm of the film is its somewhat over-the-top sense of violence combined with eccentric dialog and crude humor. While watching 'The Departed', I was reminded of Quentin Tarantino's 'Pulp Fiction' in that both films contain random and brutal scenes of violence that are juxtaposed with long scenes of quirky dialog.

'The Departed' is a remake, or more accurately, a reworking, of the popular Hong Kong produced film, 'Infernal Affairs'. Other than a change of setting, 'The Departed' keeps the basic story intact while modifying everything else to appeal to Western audiences.

With a great director at the helm, 'The Departed' winds up being one of the most wildly entertaining movies in recent years. It is sure to be a big contender come Oscar time and may even score Scorsese his long eluded best director trophy. Everybody is perfectly cast with strong performances from Jack Nicholson, Leonardo DiCaprio, and Alec Baldwin in particular.

'The Departed' works because it knows how to entertain. Whatever it may lack in thematic content it more than makes up for in entertainment value. Don't skip this film as it is one of the year's best films and deserves to be seen on the big screen.

Rating: 9 out of 10.

title: Brilliant
review:
By far The Departed is the best movie of 2006, this movie has everything you could ask for in a film, it has amazing storytelling, thrilling suspense, it has romance, Alec Baldwin also adds a little comedy to the film.

The acting in this movie is truly incredible, Mark Whalberg should definitely get a supporting nomination, as well as Ray Winstone who is way underrated, and a brilliant actor.
