Scorsese will probably win the Best Director academy award which he most definitely deserves. The only movie I can see beating The Departed for best film is Flags of our Fathers, which should be amazing considering Clint Eastwood directed it, and Apocolypto which looks amazing.

I recommend this to everyone 1st MUST SEE of 2006.

title: Fantastic Movie; A New Classic
review: Hopefully this will gain Scorsese the Director's Guild Award and an Oscar at long Last!!!! The man should have won for Taxi Driver, Raging Bull & Goodfellas!! This movie soars from the opening shots. The acting was also magnificent. DiCaprio should win best actor for the most intensely existential role since Travis Bickle in Taxi Driver. You can feel the loneliness and alienation etched on his face in every shot. All were great including Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen, Alec Baldwin, Matt Damon & Jack Nicholson. Also best ensemble cast at the SAG awards is guaranteed.The camera work by Michael Ballhaus was also perfect and of course Thelma Schoonmaker's editing is again the standard to beat for the guild awards and from the Academy.

title: Scorsese is on top once again with this fantastic crime thriller
review:
Martin Scorsese rises to the peak of his directorial skills once again. His return to the world of crime equals his return to prominence. Leonardo DiCaprio brings his best performance of his career, Jack Nicholson gives a performance worthy of his colossal acting ability and notoriety, and Matt Damon adds even more depth to the story that kept me entertained, thrilled, and in suspense throughout. In particular, though, it was the "other" supporting actors that made this film great: Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen, and Alec Baldwin. Wahlberg's coarse and biting tongue was brilliantly on display whenever he was on screen as Dignam. His dialogue was some of the best of the film, and it is easily his best performance. Martin Sheen was very good as Queenan, who was emotionally connected to Costigan and tried his best to keep him from going off the edge. Meanwhile, there was Alec Baldwin, who provided the perfect amount of comic relief. Vera Farmiga was also good in support, but her role was not as outstanding as her male counterparts. The dialogue was crisp and unrelenting, the violence brutal and unremitting. The ending, despite some negative feedback, made me love the film even more. The ending was in fact my favorite part about this film. I was satisfied, shocked, and depressed all at once. The range of emotions this film provides is brilliant in it's own right. The credit should be given to Scorsese once more, as well as to DiCaprio and the rest of the cast. The editing was unapologetic, fast, and smart, and the culmination of the film left me wanting to see it again right away. Whether or not this film is a remake does not bear weight after viewing what exactly this film represents. The gritty city of Boston plays host to a magnificent film and certainly a possible Oscar contender. Mr. Scorsese, you have done it once more.

10/10

title: Typical Martin ScorseseGREAT!
review:
Let me get started, this film is great. Like every Scorsese film I've ever seen, I was excited before and after I saw it. Scorsese has made a plethora of films that dip from genre to genre but what I think we all remember him for is his crime films (Remember Goodfellas? That way so good!!!) and I have to say he has returned to this genre with one great film.

Maybe the most surprising of the elements in this film is the casting of Leonardo DiCaprio as under cover State Police officer Bill Costigan; a part that he plays very well Dare I call him a Badass. Yes I dare. He spends most of the film terrified that he will be caught and I have to say that I felt sorry for the character (though I was a little curious as to why they hired someone with such a nervous disposition to be an undercover cop). All the casting was spot on, with big names all round: Jack Nicholson, Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen, Matt Damon (As a great Corrupt cop) and even Ray Winstone. Who is great but does have to work harder then the rest of the actors with the distinct Boston accent but that's not a criticism.

Based on the brilliant Honk Kong film Infernal Affairs (or Mou gaan dou before someone calls me on it.) it lives up to it. Like the original it has a lot of things going for it. The film takes place in Boston; a city that seems to be have been neglected by the crime story community and with this film following very closely to the tale of Whitey Bulger you get the feeling of echoes of real life. Although the film does have its share of plot holes (i.e. Why would you let a guy who use to be a cop in to your criminal enterprise and when you found out there was a mole in said enterprise why wouldn't he be your first port of call?)The script is faithfully adapted. There's even a good action sequence in it. All in all, this great film is definitely worth the £6 ticket price and I recommend it to anyone.

Plus the ending kicks ass!

title: Emotional, Intense, and all around Amazing.
review: Late on Monday afternoon my friend had asked me if I would like to go see this movie. I had seen the previews and knew a little bit about the story and since the director was Martin Scorsese, I knew that my cage might be rattled a bit. I had no clue as to the roller coaster ride that would ensue. Right out of the gate the story catches you. (dont worry, no spoilers) Nicholson shines as you would expect as the dirtiest low down devil of a human being as any actor could hope to try for. DiCaprio and Damon have a synergy through total yin and yang. And to top it all off you have moles in the system. Where can the story bring you that hasn't already been done? That is for you to see. As the credits rolled, I stood up very slowly. My stomach hurt. I was pushed and pulled through emotions (the fun ones like fear, anger, anguish, etc.) that my head was a mess so my body reacted to it. When you can leave a theater and feel tension like that, the director correctly did his job. Scorsese nailed this one, and DiCaprio has done an even better job in character acting than in the Aviator. Oscars anyone?

title: Well done, to a point
review:
There is little doubt that Martin Scorsese is one of the finest directors currently at work in America. Pictures like "Raging Bull" and "Goodfellas" established him as a master of the art. There is also evidence that, like the gangsters and heist artists he sometimes depicts on the screen, Scorsese is always looking for that one big score, the movie that will put him on easy street. He searched for it in "Cape Fear" and "Gangs of New York" and he's back in the hunt again with "The Departed." Scorsese's talent and craftsmanship cannot be disputed. He has the amazing ability to create a milieu, a textured background, fill it with interesting people and events and weave them all together. And despite his less than successful forays into other genres, he usually comes off best when he sticks to the genre that made him famous, the gangster flick. Scorsese may hate gangster films for all I know, just as James Cagney did before him, but he is smart enough to realize they are his bread and butter.

But like so many directors today, Scorsese is trapped in an industry that focuses so much on the youth market, in today's world, a poorly educated youth market that is swimming in media excess. This is the age, not of information, but rather of too much information. This is an age where movies and TV are more influenced by the computer screen than any other force in society. And as most of us know, computers have to have some type of information occupying ever square inch of the screen. So today, TV shows may have opening credits at the bottom of the screen, but they are often overlaid with promos for the show coming up next, even though the viewer isn't even into the current show yet. And since the information is overlaid, you actually can't read either, much less pay attention to the picture on the screen.

Up on the big screen, directors like Peter Jackson can make a horrible mess of his remake of "King Kong," by filling the screen with so much action the film is hard to follow. Don't have the big gorilla fight one T-Rex dinosaur, have him fight three of them, while falling down a bottomless pit and trying to save the girl at the same time.

The fear that letting up for even a second will lose this short attention span audience is slowly strangling the entertainment industry.

"The Departed" falls into this trap. It moves along with the speed of light and even though I found myself checking my watch when we'd crossed the two hour mark, I still enjoyed the movie.

Then came the ending.

Not only did one bad guy meet his maker, they all did. Even people who we didn't know were bad guys died in a hail of bullets. I almost expected the final scene to be somebody pulling out a gun and committing suicide, adding their own body to the pile.

Whether all this carnage was needed, or whether Scorsese just thought that's what kids wants these days, we will never know.

Does the film work, yes. Would I recommend it? Yes, but only with the warning that it contains much bloodshed and too much action for most of us to easily follow the plot.

Is the acting good? Mostly, yes. Leo DiCaprio and Matt Damon are good in lead roles, Martin Sheen, Alex Baldwin and particularly, Mark Walberg are good in supporting roles and actress Vera Farmiga provides some very welcome relief as the love interest, if only in that her scenes provide some of the few moments of calm in this frenetic story.

What about Jack? Nicholson ranges from brilliant to just plain Jack, an actor who is basically playing himself and done it so many times he is now almost a parody of himself.

Is the story credible? Hard to say. It is supposedly adapted from an Asian gangster film. It provides a look into the Irish mob in Boston and thus seems to be fashioned in part on the career of Whitey Bulger, a Boston mob leader who was also an FBI informant and who is still a fugitive.

Lastly, I have one question for the director. Why did he call his fictional crime boss Frank Costello, naming him after a very real Italian-American crime lord once known as the Prime Minster of the Underworld. Costello was probably the most powerful mobster in America during the 1940s and early fifties. He was a dapper dresser and soft spoken hood who lived at the Waldorf Astoria, frequented the Stork Club, and, since he was top man in "the outfit" which reached from New York to New Orleans, Miami to Los Angeles, he probably very rarely turned up in warehouses in the middle of the night where he could get caught in the middle of shady deals. He went to prison, alright, but for what they eventually got most of the big hoods on, a tax rap.

title: Scorsese is king!
review:
First off let me just say that im pretty biased with Martin Scorsese and crime movies in general, but this is one hell of a ride. Im not going to get into the plot because ill be here all night but ill just tell you why it is so awesome.

This is the best cast I've seen at work since heat, with all the a list actors in this you would expect at least one of them to slip up but it just doesn't happen. Matt, Mark, Jack, are at the top of there game but i have to say Leo di caprio takes the cake. He takes you through his emotions like a hurricane and I've seen most of his films and this is his best work.

Now to the directing Scorsese takes us back to his crime classics with so much style. From the opening sequence he hits us with one of his fav songs by the stones and then there is no let up with so many excellent scenes that will take this to an instant classic!. One of my favorites involves leo and jack faceing off for about 10 mins and it actually is up there with the restaurant scene in heat.

So if you heard all the hype and read the reviews BELIEVE IT. Scorsese's best film since casino period. 10/10

title: Dynamic, Brutal Thriller
review:
Martin Scorsese swaps the mean streets of New York for the green streets of Boston in this electro-charged double-double agent crime thriller. At his disposal are his most starry cast ever, among them Leonardo DiCaprio as the hapless cop Billy Costigan forced into the violent underbelly of Boston's crime family. The yin to his yang is Matt Damon who's character, Colin Sullivan, develops mob ties as a lad, then honours those loyalties by becoming a trooper in the state police, giving Costello influence on the inside. As the story unfolds, Costigan and Sullivan become aware of the nature of each other, and must dig each other out before the other one does, or before getting found out. Among the supporting players are Martin Sheen as the stern but caring police chief Queenan, and Mark Wahlberg, who steals every scene his in as a foul-mouthed, though as nails cop working along side Queenan and Costigan against Costello.

Whilst the movie is based on the outstanding Hong Kong thriller "Infernal Affairs" The Departed is very much "un film de Martin Scorsese". Many of the basic plot strands in Wai Keung Lau and Siu Fai Mak's film are present in The Departed, such as the famous silent 30 second phone call, but very seldom do you get any feeling of déjà vu. One such tweak is the role of the mob boss, a important but austere figure in the Hong Kong film, is transformed into a towering inferno in the form of Jack Nicholson's Frank Costello. Here he is the bulk of much of the film's power and emotion, guiding both our protagonists as they attempt to bring their factions down from the inside.

Nicholson is almost unavoidably "Jack" these days. Even when he is playing the psychotic, misogynistic, blood loving Irish mob boss Frank Costello, Nicholson instils him with his evil screen presence, effortlessly charming the audience as well as repulsing them. At times his scenery munching threatens to imbalance the gritty tone of the movie, but just as the seemingly inevitable arching of those infamous eyebrows begins to tease us, we are kept ashore by our faithful director. Not even "Jack" can steal a Scorsese film.

This is Martin Scorsese's first pure genre outing since his reworking of Cape Fear (1991). Whilst I wasn't a huge fan of that particular film, here he succeeds by not limiting himself by the material. Yes this is a genre movie, but that 1970s Scorsese potency perfumes itself throughout, through trademark snazzy editing, a barnstorming rock soundtrack and lots of gratuitous violence. The characters are multi-layered; Matt Damon's mafia ties are at one point complicated by his new found love life. Leonardo DiCaprio is honourable as a cop, but has enough violent tendencies, and drug dependence to throw his good guy image into a mist. The original film was all about entering a layer of hell of getting your real identity confused with your pretense. Whilst this film doesn't quite achieve the depth on top of the style that the original did, and nor does it compete with the heavyweight contenders of Scorsese's yesteryears, such as Mean Streets or Goodfellas, it is never-the-less one of the most electrifying movies I have seen this year. This is, in no small part, due to the wonderful cast, from the poster boys to the equally starry supporting players like Alec Baldwin as a crack police chief, and Ray Winstone who exuberates his nasty, gruff henchman persona with panache despite his Boston-Irish accent seemingly floating in and out of his native cockney at free will. This isn't quite vintage Scorsese, but with Scorsese being the genius he is, its still a dandy.

title: rugby
review: this is a rather minor point in the movie however i wish to make this clear to anyone and hopefully Hollywood if and when they would read this... Americans play rugby (at least in wisconsin and between minnesotans) NEVER allowing for such displays as suggested in the movie... we drink beer together at a kegger afterwards. rugby is the sport of brothers not of enemies. although we may hate each other on the field we are still brothers off the field and respect that honor. something you Hollywood writers shall never understand. you may and shall make fun of my writing and make fun of me (both a logically retarded move) however you shall never have the brotherhood that a rugby team has. you will never understand.

title: A few unanswered questions
review: I may not go as far as to say THE DEPARTED was as good as GoodFellas,but it was damn good, with a strong cast and superb acting. It was rated R for its violence, drugs, and sexual content but quite frankly it seemed to me that the movie was highly edited for time's sake so I think we can likely expect a Director's Cut on DVD with more violence, and OBVIOUSLY a missing wild sex scene involving Jack Nicholson, some blow and 2 women! I would give it a 9, but that being said, I had a few questions regarding who Frank was working for - where the other rat on the police force was all along and how did he know to show up at the elevator scene at the end? And what was in the envelope Costigan gave the shrink - and was it that that ended up in the hands of Dignam who finally got his rat? Regardless, it was worth seeing and I can't wait for the DVD!

title: Exceptionally enjoyable, hard to resist and leaves you a little extra boosted after its finish
review:
Similar to drinking a cup of coffee from dark, rich and well roasted beans after having a large travel mug's worth earlier in the day from the gas station; The Departed is exceptionally enjoyable, hard to resist and leaves you a little extra boosted after its finish.

The Departed is not for the faint of heart or provocateurs of political and social correctness. However, The Departed is full of everything Martin Scorsese  conflict, intensity, male testosterone, chemistry between male and female, the blurred lines between good and bad and legal and illegal. Oh, and did I mentioned gun shots to the head. The Departed is Martin Scorsese at his best.

The basis for The Departed comes from the film "Infernal Affairs" (out of Hong Kong) and screen writer William Monahan does a more than credible job extending the storyline and characters. The Departed is a story and study in the comparison of deception and honesty, crime and law, family lineage and no background, and protection and exposure.

The Departed is full of popular leading actors playing leading and supporting roles that have depth and importance to the film. It is a credit to Scorsese, the actors and the script that The Departed can blend the styles of being almost over-the-top with stretches of seriousness and high intensity yet not lose continuity or the audience. Another measure of the quality of The Departed is that it runs at 1:51 minutes but plays much more like 90.

title: Now this is how a remake should be like.
review:
Now this is how a remake should be like. Not too long ago I went with a friend to see this movie not exactly expecting much of it as it was a remake, and as they say, Hollywood version of an already great smash hit Asian movie tend to suck major ass. However that didn't stop me from going as the director of this piece of movie was no other than Martin Scorcese himself. A master director in my mind. I walked out of that cinema and thought, yep, this was actually better than the original.

Infernal Affairs appear more stylised than The Departed. In fact the reason why I liked The Departed more is because of Scorcese's style and cinematography. TD appears more gritty and realistic than in IA. When I watched IA again, I just can't help but think that everything in it was just glamorised. Even the fight scenes, they just didn't shout 'gritty' to me. I'm blaming this on the use of colour and lighting. Most of the time the settings of the locales are in some sterilised environment with tall skyscrapers and buildings. The colours blue and silver seems to be the film's favourite which creates a more modern day feel to it. Scorcese is renowned for his usual dark settings. In TD it was more 50/50 imo but that didn't really bring me down. Some parts of TD where they show the pivotal scenes was actually portrayed more realistically and more believable than in IA. For instance the part where Martin Sheen's character fell from the rooftop seemed more realistic. No music was played to coincide with the scene and that is what makes it more believable, although I do have to say the presentation and portrayal of that particular scene in IA was tapping more on the emotional side with its use of a melodic song to go with that scene.

In IA the film actually wants to go somewhere, as in it actually wants to move on to the next scene. Whereas in TD it primarily focuses on the development of the two moles. You could say that TD incorporates both IA1 and 2 into the frame. Some viewers may find that the development of these two characters tend to drag on a bit but I personally think that this sets a good ending with their minds being psychologically motivated in capturing and exposing one another. Like I said before, TD is more realistic so presentation wise, it wasn't 'perfectly' set out and co-ordinated in a fixed linear pattern compared to IA. But this is what I like about TD and Scorcese's style and cinematography. The fact that everything is hectic and fast paced shows how chaotic the world around them is and this is what he is exactly trying to convey to us. In IA it just seems like a more perfect world tbh. Everything seems so orderly and 'peaceful' in a way (even though its not).

The music in TD also conveys to us how chaotic and gritty the world is. In some scenes we hear a piece of Irish song played and then it immediately cuts off afterwards. Again this shows how the world and the characters in this film isn't set out on a pre-destined path. The film wants to show us how life is unpredictable, it wants us to feel that there is an ulterior motive or a different agenda to any of the scenes. And this unable us to think what is going to happen next. However since I've seen the original version, I already knew whats going to happen but it is that what distinguishes itself from the original.

I was surprised that it was an all star cast. Martin Sheen, Alec Baldwin, Matt Damon, Mark Wahlberg, Leonardo Di Caprio, Jack Nicholson and Ray Winston. I just thought, woah, I really do hope that this movie will turn out to be a great movie. I didn't want them to pull a Troy on this one. And I wasn't let down. The cast were amazing. Great actors in the frame especially Ray Winston's character. But my initial thoughts on Jack Nicholson playing a mobster leader was a little sceptical. I always see him as a deranged serial killer or eccentric/madman. And thats what actually put me off in this film. I'm guessing its the smile on his face and his frizzy hair cut. It just shouted 'MADMAN' at me. Most of the time you usually get mobsters being displayed as a calm, cool headed, confident and authoritative fella. Here you seen him as your quite chubby womanising smooth talking uncle, if you have an uncle like that that is. He didn't really have that authoritative figure but hey, neither does IA's mob leader. It's more about the actions that they did, the dialogue they used which makes them appear sort of like a mob leader.

But overall the whole movie was great. Watch the original if you get the chance and you can make comparisons for yourself. You may like the original more than this as some members on this board have already stated.

title: Good crime -thrilling drama by a directing legend that features an all-pro cast.
review: Last weekend when I went to the movies to see "The Departed" I knew I would see a good thriller, and it didn't let me down. Being a big Jack Nicholson fan this was a must see for me as I see all of his movies, that was enjoyable but the plot and twist of this movie made it that much more pleasing. Also "The Departed" features an all-pro cast not only Nicholson, but you have Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Alec Baldwin, Martin Sheen and Mark Wahlberg and being directed by a legend like Scorsese made it well worth a watch. "The Departed" is a terrific cops-and mobsters tale that is complicated and compelling. You have the Massachusetts State Police ready to bring down ruthless mobster Frank Costello(played perfect by Jack)enter Boston bred police trainee Billy Costigan(DiCaprio) whose put undercover to dig dirt. The police captain(Sheen) and command sergeant(Wahlberg) are the only ones to know of Costigan's assignment and nobody else does. Scandals are unaware though when rising young sergeant Sullivan(Damon)is already in the special unit known only to his commander, and Sullivan secretly is loyal to Costello who tips Frank off about the moves of police. This movie then one by one becomes a puzzle hard to figure out as no one seems to be who they are. I really like Scorsese's use of realism of the violence and intensity he shows of this film, I guess that can be expected when dealing with the Boston mob though. You will love the blood soaked gore and bullet scenes the best I've seen in a while also. "The Departed" is a film to me that shows one by one how people depart from business or the very life they have one by one as you will see in the film. This is a must see because of the good plot and twist and the great acting.

title: Back story based on the FBI's Number 2 still most wanted
review:
This Movie uses Irish Gangster Whitey Bulger who is still at large as the back drop for this story. Whitey Bulger is still at large and is wanted by the FBI (check their website).

Great film, editing seemed rushed and had a few flubs. I wouldn't be surprised if you see more movies based on Bulger in the future. So why haven't a lot of people heard of him? Maybe cause he is still wanted. As far as the plot line goes, could it be a remake of a Japanese film? Who cares? It was probably a Shakespeare story to begin with. As far as the acting goes everyone did a good job. Hey check out the history behind this gangster. like I said before I wouldn't be surprised if you see more movies based on him.

title: Good Movie, not great
review: The movie is the best film to date for 2006. However, that doesn't mean that The Departed is deserving of the Top 250 movies of all time. This is not Scorsese's best film, and should not be higher than than some of his other films, such as Raging Bull. This movie is on par with Mean Streets and Casino in terms of quality. While the plot was kept at a good pace, it seemed the dialogue took the place of the camera and its effect to speak. I highly recommend this film but I am saddened and dismayed to see a movie this recent, and this quality reach such a high status on the greatest 250 Movies of all time. I give this film such a low rating simply to lower it on the scale of the movies.

title: Good for thrills, but short on soul
review: As we all know from countless movies, cops and robbers are the heads and tails of a coin that always seems good for another flip, if the spin is sufficiently vigorous. But while this film has an interesting (if preposterous) premise of mirror-image moles in the Boston police and an Irish "mafia", and is well directed, acted, and photographed, I found it curiously unmoving. It is certainly far from the top of my list of favorites in the thriller/mystery genre. Puzzling over my unemotional state as I left the theater, I thought of The Departed in comparison to The Third Man, another movie with a mirrored pair of protagonists, and the thriller/mystery that is still at the top of my life list. DiCaprio and Damon as the cop-and-robber twins, and Vera Farmiga as the woman caught between them, could be compared favorably, as actors, to Joseph Cotton, Orson Welles, and Alida Valli, but the male characters in The Departed, unlike Holly Martins and Harry Lime in The Third Man, seem to learn very little from their conflicted loyalties as they ricochet from one violent event to another. Also, nothing happens, or can happen, between them, because they do not know one another, and even their final violent meeting is oddly devoid of drama. Only Farmiga's character learns anything, and it is a bleak lesson indeed. Nicholson's over-the-top mob boss is an entertaining Beelzebub, but actually a distraction from the main story. We certainly learn nothing new about evil from him.

title: Scorsese returns to a gritty crime-drama with near perfect results.
review:
"Martin Scorsese (the legendary filmmaker) zero Oscars - Three 6 Mafia, one!" The implication of Jon Stewart's words during the 2006 Oscars stamped a red hot exclamation point onto the thoughts of many moviegoers. Hopefully, with this recent offering returning to a gritty crime-drama, the Academy will finally recognize Scorsese's talent.

The Departed is a witty, highly original story about a State Trooper named Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio) who goes into deep cover to infiltrate Boston organized crime led by Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson), an aging, Teflon crime lord. Billy has a dark past and many connections with unsavory types, so he's a shoo-in to get close to Frank. As a fresh plot element, one of Frank's henchmen, Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon), goes into deep cover as a State Trooper. Here Damon treats us once again to his Boston accent that sounded so natural in Good Will Hunting. Once Billy and Colin discover the existence of one another, it's up to them to smoke each other out. It is in these moments where the movie truly shines. The most tense scene is probably the film's most subtle, with Billy and Colin on opposite ends of a silent phone call, waiting for the other to speak and betray their identity to the other.

The main plot is helped along the way by a wonderful supporting cast. After a few years doing comedies and misfired dramas, Jack Nicholson reprises his role as the Joker (not literally, but close), which comes almost as naturally as playing himself. His highly nuanced performance has Oscar contender written all over it. Martin Sheen plays a fatherly Police Captain that could have come off flat and cliché with less camera time, but thankfully, the film gave him enough room in which to work. Vera Farmiga, who played the wife in this year's Running Scared, acts as the romantic interest and the third point in a love-triangle between herself, Damon and DiCaprio. My only complaint with her role is that it exists in a vacuum, having very little to no effect on the main plot as a whole. Lastly, Alec Baldwin, whose making a nice comeback through supporting work after his star appeal dwindled to nothing, and Mark Wahlberg play two foul-mouthed, zealous cops and they are a treat to watch on screen, exchanging a litany of swear-riddled barbs fluidly and with perfect timing. Their characters aren't the most textured, but the actors wisely resist the urge to overplay them.

Penned by William Monahan, who also wrote Kingdom of Heaven, The Departed is evocative, witty, and violent. Scorsese takes all three aspects and runs with it, especially the violence. One scene has a character falling from a building and nearly crushing another character while another scene has brain matter from several character painting the walls. A lesser director might "tastefully" keep the gore out of frame or go the other direction and indulge in it. Scorsese simply sets the camera in place and lets the scene play out in one long take. The body count of Shakespearian proportions at the end of the movie will be shocking.

I've never been a big fan of DiCaprio's, but it seems like Scorsese is hell bent for leather to strike gold with him. When I think of DiCaprio, I think of angst and caps slung low over a brooding expression. Maybe it's the way he looks. Like Matthew Broderick, he has one of those weird, perpetual baby faces that'll keep him looking like a teenager for the rest of his life. I think, for the first time, DiCaprio has found a role that suits him in The Departed and the gold Scorsese may strike might be in the form of a little statuette that is reportedly heavier than it looks.

title: Scorcese's back!!!
review: A lot of critics were hailing this movie as one of Scorcese's best. I would have to agree. Although he will never top "Goodfellas" or "Raging Bull", Scorcese has managed to take a rather tired genre--mob movies--and breath new life into it. Of course, having about seven A-list actors in the cast would help any movie. Alec Baldwin, Mark Wahlberg, and Martin Sheen are solid, Ray Winstone is great in his biggest role to date, and Jack Nicholson and Leo DiCaprio deliver masterful performances. The weakest link in my opinion is Matt Damon, who comes across as rather stiff. The direction is pure Scorcese. The steadicam shots, the unexpected explosions of violence, and juxtaposition of humor and bloodshed--I was in Heaven. "The Departed" will probably get a few Oscar nominations. It might win one. For those wanting a break from the usual formulaic tripe, this is a true diamond in the rough.

title: I never thought I'd say this but DiCaprio is perfect in this.
review:
I've just watched the Departed and I'm a big big fan of Infernal Affairs.

I must say, I enjoyed The Departed immensely. It was smart, very funny in places and the performances of DiCaprio, Wahlberg and Winston were fantastic.

I really didn't think Leo would be able to make me empathise with his undercover cop character the way Tony Leung did. But I must say, I was wrong, this is the film where DiCaprio comes of age as a fine actor. He deserves and Oscar nomination for this in my opinion, no question. There is very little between Leo and Leung in terms of performance (I perhaps lean slightly toward Leung as he is the finest Asian actor of the modern age I believe).

All in all, a great but flawed film (some additions to the plot worked, some did not) and a return to form from Scorsese

title: The Departed
review: The movie The Departed grabbed my attention because of the fact that it features Leonardo DiCaprio. The movie is undoubtedly well- written, with many intricacies. However, I grew weary of the obscene cussing within half an hour, if not less. It would have had more of an impact if certain words were used more sparingly. However, Matt Damon and the other actors in the movie do a great job with the Boston accent. This is definitely not a movie you would take your kids to. Although it captures the mind with many plot twists and is very exciting, I would definitely not recommend this movie if the only reason you're going to see it is because you are a fan of Matt Damon or Leonardo DiCaprio.

title: Slow and first but then it's a wild ride
review:
Scorcese does it again, delivering again quality entertainment that is flashy and exciting but needs a bit more heart. The beginning of the movie hints at what could have done to make it better. All in all, the result is quite a piece of entertainment, with some outstanding performances, in particular De Caprio and Damon as the two sides of a character that is heavily manipulated by circumstances and a Faust-like figure.

Damon, in particular, is very good in the way he portraits an ambitious yet hesitant corrupt police officer. He is a despicable character, who still manages to pull a few sympathetic punches. De Caprio is upstaged by Damon a few times, but he is still very effective. Nicholson presents another variation of his naughty persona, with a twist of evil to make it interesting enough.

The man in charge is definitely Scorcese, still at his best with material that involves deceit, violence, and plenty of crime. The movie moves very well most of the time. The final 30 minutes are superb, but in perfect and unfortunate counterbalance, the first 1/2 hour is a bit thin and slow.

It could have been an instant classic. Instead, it's a very good film. Enjoy it.

title: Scorcese SCORES again! brilliant, amazing, revolutionary
review: you can add this movie to your list of favorite movies for your children/grandchildren and future generations, ie: godfather/carlito's way/and others. One of the Best directors of current times.. This movie, start to finish is action gripping sequence along with well trimmed dialogues and brilliant acting, especially LEO. Amazing picturization, screenplay. I went to theatres thinking this movie is over-hyped but I was proved wrong. I would love it see it again and again. You can learn a lot from each scene. There is a scene where Matt Damon's character looks through his balcony from his new condo<<< watch for symbolism in that scene, becomes very important in the end. I would recommend everyone to watch each scene very carefully.

title: Wicked Pissah
review: This movie single handedly reminded me why I watch movies. It isn't just entertaining but it has a great plot and is realistic(especially for native Bostonians). This movie is just like James "Whitey Bulger" and the mess that the Massachusetts State Police underwent to figure out the truth of the underworld. The acting is amazing by mainly Leonardo, Nicholson and Mark Whalberg. The character development of Leonardo Dicaprio's character was heart wrenching. I could go on and on for hours about this movie cause I've already seen it 3 times( and I want to see it tomorrow). I would say that The Departed is one of the best "Guy movies" ever. Now go see this amazing film and experience Scorcese and his masterful mind at work. Peace out Derek

title: Not too entertaining if you've seen the original, Infernal Affairs.
review: The key to enjoying this movie was to not know,in the middle of the movie, what happens at the end . I didn't know that this was a rip off of an Asian movie. I had watched Infernal Affairs (http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0338564/) a while back, with subtitles, it was very entertaining. This is an excellent movie if you don't already know the story; but if you do, well...then it looses it's value half way through. I'm surprised about how exactly they copied the original and didn't add any good twists to it. Remaking Asian horror movies might work, as they are so open ended. But this remake was nothing more than putting new faces to the actors. This movie is great if you haven't seen the Infernal Affairs; if you have, I suggest spending your $10 on something else.

title: A Stellar Movie
review:
The sophisticated cell phones, which play an important role in the movie, are too modern. They don't match the dimorphism of the movie (Nineties, perhaps?) and for me that was a distraction. Otherwise it is A STELLAR MOVIE. Leonardo DiCaprio is incredibly intense and believable. Everyone, including Vera, who plays the girlfriend and shrink, is good in this movie, but DiCaprio shines. Well, of course Jack does too, as Mr. Evil. Most of them (except Wahlberg, who is from Dorchester, which is part of Boston right beside Southie) butcher and overdo the Boston accent (we don't all sound like Ted Kennedy!) but they can be forgiven.

SEE THIS MOVIE!!

title: Departed ... a Suspense Thriller for Men
review:
It isn't often I give a MUST SEE recommendation, so lets cut through all the bull Departed is that one movie really worth seeing even for $10 a ticket. I give Departed 5-stars out of 5.

To get a 5-star rating in my book, a movie must have a very interesting story; great writing to tell that story; great directing to interpret the story; great characters; great visuals; and great acting. Departed has them all and Jack (Nicholson) doing his best work in ages.

Director Martin Scorsese made the large big name ensemble cast put their bigger ego's aside and what we get is the best of movie making. Yes Jack dominates as Jack will, but Leonardo DiCaprio, who I initially thought was miscast, is terrific. Matt Damon who I also couldn't see as a Mass "Statey" has perhaps the best role he's had to date and gives by far the best acting he's done. And add to that a solid supporting cast including Martin Sheen, Mark Wahlberg (putting aside for ever all those snide remarks about "Marky Mark") and even a decent performance by Alec Baldwin.

Departed is a "Man's Movie" with several strong male leads. It has only two women in the movie and they are both minor roles... one, of Jack's girlfriend is a throwaway.

The story revolves around a crime boss in South Boston's "Irish Mafia"  think Whitey Bulger  and two Massachusetts State Cops, one who has infiltrated Jack's boys and the other a crooked cop on Jack's payroll. To add tension each "Rat" is trying to identify the other first in a kill or be killed suspense story.

title: The script is strong but the acting is unforgettable
review:
I have to admit walking into the theatre to see The Departed today I was extremely hyped. With all the positive feedback surrounding the movie, I was sure I was finally going to see that one great movie you normally get in a year, and it truly was for the most part for about 2 hours and 20 minutes.

The acting deserves a 10/10 right across the board, generally all star casts don't work quite so well, but Matt Damon and Leonardo Dicaprio displayed career defining performances (especially Dicaprio), and Alec Baldin, Mark Wahlberg and Martin Sheen deliver unforgettably great jobs in supporting roles, while Jack Nicholson gives his best performance in years.

The one true critique I have is parts of the movie (especially the ending) come off as unnecessary and comedic, and Im not so sure that was what was meant to happen. The attempt in some places to create dramatic irony, or some shocking sequences and me and the better part of the theatre laughing in parts that we were really not suppose to laugh at.

The script is very strong, but the acting is unforgettable, go see it and judge for yourself, as it took me the better part of the night to decide this movie was an 8/10 to me with definite 10/10 possibilities.

Acting 10/10 Script 8/10

Overall 9/10

title: Masterpiece
review:
Just got back from a second viewing of Scorsese's latest, and this time was even better than the last. The script is excellent -- this is a well crafted movie that deals with the themes of greed, trust, and deceit. "Man is a political animal" said Aristotle. This film plays with that idea - it's survival of the fittest out there and man's pride can get the best of him if he's not careful. Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon) is clearly blinded by his own greed in this film -- he basically drools when he looks on the great gold dome of the capital building here in Boston. The dome is a motif that sums up the movie well - it is always looming in the background, it's glimmering gold a clear metaphor for the material benefits that men like Sullivan and Costello (Nicholson) desire. All deceive in this movie, even the "good guys". There is miscommunication galore - everyone withholds information from everyone else, even within the departments of the police.

The acting is absolutely perfect in this movie. Hands down the best role I have ever seen DiCaprio perform. He is stellar - he encapsulates the fear, frustration, and grit of his Billy Costigan. We completely identify with him, and when he meets his end we feel as if we have met our end. It would be naive of me to say that he will definitely win best actor because one never knows the intricacies (or idiocies) of the academy, but I do believe he deserves it for such a sensational job. Not far behind him is the supporting cast, most notably Mark Wahlberg and Alec Baldwin. Wahlberg plays the "bad cop" of the good cop bad cop duo and is an honorable officer who does his job well. He says to an incompetent character, "I'm the guy who does his job, you must be the other guy!" Although he's in a small amount of scenes, he steals them all. The born and raised Boston accent adds to his durable character that doesn't ever flex. He would rather resign than compromise his principles and his devotion to his superior (Martin Sheen, also played well). Lastly, Alec Baldwin seems to have perfected the wise- cracking, vulgar yet efficient boss role as the police chief. The dialogue in the movie is excellent, and he seems to have some of the best lines - every time he speaks he gets a laugh (unquotable for this paper).

It is clear that Costigan (DiCaprio) and Sullivan are foils of each other, "two sides of the same coin". They have the same task - to relay the actions of the other side. They have the same contacts, but with dual purposes. They even sleep with the same girl. It is no coincidence that Scorsese picks two virtually identical actors to play the parts. He is commenting on the dual nature of man, the antagonistic light and dark. On one side, greed, deceit, and vanity and on the other decency, integrity, and "merit". Scorsese shows their contrasting characters through their relationship with Gwen (Vera Farmiga) -- Sullivan at one point refuses to even look at a picture of her in adolescence before stowing it away with the sorry, vain excuse that "We may have company" and that "You don't see where I come from". Costigan, on the other hand, warmly embraces the picture and hangs it on her wall when he sees it. Later on, when Billy gives Gwen an envelope and instructs her not to open it, she does as he asks and leaves it sealed. Yet she can't resist opening the package sent to Sullivan. Costigan and Gwen have a relationship of sincerity and trust, whereas Sullivan cannot be trusted - he obscures his past, his true identity, and strives off his lies for his own personal ascension with blind eyes on the gold dome.

The Departed is about men who have gone off their predetermined path. The departures are both negative and positive, whether the characters have departed from a life of faith and honesty (Sullivan) or departed from a family history of crime towards the honorable, good path (Costigan). It is about men who have departed from their true identities to play theatrical roles. They then must re-search for themselves - "I have to find myself" says Sullivan. "All I want is my identity back" says Costigan. Scorsese comments on how most of us in the everyday world lead a double life, often playing more than one part for societal and political expediency - "It's a nation of rats" says French, Costello's right-hand man. The Departed is a movie that kept me on the edge of my seat through two viewings. Not to mention one scene that is an excellent homage to one of my favorite movies, The Third Man (the funeral). Marty, I hope this is the one, you've certainly deserved it.

title: Just perfect in every single way.
review:
Stars: Leo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Jack Nicholson, Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen, Alec Baldwin, Vera Farmiga, Anthony Anderson.

This is one of those rare movies that have your full attention from the beginning to the very end. Everything about this movie was just perfect. The performances were all excellent, with Dicaprio giving his most grown up and best performance. Matt Damon was great. And as always Jack Nicholson was crazy and great as the mob boss. The plot of the film is that the police in Boston are trying to take down crime boss Francis (Nicholson). There's a henchman of his that's a rat for the cops (DiCaprio) and there's a policeman that's a rat for the mob (Damon). In other reviews of this I've read how much everyone loved Matt Damon's performance, but I have to say, I actually thought Leonardo was even better. And Matt Damon was still excellent. Every single moment of this movie just screams at you, "BEST PICTURE!!!!", and I have to say it deserves it. This was truly a cinematic masterpiece!!!

My rating: ****/****. 147 mins. rated R for Strong Violence, Language and Drug Use.

title: A modern day Shakespearian tragedy
review: If you didn't know any better, you would have thought that this story was written by Shakespeare. I mean it has everything: complex characters, heavy accents (Bostonian) that are near incomprehensible, plenty of language (oh yes, Shakespeare was quite vulgar for his time), sex, witty comedy relief, and an extremely high body count (along with gallons of blood). What starts as a simple undercover job turns into a deadly cat and mouse chase between the two rats (DiCaprio and Damon) to discover the identity of each other without getting killed in the process. Jack Nicholson is, as always, superb and delightfully evil as the vicious mob boss who, like everyone else in the film, has something big to hide other than the fact that he is a mobster. Minor roles of Alec Baldwin and Martin Sheen almost steal the show with their off beat humor and sheer presence (respectively). Fair warning, this film has some very rough cursing and very graphic mob violence and is definitely not for anyone below 17. No nudity, surprising for a Scorsese film, but he makes it up with plenty of graphic sex talk (mostly from Nicholson). An excellent film.

title: The Departed
review: The Departed is an Americanized version of the Internal Affairs trilogy from Hong Kong. The film is about a young man named Billy Costigan who is assigned by the police to go undercover and be a part of the Irish mafia and do whatever their leader Frank Costello tells him to do. The police are trying to crack down on Frank and they figure if Billy gets enough information on him that he can lead them to him and they can make an arrest. Meanwhile another cop named Colin Sullivan is trying to help the police crack down on Frank as well, but little do they know that he has been a long time friend of Frank and whenever they come close to catching him Colin always tips him off, so he doesn't get caught. Frank soon starts to realize that he has a traitor among his men and tries to find out who that is and the police know that one of their men is tipping off Frank and they try and find out who that is. The rest of the film is a cat and mouse game of who ends out and top and who gets caught or not. The Departed has good direction, a good adapted screenplay, good performances by the entire cast, good original music, good cinematography and good film editing. The Departed is a smart film that has a good story and lots of neat twists and turns and you never know how the film is going to end. I thought everyone behind the camera and on screen did a great job and the story kept my interest and entertained me and kept me in suspense wondering what would happen to these characters. The conversations between these characters are very well written and the dialogue between them is very good as well. The film has a nice stylish look and at times also looks gritty which helps give the film the needed edge and feel that it needs. There are a lot of interesting things in this story and while the movie does involve several characters it never complicates the story by throwing in unnecessary side plots or other things involving the characters and when it does it all works well. This film is pulled off very nicely by it's cast and great director Martin Scorsese. For being an unpredictable, compelling and well made film that packs a powerful punch especially in it's last half I would say that The Departed is one of the best films of the year and another great film for Martin Scorsese's film résumé.

title: Great remake of Hong Kong's Internal Affairs
review: I was in love with the original Internal Affairs (http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0338564/). I watched this movie without knowing that it was a remake. Though it started coming back to me, as I went on in the film. So it gave me a different taste from the original Chinese one. If you like this one, do not forget to watch the original, it is a very good one too. One thing I disliked about this movie was it seemed to be a bit lengthy and it could have been cut short by eliminating few scenes without spoiling the movie. The strength of this movie lies on the superb acting of Leonardo, although I think Tony Leung in the original was also very good. Matt also played an excellent opposite role in this film, which reminded me of him of Mr. Ripley's (The Talented Mr. Ripley - http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0134119/). It looked like Mr. Ripley's had made it to Boston eventually.

title: Scorsese is overrated yet again
review:
This was a pretty good film, but it's mostly because it has a really great cast. Marty Gore-sese has yet another film with blood splattering all over the place and at some point in the film you know that everyone is going to be shot except for a lucky one or two.This creates a domino effect with the scenes for the final 40 minutes or so - one down, who's next? This device in screen writing is very mechanical and has been used many times (see Road to Perdition for a recent example) The music, while adding atmosphere and excitement, substitutes for dialog and is overused in my opinion. The female psychiatrist who is involved with Damon and Dicaprio is pretty lightweight for the role; she's too important to the story to be just average.

-spoilers, don't read if you have not seen the film - Once you think the story is over and the bad guy has won, the character they conveniently removed from story comes back and kills him... all the central characters die. Is that the point, no one wins these wars between the cops and the criminals?

title: Winter Hill Gang
review: While watching this movie I got the Idea that it could be based on the real life story of Whitey Bolger as well as what someone else wrote (maybe that's where they got the original idea). If you know the story of the Winter Hill Gang in Boston and yes they were southies, then I highly recommend the Movie. In the late Seventies a gang calling itself the Winter Hill Gang were murdering at will and trying to take over the city of Boston's underworld. Led by Whitey Bolger they used every means at their disposal including the legal system to hide what they were doing. Whitey finally fell when he went into business with two out of state investors. On his orders they were killed separately in Okalhoma and Florida. Investigators from the FBI tied the two murders together and upon further investigation found a suspect mole in their organization in Boston. It touched off a scandal in the FBI and the Federal Witness Protection program because Whitey was using it to protect himself. Whitey then disappeared and has not been heard from since.

title: Violence on a Pedestal
review: Gruesome. Its almost disgustingly violent, nearly revolting. Some call it gritty and real, others says it's blood soaked and sensationalistic. I think it's classic Scorcese - brutal yet elegant, visceral yet poignant. It's a grizzly ballet, a macho cinematic dance. The details of the story are well recorded in other commentaries so I'll limit my statement to my other impressions. DiCaprio is a very fine actor, with a remarkable face. His boyish looks are a high bar for him to maneuver in creating a believable tough guy, and he clears this hurdle easily, powerfully. Matt Damon is a natural as a Boston street smart cop. Mark Wahlberg likewise is a perfect fit as a hard nosed detective. Alec Baldwin is a sheer pleasure to watch, just about stealing all his scenes. And Papa Jack is in great form as an aging, haggard bad ass, past his prime but proudly protecting his turf, the King of the Streets. It gets very gory and grim, a lot of guns and blood, not much left to the imagination. Martin Scorcese uses violence like other directors use dance numbers or musical interludes, as accents and punctuations to expertly developed character studies. It's interesting that their viciousness somehow doesn't define them, but rather, these characters are merely colored and completed by their individual brands of brutality. Scorcese, it seems, has little doubt as to Man's innate inclination for violence, but he is just as shocked and awed by it as we are. He has explored this theme many times, inspiring a legion of imitators and fanatics, and once again breaks new ground with a mesmerizing, if not numbing, barrage of testosterone fueled mayhem and bravado. The love story is weak, like most of Scorcese's female roles usually are. That, I think, is what robs him of the Oscar nearly every time. Yeah, I give it eight bullets out of a full magazine of ten.

title: Just the matter of styles
review: For most of our Hong Kong audiences who would compare the original one and the departed after they watched it because most of them have watched the original one before. I would like to say it is not necessary to compare that which one is better or worse and it is not necessary to argue that the scenes are not good enough when compare to the original one. The departed has huge difference of place and cast; it is just the matter of styles. As Martin Scorsese says "I took the device from Andrew lau's film but the film turned into something else form how it began" "we do what we do and they do what whey do in Hong Kong" If you just want to watch it. It is not necessary to watch the Departed after you have watched the original one and It is not necessary to watch the original one after you have watched Departed. What could you get from your comparison? If you really want to compare, you have better to watch the difference of two of them, May be some scenes are better or worse, Jack Nicholson and DiCaprio has absolutely different performance. Just the matter of styles. Please don't forget the original screenplay by Siu Fai Mak.

title: Best movie i've seen in a while!
review: My friends and I had been talking about going to see The Departed since the first time we saw a commercial for it, surprisingly a short 2 weeks before it opened in theatres. As it came closer to us actually going to the theatre to see it, we saw more and more celebrities talk about it on talk shows and i had no idea there were so many great actors in this movie! This movie had an awesome, gripping, emotional, and at times funny story. Leonardo DiCaprio proves himself to be a terrific actor opposite Jack Nicholson and Matt Damon. The delivery of the story is smooth and leaves you wanting more. The ending does NOT disappoint! I loved this movie and it was one of the best i have seen in a long time, go see it!

title: Not His Best Film But Still Very Good
review:
Although The Departed is very entertaining and his best film since 1995 CASINO, this is one of Scorsese's more detached films. His films for the most part tend to be very personal and character driven. He does character studies on his characters exploring their flaws and weakness. The Departed is one of his few films that are actually plot driven and for the most part he does a fantastic job at it. When you think of all great Scorsese films it is the character that reveals the plot. In terms of guilt and redemption all his film posses this element. Taxi Driver, Raging Bull, Casino, Goodfellas all this films are character films, and we view life for the most part through the eyes of the protagonist. That besides the way that Scorsese stylize his films is more intriguing.

The Departed is very entertaining and that is what film should be. This is commercial Scorsese at his best. Film was definitely geared toward the masses yet Scorsese has definitely left his usual stamp with his visuals. Film is visually stunning and that is partly due to his editor Thelma. Sound track is mediocre, I thought they used the song Gimme Shelter by the Stones too many times, where as when you think of Goodfellas and Casino, the same song was never used twice.

Any way I saw it twice in the theatre and I am going to see it again.

title: Great movie but my quarrels with it
review: OK I just came back from the theatre. What can I say I love Martin's work. Was not a big fan of the Aviator. But let me say the characters were great. Jack Nicholson stellar performance from him, I love how he is kept in the without any lighting for a good portion of the film. My problems with the film well not big problems but here they are. 1) Casting of Anthony Anderson. I mean okay this guy is from scary movie he adds zero credibility to this film. I think having him in it degrades the quality of the picture. 2) the excessive headshots, okay Martin we get it don't have to knock us over the head with it. Overall the story was very involving and I love Dicaprio's part and the humor attached to the characters. I enjoyed this film very much. Any comments on the casting?? Was Alec Baldwin not serious enough for a captain?

title: Loved It!
review:
This movie was great! If you liked The Usual Suspects, you'll like this. It kept you guessing, awesome acting, and a fantastic cast. Even the 'accents' were well done. Yes, it does have a lot of violence, and some of it surprised me, but that's to be expected with a 'cop' movie. The plot here was great, and I'll have to check out the original since I liked this version so much. The ending was a jaw-dropper!

Really great job, and although the whole cast was brilliant, Mark Wahlberg & Leonardo DiCaprio stood out to me. They really made their characters real and their reactions were right on. Fantastic! Not to mention, ladies - the mostly all male cast is certainly nice to look at while you enjoy the movie! Ha ha ha!

title: Great movie. Doesn't feel like 2 1/2 hrs at all. I wanted more.
review: Everybody cries about the ending. Honestly I believe everyone got what they deserved to. Even the so-called good guys. They had a choice and they made a bad one. The ending was perfect. It brought complete conclusion to everything. Mark and Alec played wonderful off of each other. And the dialogue with everyone was just brilliant. If this movie is not nominated for best picture I would be shocked. Leo is starting to more and more show himself as an adult actor and doing some exploration with characters. I happened to see a preview for The Blood Diamond which looks good as well. This movie was very well done. I praise them all. DiCaprio, Nicholson, Walhberg, Baldwin, Sheen, Damon and Farminga. It was perfect.

title: Who was Mark Wahlberg's character really?
review: In the end, when Mark Wahlberg's character (Dignam) shot Damon's character (Sullivan), did that prove that Wahlberg was also a mole just covering his tracks, or was it revenge for Damon being a cop killer? If Wahlberg was just getting revenge on Damon, the girlfriend must have given Walhberg the yellow envelope that Leo gave her. But if Walhberg was a good guy, wouldn't he just hand it over to the police? Why would he go and kill Damon and not let the truth out? If Walhberg was also a mole, he had to kill Damon to cover his tracks. I think that it makes more sense that he was a mole... or a rat, as the film cleverly portrays with the big rat crawling on the porch. They are pretty crafty in Hollywood.

title: One of the best Scorsese ever did
review:
This a great remake. Just like the Magificent Seven was a great remake of the Seven Samurai. This was a great remake of Infernal Affairs. I mean that in the most positive way.

The Departed does a great job of taking an Asian movie and transforming it into something as American as apple pie. Scorsese creates great distinctly American characters. Damon, Nicholson, and Wahlberg are outstanding.

I just saw Infernal affairs about a month before The Departed and I I appreciate them both more. One movie doesn't spoil the other, they explore the plot in different ways.

I highly recommend both movies.

title: Mega Cast worth the wait
review: This movie rocks. The story and cast are really well done. Not rushing the plot was great. The length of the movie is necessary to get the job done and it is worth it. It has been to long since Martin Sheen has been on the big screen and he makes a nice re-intro with this movie. As alway, Damon, DiCaprio, and Wahlberg are so worth watching. Why has Damon not gotten his Oscar(for acting) yet? The man can go anywhere with a character and this is not let down. DiCaprio is in the same league. The man can go make a character all his own. This movie definitely worth a peek. The only reason I did not mention Nicholson is because well.............he is Jack and that says it all.

title: Fresh & Exhilarating Crime Thriller
review:
With "The Departed" Martin Scorsese remakes a Hong Kong film called internal affairs.

Taking Place in Boston, young Undercover Cop Billy Costigan is assigned the job of infiltrating the Irish mob ran by a violent crime boss named Costello. Simultaneously, Costello has a criminal mole of his own working in the Police Department. Eventually both the mob and Police realize there is a mole in their operations causing the ensuing action and excitement, when they try and smoke each other out.

Scorsese knows how to do crime movies with such greats as Casino, Goodfellas and Taxi Driver under his belt. He matches and maybe even surpasses those films with the Departed.

I'm neither a Matt Damon or Leonardo DiCaprio fan. In Fact I always saw them as pretty boy actors who are mainly used to attract a female audience. In Departed both attempt to step up to the plate and try erase those past impressions. DiCaprio does a decent job even though his accent was questionable, and Damon is fully believable in his role. They were backed by a great cast including Martin Sheen, Alec Baldwin, Ray Winstone, Mark Wahlburg, Vera Fermiga & Anthony Anderson.

The one actor who I think did poorly was Jack Nicholson. He overacted and really hammed it up by acting plain retarded at some points. Some of his gestures and and facial expressions were ridiculous and silly.

Writer William Monahan rewrote the script without viewing the original, allowing him more freedom. He does a great job translating this oft told story into something fresh that unfolds in an exhilarating way.

Scorsese's directing was also quite impressive. He obviously didn't feel the need to rush things and allows the film to move along at an even pace without getting boring. Many directors would have made the mistake of shortening the script, thinking they would get a tighter movie.

As I said the plot itself is pretty straightforward, but the ensuing results are anything but expected. This isn't a conventional crime thriller so things happen that you would never expect. The story and characters are exciting, and this movie packs a lot in what seems like a short amount of time.

Nothing is excessive and everything is intense, leaving you with a true crime masterpiece.

I give it a nine & not a ten only because of Nicholson. His hamming it up was ridiculous at points . Besides that this was a great movie, probably the best I've seen in years.

title: Good, but very violent and bloody... and long
review:
Amazing cast. The acting was great. I thought the movie was too long. Almost 3 hours... ( well that includes previews, so not quite that long) I don't usually go to see "gangster, mafia type" movies, because of the violence, but the reviews were so good, and I like movies with lots of twists. Heavy swearing and tons of bloody stuff with some real gore. I loved Leonardo DiCaprio in this, he was excellent. The "girlfriend" situation could of been so much more, and I was disappointed the way that turned out.

Can't say much else without giving things away, and I don't want to to do that. I will say, it wasn't the ending the I guessed.

title: Not as good as Hong Kong blockbuster "Mou gaan dou"
review:
I would not say too much on the performance of each characters because they did a good and honorable job. Especially Jack, he is back on the stage now, and I am watching him. But allow me to say that, this one is really not as good as the hong kong original drama "Mou gaan dou"! The director, to be praised that he himself had understood the theme that "Mou gaan dou" created and he really did researched a lot about that. But, if the 80% of the scene is a completely copy from the original, it won't be a success. Despite a lot from the social, cultural difference, the connection between people will also be a great issue taken consideration of the gap midst eastern and western country.

For instance, when you translate a Chinese literature into English, you can not just refer to the meaning of each individual word; you ought to fully understand the whole meaning of the article as well as those underlying meanings that the author tend to being it to you.

I am a Chinese by the way, and I can read most of the information that the director wants to express dramatically to us. On the other hand, I stay aboard for a long time I can also comprehend all the meanings inside this English movie. But, if you put them together, as me, I found that the director was trying to adhibit his understanding from the original film piece by piece in order to recreate some new western taste "commercial advertise".

To be honest, if you considered this new cake as a stand alone, original , classical, thriller; it is fantastic. But, in my situation, I can only give it 7 out of 10 points. Just enjoy the show!

title: Living up to its expectations
review: Before seeing a movie that has been hyped with such A list actors, one is hesitant on how well they will perform with each other. The Departed's cast blew me out of my seat. Nicholson, Damon, and Dicaprio each brought their own unique attributes to the characters they were casted for. The roles were both strong individually yet were given the opportunity to play off of each other. I can honestly say that this was one of the best movies I have seen in a while. The Departed not only keeps you on your seat but also intrigues you with a great story line. I would recommend seeing this movie in a heartbeat. This should definitely be considered for movie of the year!

title: the movie is good, its worth your time and money, but..........
review: I haven't seen any good crime/drama movie for the last couple of month (except Miami vice). but i think this movie is really worth your time and money, i didn't expect that martin Scorsese make a good remake movie, because usually (not all) remakes are are done it turn out bad, but i was wrong, even though not 100% exactly the same from the original movie "Infernal Affair". the departed took all the infernal affair trilogy and make it into one movie well of course it's long, overall 21/2 hours. I only gave this movie 8 because i think there are couple things that are lacks, which is the role choice of each person, Except JAck Nicholson (wow he is just amazing) i think The antagonist character are way much better than the original "infernal Affair Trilogy", because Jack Nicholson looks just like a real mafia/gangster, Eric Tsang i think his face are just too stupid he doesn't have mafia/gangster face. as for the two main character, i think it will be much better if Leonardo and mat Damon switched position. the real mafia rat (andy lau), are more mature, more experience and has meaner face, i think Leonardo is the fittest choice for this character, as for police rat (Tony leung) he looks more younger and less experience type of person, so i think Matt Damon are more fit to be the good guys, and part of if because i think Matt Damon looks dumb too hahah. and the last but not the least, mark whalberg character, i don't think i could find his character in the "infernal affair trilogy", is he playing Leon Lai's Character in Infernal Affair 3 ???? i don't know, ill see it again later, but overall one more time, this movie is good worth your time and money, you guys should watch it.

title: You would not want to be a cop in Boston!
review:
This is a good movie from Martin Scorcese, about two Boston cops: Billy Costigan (Leonardo De Caprio) and Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon) who are involved with gangster Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson).

Billy Costigan is the 'good guy' cop who is sent undercover to bring Costello down, meanwhile Costello has an ace up his sleeve in Colin Sullivan, a man who has just left Police College and is rising high in the Boston Police Department within a short time. When Costello discovers he may have a 'rat' in the house he charges Sullivan with finding out the identity of the undercover cop thus placing Costigan in a very dangerous game of Cloak And Dagger.

De Caprio is excellent in this film and Matt Damon shows us that as well as The Talented Mr Ripley, he can deliver a desperate bad guy when he tries. Jack Nicholson is his usual brilliant self, his Frank Costello reminded me of a cross between Jack Torrance and Darryl Van Horn. Kudos all around for the acting stakes.

Special mention to Mark Wahlberg as a foul mouthed hard as nails detective, he really convinces as a hard bitten detective and he has good scenes with Alec Baldwin who is also very good in a small role.

Oh and i lost count for the amount of people getting their heads blown off here, but take it from me if you enjoy fast paced violent thrillers you will lap this up.

Seven Out Of Ten.

title: Scorsese Back in Top Form with a Stunning Cast for an Unbelievably Taut Thriller
review:
Filmmaker extraordinaire Martin Scorsese finally brings back the dazzling intensity of his earlier films such as "Taxi Driver" and "Goodfellas" with his latest offering, a driving Americanized update of the 2002 Hong Kong thriller, "Infernal Affairs". Adapted with intelligence by screenwriter William Monahan, the now Boston-based story focuses in parallel fashion on two young police detectives who are leading deceptive existences, one is sharing the department's goings-on with local mob boss Frank Costello, while the other is undercover inside Costello's organization and secretly informing the police of their plans. The informant is Colin Sullivan, who impresses his supervisors with his savvy and unfettered ambition. The other detective is coiled-to-the bone Billy Costigan recruited by Captain Queenan and his hot-headed assistant, Sgt. Dignam, to infiltrate Costello's gang.

Both detectives are loners in one way or the other because they are moles always looking over their shoulder lest they get caught and killed. The movie dexterously goes back and forth between the characters with the linchpins being not only Costello but also a department psychiatrist named Madolyn. She becomes Sullivan's girlfriend and also Costigan's doctor. As you can guess, the destinies of Costigan and Sullivan intertwine like a tightening vise but not without several interrelated story lines battling for our attention. One of the key reasons that this approach works so effectively is the kinetic, time-jumping editing by longtime Scorsese collaborator Thelma Schoonmaker, infusing Scorsese's masterful direction and the adept unraveling-by-necessity character development.

A stellar cast is in peak form here starting with Leonardo DiCaprio's riveting turn as Costigan. Under Scorsese's tutelage for the third time, he has finally matured into a role that capitalizes on his visceral intensity and delivers easily the best work I have seen him do. If Matt Damon's solid work is slightly less electrifying (with a vocal resemblance to the southie he played in "Good Will Hunting"), it's primarily because the character is designed to be unapologetically covert and a braggadocio to boot. Of course, Jack Nicholson is getting the lion's share of the media attention because he is back in a showy role as Costello. Whether making subtly threatening non-sequiturs to the hapless in his neighborhood or sharing Costello's path to success with his young cohorts, Nicholson blazes without resorting to the scenery chewing we have seen in past roles.

As Madolyn, indie darling Vera Farmiga brings an unexpectedly idiosyncratic quality to what could have been the standard girl-support stereotype, bringing not only vulnerability but a guarded sense of adventurousness to her character. In supporting roles, Martin Sheen is solid as Queenan, but it's the rapid-fire profanity spewing out of Marc Wahlberg as Dignam that remains more memorable. Ray Winstone brings his trademark menace to Costello's amusingly named henchman, Mr. French, and Alec Baldwin shines in the smallish role of department head Ellerby. It should come as no surprise that there are moments of shocking violence as the movie culminates into a series of scenes quite graphic in nature yet thematically resonant to the core story. Scorsese has thankfully let go of the wearying pretensions of his last two movies, "The Aviator" and "Gangs of New York", to produce an incredibly taut, character-driven police thriller. It's aces for this kind of work.

title: Definitely worth the ticket price
review: "The departed" was the best movie I've seen in months, and that means something coming from a guy who milks netflix for all it's worth. While some viewers may be put off by the violence that is prevalent throughout the movie the true film connoisseur sees that the vulgarity is artful and masterful. Matt Damon performs in what may be his finest role to date and there were stellar performances by Wahlberg, Nicholson, and even, though I'm loathe to say it, Leonardo Dicaprio. What really makes this movie work is the comedic dialogue juxtaposed against what is a truly gritty and harsh story. I can't reveal more than that without spoiling part of the story but trust me when I say that you'll be chuckling at some of the lines if you've got a funny bone in your body. In conclusion, I recommend this film to anyone who enjoys Scorcese, organized crime, drama, action, or Boston. Honestly if none of those things interest you I'd steer clear of this one, but in reality I doubt if your reading this that that caveat applies.

title: A Must See for Scorsese Fans
review: This movie kept me on the edge of my seat for the entire 2.5 hours with the intense plot and outstanding cast of actors. As much as I expect stellar performances from Jack Nicholson, Leo DiCaprio, and others on this cast, I have to say that I did not expect the brilliant performance I saw from Matt Damon in The Departed. I was totally mesmerized by Matt's character from start to finish. He nailed this character to the very core. We didn't see enough of Mark Wahlberg but what we did see was great, of course. And I have to mention Martin Sheen. He had a significant role and did a great job! This movie was so intense that you wouldn't want to leave to take a bathroom break. The Departed is different from the other Mafia style movies from Scorsese but just as good. The Departed is definitely one of Martin Scorsese's best films to date.

title: goofs
review: Overall it was a very well made film, but for being done by an anal-retentive director, I would have thought the editing would be better. It is not that I didn't enjoy it, it is that with the story line so 'tight', you try to pick up on everything. Maybe it is because I also act that I notice these things. Two big scenes that stand out in my mind were the picture of Madolyn on a bike as a child and then Colin's gun being left in the elevator. In one scene, Madolyn pulls th picture out of the box at Colin's apartment and he takes the box away to put it in the bedroom with the picture back in it. Nice big close up of the pic in the scene. About 15 minutes later, Billy comes to her apartment and she is still packing, OK not totally moved out, but there is the same picture and Billy actually hangs it on the wall! Wow, it was so obviously done wrong. I thought maybe she brought the box back, but earlier she told Billy that she only had 3 weeks left on the lease. Nobody would float the box back and forth between apartments if you are definitely moving into one. The other scene was at the end when Billy had Colin on the roof, took his gun, and shoved it down the back of his pants (like all good cops do).
