I would highly recommend that everyone goes to see it... the cast and plot line are truly fantastic, The all star cast works a treat, the humour is second to none and the eye candy is not half bad either with Matt Damon and Leonardo DiCaprio. Nicholson plays a brilliant role as always and his witty lines will have you doubled over with laughter!!

Role on the day The Departed is released on DVD! (ps - does anyone know the release date for the DVD??) The best film I have ever seen... well maybe apart from Forest Gump!!!

title: Unrelenting!
review:
I'm aware of the fact that the concept and basic storyline for Martin Scorcese's Departed actually came from a Hong Kong/Chinese crime drama epic from a few years back. I cannot attest to what the original was,but after seeing this film,I'd be curious to see it.

This movie is arguably one of--if not THE strongest film out this fall. I'm always a little reluctant to go crazy lauding directors like Scorcese,Coppola,Spielberg and so forth because they are iconic and seem to have praise larded on them by the truckloads,but suffice it to say that there's a reason Mr.Scorcese gets the kind of laudation he gets,and this movie is one example of why.

Set in working class Boston,this film tracks the lives of two principal characters:Colin"Sully"Sullivan(Matt Damon,who's chiseled,straight,expressionless face and easy demeanor is perfect here),a model citizen from the neighborhoods who excels his way from academy into heading his own vice unit in record time,and William "Billy"Costigan(Leonardo DiCaprio,who seems to work well off Scorcese's calls,as per The Aviator from a few years before), another working class Irish Bostonian whose road to the Boston PD is much rougher and is recruited to do undercover work. Early on,you know who's who here:Sullivan is in the deep pockets of simmering,sleazy mob boss Frank Costello(Jack Nicholson,whose only flaw in this film was his wavering Boston accent)and is a link to the law enforcers who are trying to tag him,while Costigan steadily builds his links and confidence into Mr.Costello's outfit. All the while,both Sully and Billy build relationships with the police psychologist(Vera Farmiga,whom I also enjoyed in 2002's Dummy),and meanwhile work around each other. As both sides start to sense that there is a rat in their ranks,the two find themselves pushing harder to simultaneously do their jobs,cover their tracks and root the other out. The race is on,so to speak.

With quality support from Mark Wahlberg(as an incorruptible and temperamental bureau sub-chief),Martin Sheen(as Wahlberg's boss,a patient precinct veteran),Anthony Anderson(as the honest cop who works for Damon's corrupt chief),Ray Winstone(as Nicholson's brutal top henchman)and Alec Baldwin(as the charismatic paper-pusher whose investigative unit backs Damon's squad),this movie is a strong shock to the system,with violence often and yet used as a sort of gut-check to the viewer. In a war between cops and gangland criminals,the results are unrelenting and brutal,and seldom romantic.

The pacing of this film takes on more of a thriller mode towards the end,and there are a few twists thrown in to make the ending not as "neat" as some might suspect it's heading towards. The screenplay by William Monahan and Siu Fui Mak(adapting from the original)is a seamless fit to Scocese's vision. I don't like throwing phrases like "must see" or "instant classic",so instead I'll say this about it:if you're serious about your movies,catch this film any way you can.

title: Proud to have seen it in theaters
review:
Jack Nicholson. Leonardo DiCaprio. Matt Damon. Mark Wahlberg. Martin Sheen. These are just a few of the massive, all-star, ensemble cast in this film. And with Martin Scorsese behind the wheel, this movie, for the most part, is flawless. Now for those of you not familiar with Scorsese's work, I suggest you try either Goodfellas (1990), or his earlier classic, Mean Streets (1973). Many will try to argue that Goodfellas is Scorsese's undisputed best picture, but with the release of this film, I beg to differ. I won't go into the plot much, so as to keep its twists and turns secret, but I will say this; never in my life have I seen a film quite like this. This is, by far, the best movie to be released this year. Also, in my own opinion, it is the best crime/action film to be released in my lifetime.

For starters, the acting in this movie is beyond phenomenal. If analyzed, one can conclude that DiCaprio, playing Billy Costigan, is our main character and protagonist. Though everyone in the film ends up unintentionally cowering in the shadow and talent of Mr. Jack Nicholson, as Frank Costello, the all-knowing, hard-hitting mob boss. So, this film is obviously wonderful for fans of Nicholson, but don't get me wrong, everyone has their own moments. Matt Damon, as Colin Sullivan, plays our anti-hero to DiCaprio, and let me tell you, when those two are put against each other, watch out! I have never seen such brilliant acting from either of those two men.

The overall plot of the movie concerns DiCaprio, a failed Boston policeman, becoming an inside man, infiltrating Nicholson's Irish mafia world of crime. What DiCaprio doesn't know is that Matt Damon is a mobster, sent by Nicholson to infiltrate the Boston Police Department. When the two men discover that there is a mole on either side, bloodshed and violence ensue. They set out to find who is infiltrating their own side, while they themselves must be moles within their enemy's world. The plot becomes thick, and sub-plots build, but it remains friendly, and not overly intelligent to the audience. So it doesn't leave us scratching our heads at the end of the film, but it rather leaves our jaws dropped to the floor.

I give this film a perfect rating of 10 out of 10. The directing is stunning, I truly think it is Scorsese's best film to date. The writing is wonderful. Though the movie is partly based upon a Hong-Kong action film, and some true happenings in Boston concerning the Irish mafia, the dialog and structure of the plot is very well written. The editing is beautiful. Most people never take editing into consideration, but it is an extremely important part of the pacing and flow of the movie. It also plays a large role in the film's style. And as I said earlier, the acting is mind blowing. Everyone in the movie was at the top of their game. But perhaps the main reason I enjoyed this film so much was it's "stick-it-to-the-man" attitude. It was a slap in the face to Hollywood. Yes, this movie was a blockbuster. Yes, the actors are all out of Hollywood. But for someone to suggest that this film does not prove the existence of true art in Hollywood, well they're just lying to themselves. This is a return to the Hollywood we always think of in our dreams. Back to the days of Scarface (1983), The Godfather (1972), and Chinatown (1974). This film is a shining star in the argument "Does art still exist in Hollywood?". I can proudly say now "Yes it does".

title: wow
review: When i saw the commercial for this movie i wasn't sure if i wanted to see it. Then when i did i was like blown away, it was awesome. I think that it was definitely Leonardo's best movie he's ever made, and Jack was he still his strange old self. I thought that it was an excellent cast, and everyone played the part just like was to be expected of them. It was a different role for Matt Damon, but he did a good job. The movie kept you on your feet the whole time, you never knew what was about to happen. The fight scenes were excellent and the action was great. This movie is full of twist and turns, surprising you again and again even when you thought it couldn't happen. Most of the ending is what got me, i never expected that to happen, i was like what??? I was so surprised. Overall it's a great movie, and i recommend seeing it.

title: The Departed = Superficial Affairs
review:
Consider the following facts:

endless f-words (seemingly it is the way to AMERICANIZE a film, fine)

tasteless cranberry juice joke (we know it's a joke, but it's shallow one)

shameless Jack's black dick (no class at all)

needless in-bed skin exposure (weird move in a weird setting)

pointless yellow envelop (dont know what its for?)

pathetically idealess rat-running ending! (lol, everybody knows how a rat should look like, thank you very much for the brilliant reminding)

Isn't this a superficial piece of work, degrading the original decent plot into such a trash-assembly?

8.5/10? - totally disappointed at American audience. absolutely NO for academy award - still have hope for the rest of the Americans.

8.5 for IA, 5 for SA.

title: Internal Affairs?... no no, it's Martin Scorsese's The Departed
review:
I just came back from the cinema, and I can really say that I've seen one of the best and finest gangster/mafia movie of all times. After a small hiatus with the Aviator, Martin Scorsese is back in the genre and surely back in winning ways (has it ever been otherwise?).

The movie is inspired/based on its Asian counter-part Internal Affairs, but having seen both, I honestly think that Scorsese brilliantly makes the Departed look like an original and genuine chef-d'oeuvre, one he only has the secret.

The story in itself is fantastic; right from the beginning and the first lines you know you're in for a classic and the long introduction sets the tone nicely for the rest of the movie. Not a single second will make you regret entering the theatre, the action and the crescendo built up nicely and keeps you entertained until the very last shot. The direction is accurate and precise, the music pin-points key elements in the movie and the scenery is perfect for this film.

The acting is brilliant, the main actors play superbly well and the supporting cast provides much more than just a support; they are an integral part of the film's success.

I highly recommend The Departed. I hope the movie will be nominated for the Oscars, it'll be hugely deserved for Scorsese and all his actors and crew.

title: I had a blast watching this flick
review: Excellent performances by Caprio and Damon. Boy, Damon is getting better with each new one. Caprio as always looks his cool self. And of course, Jack Nicholas' controlled performance does weigh down on all else. The plot is somewhat stale but is spiced up with suspenses at each corner.And each choice Damon has to make ... phew. While watching the movie, not for a single minute are you bored. As the story progresses through its nooks and corners (very tight ones), you start feeling the haze. And just when you relax ... bam!!! . Gets you right in the face. The end does steal your breath away. Definitely worth another watch anytime. Good work, highly enjoyable!!

title: Great actors - Great premise - Mediocre film
review:
This film is getting great reviews, not because it is a great film, but because of the big names (Scorsese, DiCaprio, Nicholson, Damon, etc). Don't get me wrong, the actors did a fantastic job, especially DiCaprio. However, the movie just falls flat in so many areas.

  • Nicholson has so many negative attributes, they seem forced down our throats. - The extreme violence and language is so contrived. Scarface was violent too but it wasn't distracting. - The "love interest" was just forgotten about. Where is the multidimensional plot? - The premise (rat vs. rat) gets heated up then goes nowhere. - Finally, the ending. This is the worse ending I've seen in years.


It is worth seeing, but don't expect the whole package like we saw in Goodfellas, The Godfather, or even Carlito's Way.

title: Jack is Back
review:
Heeeee'sss Backkkkkkkkkkkkkk.

This movie is great. I went expecting to see a great film and i was not disappointed, this movie lived up to my expectation and i greatly enjoyed.

It is not better than GODFATHER however this is the best movie i have seen for a long time, its for sure the best movie to date this year.

Jack Nicolson is back with a bang he was brilliant in his role as Costello and the character will be remembered as his many characters over the years will be remembered.

Jack is Back

title: THE best film I've EVER seen
review: I'd never even heard of this film before I saw it in the papers this morning and decided to give it a shot...this was no bad move, I guarantee you. This is without a doubt the best, most entertaining, most twisted and most engaging movie since Snatch (well...that's my theory). It is so incredibly detailed that you have to follow the plot every single nanosecond, but at the end you won't be confused or disillusioned in any way. My vocabulary cannot cope with the pure brilliance of this movie. I could try to explain it, but I'd just stand there wide-eyed and stutter, and you'd all think I'm on drugs. One of the great things about the film is that there are loads of 'sub-stories', and you can ponder on these stories while you're connecting the dots of the main plot. Then there is, of course, the spectacular cast, kicking off with one of my personal favourites, the demonic Jack Nicholson. He did a brilliant job here, as always playing the bad guy, the sick, twisted mastermind. I never seem to get tired of this guy, and with this entry, I doubt I ever will get tired of him. I always thought of Leo DiCaprio as a bit of a softie, even after seeing Gangs of NY. I just couldn't help it, knowing he played in R&J and Titanic. After The Departed, I completely changed my mind about him. Excellent actor...nothing else needs to be said. I was quite surprised seeing some of the other characters who appeared along the way, amongst these were Mark Wahlberg and Alec Baldwin. I didn't see them on the cast list, so I was naturally pleased to see some more talents. Wahlberg and Baldwin did very well here and seriously suited their given roles as the heads of the Boston State Police Department. All in all, this utterly incre-specta-brilliant movie deserves a 20 out of 10 rating just for being the best movie I have ever seen. Mind-boggling plot, jaw-dropping cast and a stunning finale makes it an outstanding achievement. Thank you Scorsese...thank you very much.

title: Letdown
review:
Even in my wildest nightmares i did not expect Scorsese to remake a movie. And as remakes usually go, The Departed does not match up to Infernal Affairs. The only good thing about The Departed is the screenplay, apart from brilliant performances from Leo DiCaprio and Jack Nicholson. I thought Infernal Affairs was much more slicker and the pace of the movie is faster. Also the performances by Tony Leung and Andy Lau were scintillating. Although Leo DiCaprio and Matt Damon gave their best performances to date, The Departed is still a disappointment especially because of the dull pace of the movie.

I probably would have liked The Departed if i had seen it first. But after watching Infernal Affairs it is a sad letdown. Also the background score for Infernal Affairs was better and it was better made.

title: The best film of the 21st Century - No Spoilers
review:
There is not a film in the 21st Century than I will more and more, and again and again than The Departed. By far and away the best film that Scorcese has directed since the heyday of Goodfellas, which I always felt he could not better, but he has!

The acting is spot on, even the performance by Alec Baldwin is great, but when you get Martin Sheen and Jack Nicholson in the same movie, it is going to be something very very special.

The soundtrack is superb and really enlightened me again at how well the US directors manage to mix the vibrant UK sounds of the 80's rock with the scenery and settings of a war torn, kind of, Boston.

Do not underestimate the hype of this film it will and has to win Oscars. Praise for Scorcese to bring out the film in Oscar season as he is normally reluctant to do this, this is going to win, and win big.

Best Actor: Nominations for Jack Nicholson and Leonardo Di Caprio. Best Supporting Actor: Nominations for Jack Nicholson and Martin Sheen Best Screenplay Best Director: For Martin Scorcese has to win!! Best Score

All in all the best film of the 21st century.

As an aside: If Di Caprio had to turn down the De Niro film (the good Shepherd) to shoot this - how comes Matt Damon managed to fit it in.... schedules I guess....

Go and see this film!!

title: Why can't people appreciate the movie for what it is?
review: I've been reading a lot about The Departed and how it compares with Infernal Affairs,the original screenplay. I have seen Infernal Affairs I but not the other 2,and I saw The Departed this past weekend. People need to understand that although the idea for The Departed was taken from Infernal Affairs, it's a movie all it's own. I can understand fans of the original not liking The Departed AS MUCH, but too many people are saying The Departed is a bad movie,which I find absurd. The movie was made to fit our culture, Americanized if you will, and did a damn good job at doing so. I know people are going to tear me apart because I'm an American male along with being a huge Scores fan,but I personally liked The Departed better(and yes I saw Infernal Affairs before The Departed). It hard to use the word "better" when talking about the remake/remodeling of a movie but I''ll dare say it. The way Monacan took the original script and tuned it to our culture and way of life was brilliant, along with Scorsese's direction and music selection. I wrote this in response to original fans,many Asian,telling me that The Departed was garbage and couldn't compare to Infernal Affairs. Maybe they don't like it as much as the original,but there's no denying that this film is one of the most powerful and moving films to come out in a long time. A lot of people are taking credit away from Monacan and Scores because it's a "remake" but they did a lot more than remake and Americanize this movie,they immortalized it and turned it into an instant classic. They didn't simply take the screenplay and script from Infernal Affairs,they took the idea and changed,expanded and tuned it into a brilliant film OF IT'S OWN...You can't take anything away from The Departed because of Infernal Affairs, so stop being ignorant because you prefer Infernal Affairs and give credit where credit is due.

title: one of the best films i have seen in a very long time
review: What can I say, this movie has me smitten. The Departed contains action, suspense, drama, and at the same time retains a strong comedic overtone. Great acting all around. Nicholson finally plays someone other than Jack Nicholson in a movie and does a fantastic job. This is the first movie I've ever like DeCaprio in, although I hear he was good in Catch Me If You Can. Just look at the cast and you know you're in for a quality movie. Mark Wahlberg gives a very strong performance and Alec Baldwin is absolutely hilarious. The story is great, the acting is great, and I for one liked the ending. Do yourself a favor and be sure to catch The Departed.

title: Martin Scorsese over rated. obvious. Francis for Coppola's father once told him.
review: If your going to copy then copy from the best. I'm sure all you film buffs could list the films this is copied from. I've seen it all before. Oooh to opposing forces yet one and the same?? who is good who is bad ooh it's such a moral dilemma. I suppose when everyone says that you are genius you start to believe it and don't try so hard. They are all talking about Oscars and stuff and how it's about time. I suppose it might be one of those Oscars folks get for just staying alive long enough. I'd tell them to stick their Oscar where the sun don's shine. laters Not bad but not that great. Crank was far superior. They want more lines so like all the other wafflers her goes. Waffle Waffle

title: least favourite Scorcese film, what happened??
review:
I was really disappointed with this movie. There were so many holes in the plot, and it was such an obvious story as well with so many unbelievable scenarios.

DiCaprio was overacting the whole way through the movie, no light and shade in his performance. His acting was just full on over the top, the whole way through. I think he was overcompensating for the fact that he is a pretty boy and small framed. Wrong choice for that part.

Jack Nicholson was great as usual.

The direction was great despite its lack of story, but someone really fell short of scrutinizing the storyline and scripting. Scorcese should have gotton the writers of the Sopranos to write it for him. Trying to suspend disbelief was impossible. The added love story of a shrink falling for her bad boy patient was just too predictable as well. I actually became bored during this movie and unfortunately regretted paying for it.

Maybe thats why Scorcese was promoting this movie personally, because it needed all the help it could get. I'm sure people will go to see it just because of its director, but I will be wary of attending another of his movies unless I see many reviews prior. I love Scorcese films, but I have to say "What happened??"

title: Annoying gaffe in a great movie
review:
The Chinese gang who turn up to buy the hi-tech computer chips from Frank (Nicholson) speak Cantonese. Yet they are supposed to be a conduit for Beijing government. They should really have been speaking Mandarin, the language of Beijing and more than 50% of Chinese people.

Do audiences feel that only Cantonese (which has many more sounds that are "strange" from an English point of view than Mandarin) counts as "really Chinese"? The original version of this movie was set in Hong Kong and would have been in Cantonese. But it's unlikely when reset in Boston. There are now hundreds of thousands of Mandarin speakers around the world, some no doubt earning an honest living as gangsters.

Otherwise I agree with the raves. Some of the famous stars outdo themselves.

title: Pretty dumb
review: Its pretty dumb but it held my interest. It has so many dumb things about it I am too lazy to write them. It held my interest, but its still pretty dumb. Sure it is smart in one way, it has big actors and macho scenes that get males to jerk off to, but man, its not too smart. Oh wait, I need ten lines...how convenient for Marky Mark to disappear for awhile, and Damon to let down his guard...Jack Nicholson's character at 70 would really be out on street deals....the shrink would just happen to intimately know both leads...Dicaprio's character is moved to such a trusted position in seconds...as well as Damon's... a scumbag like Costello could talk to someones's daughter and sister like that, and still have the brother and father's loyalty...the cell phones, come on, "hey dad...I'm talking in front of my comrads to you..."...like a rookie cop could order officers around when a captain's welfare is at stake. I could go on. Just the top of my head. I know its just a movie, but jeez I was disappointed.

title: Almost flawless
review:
The Departed is truly a film that could be called flawless. The story is engaging, the character development is superb, the acting is Academy Award worthy, and production-wise, the film is polished to a mirror shine. There is only one thing I can find to hold against it: there is nothing new or original in the film. You'll find things you've seen in other movies brought to perfection in this one, but the only aspect in which it could be called groundbreaking is the amount of blood droplets you'll see suspended in air.

The story is a complex tale of betrayal in the crime and law enforcement scene of modern-day Boston. It is told very effectively, never losing the viewer in all of its numerous plot turns and revelations. In true Scorcese style, it is also bluntly violent, but every death on screen is strongly tied to a particular plot aspect or intended audience reaction, and never seems gratuitous. Even the romance subplot does not seem forced, as is the case with many Hollywood productions of this type, and is integral to the picture as a whole. As with many action movies, there is plenty of quality comic relief in the form of witty remarks, and even those remarks never seem forced.

Not surprisingly, given the extensively star-studded cast, the acting is top-notch, perhaps at least in part due to material the actors had to work with. What was surprising though, was that you'll never find a particular actor stealing the scene. Scorcese has managed to bring out the best in every person on screen, and that best was being true to their character, making the audience forget that these people are actors despite their recognisability.

As I mentioned, however, there is little about the film that will leave a lasting impression on the viewer. It is a great ride while you're in the theatre, but upon leaving, you'll find very few details that are truly memorable, or plot points that warrant further pondering. You'll know you just saw a great movie, but it just failed to extend beyond that screen. Perhaps the only exception to this is the visual feel of the movie. The sepia-like tones that help emphasise just the right aspects of the movie's action are what really make the film feel unique, and are a prime example of cinematography being used to enhance the story, rather than detract from it. One can only wish that more movies were as flawlessly executed as this one.

title: When American remakes of Asian cinema go RIGHT for a change.
review: It's not pretty, it's not cheery, but it's gritty, intense, and provocative. It's more than just another crime film. It's tightly wound characters fit perfectly into the tightly wound story about a Massachusetts State Trooper(or a statey if you will) with family ties to crime gone undercover gangster and a clean-cut gangster who has excelled in infiltrating the state police as a mole. As they both become aware of each other, they start a race for control of a situation that tests their wits, endurance, and their very souls. I was very pleased with Scorese's adaptation of Mou Gaan Dou (US: Infernal Affairs) overall. William Monahan did a fantastic job, not only in rewriting the story but in fully revising the tone of things to localize the story in Boston. The original played heavily on the relationship of Chinese organized crime and the police. That dynamic would have been largely lost in a literal translation of Infernal Affairs. Instead, Boston native Monahan adeptly instilled the essence of various elements of Massachusetts into the script. This is especially exciting for those of us who are from Massachusetts, but for everyone else it should create a very stable and detailed sense of setting. Scorsese did well to cast several Massachusetts-based actors as well. Not just because of their connection to the area though, don't be confused about the performance of Matt Damon, and brothers Mark and Robert Wahlberg, because they're phenomenal. Several Asian films have been remade for America in recent years, and while they've kept the exciting stories, they've often eschewed the style and depth of the originals. By setting the film in a specific American locale and then embracing the setting and drawing from it for inspiration, Scorsese and Monahan have taken a great story and remade it into a truly worthy American remake. I'm more content to watch the Asian films that these remakes are created from for the most part, but when it's done this well I can't complain. Instead of one film with a fantastic concept, we have two. I can watch Infernal Affairs and The Departed and, despite their similarity, view both as fantastic, original works.

title: Departed is an absolute must...
review:
I can't say enough about this movie- Leonardo was PHENOMENAL! The acting is just perfect on all accounts. I love EVERYONE in this movie. How could you not like an all star cast like this???? The writing of the movie was fluent- the movie kept you the whole time. I walked out of the theater completely blown away. I am VERY picky about movies- not many would earn a perfect ten from me, and I am usually a comedy lover anyway; but this was really worth seeing. It definitely earns the "R" rating though. Martin Scorcese scares me, but he is REALLY good at what he does. He has his niche. If you've seen his movies in the past, then you have the idea.

Wow. Wow. just see it.

title: The Masterpiece of this decade
review:
Every decade since the 1970's, American cinema has been blessed with a distinct masterpiece from a master director. This director is of course Martin Scorsese and his films are "Taxi Driver", "Raging Bull", and "Goodfellas." Since the dawn of this new millennium, fans of the screen have awaited the Marty film that would define the decade and join these three masterpieces as the crown jewels of his career.

In 2002 "Gangs of New York" represented a director who tried to gain the wind back in his sails. The result was a satisfyingly uneven, but undeniably good film, headlined by great performances and a beautiful look. Two years later, he swung for the fence with "The Aviator" and it almost made it out of the park. This wonderfully entertaining film represented Marty's latest futile attempt to win the O. At the time, it seemed like a safe bet, but the Academy didn't agree. It wasn't in the league of "Raging Bull" or his other masterpieces, but it seemed that if he didn't get it for "The Aviator" he was going to have to wait for the lifetime achievement award.

It almost seems like the Academy had incredible foresight, for Martin Scorsese has done the impossible. He has added a forth film to his masterpiece collection, and that film is "The Departed." It is not only Martin's finest film in sixteen years; it's also the BEST American FILM OF THE DECADE! Like a genius politician Scorsese surrounds himself with the best. The cast doesn't have a weak spot with DiCaprio giving his finest performance to date , the writing is the finest ever for a Scorsese picture, and Schoomaker's editing continues to demonstrate her pure ecstatic control over the medium. Though, it is still Martin's show and after decades of producing the finest films in the world, he has still not lost his touch. Excitement was felt last year when Peter Jackson's "King Kong" represented the finest remake in the history of Hollywood, but less than a year later, Scorsese owns that title again. If it weren't for his other three films (which are amongst the greatest of all time) this would be Scorsese's masterpiece. But with time, this film will surly join their company.

title: Two men must find one another before both are killed.
review: This movie in my opinion is Martin Scorceses best work. It kicks ass. Nicholson my all time favorite actor is great, Matt Damon is great, Leonardo Di Caprio is great, and the rest of the cast is great. This movie should go down in history as one of the greats. If you want to see great drama,great action and great acting come see this movie. Some people have been saying that Jack Nicholson is no good in this movie but i say that he is fantastic. He is just playing the part and thats why the character is so weird and i think very creative. He is funny and evil and straight up awesome. I also liked Mark Wahlbergs performance in the movie he was overlooked i thought when this movie was reviewed.

title: Best modern gangster movie made thus far!
review: This movie was so incredible from the opening scene to the end credits. Jack Nicholson had some of the funniest scenes and he had some hilarious facial expressions. Leonardo DiCaprio (why does everybody hate his guts?) was top notch as well as Matt Damon. The Departed was extremely violent and extremely profane yet you hardly noticed either of these things because of how fast the pace of the movie was. The 150 minutes, in my opinion, went by extremely fast. I never once looked at my watch to see when the movie would end. It was lovely to see Scorsese back to his gangster movie making. Note: No gangster movie will ever be better than GoodFellas. However, The Departed came pretty darn close. I do not remember the last action movie where I laughed so much. I will not give anything away but there is a scene where Matt Damon is meeting Jack Nicholson in a theater and let's just say Damon almost had a heart attack. I found myself laughing for a couple of minutes after that scene. Absolutely wonderful film that is deserving of Best Actor (Nihcolson) and Best Director (Scorsese) at the next Academy Awards.

title: An instant classic.....
review: Martin Scorsese creates a masterpiece, his skills as a director continue to grow and mature. Amazing! I enjoyed all of it with the exception of the very last ten seconds before the credits roll. I won't kill it for you but I think you'll know what I mean. Unless you can't take this particular violent crime story genre, this should not be missed on the big screen. It's the best film that's been around in a long, long time. The high power cast is in top form and I think that you'll be hard pressed to remember any film where Matt Damon, Martin Sheen, Alec Baldwin have been better. Leo DiCaprio, who is already one of America's great actors, hit's a new level of excellence. I've been a huge fan since "This Boy's Life". Jack Nicholson...I'm at a loss for words, he's so good in this film. In thinking of his entire body of work, from "Easy Rider" through to "The Departed' he's like a fine wine, getting better and better as he ages, his range of successful roles is just astounding...."heeeer's Johnny...". I was hugely surprised by Mark Whalberg who, in my opinion, turns in the best performance of his career. I look forward to seeing more of him in the future. Anthony Anderson was a surprise addition, and he really contributes a lot in his supporting role. Super directing, stellar cast well utilized, decent storyline, excellent sound track, great editing and continuity.......this is the one to spend $8. on.

title: A great crime movie.
review:
The Spoilers herein will pretty much give away the entire movie. Most of it can be inferred from the previews, but I will indeed wreck the ending for you.

This is a movie that is very good, but is not one that I am not sure how well I liked it, which essentially means that its probably not one I would watch a second time.

On the plus side, its has great acting, dialog, and very memorable characters. Damon and DiCaprio are both put in a very strong performance. And Jack Nicholson is very entertaining in his role, as is Mark Whalberg. The plot is interesting too. You have a mole in the police department trying to identify the under cover agent in the crime lords gang, while the agent in the gang tries to find the mole.

But the story in and of its self is not that interesting to me, mostly because it feels like it does not really resolve its story line. By the end of the movie, all the principle characters end up dead, but there is not climactic gun fight. The undercover agent is very suddenly shot in the head, and then those who were in a position to expose the Mole are also shot dead. And then finally the Mole is in turn shot by one of the officers who quit the force when the Mole demanded access to the undercover agents in the wake of the death of the head of the under cover department. While the ending does fit the circumstances quite nicely, the is just not that satisfying and ending. Rather then resolving the character plot lines, everyone is just shot, and the truth is never really revealed. I would have preferred to see either the Mole or the Agent survive.

Its hard to have a worthwhile ending, I think, when both the hero and the villain of the story end up dead and no one around them ends up knowing exactly why. I don't mind that the Mole gets killed at the end, but the ending would have been so much better if there were some on screen element explaining exactly why the ex-cop who killed him did so. For all the audience knows, he was murdered in cold blood out of a grudge having nothing to do with the central conflict of the story.

END COMMUNICATION

title: Fantastic
review: I don't think I even have enough words to describe how good this movie was or how much I enjoyed it. Easily one of Scorsese's best films! I too haven't been a big Leo fan and don't get much of the hype, but he was #@$%^ brilliant in this movie. I was thinking with this pretty boy cast (Damon, Wahlberg, and DeCaprio) that this would be a movie full of fluff and not a lot of substance. Not so. If you loved Good Fellas, A Bronx Tale, The Godfather... you have to add this one on your list of movies to see. Everyone in the movie gives a fantastic performance. A great story line with enough twist and turns to keep you guessing. It is a bit lengthy, but totally worth every minute!

title: Whitey Bulger banned in Boston
review:
Well, no question in my mind now that I've seen the movie why it's called "The Departed." As a lifelong Bostonian, I put off seeing the movie because there's nothing like a poory done Boston accent to ruin an otherwise good experience for me, but with just a few exceptions, everyone pretty much got it right. I have to tell all the reviewers who show up on the IMDb main page, though, that there is a BIG differnce between the Bosotn Police Deparment and "the Stateies," and these were the Massachusetts State Troopers, presumably a cut or two above the BPD.

Jack Nicholson as Whitey Bulger was only missing his fondness for young boys to make a true picture. Here's a good link to read the true story: http://tinyurl.com/y5cm2m Some of the facts in the movie were changed a bit to make a better story.

title: Be original, Hollywood
review:
Can't believe this movie follows exactly the same plot as "Mou gaan dou I" which was filmed 4 yrs ago! Just wanna say if Hollywood wanna shoot a film based on an old story, at least they should add something new, not making a duplicate. I believe they are gonna release Departed II/III in the coming year, cuz II/III will explain what was happening before and after this one.

if someone wanna have a taste of the original ones, check this out:

http://imdb.com/title/tt0338564/

http://imdb.com/title/tt0369060/

http://imdb.com/title/tt0374339/

title: A Brawl of a Movie
review:
I will be brief and to the point. The Departed is a near perfect film. The story is engrossing. The acting is superb. And, the direction delivers a film that will stand up against the best of gangland cinema.

Jack Nicholson is a master of his craft. And no one plays the devil incarnate better that ol' Jack. His portrayal of the mob boss Frank Costello is a classic. It's a role where he can stretch his acting talents and play the bad guy we all love to hate.

Leonardo DiCaprio is his best role to date shines and shows us he is maturing into a great actor. Matt Damon does an efficient job in his role of inside man and keeps the film moving. Martin Sheen and Mark Wahlberg are excellent in supporting roles. And, I have to give Alec Baldwin an A+ for his supporting role as Ellerby. He hasn't shined like this since Glengarry Glen Ross.

Perfect at 2 1/2 hours - this is truly one of the best of 2006 and worth a trip to theater. Don't miss it.

title: Best film this year
review:
So you get one of the best directors in the world, a cast of outstanding talent, a brilliant script and you end up with the departed the best film of the year so far.

There is so much that is good about this film, it is exceptionally well told, keeping you hooked from the word go, the music is great the cinematography outstanding. You move from scene to scene in a state of anticipation and excitement, not quite knowing what is going to happen next.

The acting, well the Oscars need to extend the number of nominees in the categories of best actor and supporting actor because all involved in this picture deserve to be up for a gong. It is difficult to pull anyone out from the crowd so I wont because it will just read like a cast list. I do hope that the Acadamy recognises this film, they tend not to go for adult rated movies but this one deserves the lot.

My best bits; Di Caprio's face when Martin Sheen is thrown off the building, outstanding acting. Marky Mark interviewing Di Caprio, Jack throwing cocaine at a babe and telling her not to come up till she's numb and all the shooting. I think I'm gonna have to stop here or I will go on for days.

If you read this and think not another glowing review it can't be that good, well it is, you would be mad to miss this film.

title: Jack at his finest! Not a dull moment.
review: I was not really looking for this movie to be so good based on it's description. Great action, enthralling story line, GREAT acting, seamless direction. Hannibal the Cannibal, Tony Soprano, meets Jack Nicholson. This movie really has a deep dark comedy streak it, and it's not your typical dirty cop movie. Loaded with surprises, clever twists, and even a good drama thread. Great for guys and girls of all ages. (Except kids of course, they may not enjoy watching people get shot through the head, no cuts or scene changes.) I highly recommend, and I rarely recommend, as the movie industry has been slinging out garbage for a long time now. Nice and refreshing to see a quality flick hit the big screen.

title: can it get much better???
review: Alright, to start with I would have to say that going into this movie I had wondered if this was a little over hyped due to the director as well as production, but was I ever surprised. This movie is amazing in every category that matters, story, acting, direction, editing, musical...you name it this movie excels. With all this I would not doubt if this movie doesn't snag best picture, director and at least lead actor. Moving onto the movie...the moment story began I was hooked. Without giving away spoilers...the small doses humor throughout, great acting all-around (including Mark Walhberg surprising enough and worst I have to say being Martin Sheen), wonderful camera placement, and the last 15 minutes will leave you wondering whats happening next and when you leave you will realize you have just witnessed a masterpiece.

title: Good Faahking Movie!
review:
Phewy, we got a movie here. You have a star-studded cast, big named director, more swears than Goodfellas (kidding), some great violence...what a good flick.

This movie is about the involvement of "rats" in Boston police and Boston Irish mafia. Like I said before, almost everyone in the movie is a big name....so they are all willing to display their best acting. Unbelievably everyone brings it. Fantastic acting. Jack Nicholson and Mark Wahlberg were my favorites in this one.

The story itself is great also. Taking the story from a Chinese movie called Infernal Affairs, but mixing in Boston Irish Mob history.

The movie is pretty long, but what do you expect from Scorcese. Gangs of New York went on forever...thank God for Daniel Day Lewis. But I only say this due to the fact my knees hurt, and I need to stretch them every so often. Forgetting that, the movie moves at a pretty fast clip.

It's flat out one of the best crime movies ever made, and definitely one of the best movies this year. I would say this and Flags of Our Father are the top two. If you like smart, gritty, well acted flicks you'll most likely love this baby.

title: Scorsese scores again!
review: To be honest with you as soon as i saw the trailer and the set of stars in that movie i just wanted to see it from the get go. I finally got time this Sunday to see it. If you really want to enjoy this movie don't wait till its out of the theater..go now and see it on big screen. At any rate. This is the best movie Leonardo Dicaprio has ever been in, and damn me if he doesn't win an Oscar this time around. That's not it though, the storyline was so rich i followed every single scene intently, and my attention was undivided for the whole 2.5 hrs. The characters are also very complicated and Scorsese did a great job at introducing every one and each of them, even the small characters. Especially Mark Walberg's character introduction, which is memorable and you will agree with me when you see it. The right movie has finally found Mark Walberg, and this will definitely open bigger doors for his future career. The best thing about this movie is how close all the characters become related as the story goes on. Of course i will have to comment about the cinematography, of course the angles and shots were fabulous, but some parts of the movie were edited roughly. But that was just a technical thing, it didn't really take away much from the movie's glory. Codos for Dicaprio,Damon and Nicolson, and above all Thanks for the best gangster movie Scorsese!

title: Please don't feed DiCaprio to the poor...
review:
...I want him to make another movie as timeless, powerful, entertaining, in-your-face, and brilliant as this.

I stick by these words: best movie all year. I have yet to see the Prestige or Flags of Our Fathers or The Fountain but I highly doubt those movies had such staying power that I could watch it for nearly three hours and not be bored, once. I literally ran to the bathroom so I didn't miss any parts.

Talk about an Oscar nod... The Academy might as well not even hold Oscars this year, and just mail them to DiCaprio, Damon, Nicholson, and Scorcese.

title: Marty Scorese is God
review: Just been to see The Departed, excellent movie. The direction, action sequences and the acting, all come together to make for a high quality movie. The cast is stellar, and who knew Leo DiCaprio could act! took me half way through the movie to work out it was actually him. Jack Nickleson also brilliant. Excellent supporting cast too. I love the gangster genre and I love Marty Scohrese's movies and this is him on top form. I've watched the original Hong Kong crime thriller Infernal Affairs, on which this is based on and its a great adaption. So go see a movie which has depth and emotion amidst all the bloodshed. Definly in my top 10, I love this movie! 10/10

title: As Frank Costello says so humorously, "No tickey, no laundry!" To that I say bring all the loads you can muster, 'cause this movie can't fail to wash you to the core.
review: Martin Scorcese is among the most influential, masterfully-gifted film directors of all time. He's contributed countless movie classics from his under-the-radar classic Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore to his beautifully violent Taxi Driver; his graceful docu-masterpiece The Last Waltz to the unprecedented bio-pic Raging Bull; The King of Comedy, The Last Temptation of Christ, The Color of Money, GoodFellas, his daunting and haunting re-make Cape Fear, Casino, Bringing Out the Dead, Gangs of New York, The Aviator. All of these timeless trend-setting genre spectacles amass to a resume in American cinema outdone only by Hitchcock, Ford and Huston. Despite his triumphs in moving pictures, Scorcese has yet to attain his due recognition as Best Director and none of his Academy Award-nominated films have won the prestigious Oscar for Best Picture of the Year. Well, this year's chances are as good as any for his drought to catch some rain. The Departed, an Americanized adaptation of Japan's hugely successful crime-drama, Infernal Affairs, is already being considered a crime-classic for time to come and is Leonardo DiCaprio's most concrete Oscar-prone vessel to date. Each and every performance is teeth-shatteringly good with strong leads from Matt Damon, Mark Wahlberg, Ray Winstone and eight-time nominee, three-time Academy Award-winner, Jack Nicholson. However, outshined are all of these phenomenal actors; and by one I figured least likely to do the deed. Leonardo DiCaprio truly delves into Billy Costigan's persona, becoming the young lad from South Boston. Along with Costigan, Colin Sullivan (Damon) is leading an excessively dangerous double-life. While Colin is moving up the hierarchy at the city's law enforcement branch, Billy's mischievous past and family reputation keep him from staying on the task force. The careers of these two young gentlemen, and their addressing captains (Alec Baldwin, Martin Sheen) each amount to the reign of South Boston's organized-crime leader, Frank Costello (Nicholson). Scorcese's expert knowledge on the industry's does and don'ts, leave The Departed the crafty modern masterpiece that it is, and without any splotches. As Frank Costello says so humorously, "No tickey, no laundry!" To that I say bring all the loads you can muster, 'cause this movie can't fail to wash you to the core.

title: Outstanding movie!
review: I was riveted throughout the whole movie. The acting was untouchable, and the plot was unique as well as believable! My husband didn't even make it through his raisin-ets! I have always been a fan of Matt Damon and I still think that The Bourne series is his best work, but this one is close to it. I feel that Jack Nicholson will be getting an Emmy for this one! Do not get me wrong, every actor/actress did a 10+ job as well. I did not understand the ending, however. Without a doubt, a guys movie! Maybe someone can help me understand the ending. This movie is worth seeing two times in the theater and about a dozen on DVD! A must see!

title: When the good and evil cannot be distinguished!
review:
This film is the remake of the Hong Kong film 'Infernal Affairs'. It is about the situation when evil and the good can no longer be distinguished.

This film does not feel like 2.5 hours along at all. There is not a moment of slack. Crucial things happen in every scene, and they happen for a reason.

Apart from the suitable pacing, the story is also great. Though it is a remake, I can see quite a lot of difference from the original. I like the way that only the concept from the original is used, and all the details are original.

Acting is great by all parties. There is romance, there is a lot of blood, there is portrayal of trust and betrayal. There is something for everybody.

One minor complaint though, is that the ending (outside the lift) is a bit artificial. I can't say more, but if you watched the film, you will know what I mean.

title: Everything I hope it would be
review: I loved this movie. I saw it last night and I think three hours have never gone by so fast. It was great from start to finish. Plenty of funny moments and great lines and of course top notch acting. Leonardo DiCaprio was really showing his skills in this one. I think Leo might be the next protégé of Scorsese. Jack was great like always and I really enjoyed Mark Wahlberg's character. I can't say enough good things about this movie, it really doesn't have any flaws. It keeps you interested from start to finish (like all Scorsese's movie) and it was cool to see an Irish Mafia movie, rather than a typical Italian one. If you haven't seen this movie yet, you need to, this one is actually worth the 9 dollars. Check it out.

title: Absolutely Haunting
review:
From a person who loves epic films like Braveheart or Gladiator and crime dramas like Good Fellas, I was totally taken aback by this film. This has Oscar written all over it....somebody from this movie will be getting an Oscar.

Nicholson is once again a master of his craft and I'm not a big DiCaprio fan but he definitely has my respect for his accent and performance. Scorsese has once again done a very tasteful and beautifully violent film.

Every big name actor in this movie has really put it up in the open for everyone to see...Marty Sheen?? Wow!! The old man still got it. Marky Mark...still has my respect since he left the Funky Bunch!!

I don't buy too many DVD's but this will be on my shelf when it comes out. Again, absolutely fantastic and haunting. There were a couple of loop holes in the end but not too major.

title: Really Really Good.................really
review:
Simply put, this movie was so good. I'm so glad that we chose to spend the money and see it in a theater. The shooting in the film almost blew my ears out- just the way I like it. I would have regretted waiting till it came out on DVD,etc.

Leo did an amazing job. I thought about his character for hours after the film. I LOVE Alec Baldwin in this. This is a role he was born to play. Sheen did a terrific job and Nicholson......amazing.

Damon was good but I'm not a big fan of his physical mannerisms or walk......they tend to be the same in every movie. But his acting was good.

I'm going to buy this movie when it comes out and watch it again. Now that I know how it turns out- I want to re-watch it and see if I can catch some stuff.

If this movie or the actors in it don't get an Oscar......so help me....

This movie is now on my top 10 movies of all time. And that includes The Godfather, Goodfellas and the like. I really really like this movie.......... go see it.

title: Excellent Mob Movie! Scorsese is Back!
review:
After walking out of the theater today I realized why movies are made. Movies aren't just made for money, but for our entertainment. This so far happens to be one of the better mob movies. Superb acting, and an excellent story.

Leonardo Dicaprio plays Billy Costigan, an undercover cop known only to Cpt. Queenan and Dignam (played by Martin Sheen and Mark Wahlberg) who is investigating Frank Costello who is played by your truly Jack Nicholson. Unfortunately for Boston Police, they have a rat in their department too. Colin Sullivan played by Matt Damon who has been with Costellob since he was a young boy is a detective in the police department and tips Costello when every raid will take place. When both the Mob and the Cops find out they have rats, it becomes a game of trust.

With smart-mouth comments and excellent storytelling the movie goes from normal and smartly told to suspenseful and an excellent storyline. I highly recommend this movie. Mr. Scorsese, WELCOME BACK!

title: I'm sorry DiCaprio and Nicholson, but the Oscar goes to Mark Whalberg
review:
I'm going to be quite honest with you, Martin Scorseses latest masterpiece is one of the best movies i have seen for years. Jack Nicholson, Leo DiCaprio, Martin Sheen and Matt Damon all deliver stunning performances. But Mark Whalberg stole every scene he was participating in. His staff sergeant Dignam is one of the most brilliant characters i have ever seen on screen. Just that is a reason to see this wonderful movie...

Best movie of the year isn't enough to describe the departed. Best movie of the centaury, then we are getting close. There are a few, but only a few frustrating scenes but these are easily forgotten. Theses scenes are replaced by momorable ones, like the ending scene, witch is simply amazing

title: Brilliant Scorcese! Masterful acting!
review: I haven't seen the original Chinese movie, Infernal Affairs, and it really does not matter at all... I can simply tell you that I saw this movie with my 17 year-old daughter and we both thoroughly enjoyed it. It kept us on the edge of our seats for the full 2 1/2 hours. We both felt the strong suspense and we loved the powerful performances, especially Leonardo DiCaprio's. We literally felt his fear and anxiety mounting until the shocking finale. DiCaprio really deserves an Oscar nomination. Damon is brilliant as the cold-blooded villain. Everybody else in the cast was brilliant. We strongly recommend The Departed, so much so that my daughter wants to see it again. It is the best movie out there right now!!

title: Thoroughly enjoyed this movie
review: With all the great actors in this movie I expected it to be pretty good. I was not disappointed. It had a neat thought-provoking plot which took quite a slow build-up, but once all the pieces came together the story took tons of twists and turns and was always keeping you wondering if the bad guys were gonna get theirs in the end. The extended use of bad language (there weren't very many lines in the script that did not include some variation of the F-Word} is probably too much for many people (my wife included)but was very realistic for people in this line of work, so to speak. If you liked Scarface and Wise Guys you will probably like this as well. The plot certainly has more to offer and is not an easy one to predict. Well worth seeing if the language and gore (there are many bloody scenes) does not bother you.

title: Rats.
review:
It starts out rather slow and methodically. But the plot rivets attention unto itself because of how we know WHO everyone is in the story... Great performances all around. I loved the scene when the 2 men joke about a dog-walking girl being the Commissioner of the police department.

I think in storytelling, the irony of having the audience know more than the characters makes for BETTER suspense and anticipation. Yet THE DEPARTED still has it's unexpected U-Turns. I like the last and final shot. A visual cue and the ultimate representation to something of a recurring element or role in what the movie is about.

title: Scorsese back where he belongs
review:
It's refreshing to see three of American cinema's biggest names return to something like top form. Since Goodfellas, Scorsese, Hollywood's crime lord, has seen switches in genre proved unsuccessful at the box office and amongst critics: period pieces, Kundun, Gangs of New York and The Aviator. Damon and Di Caprio also make searing returns to form, the former finally coming out of the shadow of that infernal puppet in Team America (remember he wrote Good Will Hunting) in this thrilling Boston crime epic from the master of the genre.

A remake of the Hong-Kong 2002 thriller, Infernal Affairs, The Departed sees the divide between both sides of the law blur as an all-star Hollywood cast swear, kill and even butcher their way through the complexities of life in the Boston-Irish mafia. There are rats on both sides and no one can be sure who has the sharpest teeth until Scorsese pulls back the curtain for his tense, seat-gripping finale.

This is an 18 certificate movie so: vulgar profanity. Check. Lots of blood. Check. And Jack Nicholson's sublime gangland boss hitting on an underage girl asking if she'd got her period yet. Check. It sounds wrong but trust me; this is comedy but damn is it dark.

The movie has is problems: it's a 'bum-number' i.e. a little long for some tastes and female character who becomes involves with Di Caprio and Damon feels at times somewhat inconsequential but these are very small needles in a gloriously entertaining haystack.

In a nutshell: Awesome! The most entertaining picture this year. Not for the faint hearted but if you loved Goodfellas, if you love Scorsese you will not be disappointed.

title: Better than Hyped
review:
Wow...I just finished watching and I have to say it was even better than I expected. I was pretty much the last one to see it out of my group of friends and I wasn't given a bad review by any of them. Going in I was a bit apprehensive, with the movie being pumped up the way it was I was sure a letdown was inevitable. All I can say is, boy was I wrong. Not only was the movie well written and directed, but the acting was out of this world. Nicholson as usual was phenomenal, Damon as the villain was tremendous and DiCaprio blew me away. I really expected great acting out of everyone, but I think Leo has finally come into his own and possibly stole the movie. I have never really been a big fan of his, granted he is a talented actor, but I thought in previous movies he was more of a pretty boy than a show stopper. In the Departed DiCaprio plays one hell of a bad-ass.

Visually this movie was gripping. I am a bit biased and find Boston to be a great city with many sites, but in this movie they were able to find every possible dirty, sleazy and just plain rough area they could find and made Boston look like a city to avoid.

In all I think this is by far the best movie 2006 has offered to date, and I personally feel this is actually one of the greatest action/thriller movies ever. Scorsese has outdone himself by far, and that is saying a lot. This movie might only be topped by Taxi Driver or Raging Bull on Scosese' impressive resume. In general I would recommend this movie to all, though I would suggest leaving the kids and anyone that can't handle the sight of blood(there is definitely LOTS of it) at home.

title: A New Classic!
review: So much depth in the characters. This flick sucked me in right away. DeCaprio does one of his best performances in this one and i felt he out-shined Nicholson. Keeping in mind that Jack was his usual fun self. Never really being a Matt Damon fan, he certainly gained my respect by his believable and extremely uptight performance. Martin Sheen and Mark Wahlberg were a great team as well. Mark's part was hilarious. Overall the cast was 5 star and well chosen and I found that this was practically the perfect Scorsese film.(Hence my 10 rating) Especially for a big Scorsese fan like myself. A must see for anyone that needs a classic Scorsese fix or anyone looking to break into his movies for the first time. Enjoy!

title: The Departed (2006)
review:
Maybe you've heard the Internet buzz about The Departed being an old-school cop flick, unburdened by profundity. Maybe you'll think so too if you don't pay a lick of attention to what's on screen. Or maybe you'll recognize The Departed for what it is: a new American crime classic from the legendary Martin Scorsese, whose talent shines here on its highest beams.

A title card sets the scene: boston. some years ago. And we're off, watching Leonardo DiCaprio as a cop pretending to be a hood and Matt Damon as his opposite. Both are trapped in circumstances where you can't tell the good from the bad.

All the actors bring their A games to this triumphant bruiser of a film, its darkly wanton wit the only defense against complete chaos. DiCaprio and Damon give explosive, emotionally complex performances, but it must be said that Jack Nicholson reaches undreamed-of heights of decadent devilment as Irish mob kingpin Frank Costello. Whether he's wielding a gun or a dildo, buying off cops, dissing Catholic priests as pederasts, seducing children into a life of crime, letting it snow cocaine on favored hookers or chatting while elbow-deep in blood, Nicholson is electrifying. Dispassionately executing a woman on a beach, Costello notes to his henchman Mr. French (a terrific Ray Winstone), "She fell funny." But Costello is no campy Joker. Channeling James Cagney in White Heat and Paul Muni in Scarface, Nicholson leeches out the glamour to create a landmark portrait of evil.

title: Absolutely the best movie ever filmed
review: This movie is a go for everyone but the faint hearted. This movie is a testament to movie quality. Martin Scorcese deserves that directors Oscar for this movie alone. The way he was able to turn a Hong Kong thriller into a blockbuster hit with some of the best stars around. The DiCaprio -Matt Damon combo provides this movie with the key character relationships that define key acting. If I had any influence over those in Hollywood, I would definitely give this movie 7+ Oscars. (especially in male, lead and supporting actor, and director categories) Therefore, I strongly recommend everyone to watch the best movie ever put out of Hollywood.

title: Scorsese's best yet!
review: Truly a must see, it is unbelievable how far Scorsese has come as a director. His most ambitious film yet is a knockout, with a stellar cast and an even better plot. A cat and mouse game until the very end, The Departed had my heart pounding for the whole film. The characterizations were perfect, with each actor playing roles that seemed tailor made just for them. The story is such an immersive and masterfully interweaving tale that I actually had to catch my breath a few times due to the intensity. Complete with the trademark Scorsese tongue-in-cheek dialogue and violence and The Departed packs plenty of laughs and even more thrills. Ultimately this is why we go to the movies.

title: One of the best action/suspense films i have ever seen!
review: All i have to say is put your criticized things you said about Leonardo D because this is one of the best movies i have ever seen in my life! Great acting and these roles could have never been filled better than they were! A must see, a must buy, a must loved movie of the year! I give this movie an 11 out of 10 and there is nothing more to say! You will not regret my words of wisdom on this one... if you don't agree please hit me back up and tell me other wise! This movie will be in households everywhere when it comes out on DVD. This movie rocks, and keeps you guessing until the very end. It is action packed with Boston's crime syndicate doing what they did best. Put your guessing games away on trying to find out what movies are good... take my word and get up and go see this awesome movie!

title: One of Scorsese's bests
review:
The Departed is about two men from the opposite sides of the law that are undercover within the Boston State Police department and the Irish mafia, but violence and bloodshed boil when discoveries are made, and the moles are dispatched to find out their enemy's identities. This is an excellent film by one of my favorite directors, Martin Scorsese. The all star cast represented by Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Jack Nicholson, Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen, and Alec Baldwin are all brilliant and they act out their performances with much realism. The screenplay is written out very well by William Monahan and the direction by Scorsese is sensational, with his trademark camera work. The soundtrack was also very well done. Overall, this is the best film of the year so far and even though it's no Goodfellas, it is truly, one of his greatest films. I highly recommend it.

Hedeen's Outlook: 10/10 **** A+

title: The Streets Just Got Meanier
review: This was a great crime drama, it was amazingly well directed by Martin Scororsese, it was well acted by the all star cast. They play off each other so well with drama and a little humor. The movie begins with Billy(Leonardo DiCaprio) is a cop who is in deep cover to infiltrate sadistic mobster Frank Costello(Jack Nicholsen at his best), as of Colin Sullivan(Matt Damon), a cop on the take, is trying to find out the undercover guy on Costellos team. It is only of matter of time on how both men are in over there heads, and will it come crashing down on both of them. A great way to spend 2 hours and 30 minutes, but it is so amazingly well paced, you'll forget how long it is.

title: spectacular film, perfect writing and acting!
review: It takes an extraordinary movie to lead me to commend on IMDb about it. This is film work at its finest. Leo is as good as it gets between his performances in Gangs of New York and this. The writing (apparently it is based on another film called Internal Affairs) was amazing making us strain to understand every little nuance that is occurring (but in a good way). Spectacular everything. I will be very upset (and surprised) if this doesn't win best picture and director this year. (Although I have no real feel for which of the leads, Damon or Leo, will get a best actor nomination....I'm hoping its Leo.) At 2 and 1/2 hours, it was not one minute too long. Amazing!

title: Extremely entertaining- nothing more
review: One of the America's sharpest action films of the year? Yes. A masterpiece? No. A return to form for one of America's most celebrated directors? Yes. An evolution of style and substance? No. Martin Scorsese certainly gives the finger to critics citing his recent geriatric tendencies with his most visceral work in at least a decade, but in turn somehow manages to imitate, not emulate some of his finer styling's, at peak form during the "Goodfellas" era. While stepping away from his traditional mobster and New York flavorings to tell this story about Boston police corruption, some of the more violent scenes, and even some of the environment panning clearly parallels, if not directly imitates classic moments from that prototypical masterpiece. What's worse is Scorsese's inability to change his musical palette when scoring these types of films, as half of the soundtrack also feels like a retread of the scenes he was trying to direct years before. Despite all of the noticeable unoriginality, The Departed still evolves into one of the most engaging guessing games in recent action memory, tightening the rungs around the paranoid plot line until we are all feeling the pressure. While some of the acting might not be academy-worthy, even the likes of Stiff Damon rose to the occasion to contribute to this classy thriller. Dicaprio provides a much needed boost to his sagging relevance as one of our finest young leads with his tense performance, while Nicholson once again shows that he has been done "trying" for some time now, and just gives the camera whatever it is he feels like giving it, which sadly is still way more engaging then most actors, despite his characters becoming way to silly. Ignoring desperate, idealistic preconceptions and bitter Scorsese fanboys who vow to get a genius his directing Oscar, The Departed is a very enjoyable, engaging, and fluid action thriller that will leave anyone with the slightest bit of testosterone feeling very satisfied.

title: I departed Disappointed
review:
Much of this movie seemed contrived and lacked credibility.

Biggest weakness in my opinion was the shrink character.

She was a lousy actress.....and miscast as a shrink.

More importantly, the movie would have lost nothing had that entire role been eliminated.

Her character seemed a distraction throughout the entire script.

Nicholson was terrific. There was one scene which I won't describe in detail (for the benefit of those who have not seen the movie)where he made a facial expression that perfectly conveyed what he was describing....as memorable a moment as I can recall in a movie.

I still recommend the movie as very worth seeing.

My expectations may have been too high because I saw it after all the great reviews. It is a very good movie with some great performances by Nicholson and DiCaprio especially. But fell below being a great movie in my opinion.

title: damon caprio nicholson are a blast, Movie is fantastic
review:
After walking out of the theatre after watching the departed, I felt like going to the ticket counter, and buy the ticket for it again. The departed can best be described as the most powerful and the most entertaining movie of the year. It's very hard to decide who was better than who in the movie because everyone gives a great performance. Leaving Nicholson, Dicaprio and Damon aside the supporting cast too gives a great performance.Martin Sheen and Wahlberg gives some great support to the cast. My favorite scenes includes the one involving Martin Sheen, Wahlberg and Dicaprio. These scenes are really well executed. I have always been a big fan of Scorsese, and even this time he doesn't disappoint. He surpassed my expectations by leaps and bounds. Thank you Mr. Scorsese for making the departed.

Dhruv Puri gives the movie Two Biggest thumbs up way up.

title: Scorsese's invasive camera sets the tone for...
review: VERA FAMIGIA and LEO DICAPRIO in a bedroom scene that keeps us feeling as though we are invading their space. Scorsese accomplishes this effect with an invasive camera and the actors speaking quietly with low voices and closing in on LEO's psychological awakening degenerating into a sexual encounter with his therapist. I still feel that LEO's the protagonist in this film when asking for a cranberry juice, he seems as though he's trying to cut the female form for us and using his masculinity to pull it off at the same time. This created the dramatic need for VERA's character. I also feel favor towards the defense of his name being used only to explain himself to others, was a rejection to labels in society. Only MATT DAMON doesn't seem the type to need a label. I did not like that MATT had to play such an ordinary part. I think he deserves best supporting actor. It was so exciting to see the plot unravel to the Rolling STones soundtrack "Your'e just a shot away". It made an otherwise boring stupid scenario, seem envious and vengeful. I thought the the Director's intention with the cast showed that Scorsese deserves his reputation in cinema in that respect. Definitely an impressive film. Classic cinematography too! No, i'm not a homicidal ex only a paranoid fan. Here's to the auteur we all know and love.

title: The original is just hard to live up to
review:
I was really looking forward to this remake. The original and it's sequel (more accurately, the prequel) were two of the best Asian movies ever made.

Without making any comparisons to the original cast, I think Leonardo DiCaprio did a good job in this movie. Everyone else was their usual - Matt Damon's performance was a tad too Talented Mr Ripley for me, Mark Wahlberg was just his usual Four Brothers self. There was nothing notable about Alec Baldwin or Martin Sheen's characters.

Oh and Jack Nicholson can't be taken seriously acting that way. Really.

I did expect that changes would be made to the original, after all, Infernal Affairs contained too many Asian nuances to be universal, but I liked that what really happened was implied rather than shown. I feel that script was just too literal, and everything had to be played out. You hardly have the chance to feel the anguish anyone goes through, because they're yelling it all the time.

I guess the biggest problem I have with the The Departed is that everyone was a one-sided character. Besides maybe Leo Dicaprio's Billy. And that's just not how life is. The original movie really took the trouble to show that part of the characters. No one was truly honest, and no one was truly evil. And that's where The Departed failed.

Honestly I did expect a lot more from The Departed. Lots of big names were attached to it, and with a director like Martin Scorsese, you really expect to have your socks knocked off. I expected Cape Fear, or Goodfellas.

But alas. It was just an OK movie for me. I'll watch the original versions over this any day.

title: Overrated!
review: Once again another movie with potential ruined by a confusing, poorly edited ending. Thelma, maybe you should finally retire to the SAG home (if you are a member). The ending had all the earmarks of a Quentin Tarantino movie, and Mr. Scorsese should be ashamed of himself for copying a master, who was making movies such as this 15 years ago. I left the theater thinking of The Bourne Supremacy, with it's twists and turns, and superlative ending and comparing this mish-mash I had just seen, leaving me feeling confused, and wondering why such an intriguing first half was totally debased, hacked up, and ruined by Tarantino theatrics, which are best done by him anyway. Great cast and good performances by all concerned, except Mr. Scorsese, his editor Thelma Scoonmaker, and the writer, or should I say "adapter", since this movie was taken from another script.

title: Wow!
review: Not a big fan of Leonardo or Alec Baldwin, but both had great roles and maybe no one could have played them better, i have a newly found respect for both actors after this movie, they were great from start to finish, it has a great lineup of some of the best actors in the biz and it shows, i wonder how much it cost the producer to pay them? = )The departed is great once the premise really starts to kick in,and jack Nicholson is awesome and you gotta love where the director was going with a little bit of humor. the only thing i didn't like about the movie is the elevator scene near the end, for example, are not handled as well as in the original (the audience laughed during the elevator scene, and I'm not sure that was the original directors intent. If you love action, suspense and a little dark humor toped with some blood then spend the 10 dollars at the your local theater, its worth every penny!

title: Great performances, choppy editing.
review:
I thought the entire cast was excellent. The performances made the movie for me. It didn't seem very Scorsese-ish though. Its a cops and robbers kind of movie and it seemed to me like it could have been directed by anyone competent and didn't require a master filmmaker. It didn't explore the psyche of these people in the way that Goodfellas did, but as a popcorn thriller, it worked.

I didn't really like how the sound and picture were cut though. It felt a little choppy, but it was clearly the style Scorsese was going for. Like the music would cut out suddenly or it was competing with the dialogue. Sometimes picture edits would bump together like a jump cut. Did anyone else notice this?

title: Powerful story, magnificent performances, lousy ending
review:
A stellar cast and a very good director nearly delivered on their promise of making an amazing movie.

A very good movie was ruined by a lame, almost idiotic ending. After spending 2 hours in a edge-of-your-seat gripping thriller with magnificent performances by Jack Nicholson, Leonardo DiCaprio (yes, him too! who would've thought that he could turn out such a powerful and gritty performance?), Matt Daemon (his usual performance, not unlike his performance in "The Talented Mr. Ripley") and Mark Wahlberg, I expected the movie top live up to its potential right to the very end. It lived up to most of its potential through most of the movie except for the last 10-15 minutes.

Different movies treat violence and murder in different ways. Training Day (with Denzel Washington) does an incredible job of turning violence and murder into a powerful tool. In Departed, Martin Scorcese turns it into combination of gratuitous violence and otiose murder.

Martn Sheen and Alec Baldwin gave standard performances that did little to enrich the movie. They're extremely good actors who were horrendously underutilized.

What was Martin Scorcese thinking when he populated the film with a plethora of stars and when he filmed the ending? He either ran out of time or ran out of interest or ran out of thoughts. Or maybe he fell ill while filming the last part and designated an intern or a studio executive to finish it. In any case, at the end of the movie, you are left wondering "Huh? Why? What was the point?"

title: Disappointed
review: I expected more from this movie but after watching it yesterday now I know how great was the original "internal affairs". When I learned that Martin Scorsese was the director for this remake of Hong Kong's best selling detective movie I was so excited but was disappointed in the end . The ending was horrible does not make any sense. They try to make a drama into a comedy what a joke! The casting and acting was horrible too. Only Matt was pretty good in the movie the rest are ridiculous. In addition the tempo of the movie was so slow it seem like it was never going to end. The departed is one of the worse remake of all time. If you want to see a masterpiece watch "internal affairs" if you want to watch a comedy with sub par acting watch "the departed". I can not believe how they can mess up an excellent plot and come up with this rubbish.

title: it is not as good as the original
review:
Frankly, speaking from a Chinese point of view, the departed is a pale comparison of the original. Even as many have pointed out, the entire movie is too long and draggy. What i think maintains its attractiveness, i.e. excites many people, is that they have not watched Infernal Affairs at all.

And indeed, plots like these are really refreshing, exciting and thus captures its audience. Those who have seen the original no doubt will be very much be less entertained by it.
