I think the best thing about Infernal Affairs is that it really sets people thinking about the bad and the good, and how often the line drawn between them can be so vague. I don't think the departed succeeded in doing so though.

title: Great film but some "what the hell?" moments
review:
I saw this with my best friend and have just read over 3 pages of comments. All praising or dissing the film based upon comparing it to Infernal Affairs.

For me none of that mattered, what I did find jarring was how uncomfortable most of the actors seem to be with expletives. Being half Irish and growing up in working class England, I just couldn't believe the dialogue. Whenever a character swore it sounded forced and unnatural - if you want to see what natural swearing sounds like rent Billy Elliot.

Also what the hell was Scorcese (an Italian) thinking, putting the song Scotland the Brave in a film about Irish mobsters? Does he know who the Irish and the Scots are? An Irishman is more likely to have Oh Danny Boy as his cellphone ringer than a protestant Scottish bagpipe song.

BTW Irish bagpipes just have a bladder you don't blow into them and Irish kilts are one colour beige not Tartan. Maybe these inconsistencies in Irish-American culture are to blame for Scorcese's blindness when picking out the music.

title: my new favorite movie... seriously, it's that good
review:
Wow. Just wow.. and a good wow. Last night I finally went to see The Departed. I say "finally" because I've been dying to see it for weeks now. Typically when I get my hopes up this high for a movie, I end up being disappointed. Last night was different. As I sat in a run-down movie theater with about 80 other college students (on what is typically a HUGE bar night) I saw what is perhaps one of the best movies i have ever seen.

Let's start with the acting... it was incredible. I honestly had low expectations for Leonardo DiCaprio because, in my mind, after Romeo & Juliet and Titanic, I could never get the pretty boy image out of my head... until last night. He was incredible. From his depressed eyes to his witty comments, Leo stole the movie. But that's not to take anything away from Matt Damon who was an amazing counterpart and the brilliant Jack Nicholson in what was truly a great performance of a Irish mafia leader, one that even DiNero couldn't have done better...

i think what shocked me most about this film was that it was funny, i mean sure i expected some amusing lines, but The Departed was actually FUNNY... like laugh out loud funny... to make a film that has you on the edge of your seat yet also has you laughing out loud... now thats impressive... the story line was great, it didn't bore me for a second and for a 149 minute movie thats says something about the movie... basically I'm telling you to go see the movie... now. The Departed will absolutely blow your mind it's so good... i would recommend it to anyone... guys and girls of all ages and even people who typically don't like bloody movies (like me!) because it's THAT good...

If The Departed doesn't win an Oscar, I'm boycotting the show.

title: This is the movie that movie lovers have been waiting for!!!!
review: This movie ROCKS!!!! It is the best film I have seen this year. All the performances were amazing. Mark Walberg stood out, and that is tough to do with this flawless group of actors, that did extraordinary jobs.This movie experience reminded me of how much I love going to the movies, but movies this high quality are rare now. The dialog was witty, funny and powerful. The story was suspenseful and intense. Not ONE dull moment, it took me an hour to calm down after. I was riveted by every performance, the actors blew me away....Every one of them. Martin Scoresse has done one of his best here. It is very violent, almost to much for me, but I squealed and looked the other way now and then, and i was able to hold on.

title: The best in a while...
review: The last time I remember being this satisfied sitting in a movie theater was when I saw Mystic River. This great cast definitely lived up to my expectations. DiCaprio was stellar in every aspect of his performance, which was most likely not very easy when you are next to Nicholson. Walberg has once again separated himself from his previous years of underwear modeling, he is not just a pretty face. Damon was an unexpected choice for the rat but he pulled it off beautifully. Sheen was absolutely excellent, he played a great father character to DiCaprio. Even Baldwin who wasn't a huge role but made sure that you left remembering his performance. Of course Jack was off the charts oozing with sleaziness, but you can't help but still like the guy, he's that bad guy that everyone feared and loved in school. The dialogue was great and the nearly two and a half hours flew by and left me wanting more.

title: movie snobs
review:
it is rare for me to go see film in a major theatre as I would wait for it to be screened at the Bloor (toronto), or i would get a spadina special ($4 quality burn). but this was worth it. i am glad i caved. i did not xpect the flick to be that good. (in my defense I was drunk) it reminded me of the Casino experience in the theatre. the last movie I saw in a theatre was "The Fountain", Aronofsky's proof that anyone can fall off the wagon. Needless to say, I lost all faith in my big time directors. Marty challenged my cynicism by droppin a bomb. if -YOU- are holding out to buy a burn...two words...crazy talk. this is a definite theatre screening or you will kick your own a#s later. drop the $$$ and feed the movie-machine.

you know who u are...

title: a masterpiece
review: this is a really beautiful movie. definitely the best Martin Scorsese film in a long time. this really movie really bring up a level with everything it has to offer. it has incredibly well written dialog, which is only furthered by top notch acting by everyone in this film. character development and the relationships in it are really well played out through the movie. there is such a wonderful contrast between Matt Damon and Leonardo DiCaprio, and its all so well played out. all of this in a deep and involving story enthralling you for every moment of this movie. i couldn't ask for more. kudos to the director and an outstanding cast.

title: Goodfellas Hunting
review:
I walked in with mixed expectations. From friends, I heard it was awesome, "up there with 'Heat' in my all-time top 5." The trailer looked awesome. "Goodfellas" is obviously a masterpiece. But then I remember the bloated mess that "Gangs of New York" became.

The good: I'm not a Leo fan by any stretch, but I thought his performance was for the most part engaging and believable... Except there's no answer to the question of why he does what he does. Is it to clear the family name? Rid himself of his father and uncle's ghosts? Why go through all that? Matt Damon seemed like he was playing "Will Hunting becomes a cop." For the most part, believable. Alec Baldwin and Marky-Mark were solid as well.

Cinematography was great. I've always loved Scorsese's use of steadicam and dolly shots. Editing was good, sound was good.

The bad: Not for one minute did I believe the romantic relationship between Leo and the shrink. First, it wasn't set up, he was just sitting in her office, screaming about how he needed pills. Give me a line where he was ordered to see a psychologist, something... But out of the blue, there he is in her office. Next, he was asking her for coffee, and apparently she said yes. Would that ever happen?! I just didn't buy it. And gee, it sure is convenient that she's in a love triangle between the two main characters. Vera Farminga is beautiful, no doubt, and she sold the chemistry between her and Matt Damon. But her and Leo, I just didn't buy it. And the scenes with those two was so randomly interspersed. Their relationship was a crucial point to the film, and with it being non-credible like that, really a major hang up for me.

Jack Nicholson has become a caricature. It was like an amalgam of the Joker and Melvin Udall. Is it acting? Or is he really crazy? Just a little too over-the-top.

And finally, Martin Sheen's Boston accent was Atrocious! One cut it's there, the next (even in the same scene) it's gone. Dropping a few R's does not a Boston accent make.

All that said the twist at the end was great and shocking, and while I could've done without the rat on the rail (just to make sure that we got the point), I liked the mildly ambiguous ending. Did Marky Mark get the information from the shrink and was avenging his police brethren? Was he another part of Costello's outfit? I prefer to think the former...

Overall, it's worth a look for some great performances. Just more suspension of disbelief is required than is the norm for films of this type.

title: Flirts with 'classic' status, but comes up short
review: Quick appraisal: Beginning is slow, middle is meaty and contains well-crafted scenes and performances, ending seems forced and intellectually lazy. Just seemed like Marty didn't no how to end this thing. Still worth seeing. I feel like Leo inhabits his role, Jack plays himself with deviant character wrinkles, Damon does a good job of being one of those conflicted, ethical dilemmas that have always been a hallmark of Marty's best work and Alec Baldwin continues to impress me. He is at his best when he is used as comic relief. Marky Mark is not great, but he, like Damon, gets points for being from Boston. Wahlberg is a damn good actor, even surprisingly so at times, but this character is largely one-dimensional. I know that's part of the plan, but I felt that it was an avoidable pitfall.

title: Good Movie but a bit too much
review: I happened to watch the movie on opening day. It's a very good movie since it was a remake of one of my favourite movies actually called "Infernal Affairs", which stars 1/4 of HK's heavenly kings (top idol) entertainer Andy Lau (Matt Damon's character) and Tony Leung (Leo's role). I loved the setting and the plot and how their facial expressions were dead on when they act out certain scenes. The cons? I did not however liked the fact that they only had 1 female lead since there are supposed to be 2 like the original but this had the 2 characters merged one person. I like how the actress portrayed herself but it didn't feel right. Another thing is that it felt too long as if they tried to combine all three of the movies into one.

title: The World Is Full Of Rats.
review:
BEFORE READING AHEAD PLEASE NOTE THIS COMMENT CONTAINS Spoilers !!! As a huge fan of the original Hong Kong Infernal Affairs I had my critic's eye firmly on place during The Departed. Frankly, I did not expect much from Scorsese who - with the exception of the wonderful The Aviator - has been on a downward spiral for many films. Imagine my surprise when The Departed impressed me, impressed me a lot. The story is very similar to the original film and despite my general hatred of Hollywood making a living remaking Asian films (PLEASE tell me no one is redoing the best film of the 21st Century Oldboy???) these days, The Departed is impressive on all counts. Scorsese's direction is masterful, DiCarpio just gets better and better with every film (Scorsese DeNiro of the Noughties?), the editing is Oscar winning and even Damon is bearable for this two and half hour gangster fest. Plus, who cares DeNiro could not do the part of Frank Costello, Nicholson is outstanding.

My only problem with the film is the ending. If you can get passed the very rushed last 20 minutes and even beyond the speedy demise of Damon who can forgive Scorsese for the final "rat" we see on screen? The final shot does not diminish a very good film but why oh why did he do that? I mean as if the audience didn't get the message that the world is full of rats by then! Come on Marty, tell us why?

title: well...
review:
The ending of this movie was so neat, Marky Mark was wearing booties.

...

Honestly. Amazing potential, a golden cast, incredible acting, a perfectly executed story, each scene so crafted, and then the ending wrapped it all up in such a contrived way. You could actually predict the last five minutes.

I am all about movies ending - no loose ends - but this ending was so planned... It just ruined the movie for me. The movie is an 8, but with a different finish, it would easily have been a 9.5. There is no bad acting in this movie at all. The overall culture is represented almost flawlessly, and each person plays a necessary role (save perhaps Alec Baldwin, but I like him a lot, so it was all good).

Martin Scorsese also seems to be stuck in a little bit of a genre rut. I can't blame him - he does movies like these very well - but you almost wish he would strike out and do something a bit less mob-oriented.

title: Scorsese's Touches Give Us A Very Different Take On Infernal Affairs
review:
The first thing people need to realize about The Departed is that it is in fact a remake of a Hong Kong film called Infernal Affairs. Specifically the first film of a trilogy. The basic plot involves a mole in the police department and a mole in a gang. Both guys end up discovering that the other exists and that his job is now to flush him out before getting caught himself. An interesting premise that both films bring to the big screen in their own way. With that out of the way, let's look at Scorsese's latest.

Wow. Just wow. This film was simply incredible. I watched Infernal Affairs a few days before The premier of The Departed just to refresh my memory and all I can say is that the naysayers really have nothing bad to say about Scorsese's latest film IMO. He adds so many of his typical yet effective touches that The Departed in essence becomes it's own film. It really is Scorsese's if you ignore the fact that the basic plot elements were ripped from a Hong Kong film. This is a remake I am very glad Hollywood decided to do because it differs from the original so much that it effectively keeps the great elements of the original and mixes in more than a few new colors to give audiences an effectively brand new take on a 4 year old plot.

The original Infernal Affairs had a sort of dark crime/noir Michael Mann feel. Scorsese was smart and changed things up quite a bit by adding a lot of Boston flavor to the story. The A-list cast doesn't hurt either. The humorous one liners in The Departed really make this an American film. It differs so much from the original that it stands well on it's own two feet and the scenes that were shot for shot recreations from the original (like Damon pretending to be a lawyer or DiCaprio showing one of his buddies how to correctly spell a word) end up feeling more like homages rather than plagiarism.

Moving off of comparing these two films lets look at that A-list cast. This is the first time in a long time that ALL of the A-list actors signed here live up to their reputations. Jack Nicholson was terrific in this film. It's been a long time since he's played a bad guy but The Departed is proof that he still has it. Leonardo DiCaprio proves that he is a great actor in this film and if you still think he's nothing more than a pretty face after his performance here I don't know what movie you went to. Mark Whalberg reprises his bad mouthed, slick talking persona he introduced to us in The Italian Job and polished to perfection in Four Brothers. I also also impressed with Vera Farmiga who I was introduced to in Running Scared. Matt Damon, Alec Baldwin and Martin Sheen also do very well in their respective roles. Then again it'd be hard for them to mess up with such great lines written for them.

I don't know who wrote these one liners but please promote the man or woman responsible for the dialogue in this film. The best way to describe the exchanges between characters here is "honest." The dialogue sounded genuine and real in that you know they'd be making fun of each other's Mamas in real life.

Scorsese hit the nail on the head with the score and the direction. He utilized his freeze frame action shots during a shootout that I really like and did a great job of making New York look like Boston. However certain scenes did feel a bit campy at times. When Sheen's character is killed I thought the manner in which he dropped in front of DiCaprio and the way the blood splattered was a bit cartoonish and campy. I think everyone kind of wanted to laugh but was too shocked from the scene preceding it which depicted Sheen falling through the air.

Aside from a few confusing (as in I didn't understand if Scorsese wanted me to be shocked or laugh) moments I was impressed. THIS is how to properly do a remake. Scorsese did alter the ending but I didn't mind too much. With the large differences in culture between America and China I felt that the ending to The Departed fit just as well to this version of the story as the original ending to Infernal Affairs fit the Hong Kong version. An excellent film and by far the best film I've seen this year. 10/10. I'd give it a 9.5/10 for being a remake but because it differs from the original so much and IMDb don't give out half points I'm rounding up here. Go watch this film as you will not be disappointed and then go rent the original and see how similar yet different the two are. Kudos to Scorsese for teaching Hollywood a thing or two about remakes and for making The Departed his own.

title: A wonderful movie
review: The Departed was by far one of the greatest movies I have seen in a very long time. This movie was just as good if not better than Goodfellas and Casino. Im not a huge fan of Leonardo Dicaprio but his part was excellent. The full cast was great. This is a must see for anyone who is a Scorsese fan. The movie packs constant action, and does not let you rest for a minute. Also from the beginning to the end Jack Nicholson plays one of the greatest villains I have seen for a while. The man plays the part perfectly and it goes completely with the movie. If I get the chance I will most likely see this future cult classic again.

title: Scorcese On Form
review:
The new offering from martin Scorcese sees him leave behind the historical sets of Gangs of New York and return to his roots with gangster flick The Departed. Billy Costigan (DiCaprio) has always wanted to be a cop and he's sent undercover by Massechutesses State Police to infiltrate Irish - American gangster Frank Costello's (Nicholson) mob. Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon) has been groomed by Costello to be a mole from a young age and is now Costello's informant in the Special Investigations Department. The two contrasting moles while keeping their real agenda a secret go in search of each other.

The picture is unapologetically violent and depicts murder merely as a way of life, but in the midst of the guts an gore the film explores particularly in the case of Billy Cosigan living a life with an identity that isn't yours. Scorsese's latest muse Leonardo DiCaprio excels as the troubled cop horrified by the release he feels from indulging in the violent lifestyle he's being forced to lead. Despite a stellar cast of DiCaprio and Damon supported by Martin Sheen, Alec Bladwin and Mark Whalberg they are all overshadowed by Jack Nicholson as the seasoned actor goes from charming to one step short of the nut house in the toss of a coin. The one draw back to this film is it doesn't break any new ground in the gangster movie genre. Put that aside and this movie is intelligent, fast paced and unpredictable with Scorcese unquestionably at his best and with great turns from DiCaprio who off the back of The Aviator has left behind his pretty boy Titanic days and Matt Damon who's acting career is going from strength to strength. But this is without a doubt Jack Nicholson's movie.

title: the real departed
review: First of all everybody that is comparing this movie to Internal Affairs. This movie is based on true events in Boston during the last 30 years. These people actually existed and were even more violent than in the movie. The main character does not get kill and is still out there on the run somewhere. Matt Damon character get caught and goes to prison. Leonard character is still alive and well. And no police get throw from any buildings. So let just say that this is not based on any other movies. The movie was very well done the acting first rate. Jack character was the best i seen in a movie in a very long time. So see you around Whitey where ever you are.

title: Better than Goodfellas? What a bunch of B.S.
review:
This film is good but it's not great like earlier Scorsese, i.e.. Goodfellas, Mean Streets, TLTOC, or Taxi Driver. The characters are not fleshed out like Goodfellas. When I walked out of the theatre after seeing Goodfellas I actually felt like I knew Henry Hill, and Jimmy the Gent. If they finally give Marty his Oscar he should hand it back to them. This film was long, and not as well edited as Thelma's better work. The scene with the two priests and the nun was awkward, and the much anticipated "Threesome Scene" was cut to shreds, which ended up being Jack Nicholson throwing piles of cocaine into the air. It should have been cut completely. The scene where Colin Sullivan kills Frank Costello was spaced and paced all wrong. How far away from the police activity did these two wander? It didn't really matter because at that point of the film the Costello character was acting like a moron instead of a savvy mob boss. That scene was so contrived it was insulting to anybody with a lick of street sense. Did Costello really have to taste the drugs? So much of the dialog was redundant... There's a rat, are you the rat? No are you the rat? No are you the rat? Maybe he's the rat...

There were some great performances from all of the actors and some surprises, like the killing of Queenan and the protagonist Costigan. There should be best supporting nods for Ray Winstone and Martin Sheen and Best acting nods for Decaprio and Damon. It will get Best Director and Best Picture nom's and if it wins Best Picture, Brad Pitt will get an Oscar. How cool is that! It will get a best editing nom which it does not deserve.

Better than Goodfellas? Nope!

title: Finally !!!
review:
I've waited for 2 yrs to finally see this movie & it didn't disappoint. Being from the Boston area & also being a huge fan of Scorcese & his all-star cast for this movie, yeah I was a little excited.

The cast & acting was top-notch. The 1st hour & a half was sort of predictable, but still very interesting. Then everything changed. The characters I expected to face-off in the end started dying one by one. I never expected Leo to meet his fate so early. Leo's death was comparable to Joe Pesci's demise in Goodfellas. It was shocking & I wished both of them triumphed in the end. The killing didn't stop there. It continued right through the final scene which was perfect.

Looking back at this film a day later, all I can say is WoW !!! Great movie, it's about time a film lived up to the hype.

title: The Lady Shrink
review: Did I miss something?? Why was Billy seeing the police department shrink when he was so deep undercover. His appointments were in her office, out in the open. I had a hard time getting around this. I know they needed to provide a connection between Colin and Billy but this was weak. Undercover officers normally have no connection, however marginal, to the police force. Maybe Colin needed to be dating Billy's estranged sister? Or she could have been a bartender who befriended both of these guys? This was the only part of the film that I thought could have used changing. Nice to see DeCaprio finally maturing enough to play believable adult roles.

title: Scorsese's Best Directing Oscar... Finally...
review:
This was an intense, off the edge of your seat, runaway train of pure excitement about two police officers; one molded by the Irish mob (Damon) to be an inside probe in the police department and the other was molded by the police department (DiCaprio) to be an undercover in the same Irish mob.

The Irish mob was led by the extraordinary Jack Nicholson in one of his best performances since "As Good As It Gets." Leonardo DiCaprio and Matt Damon both give great performances, as the stressed out, under appreciated police officers, playing opposite sides of the law and trying to do their jobs to satisfy the powers that be.

However, it was Scorcese's directing that brought this complex piece about the philosophies behind modern crime, the law and police corruption, that takes this piece to the next level. This has to be his best work since "Goodfellas" and I'm hoping that he receives a long, overdue Academy Award for Best Director.

The only reason why the film doesn't get a ten from me is because I had issues with the ending. I won't give it away. However, in my humble opinion, it was too easy for the characters played by Damon, DiCaprio and Mark Wahlberg, and it's contrivance eerily reflects the assumed angst by the writers to end a screenplay to a magnificently crafted, complex story. I'm sure the original film was the same way, so I'm critiquing the filmmakers behind "Infernal Affairs" for this as well.

Nevertheless, it's still the best film I had seen all year thus far.

title: Overall an excellent movie ruined by the ending.
review: This is one of the best movies I've seen in some time. I thought that the performance of Leonard DiCaprio was phenomenal, really exceptional. Matt Damon was, Matt Damon. Jack Nicholson was a perfect choice for this character. He played it with the right amount of malice and psychopathology. The dialog was witty, real, and engrossing,; the use of the Whitey Bulger background, etc. was a nice touch, and were it not for the final 30 seconds, this could be a 9 or 10. However, the departure from a comparable ending to "Infernal Affairs" for a non-ambiguous, "righteous" finality ruined this for me. It seems that American audiences require that justice be served or something. The ambiguity of the original is what made it such a great story.

title: Same problem as with "The Aviator". Scorcese won't take home the Oscar.
review:
The Departed - The Departed is set in South Boston, where the state police force is waging war on Irish-American organized crime. Young undercover cop Billy Costigan (DiCaprio) is assigned to infiltrate the mob syndicate run by gangland chief Frank Costello (Nicholson). While Billy quickly gains Costello's confidence, Colin Sullivan (Damon), a hardened young criminal who has infiltrated the police department as an informer for the syndicate, is rising to a position of power in the Special Investigation Unit.

First off, this movie has the usual strengths of a Scorcese film. Firstly, a strong performance from Dicaprio and downright brilliant performances from the supporters .In The Aviator it was Cate Blanchett, in The Departed it is Jack Nicholson. My god, the man has created such a chilling and funny villain that somehow avoids being over-the top. Believe it or not, I didn't loath him half as much as I hated Matt Damon's character Colin Sullivan. The man was such a weasely runt of a social climber that one couldn't help but hate him. The film also has strong support from Mark Wahlberg as a trash-talking sergeant, Martin Sheen as Captain Queenan, and Alec Baldwin in a serious movie for once (in the last few years) it seems.

The film also has a strong script and great camera work. The violence is sparingly used but effective. The film's drawback is Scorcese's continual mistake: He doesn't know when enough is enough. He gets too leisurely with the pace of his films, and doesn't know how to make me sit through them either. It wasn't as weary long as The Aviator, but I was still looking at my imaginary watch far too many times. The movie's two and a half hours long, but it felt even longer. People always lament that Scorzese never takes home The Best Film Award, and this is the reason: He continually turns in the A- film, but different people keep on turning in the A film each year.

A very good film, but I was happiest when The Departed finally departed. It gets an A-

title: Wahlberg Rocks
review:
Nicholson, Damon, DiCaprio, Baldwin, Sheen--all do their thing great, but not since Glengarry Glen Ross has an actor stepped into a scene and commanded everyone's full attention. Walhberg steals every scene he's in...how ironic he does it with Alec Baldwin standing there. Definitely best supporting actor this year! I was so happy to see that with such a large cast, everyone's screen time was meaningful to the story. Sometimes directors do not know how to do that well. With this film, Scorcese takes us to school and it is a great lesson I really appreciated.

Some of the editing was too abrupt, sometimes the quick music changes were too distracting.

Overall, a great cop and criminal story that should not be missed.

title: Good movie
review:
For every HK people, The Departed must be one of the movies that most yearned for. But many HKers find it disappointing as Departed did not bring out the marrow of the original -- both moles living in "wo jin dao" (the Chinese name of the original, meaning the lowest level of the hell) -- and lost the tension between the FOUR leading roles -- Ming (Billy in Departed), Yan (Colin), Sam (Costello) and Wong (missing character, the role is functionally shared by Martin Sheen and Mark Walhberg). Without these two elements, Departed, from my point of view, is only a good, entertaining, well performed movie.

The Departed has shortened the time that Billy was put in the gang (nine years in the original to one), weakening the complexity of Billy's situation that he may not be able to turn back to be a good guy. And it makes Colin's fast lifting career less logical.

After erasing Wong's role, the film just losses the "cat" in the "cat catching mice" game, leaving Costello an ordinary but crazy gang boss, while in the original, the interaction between Sam (Costello's role) and Wong is a very interesting line.

One more thing, about the micro chip scene, it just doesn't make sense that the Chinese speak Cantonese for such a deal by PRC agency. They should speak Mandarin!!! Cantonese is only used in Hong Kong, and part of the Guangdong Province!!! And if they really want to use Cantonese, please find somebodies that speak REAL Cantonese!!! What they are speaking is like English-accent Cantonese and every people in the cinema just cannot stop laughing at their tone. And the script is wrong in meaning too, such that "fong de cheong" (meaning put down the guns) was read as "fong cheong" (don't have such phase in Cantonese, but somewhat implies the meaning of "to fire").

title: Boston!!!
review:
Okay. The fact that this movie is a remake, and an AMAZING film is already well covered territory here by the time I'm writing this. I'm going to address the film's realism in relation to it's setting. I grew up in Boston. I love Boston, it will always be home, no matter where I live. I came up in a neighborhood pretty similar to the one depicted in the movie, and spent some time in that neighborhood (S. Boston). I've seen comments here (by others from the Boston area) implying that Boston isn't like the one depicted in the film. Well, maybe out in Wellesley, where you grew up, it isn't. I have NEVER seen a more accurate depiction of actual Bostonians in my life. The dialog between these guys is absolutely on the money, and never before have I ever seen it quite captured. Bostonians have a seemingly magical ability to express both love and hate in the same hilarious sentence in a way that I have never witnessed elsewhere. Aside from enjoying the film for it's MANY other virtues, it was like a three hour trip home. For that I am quite grateful.

Oh, I almost forgot. Dicaprio was BRILLIANT. I had serious doubts going in as to whether he could pull this off. Walking out of the theater, I was speechless. I absolutely, 100% bought him as a kid from Southie trying to do the right thing. I'll never doubt him as an actor again.

title: Brilliant
review: Everything was perfect about this film except for the girl. I can't decide if it was poor casting, horrible acting or she just wasn't ready for this caliber film. Although her presence wasn't irritating enough for me not to enjoy this movie, it really made me question the professional opinion of who looked at her and thought... "yes, she's perfect." DiCaprio, Wahlberg, Damon, Nicholson & Baldwin gave masterful performances...even the supporting cast (with the exception of the girl) gave applause-worthy performance. Visually stunning. I expected nothing less from Scorscese. This film is the epitome of what film-making should be and it was long overdue from Hollywood. A film that makes you recall that film-making is an art-form. Although there were parts that made me cringe, I could respect their necessity and move on because I was thoroughly engaged in the rest of the film. I recommend that every true fan of films, film student, and respecter of fine art go see this movie and if you know Scorscese you know its not for the faint of heart think more Casino/Goodfellas/Raging Bull/Gangs of New York rather than Aviator or anything else he's done.

title: Scorsese is simply at the top of his game!
review:
When I heard Scorsese was remaking Internal Afairs, I thought he was reworking the 1990 Andy Garcia/Richard gere film which displays ho much I know ignorance of Hong Kong cinema. I must admit I have still not seen the original Hong Kong version, not because of any conscious decision but only because I was determined not to know anything the plot before I see Scorsese's film. The end result is simply explosive, and exhilarating cinema. Scorsese expertly handles the narrative, inter cutting between the two protagonists, one sent to infiltrate a vicious mob, and the other planted in the police force as an asset for syphoning information for the eccentric mob leader. The first half of the film builds slowly, as with Scorsese's films, taking it't time to unravel slowly and setting out the intricacies of the story and the character's various backgrounds. Nicholson is in eccentric mode as the boisterous gang leader Costello, but the hour belongs to Damon as Sullivan, the deceptively charming career orientated mole in the police department. Having said that, Di Caprio, perhaps shunning the weightier and more complex role of Sllivan, does a competent job at keeping a low profile as Costigan, the undercover police agent living on the edge.

The film, however, really comes alive in the second half, when Sullivan reaches the pinnacle of power in the police department and Costigan is on the verge of being revealed as the rat in Costello's gang. The film bears all the whole marks of the Scorsese's earlier work. Scorsese masters the camera like no other, and the editing is wizardry. However, one of the least talked about Scorsese talent, is the ability to select the right type of music track to set the tone of the film. I bet his record collection at home is to die for!

title: good movie
review: but not original. Scorsese simply adapted the plot of "Mou gaan dou", a Hong Kong Gangster movie of 2002. Down to the detail of the two guys hang out by the street joking about spotting cops. At the very beginning of the movie they gave a bit of credit to Media Asia. Overall a great adaption, I think most people went to see Jack Nicholson. Leonardo DeCaprio's best act so far. As it doesn't make sense for most people to seek out the original movie, go watch this one. Personally I think the original one has a more developed plot. This one was rushed a bit at the end. Farmiga's role was somehow confusing. But well, didn't go in to see Analyze that.

title: Amazing directing, writing, casting and acting
review: Although it was a bit long, I found the movie extremely entertaining. Amazing directing, writing, casting and acting !! And there were some great comedy lines...in fact, from a comedy standpoint, Alec Baldwin stole the show. I laughed my ass off at some of his lines. Of course a close second was Nicolson. Highly recommended, but you better be ready for some true Scorcese-style violence !! Nicolson was excellent. DiCaprio was excellent. Baldwin was excellent. Walberg was good. Damen was not annoying. The music was very good, but I prefer the original version of Dark Side of the Moon (Floyd). I highly recommend this film to anyone who loves Nicolson, Baldwin, or DiCaprio.

title: Yay! Another Leo Movie to See!
review:
I am surprised I liked this movie as much as I did. Well, I thought it was very well written, and funny--badly funny, like why am I laughing at jokes like this kind of funny, because it's such a dark movie.

When I found out that Leonardo DiCaprio was going to be working with Jack Nicholson I was so happy for him. I figured he would be excited at the chance, so I was excited for him. He held his own and he has a lot to be proud of, but why wouldn't he do well? He's one of the few talented actors out there worth paying $9.75 to see.

When I saw that Mark Wahlberg was in this movie, with Leonardo DiCaprio, all I was thinking of was the movie Basketball Diaries. They haven't worked together since then. I was pleasantly surprised to see the two working together again.

If you can call this a spoiler to the movie, here it is: The movie is very violent and bloody, but that's Martin Scorsese for you--it's not like I went in expecting Mary Had a Little Lamb or anything. If you see this movie, just remember, it's not for the faint of heart. At nearly the end of the movie, I gasped and put my hand up to my face, but there were a lot of times I could have done the same thing.

title: Irish GoodFellas?
review: I've heard a lot of people say that this movie is like an Irish Goodfellas, but thats only because of the level of violence, which is comparable. I would say that The Departed is a better story. The juxtaposition between the two main characters, Damon and Dicaprio,is something that I've never seen done as well before. To top it off Jack Nicholson plays a great psychotic villain (for want of a better term). The cast is rounded out by Martin Sheen and Alec Baldwin, who play their characters amazingly. The big surprise was Whalberg for me. I can never really buy his acting when he's trying to be a tough guy but in this case he knocks it out of the park. Like all Scorsese the sound track is excellent and the violence is jarring, in a real good way. I highly recommend it. I think it is a better movie than goodfellas, but I doubt The Departed will get the classic praise which GoodFellas did.

title: Incredible Movie
review: This movie has Oscar written all over it. I had to go to the restroom so bad but was afraid to leave my seat for fear of missing something. This was the most thought provoking, intriguing film that I've seen in years. It's a movie you can't quite figure out, there are so many twist and turns. One minute you think you go it and boom you are dead wrong. Top notch actors are in the film and what can you say about Nicholson, his performance is outstanding. I usually don't care that much about DiCaprio, but he even impressed me with his performance. Scorsese has outdone himself with this one. I have told everybody I know that love movies to go see Departed. I plan to go see it again, its just that good!

title: Fantastic film
review:
This movie is spectacular, in almost everything it does. The script is solid, the acting is good, action and suspense is tense. This movie is packed with scenes that will make you go WTF! Everything from Nicholson's over the top psycho mob boss, to Mark Walhberg excessive use of expletives to further his point in the movie.

Previous to this movie I regard Dicaprio as an over actor whose career wouldn't go farther then it has already. He was okay in Gangs of New York, but he was horrid in Titanic and Romeo & Juliet. In this film he plays his part just right. He offers the right amount of tense anxiety, mixed with despair, to puncture a hole in your senses and make you feel for the character, constantly fearing that he will be discovered. Matt Damon plays his part well to, but not as well as Dicaprio. He plays his paranoid undercover mobster role with a sense of panic that fills the viewer with a sense of despise for his character. Nicholson, the main villain plays it just how you would imagine, trust me when I say that is a good thing. He brings his acting to such a point that you think that he is insane. You despise him through the movie but you cannot truly hate him because he brings a charm and sophisticated insanity to his roll others would be hard pressed to do. Wahlberg, Sheen, Baldwin, and Farmiga also do a great job to support the leading cast with each character bringing the right amount of emotion to the screen. But special nods go to Anthony Anderson, who may have just broken out of his lame phase with bad action films (Exit Wounds anyone).

Frankly this film is bound for the Oscars with at least three possible nominations for supporting actor.

Definitely go check this out, you will thank your self for doing this.

title: What an amazing movie
review:
So this is the first review I've done for IMDb, and I'm not gonna lie, I feel like I need to do it for this movie. I love reading the boards and everything here, but many people forget what movies are about. They are about ENJOYMENT. Plain and simple. And The Departed is an enjoyable movie, very, very much so.

The only thing to say about it is go and see it. The cast top to bottom is amazing, from Leo and Jack down to Alec Baldwin and Martin Sheen. Too many times guys like Leo or Matt Damon or Mark Whalberg are given a bad rap cause of their "pretty faces." Thats too bad because all three are excellent actors, and all three deliver steller performances in this film. So far this year, of the films I have seen, this movie is the best. Thats why I gave it a nine, and thats just to be on the safe side. Believe me it won't be a waste of money to see this one film, if no other film, this year.

title: Here I go again
review:
Can you say "piss poor" in a review? Here we have an infiltrator into a gang organisation on one side and the plant in the police department on the other. Not a bad premise, but so ineptly put together that neither side could discover the villain without the help of audience. Phony Boston accents, ham acting, very poor plot line and too much reliance on expletives. I usually like swearing in a movie but in this one it was just used to cover script deficiencies. To say that it is a mediocre film is being too free with compliments.

Put up a few big names and you've got a hit right?

Wrong.

This was a bummer right from the getgo ; Nicholson mailed in his performance, Winstone completely miscast, DeCaprio OK and what'sisface Damon only marginally better. The trouble with Mr Wahlberg is that you can't tell whether or not it's actually him, a cardboard cutout or a CGI. It doesn't really matter because none of the three do anything to improve the project.

Sheen was pathetic and his Boston accent was like a cinder caught under a door.(the other attempts at Boston accents weren't much better, only Matt Damon's was real .. and even though he grew up there it was exaggerated to match the other speech-coached "Siri" effect)

As for the plot, gimme a freakin' break will ya. If either side couldn't find the rat in the first five minutes, then neither the police nor the gangsters deserved to hold down their jobs.

A waste of time and money, you could make a better movie with your iphone

At least it's a new genre... crime mush

title: Beyond Overrated
review: A ridiculous movie, often unintentionally hilarious in too many spots. Nicholson is wasted, and his accent is ludicrous. Many fine actors offering their worst performances, and an even worse story. John Woo did it much better.

title: Nobody But Me!
review:
Martin Scorsese is more sentimental about the mob than Margaret Mitchell ever was about the Ku Klux Klan. On the other hand, where else can you see Leonardo DiCaprio looking sexy and beating up on a helpless storekeeper while dancing to the sounds of "Nobody But Me" by the Human Beinz?

Eat your heart out, Malcolm McDowell!

title: i think the DIRECTOR IS MAD
review: how could they made a movie like that i gave 3 stars because of leonardo ,this movie is a piece of crap.i prefer that you do not watch this movie there was no sense in the movie .if you read this then i recommend you to not see this movie really otherwise you would regret wasting your 151 minutes .what you would say is "i would much rather with star wars series than with this full of crap movie

title: What if it hadn't been Scorsese?
review:
I watched this movie last night and before all I have to say, that I haven't seen Infernal Affairs, but I will as soon as possible.

Martin Scorsese is a great director. The directing in The Departed is great. Not his best but very good. The departed will never get close to Raging Bull or Goodfellas in my opinion.

When I watched the movie last night, I was very curious and excited. Before I watch movies I look at their ratings here at IMDb and mostly the ratings reflect my opinion. But this time the ratings got me all wrong. This movie is totally overrated.

The story starts very nice. You get excited, you get curious. You wanna know what happens next and it all your expectations just don't get realized.

Jack Nicholson is a great boss, but is he a big boss or a smaller one who still collects protection money? In the beginning they talk about microchips and you never know what happened to them. It doesn't make sense at all! Why do they want to get Castello when he only does small business? What about the ending? I thought Vanilla Sky or Secret Window had the worst endings ever but The Departed is not far away from them.

Maybe that is why I didn't like the movie. You don't get what you expect. And maybe if there was a better ending, you could remain blind to little inlogical contents of the script.

But it's not a good ending and I was really disappointed. The story is great. But the outwork is crap.

If you want to see good acting and perfect directing watch this film. But if you are into good story, nice messages and thrilling ends or twists... don't waste your time.

title: As good as it gets . .
review: Yes, I know it is the title of another great Nicholson movie but this really 'is as good as it gets'!! Another terrific Scorsese movie with an even better cast. Great storyline, great action and great twists. This is one of those MUST HAVE movies to have in your DVD collection. Just watch it!! Every character plays their part - I can even forgive Ray Winstone's dodgy accent! Or maybe I'm just to used to hearing 'cockney' Ray. Di Caprico, Nicholson, Damon, Sheen, Winstone, Wahlberg (best yet?),Baldwin . . as well as being a who's who of Hollywood they ALL turn in tremendous performance's that just leave you wishing the movie would never end.I cannot think of a better way to spend 2.1/2 hours - like the great Dutch football side of the 70's who invented 'total football' this has to be TOTAL CINEMA!!

title: Phenomenal.
review:
Even through about ten viewings, The Departed manages to be a highly engaging, suspenseful and thrilling film that's easily one of the most entertaining films I've ever seen. Scorsese creates an entire ensemble of interesting (some more so than others) characters that make every second just as fun and enthralling as the rest. When we switch from Costigan to Sullivan it never loses or gains entertainment value and its steady level is higher than practically any other film around. There's a wonderful mix of humor involved as well, coming primarily from Mark Wahlberg, Alec Baldwin and Jack Nicholson (more in the character's reactions to Nicholson than the man himself). Everyone in the cast is brilliant from DiCaprio and Damon all the way down to Alec Baldwin and Ray Winstone (though I've never been too big on Vera Farmiga and thought she was a thousand times better in that year's Running Scared).

In my first viewings of The Departed, I knew it was wildly entertaining but I always thought it was a little shallow and the characters lacked depth. But this viewing helped me see that what I originally thought was a thrilling story of undercover deception is really an intricate study of the loneliness and mental breakdown that occurs when you decide to live a lie. As William Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio) and Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon) delve further into their life of being an undercover criminal and an undercover cop, respectively, they become so much more lonely and their psyche continually falls apart. While these two character's lives are polar opposites, they are quite similar at their center. They are both morally decent men who live a life of crime for unfortunate reasons; Costigan obviously because he is an undercover cop but Sullivan seems to be a good man at his heart but lives his life of deception out of loyalty to Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson) who was always a surrogate father to him after he lost his own. Of course they do have their contrasts which I thought came primarily in their way of making decisions. Costigan is indecisive, paranoid and is never confident in his decisions but Sullivan has snap reflexes and can make an insanely tough decision in a second with no hesitation. But in the end they are more similar than they are different; they even have romantic interest in the same woman. Ultimately it's their loneliness that links these two men; which Scorsese beautifully shows in the shots of Sullivan sitting in his office alone in the dark having to live with the horrific decisions he's made in his life (further proof that he's a morally decent man unlike the purely evil Frank who shoots a woman dead and his only remark is that she fell funny).

So while the film is still probably the most entertaining I've ever seen and is stylish, fun and completely enthralling my original belief that it was hollow was quite incorrect. It's a remarkable study of the toll that a life of lies can take on a person and is highlighted by two phenomenal performances that perfectly immerse into these characters. In fact every actor fits perfectly into his character. It never feels like you're watching Leonardo DiCaprio, Mark Wahlberg and Alec Baldwin but you're watching the characters unfold this story. Even in ten viewings it still manages to be completely suspenseful (Damon and DiCaprio sitting silently on the phone with each other, both knowing that the person on the other side is the rat, still had me holding my breath) and wildly entertaining. There's never a dull moment in this magnificent picture that I love more and more every time I see it, and that love was significantly increased in this viewing. I don't think any words can do the story justice, but there is so much depth and intricacy in there that I never saw before. And of course William Monahan does a perfect job of adapting the originally Asian story into the streets and people of Boston. Amazing in every way.

title: A true great, I loved every minute of this great film!
review:
In my list of favourite films ever (I don't believe that you can have just one true favourite film, but a select few!) This movie was simply brilliant, great acting, great directing, great production, and most important (for me) a truly great storyline which left you clinging to your seat right to the very end. A "I didn't see that coming" sort of movie, very well directed, quite difficult to follow the first time round till the very end, but gets better every time you watch it. Have seen it many times now and it just doesn't get boring, with Jack Nickleson in, how can it be a bad film? For me, he made the movie, and I thought he has done a great job of acting out a true gangster character.

For me this is what Cinema is all about!

title: Be warned - this is a scorsese movie
review: Given the sheer mass of acting talent in this movie I think Scorsese has completely out done himself to create something thats for the most part boring. Yet again the sheer scale and charisma of the actors have carried his bad directing and shocking dialogue. I cannot emphasise enough how patchy this movie is - any scene thats enjoyable is followed by some amateurish gibberish that just makes you want to run up to Scorsese and hit him with a bread stick. Given my rant, the plot is OK for the most part and makes me really want to read the book. The actors cant really be blamed for the bad dialogue, aside from matt damon who just drains your energy with his shocking facial expressions and poor performance. If you *must* see this movie make sure you're not the one paying for the DVD caus you're guaranteed to feel like you wont get that money back.

title: Best movie of 2000's
review:
Oh god what should i say...This movie is gr8, gr8, gr8!!! I recommend this movie to everyone who likes crime and undercover movies. You'll love this. I'm 20 and I did.

The cast was one of the best in years. MARK WAHLBERG was my favorite although others were also great including Jack Nicholson.

The original Chinese film SUCKS! believe me. I must say that "THE DEPARTED" is the best movie of the decade. Just see this amazing movie and u don't wanna watch garbages like "Crash", "Lord of the Rings", "Million Dollar Baby", or even "Litle Miss Sunshine" or any other crappy films that won the Best-Picture award.

10+/10

"Don't laugh! This ain't reality TV!" -Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson), "The Departed"

title: first five minutes are the best part of the film
review: This film is not in any way up the standards of him magnum opus "Goodfellas" or even that early gem "Mean Streets". What we got here is a very nasty, vicious and gruesome film with a musical-chairs killing ending that rivals the final scenes of "Taxi Driver". The only bit of authenticity, aside from the Boston location, and I live West of Boston, is the accent of Costello's mistress: all of the other principles are too polished in their speech and mannerisms to give much credibility to the film, which was not the case with "Mean Streets", but then again the director comes from NYC and was cognizant of the subtle characteristics that lend credence to the work. I could go on like this but will end my comment by saying that my opinion is that the Academy felt compelled to reward this piece of dreck because they felt guilty at not bestowing awards on "Goodfellas", a justly-deserved masterpiece.

title: Brilliant, Gripping Crime Drama
review:
The Godfather. Goodfellas. LA Confidential. Pulp Fiction. Scarface. These movies stand tall among the greatest gangster dramas ever made. Each of them features a gripping story, complex characters, and a memorable tale of intricate passion and power. The Departed will take its place among these greats and stands tall as Martin Scorcese's greatest achievement yet.

There is a rather large cast in The Departed, but if it were to be boiled down to three main protagonists, they would be Billy Costigan, played by Leonardo DiCaprio, Colin Sullivan, played by Matt Damon, and Frank Costello, played by Jack Nicholson. Costello is a rich, powerful, Irish mob boss. Costigan is an undercover cop who wheedles his way into Costello's inner circle, which includes an undercover gangster working in the police department, Sullivan. The Departed follows the investigation into Costello's mob work, Sullivan's interplay with Costello, and Costigan's growing guilt and inner torture over the things he must do and see as an undercover cop.

One the The Departed finest aspects is the stellar acting from virtually every member of the all-star cast. Leonardo DiCaprio turns in one of the most impressive performances of his already impressive career. He portrays the tortured Billy Costigan to perfection. Matt Damon continues his unbroken string of masterful performances as Costello's mole in the police. Unfortunately, Jack Nicholson turns in one of the most disgustingly over-the-top performances I had seen in awhile. It looks like he's begging for an Oscar with the way he tries to come across, but all that I kept on seeing was Jack Nicholson playing himself. What could have been a deep and complex character turns into nothing more than showboating at its worst. The character he plays is complex enough, but Nicholson does not give it nearly enough justice. Mark Wahlberg, Alec Baldwin, and Martin Sheen all turn in their own noteworthy performances, most of all Wahlberg, and though he doesn't get much screen time, still manages to portray his character to its full depth and potential. Alec Baldwin's role is almost funny in how close it comes to self-parody, and Martin Sheen plays the head investigator Queenan with a serious fun Character is another impressive aspect of The Departed. Every last character is fleshed out, full, complex, and detailed. The closest thing that any character comes to one-dimensional is the cop psychologist, Matt Damon's love interest. She is supposed to be this amazingly brilliant woman, but she just comes across as irrational and careless as she eagerly dives into dangerous relationships and situations right and left. Aside from her, though, the other characters are sketched out perfectly. Ellerby, Dignam, and Queenan (Baldwin, Wahlberg, and Sheen), though secondary characters, still feel like completely real people. Damon's character of Sullivan is wonderfully drawn. Costello, as I already mentioned, is almost ruined by Jack Nicholson, but he still manages to shine a bit of his complexity through the ruinous vehicle of Nicholson. Most interesting is Dicaprio's multi-dimensional Costigan, who is the most interesting and multi-faceted character I have seen in a film in a long time. He's not the typical cop who's feeling guilty over coming dangerously close to becoming a criminal. He is this and so much more and the huge complexity of his character could easily have been fumbled by a lesser actor than DiCaprio. It's beautifully pulled off, though.

The intricate interplay of characters and the complex twists and turns in the film are another hallmark of its greatness. This is not some straightforward crime drama. There will be surprises. There will be twists. But more than this, everything, all these aspects, all work together to grab us in at the outset and to never let go. The storyline is positively riveting in its intensity and uncompromising vision of the dark underworld of crime. We have seen this before in films, portrayed especially wonderfully in the films mentioned above, and The Departed is no less great or capable than those others. At two hours and twenty minutes, it doesn't even stretch its waistline or overstay its welcome. It's just the right length. Usually any movie that goes over two hours overstays its welcome plenty, but The Departed is a notable exception. It is a very clean, streamlined movie. This being said, though, it is not a perfect one.

Jack Nicholson's performance drags the whole show down more than any one aspect. If it hadn't been for him, the film could have been so much better. The character of Madolyn comes across as two clear and one-dimensional in comparison to the rest of the cast. Besides this, though, Scorcese seems preoccupied with all the horror and evil that goes on in this world, while never really focusing in on the good. He touches on it in brief tender moments between Costigan and Madolyn and Sullivan and Madolyn, but he never focuses there. Scorcese obviously prefers to show us the brutality and debauchery of this world, which is fine if that is his vision for the film. A more clean and hopeful view, though, could have helped the bleakness a little.

Fine performances have always been the hallmark of greatness in films. The cast of the Departed is one of the best to come along in a long while. (If it weren't for that darn Jack!!) Its storyline is not simplistic or overly violent for the sake of violence. Everything, every line, every action, every moment serves a purpose and serves to drive the vehicle of the film forward. The gripping, dark score does its part well in this as well. The complex and multi-faceted characters interacting and clashing on screen have been some of the most real and fleshed-out characters that I have ever seen on celluloid. True, it has its flaws, but as a gangster crime drama thriller, these days, it really has no equal.

title: I am one of the 15 % who is not raving how great this film is
review:
I cannot quite believe that over 85 % of all the viewers gave this a rating of 8 or higher,. I must have seen a different print.

My rating of 3 stars,86 points & IMDb grade of 7 means this is a GOOD film,

It is gratuitously violent, with overly excessive use of certain curse words, ,Even though I am 78 years young, I do not have too much objection to violence or cursing, BUT the screenplay carries it way over the top.

THAT DEAR READERS DOES NOT MAKE A GREAT FILM.

The Departed does have a great cast & all give top notch performances, Leo DeCaprio, Jack Nicholson,Matt Damon, Martion Sheen, Alec Baldwin,Mark Wahlburg, & Vern Farninga ( I hope that is the way it is spelled) are first rate actors, A few pf them could even read the Phone book & be great doing so,.

Martin Scorcese directed this in his usual first rat manner, BUT this is not an Oscar winning film or direction. If he wins the Oscar it will be because he has been nominated 7 times & has not one one Oscar.

The balance of the production credits are also first rate.the film is long though & could have been edited sharper,.SPOILER COMING UP

The violent ending,leave only one of the above mentioned cast alive.This movie was based on the first part of the Chinese Trilogy INFERNAL AFFAIRS which I haven't seen yet: so what the do I just do not know.

rating *** out of 4: 86 points out of 100 IMDb 7 out of 10

title: Never again
review:
From time to time I watch a movie, because I trust the good reviews and also because I think, I should watch not always the same kind of movies. Usually I avoid violent movies.

What shall I say? That I was wrong to trust the good reviews? That I have no idea,what is going on in the world? If anything, what was portrayed in this movie, is going on in the real world, we are really doomed. I thought, the Iraq disaster was bad enough. But obviously the members of police departments are a bunch of corrupt, constantly swearing, murdering thugs, every citizen should avoid to have any contact with.

Commenter before me have pointed out the many improbably scenarios. But if any of this should be based on real events, I will look as quickly as possible to emigrate to another country.

title: Very good movie, but....
review: I enjoyed this movie for all the reasons everyone else did, so I won't list all that was good about it. However, I did feel the plot had one major flaw, which made the film less enjoyable: If the cops had been following Jack Nicholson and his crew for years, how is it that they had no idea who Matt Damon was? How could they have not known of his existence way before he even ever joined the police force? Since the whole premise of the film was for Leo and Matt Damon to find each other, it seemed a bit ludicrous that they wouldn't know who Matt Damon was to begin with. If anyone has a good explanation for this, I would be happy to hear it. Other than this one thing, it's still a great movie.

title: Way worse than the original
review: I don't understand why people give "Departed" such high ratings. The Hong Kong original "Infernal Affairs" was way better than this. The acting in this movie doesn't seem to be very authentic, and the plot is similar to "Infernal Affairs", but less complicated. I wants't even too impressed with "Infernal Affairs", but I thought it was a lot better than "the Departed". Personally, I think "Infernal Affairs 2" was the best of the 3 "Infernal Affairs" series. I recommend people to the 3 "Infernal Affairs" movie before judging how "good" this movie is. Unlike "Good Fellas" this movie isn't original nor is it based on a true story. Peronally I would give this movie a 3/10 if it wasn't for the fact a awful remake of "Infernal Affair". Since it is a bad movie with unoriginal ideas. I gave it a 1/10. I am not trying to offend anyone who is a fan of the movie. Thank you.

title: Over-rated!
review:
I cannot understand why this movie's rating is so high. I saw it in a theater, somewhat "against my will" and hated it. I kept thinking "there has to be a payoff" at the end (to compensate for how ordinary the first hour was). Instead it just got worse.

When the rat scurries along the railing, my boss (who had dragged me to the movie) said to me, "see, that makes sense, doesn't it?" My reply was that it was the only thing I'd seen in the last 30 minutes that made sense.

Are you fascinated by the lurid violence? Are only Scorsese fans going to it and voting? The only movie he's made that I liked was Cape Fear, and even that felt like a guilty pleasure.

title: Jack Nickelson plays a Irish underground crime lord in Boston, who has set up his own connections in the Police Force (Matt Daemon), but the police want to spy on him.
review:
This movie was actually not that bad. It has its pros and cons. The movie had great camera people, which included a great plot, and amazing acting. All of that made up for the "cheesy" film, and language Sailors would jump to imitate. If you choose to see this movie, be prepared for literally close to a hundred F bombs, and close to 10 very bloody headshots. In fact, just be prepared for buckets of blood throughout the film.

It also may help to bring a notebook, to avoid from losing the plot. The movie jumps constantly from each side, and includes random frames of murder, which have voices to remotely explain whats going on. The characters often show up later, so remember the faces.

title: Not that significant
review:
Being out of the country at the moment I hadn't been inundated with the hype of this movie (which I think is a good thing). It was a Martin Scorsese movie following the irish mob and corrupt police: my probable expectation was a focus on extreme depravity and violence.

Boy was I right. The violence was extremely graphic and I believe distracted from the story which I thought was of a semi first rate b movie quality. It was entertaining, don't get me wrong. The acting was exceptional, including the (usually ridiculously over done) late age Jack Nicholson, the (usually adolescent) Leonardo Dicaprio and the rapper turned "actor" Mark Wahlberg. Even Alec Baldwin showed up to make some wise cracks which I thought lent the movie it's b quality qualities (are b movies worthless ? I don't really think so). The movie crackled with an energy and I have to admit I did not look at my watch until about the second hour of the movie (which usually for me means I have been thoroughly entertained).

The bad part of it is of course the violence, which I feel Scorsese must love to portray, because his movies are sadistically concentrated on graphic acts of violence. Why this is and why he loves violence so much is probably more for his psychiatrist to figure out (if he is seeing one, which I think he should be). The fact that so many people are lavishing praise on this movie and ranking this as the 161st best movie EVER MADE is probably a sign that the apocalypse is upon us. I do not think a society desensitized to violence is really that great of a sign. The head shots to the various unlucky people were out in the open and not disguised at all, nothing was cut away. Was he hoping to make a statement about how disgusting violence is ? Didn't translate to me if he was.

Anyhow, the movie was silly and there were many unintentional laughs, one being the secret dealing with Chinese terrorists. The movie was completely over the top and wholly, insignificant. I know Scorsese has rarely deals with deep issues in his movies (other than alienation in Taxi Driver), but I think he is a great film director and should probably try dealing with more "internal" issues (and I don't mean internal organs of people blowing against the wall).

title: The Departed / a total copy of Infernal Affairs
review:
All star cast with best director of all time brings you a great movie. Interesting movie with a slight twist. However, this movie was a total bite of the award winning Hong Kong movie Infernal Affairs which stars Andy Lau and Tony Leung. A story between a mole in the police department and an undercover cop. Their objectives are the same: to find out who is the mole, and who is the cop. Matt Damon and Leonardo playing the parts of Andy Lau and Tony Leung. Infernal Affair can be found on this website for review. This movie Which is couple of years old would be recommend that movie which has a sequel and a prequel. Leonardo Dicaprio is all grown up, great acting from all the actors Martin Scorcese seem to have adopted Leonardo Dicaprio in his recent movies.

Cant wait to see what he comes out with next

title: Scorsese's best film since "GoodFellas"; one of the year's absolute best films
review:
THE DEPARTED (2006) **** Leonardo Di Caprio, Matt Damon, Jack Nicholson, Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen, Ray Winstone, Vera Farmiga, Anthony Anderson, Alec Baldwin, Kevin Corrigan. Excellent Americanized adaptation of the Hong Kong policier "Infernal Affairs" envisioned with a sharp resonance, brutal no-flinching violence and well-rounded characters, from master filmmaker Martin Scorsese (his best since "GoodFellas") embedded with a top- notch cast and a gritty screenplay by William Monahan depicting two powerful worlds in Boston: the cops and the gangs with a twist: rookie cop Di Caprio is groomed to be a mole to infiltrate violent thug Nicholson's enclave while his own right-hand protégée Damon is sent into the police force to gain information to keep one step ahead of their on-going investigation to but to rest the years long reign of Jack. Excellent acting by all around; a particular wild card in the unlikely form of Wahlberg. One of the year's absolute best.

Sheen, Ray Winstone, Vera Farmiga, Anthony Anderson, Alec Baldwin, Kevin Corrigan. Excellent Americanized adaptation of the Hong Kong policier "Infernal Affairs" envisioned with a sharp resonance, brutal no-flinching violence and well-rounded characters, from master filmmaker Martin Sheen (his best since "GoodFellas") embedded with a top-notch cast and a gritty screenplay by William Monahan depicting two powerful worlds in Boston: the cops and the gangs with a twist: rookie cop Di Caprio is groomed to be a mole to infiltrate violent thug Nicholson's enclave while his own right-hand protégée Damon is sent into the police force to gain information to keep one step ahead of their on-going investigation to but to rest the years long reign of Jack. Excellent acting by all around; a particular wild card in the unlikely form of Wahlberg. One of the year's absolute best.

title: Simply put, a Hollywood rip-off of Infernal Affairs
review:
I must admit, I saw this movie before I saw the original - 'Infernal Affairs' - and thought it was good. Mainly, I thought that the plot was very interesting and unique. I never really thought that this film needed so much swearing and gore to make it good, but in Hollywood, those two things are the only reasons why people watch films. However,once I watched the original version - 'Infernal Affairs' - I was really turned off to The Departed for a number of reasons.

1. The Departed literally took the script from Infernal Affairs and stuck a bunch of big-name Hollywood actors in it, but kept everything else the exact same. I would say about 80% of the movie was simply regurgitated from the original (including some of the actual lines), and I thought that was d tacky and disrespectful on the part of Scorsese. I would expect more from a film maker of his caliber.

2. The script here is so rushed and unrealistic. Unlike in Infernal Affairs (were the movie is stretched out over 10 years), The Departed takes place over what appears to be a few months to a year. What is so stupid about this is that we are lead to believe that a mole was able to work his way from a nobody newbie in a mafia gang, to the Boss's second hand man in that short of a time. All I have to say about that is 'bull sh*t'. That would NEVER happen, and everyone knows that.

3. I didn't buy into all the over-the-top characters in the Departed. It is like all of the actors thought they were the lead role, and nobody was willing to take a supporting cast. This leads to constant theatrical rants and over acting by most of the cast.

4. The characters were too white and black. The good guys were cliché good guys, and the bad guys were cliché bad guys. In Infernal Affairs, the moles from either side show their good and bad sides, and struggle to figure out who they really are.

5. The cinematography is nothing special, and compared to some of the scenes from Infernal Affairs, it sucks. The scene from IF on the rooftop at the end is amazing.

6. Again, I am just going to say how disgusted I am at how unoriginal this movie is, and ask people to watch Infernal Affairs instead.

On a positive note, the one thing I did prefer in The Departed over the original was the amount of character development that was done (however at times, that was even too much). Personally, I would have liked to see a bit more of that in Infernal Affairs.

When all is said and done, just watch Infernal Affairs. You may not know the actors, there may not be the amount of character development and a couple of the lines may seem slightly cheesy (only the ones between the moles and their lovers), but at least you will be watching the original film and not some Hollywood knock-off.

title: Scorcese gets his Oscar - for this?
review:
The Departed not a horrible film and that's the best thing that I can say about it. It was instantly forgettable. As soon as it ended, I felt about the same as if I had just watched a rerun of "Family Ties." It was a sterile, by the numbers film that featured phoned-in performances from everyone. DiCaprio was probably the best but there was not much there with him either. Jack was just unshaven, ugly old Jack being Jack the mobster. I didn't get much depth from the character, at the most I felt that he had been doing what he was doing for so long that he was locked into it and didn't much care anymore. But the whole plot line of the two kids from Costello's neighborhood and the paths that they took - and the initial uncertainty of which was which - was very much underplayed and subtle to the point of not being the strong plot device that it should have been. As far as Matt Damon, I can only say that he sucked. Sorry but that's all that I can think of to say. Bland, boring, a true flatliner. He and Affleck made their names on one overrated film and now they are in my opinion a major factor for the dullness of Hollywood these days. I wish that "Good Will Hunting" had been mistakenly put into the shredder before anyone ever saw it, but what are you gonna do...

This is a by the numbers Scorcese film without the fire. It's no "Goodfellas" - it's nowhere near being in the same conversation otherwise. Where Goodfellas was chock full of memorable lines, and left a dramatic impression on you after the film ended that lasted and lasted, this film has not one line that I can recall, hardly a scene, and left no impression - in fact it was overlong in its dullness and I was glad when it was over. And unlike the riveting Goodfellas, it took me three separate viewings to get through this.

I think that Hollywood felt that it owed the guy his gold piece - it did - and wanted to get it to him before he had to get an Irving Thalberg. Feel free to skip this one, secure in the knowledge that you are not missing anything.

title: Possibly the worst movie to come out in years.
review: Am I the only person with enough courage to say how thoroughly offended and disgusted I was with this movie? I am not a prude by any stretch of the imagination, but it was crude and vulgar in the true sense of the words. I usually can tolerate vulgar language if it serves to advance the plot or to add to a characters portrayal. But this movie was excessive in everything it did. I hope that isn't considered a 'spoiler'. But what is even more annoying is that the plot could have been quite good - if it had been handled differently. Actors like Nicholsen, De Capprio and Damon should be ashamed to be associated with it. Trust me, the next time I see Martin Scorcese's name as director, then that will be the film I WILL NOT SEE.

title: The Departed is easily 2006's most overrated film so far!
review:
All of the undue "praise" coming upon Marty Scorsese's film of The Departed is completely irrelevant.

The film is simply a remake of the superior Infernal Affairs, a Chinese action film from 2002, that had better narrative, better characterization, better dialog, and far better tension.

It seems that every Scorsese fanboy and Leo fanatic across this nation has made The Departed a major hit, however the goods just don't deliver.

Once again Marty is back to his old gangster film-making, and this time it's the old and tired cops versus gangsters tired and clichéd formula.

It worked for GoodFellas, not so much for Casino, and it badly misfires here.

Titanic teen heartthrob, Leo DiCaprio, trying unsuccessfully again to look like a mature actor, plays an undercover cop sent by the Massachusetts Police to infiltrate the Irish Mafia headed by Jack "over the top" Nicholson.

Jack once again plays Jack, this time with a darker side.

Matt Damon plays the mafioso sent to infiltrate the Massachusetts Police Department.

The whole film is about both Leo and Damon trying to find each other's identity before it's too late.

None of the characters are remotely interesting, and I could really care less about who got killed or not, the film plays like another one of Scorsese's tired gangsta flicks.

Slightly better than Scorsese's two previous efforts, but, nowhere near as good as his last great film, GoodFellas, The Departed ranks a 3 on a scale of 1-10!

Looking for a better film, try the Hong Kong action flick, Infernal Affairs, which The Departed is based on, it's a MUCH better flick than Scorsese's latest film.

title: Best Movie of the Year
review: It was a long awaited return for "THE" Martin Scorsese, but it was well worth it. Not since Casino have we seen crafty camera-work and not since Goodfellas have we seen the twists and turns of a great gangster movie. What Shakespeare did for the theater, Scorses does for the movies. If they snub him again at the Oscars, it is truly a crime against movie society. Jack Nicholson is back in "Jack" form. He has abandoned the feel good roles and makes the moviegoer actually feel good about their lives. Matt Damon returns to his Boston roots and once again captivates audiences as he did in Good Will Hunting. The entire cast, from Martin Sheen, Mark Wahlberg, Alec Baldwin, and Leo DiCaprio were cast perfectly and make the movie one of the best ensembles in recent history.

title: Scorsese is back
review: Yes, Gangs of New York and the Aviator were excellent by critical standards, but what ever happened to the real martin Scorses. And now we know as we see him back in his comfort zone with "The Departed". The Departed is an intricate tale that is edited to perfection and directed beyond belief.
