The story ends pretty baldy, in the end no one is happy ? Sulivan Costigan, Brown Hannan, FBI agent are all dead, police officer quit. Plus this beautiful women get to raise a child on her own. (i have to admit she is OMG wonderful). So no one is happy in the end. Well Drama is showed here! and i just wished costigan or Sullivan was alive to stay with this girl. Also, what was on that letter ? i think the one who made the movie should of shown the letter (show the girl reading it with Costigan's voice :)) so we know what he was thinking. Also an other thing iv notice : Why everyone gets shot in the head ? Anyway, the movie was great, i just came from the movie theater and I'm still thinking of it.

Thank You MrTouz if anyone wants to answer me about what was on the letter... or give an answer to this comment.. MrTouz@Gmail.com ill probably never check back here, but i will try :)

title: Amazing
review:
WARING THIS COMMENT GIVES THE ENDING AWAY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I have to say that this is one of the best if not the best Scorcese film that I have ever seen and is definitely in my top five best movies I've ever seen right after Pulp Fiction, Sin City and Good Will Hunting and right before Die Hard.

This is a masterfully made movie with a knockout all star cast. I was Shocked through most of the movie however i did predict one thing. I knew Sheen was going to go out the window. and agree with me if you laughed a little after Dicaprio's sudden bullet in the head like I did. how ever Mark Whalberg's return to kill Damon was unpredicted as well but was cool. No Flaws! 100% Great! Gripping! Stunning!

title: Leo's best performance....Scorcese's best ever as well?
review: I've slowly became a huge Leonardo DiCaprio fan over the last few years... love him or hate him... his movies are usually pretty good and he almost always delivers a very impressive performance. It's sad that until very recently, he's ever gotten more attention for his abilities. in this Movie he proves why he is arguably the best American actor working today, along with Jack Nicholson and Johnny Depp. He delivers what I believe to be an Oscar worthy performance and teamed with a great cast I think this makes the Departed the best Scorcese film ever made. As far as entertainment goes I haven't seen anything as good in years.

title: i don't like this movie
review: Departed was not a really good film.It was made good but for me and a lot of people they don't liked the swearwords.They were to much.The most was about gays.And i think i am not the only one who can say"OK there a fictional characters and its only a film" but a good film lives not from swearwords.And there were a lot!What does gays have to do with this film.Why they have to say these words against gays.We have 2006 and i think no film have to use swearword's against gays in this time.These times are over.And my next critic is that Serpico with Al Pacino have more thrill then departed.So i hope Hollywood is ready for a good film without strong language.If someone think the same he/she can write a comment about this.

title: Breath-taking, the return of the original Scorcesse.
review:
It has been a long time, a very long time since we last saw a powerful movie by the revered Martin Scorcesse. Many of us movie goers had been missing the director that made the streets of New York part of Hollywood's history. Amazingly enough, Martin doesn't have Robert de Niro to make him another incredible movie but instead he chose another living legend: Jack Nicholson. After he made sure he had the experienced multiple Oscar winning actor, he managed to secure an all-star cast also composed by Alec Baldwin who apparently has improved his craft with the years. However, it would be unfair not to include Leonardo DiCaprio as the one character that pulls everything together, making the movie worthy of an Academy Award Nomination for Best Picture of the Year. Di Caprio's lands his best role yet and takes it to another dimension. This is a breakthrough performance of a young Hollywood talent that many people doubted after his innocent and naive role in the very popular Titanic movie. Scorcesse goes back to basics, displaying raw characters with clear ambitions in an underground world filled with violence, greed and politics. This is a movie about deception, about loyalty and how it can be broken when you feel surrounded and with no escape. The many twists and turns makes for a unpredictable movie that delivers surprises left and right. The tension of a particular scene where Leo Di Caprio and Matt Damon face each other through a cell phone is the climax of a great movie.

Maybe the only flaw is that the movie lacks a message people could relate to, violence is plentiful and sometimes too much.

Still a great movie. A 9 out of 10.

title: "Maybe, maybe not. Maybe **** yourself." Dignam
review:
WOW !!! FANTASTIC !!! This movie is a little jewel of dark humor !!!

Martin Scorsese is really a great director and the actors are fantastic ! Look at the cast: Leonardo DiCaprio, Jack Nicholson, Matt Damon, Mark Wahlberg, Alec Baldwin, ... I wasn't a fan of DiCaprio but I'm really impressed by his interpretation. Nicholson is great as usual with his crazy eyes, the perfect bad guy. Matt Damon is a very good traitor. Special mention to Mark Wahlberg aka Dignam. Excellent ! His vitriol humor is absolutely awful and... hilarious !

The story is great, the actors are fantastic, so the movie is excellent. That's Scorsese. Who else ?

title: by all means the finest movie this year
review: Everybody is talking about this movie, and once you see it, you'll know it's with a darn good reason. An honest guy coming from a crooked family and having nobody in his life anymore tries to live an honest life working as a police detective. But having failed the exams, he is practically forced to take the only choice offered to him. He goes back to the crooked place he was desperately running from, and tries to make the right thing by acting as an undercover mole of special investigation unit, rendering the criminals and crooks, he works with now, to the justice. Nobody even knows that he belongs to this special unit except two agents. But their mission is far from being trouble-free because the place is infested by rats of all kinds. Witty swears, dirty games and murders, secrets, dangerous liaisons and betrayals, the movie is pretty tough. It's hilariously shocking and shockingly hilarious. The shocking moments are presented in such a way that most of the time you don't have any other choice than to laugh. Jack Nicholson is outstanding and the performance of DiCaprio is dazzling. Both of them make this movie a real joy to watch. By all means, the finest movie this year.

title: 'A Director going back to the bloody basics'
review:
'The Departed', the newest Martin Scorsese picture, is his best since 'Goodfellas'. It's the classic Marty fusion of character, music and lots and lots of blood. It's possibly the year's most engaging and entertaining film.

Billy Costigan is a new Boston police cadet. Once passing training he goes undercover to infiltrate the operations of Mob kingpin, Frank Costello. Costigan utilizes his past familial connections through his crook of an uncle.

Collin Sullivan is also a rising cop. He had a rough childhood, until Frank Costello buys the family some groceries. This brings him into a world much like the one of the young Henry Hill in 'Goodfellas'. When the boss finds that the Sullivan kid's in with the cops, he knows where to get his information and get it regularly. When each group finds that the other has a mole in on their operation, they all try to decipher who's the rat. It's the highest order of the game of Cat and Mouse.

The performances are stellar all around, with Martin Sheen, Alec Baldwin, Vera Farmgia and Mark Whalberg giving able support to the three principals: DiCaprio, Damon and Nicholson. Baldwin and Whalberg provide many laughs with the latter giving his best performance. Nicholson, in his scenery chewing glory, shouldn't be forgotten come Oscar night. DiCaprio creates a fully developed character with great success. Damon is at his best and Vera Farmiga is a wonderful as Damon's lover and DiCaprio's therapist.

The Direction is crisp and hopefully will capture Martin Scorsese his (long) overdue Oscar.

Nothing I can say can do service to the wonder that is 'The Departed', possibly the year's best film!

title: Nice build-up and terrible let-down
review:
The post-Casino Scorsese is a director who has nothing more to prove and seems to be content with shooting big budgets that fall into line with big concessions.

The Departed feels much like an impersonal movie and the most Scorsese-like feature in it are the sudden bursts of violence. Violence clearly has an important status in Scorsese's filmography, were it only because it is not gratuitous violence but the cathartic display of the animal part in male characters. But at some point in the storytelling violence hurls the rest of The Departed to hit the rail. Too much, no longer meaning anything.

For me the big flaw in The Departed that makes it yet another over-bloated Scorsese flick is the fact he was compelled to deal with two intertwined story lines. Yet obviously the Scorsese hero is not the clean bland Sullivan (Matt Damon) but the grim edgy Costigan (DiCaprio). The Sullivan part has nothing to do in a Scorsese movie, it's a stereotypical part which only hijacks half the runtime from the real guy. Star egos? Matt Damon's agent negotiating to have equal time with DiCaprio? Anyway it's a sorry result.

What makes the great Scorsese's movies so great is the flow, the fact we have a voice-over that rushes us into the action, into the heart and soul of the characters. Here Sullivan is so uninteresting they had to put a prologue to set his character, and the screen time he gets only distracts the story-telling from gaining momentum with Costigan's inner struggle.

On the whole The Departed would be a good thriller (and a minor Scorsese stint) but the ending makes it a very disappointing one with its deus ex machina conclusion. Never thought Scorsese could be able to deliver such a pitiful executive-like busted mess of an ending. I felt it coming as the storyline was screeching with four-reels not to take the path of fatality, not making it to convert a nice ensemble piece to stay more with Costigan, our genuine tragic hero, the only one we truly care for.

UPDATE: I have now seen Infernal Affairs, the original Chinese movie, and the only points where the Americans have improved on the original material are 1/a better characterization for DiCaprio and Nicholson's parts 2/a slower rhythm more suitable to this story yet 50 min in excess (150' vs. 100') are twice too much. Infernal Affairs looks a bit rushed to fit in the 90-100' format and I have to admit the error of not insisting enough to flesh up the undercover cop was already the main problem in the original (we have very little time to feel the cop spent 10 years under cover) so The Departed has very little to be praised for. Even more so pumping up the Godfather part with the Nicholson impersonation proves detrimental, in the end, to the whole movie.

title: Masterpiece iffy ending....
review: I loved the film. I was genuinely taken aback at DiCaprios performance. He was outstanding in spite of the tremendous cast. As was Matt Damon. I do agree with other reviewers that "Infernal Affairs" is as good a film as "The Departed" if not a tad better. The only thing that bothered me was the ending shot of the rat crawling across the scene. I thought of it as a slight against the film-watchers intelligence. Hitting us over the head with the "rat" reference as if we already did not "get" the point of the film....I was ticked at that last shot...I thought he "dumbed-down" the ending. That kept me from giving this film a "10". It does not ruin the film though...just the opinion of a fastidious, obsessive-compulsive. this film should rank up there among the best mob films ever. A must-see.

title: Superb!
review: This movie is easily some of Scorsese's best work. He uses great characters, an interesting plot, great climax, and a completely unbelievable ending. YOU WILL BE STUNNED! His 3rd movie with DeCaprio is his best. This movie may not live up to the name of "Goodfellas" but it sure does a fantastic job. It also shows why Martin Scorsese is the "God of the Mob". He knows exactly how to keep interest in all movies and an even better way to end them. Throughout this entire movie, i found it quite entertaining and also kept me on the edge of my seat. DeCaprio and Damon are a great combination. Two experienced actors at the top of their career(in opinion) in this one. DeCaprio should(also in opinion) be up for numerous awards. Best Actor in a Leading role is what i see in his future for this film.

title: Over-hyped.
review:
I gave this movie a 5 because it was a complete disappointment, I liked DiCaprio's's acting also Whalberg was good, anything else is just mediocre.

The movie didn't have a solid plot.. just a random set of scenes with some good acting and directing, that doesn't pull it off even of the director was a legend.

I think taking a 3 parts movie like IA and make into a 2hr movie wasn't the best idea, if you wanna remake something don't try to make your own edits on it and change it into another movie that's not even close to good.

title: It's tough to live up to the name
review:
The movie takes off a bit slow and leaves certain question marks regarding the "face-off"(by John Woo) kind of premise, which doesn't only appear far-fetched but also a bit childish, and even if it were true somehow has a comic-book feel about it. When one comes to terms with this there still remain some other plot-points insufficiently explained, like how come both of them are so successfully quick in infiltrating the structure. We are barely shown an interview both undergo which subsequently sets the premise for the cat & mouse game, but therein would have been the chance to transcend the action-genre. Comparison to, let's say Donnie Brasco, for example, would be unfair to the latter. In stead we suddenly find out that 30 minutes into the movie Di Caprio's character has already been one year undercover, and vice-versa. Character development is insufficient by Scorsese standards, and dialog is a bit wooden, proving that the Irish mafia is not quite up Scorsese's alley.This is not a usual Scorsese movie. It's an action movie with some scars moments reminding of Scorsese trade-marks, like music, violence and camera movement. Attention to detail, and that is what sets Scorsese apart from others, is shallow, in stead numerous close-ups are being used to distract.

This movie is NOT Scorsese's masterpiece, and I'm sure time will bury it somewhere underneath the likes of Goofellas, Raging Bull, Taxi Driver, Gangs of New York, Casino, The King of Comedy or Mean Streets, and this for a simple reason, the standard is set extremely high for S., and honestly this one is a bit self-indulgent and shallow.

However, taken by action-movie standards, it's above average, and there are some small treats for the fans of all the great cast involved, especially Di Caprio, who has studied De Niro's facial expressions lately, Alec Baldwin, and Mark Wahlberg. Also I was pleased to see that S. didn't sell out on the ending, which scores some big points with me. It's not a must see for Scorsese fans, but it doesn't disappoint either.

title: Why The Departed is better than Infernal Affairs...
review:
Well,having watched the Infernal Affairs trilogy just one day before going to The Departed,I entered the cinema,only to find out why this movie is so better compared to its predecessor. So let me start from the Chinese trilogy first... (What follows is just my opinion)

~Infernal Affairs was the movie that started everything...great story and....I have to admit....nice music in the moments with suspense(I liked more the music they played in IA when Yan was chasing Ming in the Cinema than the one in TD....also the ringtone of Ming's mobile when Sam called him in the end was better)...another great thing were the flashbacks which showed us how the characters grew up,from "kids" to adults(while in TD were just the same actors). But that's it....it was a nice story,but I think it was not complete...something was missing....perhaps some action in order to make it more interesting(just a bit,I was not asking for The Matrix)

~Infernal Affairs II was a bit more confusing as a story compared to IA and less original,but it had what IA lacked:Action Scenes...and I must admit that the action scenes(I mean the executions) were comparable to the Godfather...simply great...except from those,it also featured some good lines("Evil Things Live On and Only the Good Die Young.The World Shouldn't Be Like This.It's Not a Way to Be."-forgive me for the mistakes),but moreover(the lines) were the same as those in IA(Both the story with the two cards and the line:"Have You Ever Seen Anyone Shaking His Hand With The Dead" were great-again sorry for the mistakes)

~Infernal Affairs III confused my opinion:Up to the end I hated it,but it was the ending that changed everything...that very twisted ending...I must admit that I'm a fan of twisted endings....and until the end I hated the Inspector with the Glasses,I thought he was a horrible arrogant person...but for one more time things are not what they appear to be and Andy Lau failed again on trying to be a good guy(as Sam said:"I Have Passed the Point of No Return")...except from this whole (Great) idea of Ming's double personality,the very ending was also awesome...finishing were IA beginned(we even saw how Yan broke his hand)...

So,those 3 movies gave us exactly what a good cop thriller needs:Good Story,Suspense,Action,Nice Lines and a Twisted Ending... The 1st one was the present,the 2nd one the past and the 3rd one was both the future and the connection between IA and IA 2....and the story was complete

Now we've got the Departed;

Was it better that IA?Of course it was(except some small points I stated before):The whole movie is longer,deeper,has a great soundtrack and it is far more realistic than IA;everything is done more accurately and with no rush,always thanks to the bigger budget...

Was it Better than IA 2?Of course it was:The story is less confusing,smarter and the action scenes comparable...

Was it better than IA 3?(Again)Of Course it was:TD kept u on the edge of your seat from beginning to end,while IA 3 only in the end...

What I'm trying to say here is that The Departed succeeds where every Infernal Affairs movie(alone) fails;That's why there will be no sequel to the Departed(I don't know about a prequel)...it's already complete and doesn't lack anything...

And so we arrive to the final battle:The Departed against The Whole Internal Affairs trilogy:

Is TD better?Of Course No(although I believe that the whole trilogy slightly beats TD,because TD is always more realistic and has better acting-->Nicholson was much better that the actor playing Sam and Vera Farmiga was way hotter than the psychiatrist in IA)...The IA trilogy has more lines,more scenes,more twists,more jokes(crazy Keung was great),more action...more everything....but we must also notice that what The Departed does in 2 1/2 hours,the Infernal Affairs Trilogy does in 5 1/2 hours (moreover)...end of comment

I know that lots of people will find a (logic)reason to disagree with my comment,so I would like to state that everyone is free to agree&disagree with me as much as he/she likes;

Because this is what makes us human...Differences

title: Disappointing ending
review:
Part of the film were brilliant, and the acting for the most part was very good. Scenes, like the 'i smell a rat' scene, that could have been very corny were acted in a way that built suspense with the undercurrents and true intentions being seen in the faces. The character development seemed real-ish (particularly Di-Caprios fall from grace) but all of this good work was undone in the ending.

Damon and Di-Caprio, throughout the film are cutting and thrusting to expose the other and I was waiting with anticipation for some kind of showdown. There was none. Instead 3 new characters be are introduced, and then killed in the closing 5 minutes of the movie including the two leads, albeit not by each other and they do not confront.

Why would a showdown between the two leads be central to the entire film but never realized. Why is Mark Whalberg coming back into the film to completely destroy the symbolism of the rat in the final shot. There are no rats climbing into the police academy if the have all already been killed. So thats were I'm left, with all of the build up to conflict in the film thrown away in a few suspense-less gunshots. If the aim was to show that nothing is resolved then so be it, i still left the film disappointed that the characters could not get resolution along the lines of their motivation.

title: Slipping away from Oscar for Marty
review:
I like Marty a lot, love his works, but that's not enough for me to hide my true opinion on this film, maybe that is the very reason why I feel the need to express my thoughts.

First of all, it's a remake of Infernal Affairs, no originality there. Fair enough, not every English speaking person has seen it, especially in the states, considering 80% of them don't even have a passport, it's hard enough just to imagine how they would react to anything without a white face in it.

Secondly, Marty should check his eye sights, or his memory. There were many obvious continuity mistakes, fight scenes, office scenes, you name it, they got it.

The next thing is lighting, I was actually quite surprised to see Marty allowed somebody this lousy to be in charge of lighting this film, imbalanced mixed lighting, the most obvious one was the end of the scene when Matt lies in his blood, the sunlight hits the roof front lit, at the same time, it back lits the balcony window! From a filmmaker point of view, a film with an old storyline, inadequate lighting, you will need some big names and serious attention to details to cover up the fundamental flaws in the making, still, there just wasn't enough effort to hide it.

Sorry Marty, you just gonna have to try harder if you want to get your hands on an Oscar, maybe, just maybe, look out for fresh new Asia market and direct an original piece there would make it easier to land yourself a golden statue.

Some times you just have to step away from the box to see what's really going on in the box.

title: Excellent ! Excellent IS THE BEST WORD TO DESCRIBE IT !
review: Yes indeed "Excellent" its the best word to describe this movie. Today i want to comment according to quality of this movie. Therefore my comment is that Everything is Excellent ! hope this comment is helpful, have a great day ! OK, to submit the comment i need to write something more (10 lines of text minimum) so : Acting - Jack Nicholson (espectacular acting, everyone knows him, he is great and keeps better and better). You cant miss this movie, and it shows a reality that most of us don't know but unfortunaly exists. I guess thats all! Great movie ! Im sorry but i don't agree with this 10 minimum text lines, what is i want to make a specific comment that only needs 3 lines ? Thats OK anyway, i tried to comment this movie my best and its Excellent !

title: Pretty Bad
review: This was a pretty bad movie in my opinion. It went on for about an hour to long and was very violent. A lot of violence is not always a bad thing but when it is too serious, I think it can screw things up, and it did. The language choices, while very eloquent, were, not offensive, but offputting - although this may accurately portray life in Boston, I don't know. I was having doubts when I walked in, due to the presence of two of my least favourite actors - Leonardo Dicaprio and Matt Damon - and I was right to be worried, they were pretty bad. I gave this movie a 3 because Jack Nicholson and especially Mark Wahlberg were very good, the psychiatrist love interest was quite good, and they played Comfortably Numb in one scene.

title: I don't mean to by cynical, but....
review:
i went for The Departed yesterday and i think Hollywood is just trying to cash in on us, ripping off a great Hong Kong triad story but not doing it any justice.

being a huge fan of Infernal Affairs (i've seen the trilogy tons of times), i've been looking forward to seeing the Western take on the story. The Departed is a combination of Infernal Affairs I and II, with some minor tweaks here and there to make the film gel together as one. so, a good plot, good story directed by Academy Award-winning director Martin Scorsese and starring talented actors like Leornardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon and Jack Nicholson; i was somewhat hopeful that it would be a great movie. i was, of course, disappointed. it's nowhere near the Hong Kong version. nowhere near. okay, the plot was close enough (though not quite), but that's not what i'm talking about. you can say that i am bias, and i probably am, but...

okay, first let me tell you what i like about the movie.

1) it stars Leornardo DiCaprio, and he has finally stepped away from the pretty boy category; he's now very much a man, and a very dishy one at that. i've been a fan since Catch Me If You Can. well, all his movies are good, actually. save Titanic, of course. Titanic... *upchucks*.

2) there's Jack Nicholson, who is amusing, as usual.

3) Overall, it's not really all that bad. I wouldn't say that it has completely wasted my 2 and 1/2 hours. Perhaps, if you combine all the good bits together, only about 1 was wasted.

err, right. that's it.

now let me tell you what i don't like about the movie.

1) even though i like him, let's face it, Leornardo DiCaprio is NO Tony Leung. his performance was nowhere as intense, nowhere as electrifying.

2) Matt Damon is even worse than Andy Lau. i've never liked Andy Lau's acting, he's rather like deadwood. so i think it is saying a lot when i say that Matt Damon is worse. not much expression. i say, stick to The Bourne Trilogy. Jason Bourne's supposed to be rather expressionless, so he's doing very well in that.

3) Jack Nicholson... okay, i've got to give him some credit. he fares the nearest to the original. but when i say nearest... there's still miles apart from Eric Tsang.

4) Martin Sheen. Now, this is where i'm really, really upset. He plays Anthony Wong's character, but did he do it any justice? a big N.O. in Infernal Affairs, i love Anthony Wong. he is just so cool. i burst into tears when Anthony Wong died; he crashed onto the taxi and it was cut to a close-up of his face, and then even closer as the focused on his eyes and they were still open, they seem to pierce into yours, filled with regret... they tell you a story.

But not only was Martin Sheen a bore (his character was stolen by Mark Warlberg, who shouldn't even be in the movie, you cannot divide Anthony Wong's character into two~!), i felt no connection with him, and his death was also very insignificant. he landed with a dull thud, there were no heart-wrenching close ups (heck, you can barely see his face) , and i went, "riiiiiiiiiiiiight. so he died. do i care? phffft. NEXT~!!" 5) the cinematography sucks. no stylish takes from top, no zooming ins, NO SUPER COOL ALL AROUND DOLLY SHOTS, PULL-FOCUS, PANS, CUT AWAYS OR DOLLY ZOOMS (AAARGH~! DOLLY SHOOTS AND PULL-FOCUS ARE VERY IMPORTANT!!!), nothing. one of the reasons why Infernal Affairs is so engaging is because of the cinematography. a lot of emphasizing on the intensity of the moments and its characters, Infernal Affairs is the epitome of coolness personified and mega movie magic moments. The Departed? Just.Not.Cool.Enough.

6) the Chinese people in the story. they are SUPPOSEDLY FROM MAINLAND CHINA, but THEY DON'T SPEAK MANDARIN, they speak CANTONESE??? okay, so maybe they are from Guangdong or something, but THEIR CANTONESE S**K either way. those actors are obviously Americans, they have VERY HEAVY American ACCENTS. and it was mixed up with a bit of mandarin, they actors themselves were obviously confused with their own language. I CAN SPEAK CANTONESE A LOT BETTER, and that's saying something. seriously, they should either:- a) find non-American Chinese actors who speaks Cantonese properly; or b) DON'T say that they are from mainland China. say they are from the local Chinatown or something.

Martin Scorsese definitely did not do enough homework. really, in those 10 minutes (which seemed like eternity) i didn't know whether to laugh or cry. as a Chinese, i felt insulted and violated. also, this has spurred me to start speaking more in Cantonese from now on.

the verdict? i would say that The Departed is a good movie if Infernal Affairs had not been made. this is one example where, there are just some things that us Asians know better. but do watch the movie, just so that you can have a great time comparing it to the original, like what i just did. after that, have an Infernal Affairs Trilogy marathon back home and say, "see? this is better." every now and then. it gives you a great sense of well-being.

title: Disappointed again
review: I'm sorry but I cannot just sit here and allow this to happen. What Iam wondering is when Martin is going to make a movie that doesn't resemble the work of a recently enrolled film school student. Leaving pieces of the plot unexplained and using plot that is not even germaine. I was not surprised or shocked by the elevator scene nor was the ending something totally out of the blue. Is Martin trying to become Hollywood's best cliché director? I will say that Leonardo finally gave a performance worth watching. How long has it been since Gilbert Grape anyway? This movie had potential and then the credits started and Ileft the theatre wondering to myself how I could get my money back. Martin, your boring me to tears and you owe me $5.25.

title: Bravo Bravo Bravo
review: My husband and I went to see this movie last night and I can't believe how amazing it was! It keeps you on the edge throughout the whole movie! I can't divulge any information because any part will just give rise to it. I'm astonishedI am speechless..it was one of the best movies I've seen in my life! This movie is forever on a roll - at many times I thought something was going to happen and I was wrong..but the movie kept rolling! My eyes were wide and no room left to blink for I was afraid of missing something! Amazing actors, Leonardo DiCapro stole my heart. I didn't like him before but now...he is truly hot! There were many great actors. Everyone did a superb job. This is one movie you cannot miss. This sure is bound to win something this year!

title: Greatest Movie Ever!
review: this movie was great. i went to watch it because of all the hype i heard about it. it sure lived up to the hype. it was absolutely crazy. people die everywhere and most of the time you don't even know it is coming. the plot outline was just great. all the characters lived up to there part. sure the movie is two hours and thirty-five minutes long, but its worth the butt cramp. lol. it definitely deserves the awards coming to it. the director did a great job on keeping your attention. there wasn't one minute that i wanted to leave the theater, even when i heard to pee, i still sat there and watched it to the bitter end. this movie contains all the elements a movie should have without over doing it. DRAMA, COMEDY, ACTION, BLOOD, LOVE, SUSPENSE... you name it, this movie has it. it kept me guessing and interested the entire time. so if you have the money and two hours and thirty-five minutes to spare i highly recommend you see this movie. trust me its worth the money.

title: THE DEPARTED (Martin Scorsese, 2006) ***1/2
review:
I haven't watched the Asian original - though the 3-pack of the entire series has been available for rental forever at my local DVD outlet! - and, frankly, now that I've seen Scorsese's 'version' of them I don't really need to either!!

For one thing, he manages to make the subject matter all his own: it's a veritable companion piece to MEAN STREETS (1973), GOODFELLAS (1990) and CASINO (1995). Still, I don't see this as an Oscar picture: much as I loved GANGS OF NEW YORK (2002) and THE AVIATOR (2004), I'm glad Scorsese has returned to more typical (and familiar) territory - and his stamp is all over this film, from the dynamic editing to the terrific soundtrack to the multi-layered violent-yet-likable characters (this has to be one of the most foul-mouthed mainstream films ever!).

The cast is top-notch and, while I've never been enthralled before with the baby-faced trio of Leonardo Di Caprio, Matt Damon and Mark Walhberg, they're all extremely convincing here (with DiCaprio delivering his most De Niroesque performance yet); as for the veterans, they add authenticity to the material which could never happen by watching the originals, because the actors would be unfamiliar to us - Jack Nicholson (his best role in years) and Ray Winstone (though he seems to be stuck with this type of character!) are effortlessly menacing, while Martin Sheen and Alec Baldwin are the image of integrity itself; lovely Vera Farmiga makes the most of her difficult role (the only female character of any consequence).

There are flaws, however: the plot is quite convoluted and the film rather too long for its purpose (hell, it goes on for another half-hour after the Nicholson character is bumped off!) - culminating in an over-the-top, body-strewn climax (though the unexpected death of one of the leads is as shocking and powerful as Kevin Spacey's demise in L.A. CONFIDENTIAL [1997]).

I haven't watched that many films this year, but this is easily the best so far.

title: Damn trashy clone, good humor though
review:
Had I known that this was a clone of the Chinese movie http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0338564/, that by fluke I happened to watch last weekend, I really wouldn't have bothered going.

Personally I would recommend the earlier Chinese version, it has more sentiment, just simply has more feeling to it. With The Departed/Internal Affairs (2006) there's an extra action spin on it.

I did however really enjoy the humor. Jack Nicholson as usual plays an excellent role as crazy/funny guy. I did feel that some of the acting was, well, staged. I'm wondering if this was deliberate, yet to make up my mind on that one.

title: overdone, and silly
review:
somewhat entertaining, mainly because of the sheer star-power. But even these performances fall short - like Jack Nicholson's overwrought version of that now too familiar smarmy diabolical thing he does. And all the characters were flat - Sheen the professorly good cop; Wahlberg the unabashed, loud-mouthed crime-hating hard-ass cop; Damon, the overly Boston-ized bad cop; and poor Alex Baldwin, stuck in a SNL-like caricature of a good-natured simpleton. Otherwise, no change, no growth, no depth to any of the characters, so, therefore, thus, no compelling character driven-story. A meandering plot that takes wayyyyyy too long to climax, loaded with unnecessary, and often unresolved, and often very foreseeable sub-plots - like the hot psychiatrist (Vera Farmiga)who bangs both protagonists, then becomes pregnant, and then, walks out of the story, having contributed nothing to the plot or to our understanding of the main characters.

too long, and very so-so. very poor writing...

title: Yes, this movie was totally awesome.
review:
While this movie was quite awesome, I do not think it was as good as other Scorcese classics or by any means the best American film in ten years. Mostly for two reasons: one, character and backdrop development could have occurred earlier on and been more thorough, respectively; and two(not to give too much away), the ending was so disturbing, different, and nonchalant that it almost seemed unsuitable for a movie of this caliber, yet on the other hand it might just be what made this movie so great. It's been hard for me to decide if it was good or bad.

The reason I say that character development could have occurred earlier on is because the chance was there, and it might have made the difference between an Oscar caliber film and a non-Oscar caliber film. Maybe it was forfeited on Scorcese's own volition for the purpose of a building effect in the plot line, but I believe that effect could still have been achieved with some added character development early on.

As for the ending, I'm still on the fence about it. Something about it made me feel cheated, not just in the way that I was cheated out of a Hollywood ending (which never bothered me), but in the way that I was cheated out of an explanation of some of the characters emotions. An element to a film which to me seems important, but to other's may not. To me it is a way of providing closure with out being Hollywood and sappy, as well as telling a complete story. However, it might just be that even the kind of closure that I'm talking about is too close to Hollywood endings for comfort for some people, they have to take the risk of not telling a complete story just to squeeze the kind of movie they want out of your emotional responses. If this is the case for Scorcese in this picture then I think he did this in a way that doesn't force the emotions out of the viewer, but finesses them, much like the rest of the film, which all in all makes the ending in addition to the movie as a whole, a very fine film. Maybe it was ONE of the best American films of the past ten years after all. That's for you to judge.

Thanks for reading my review!

title: Saw it and absolutely loved it
review: Will buy it as soon as it hits the shelves at my local video retailer. Now for the movie. It became obvious very quickly why they chose Jack Nicholson (good choice by the way), it was not only because he is a huge name first rate actor (and he is) but because he gave the film the humor and antics that it so desperately needed to break up the drama, tension, and non stop killings. Wise move Mr. Scorsese. I am the first to admit, I am not a DiCaprio fan. But it's the best performance a director has ever gotten out of him thus far. Matt Damon is terrific, Ray Winstone was solid as a rock, Alec Baldwin and Martin Sheen both good picks, but I have to say I was a little disappointed in Mark Walberg as he struck me as being way too crass and obtuse even for a cop. His character was the only guy I was hoping was gonna get wasted and shoved down a drainpipe far more than Damon's or even Nicholson's character. That having been said, I look for "The Departed" to rake several nominations, and saints willing, some wins as well come Oscar time. Crime fans and drama lovers, flock to this film. I will most likely see it again before it leaves the big screen.

title: Moles and the insidious tunnels they dig
review:
Martin Scorsese has another major hit on his hands with the release of the intelligent, chilling, violent, puzzling, and completely fascinating THE DEPARTED. This viewer has not seen the INFERNAL AFFAIRS on which this film is based so comparisons are not possible. But taking this film solely on its own merits this is one gripping piece of cinematic art. Beginning with a very smart script by William Monahan (apparently based on the original screenplay by Siu Fai Mak) and employing one of the best ensemble casts of the year, Scorsese does what he does best in giving us a film that holds our attention, our breath, and our applause throughout.

The story involves two young recently graduated from police academy, men from opposite sides of the law and backgrounds, who are made moles within the Boston State Police department and the Irish mafia: Leonardo DiCaprio is one and Matt Damon is the other and both young actors turn in committed and convincing performances. On the polar aspects of the battleground are Jack Nicholson as the crime king Costello (his finest work since 'A Few Good Men') together with Ray Winstone as Mr French and on the other end are DiCaprio's mentors Martin Sheen and Mark Wahlberg and Damon's mentors Alec Baldwin et al. The very beautifully written female lead is played to perfection by Vera Farmiga who finally has a role (a conflicted psychiatrist for the moles) hat takes full advantage of her prodigious gifts as an actress.

Some may find the violence obsessively graphic, but then this is Scorcese's style and for this viewer it is necessary for the drive of the story. It is impossible to stop concentrating for a moment during this rapid fire drama, spiced with just the right amount of wry humor, making its running time (in excess of two and a half hours) speed by as fast as the many bullets in the atmosphere. This is one of Scorsese's best films and one that begs to be seen again. Grady Harp

title: Best Film of the Decade
review: 24 hours after seeing 'The Departed' I still can't stop thinking about it. In a long lifetime of movie-going, I have seldom been as exhilarated, as excited, as palm- sweatingly gripped as I was by this film. Every scene contributes to our understanding of the complex plot which drives inexorably towards its electrifying conclusion.This must be Martin Scorses's masterpiece. Maybe at last he will get his Best Director and Best Film Oscars; since there are no gay cowboys in the story, there's a chance. I would similarly award William Monaghan for his cracking script and among the acting contenders who would have thought that in a film of magnificent performances di Caprio would be up there in front? At last the bum-numbingly boring 'Titanic' can be quietly forgotten. Jack Nicholson does his familiar mad psycho shtick, but nobody does it better and at his age it's probably his last (grand)stand. He has most of the smart lines, but Mark Wahlberg is a close second. Go and see the movie of the decade.

title: A great movie!
review: A well-crafted movie with intricate plot developments based around many characters. Scorsese adds his familiar motifs to the movie to define it as his, hopefully he will finally breakthrough and get the Oscar. This is certainly his best since Goodfellas, with as much violence to boot. Great acting from the main characters, as well as the supporting ones makes this film a must-see for all film lovers! The movie's length is deceiving, at 2 and a half hours it seems more like a 90 minute film. Perhaps this is due to the varied plot development of the main and supporting characters. Time, of course, will alone tell if this film is to stand on it's own in relation to Scorsese's big three - Taxi Driver, Raging Bull and Goodfellas. I frankly have no doubt it will.

title: loose end drove me mad
review:
I saw this last night and thought it was brilliant. Mark Wahlberg got my vote for his brilliantly offensive bad cop, to Martin Sheen's avuncular good cop. Leonardo Di Caprio can do no wrong and as the psychiatrist love interest said, his character's vulnerability is disarmingly attractive. The pace was great, the twists had me digging my nails in my partner's hand and even though I'm not a fan of screen violence, I was able to watch the whole thing.

But please can someone explain to me a glitch in the plot which left me really disatisfied with the ending. Why, when the girlfriend knows that Sullivan is a rat and has evidence to prove it, does she do nothing? She has nothing to lose at this point and exposing him would be the obvious course of action, particularly as she has fallen a bit for Leo. I just don't get it and it drove me mad all night. Please explain someone.

title: Wow
review: The Departed is one of those movies that leaves so many points in the movie as a logical closure point but then punches you in the face and says "NO! I AM NOT DONE YET!" I am not trying to give the idea that it is long and drawn out just for times sake, because it is not. Each of what seems to be a logical closure point sets up for something that just adds to the experience that Scorsese is trying to fabricate. And it works, good Lord does it work. Scorsese creates an experience that hooks the viewer into a world that is so intricate and well thought out, that everything else during those 2 1/2 hours in that person's life are secondary. Thank you Martin Scorsese, thank you.

title: Not Just The Best Picture Of 2006, But The Best Picture Of The Decade, So Far!
review:
The Departed **** The Departed is one of those movies where you really get into the story. Now I have to admit, Interal Affairs, the original, was a good movie with a good story but I was amazed that Hollywood came through and made a great movie with a great story. It may not be original but it's a lot more interesting than Interal Affairs. Like many other people, nobody thought much of Leonardo DiCaprio's acting when he made Titanic and The Beach, (I was one of the few males who though Titanic was a great film), but DiCaprio has turned out to be a class A actor, not like he wasn't before. He's not Robert De Niro, Al Pacino, or Marlon Brando of his generation, he's Leonardo DiCaprio, a stand alone actor and if he continues getting great roles in great films, he'll be an Academy Award winner, if not, then he'll get an Honorary Oscar. Matt Damon does a fantastic job of playing a villain for once. Jack Nicholson is veteran actor in The Departed. Some veteran actors can't match up their Academy Award winning roles over and over again. However Nicholson does. His performance as criminal Frank Costello equals up to his performance in One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest, Terms Of Endearment, & As Good As It Gets, which he all won an Oscar for. He may not have won the Oscar for About Schmidt, but he might win it for this performance.

Thats all I'm going to say. Just watch the movie and enjoy.

title: And so the decline continues
review: A new Scorcese picture and everyone is thrilled. However, the emperor has no clothes. The parallels with the great Walter Hill are uncanny. Hill's first half dozen movies were sharp, bare pictures with crackling dialogue but he somehow got lost along the way. Turning out rubbish like Brewster's Millions before returning to the well and churning out garbage like Another 48 Hours or attempting to reprise his finest hours with rubbish like Johhny Handsome and Last Man Standing. So it is with Scorcese, who after early success has turned out consistent sub-standard fare like The Departed or the execrable Gangs of New York. Possibly the reason you haven't won the Oscar Marty, is because you haven't made a decent movie since Goodfellas. Go the way of Walter and become a Producer. Leave the film-making to those who show a bit of originality.

title: Best Picture Oscar Candidate
review:
This movie is, to be succinct, an excellent blend of story and character development, backed up by an all-star cast who collectively deliver the best acting you will see in a film, period. Of course, from Scorcese what would you expect but a masterpiece, and here he delivers in spades. The characters are intricate, the story well developed, the violence brutal and non-gratuitous. Above all this, there are many, many twists, more than most Scorcese pictures, that will keep the viewer guessing and at times, even jumping in their seats.

The cast is outstanding; Nicholson (with perhaps his best performance in decades), Martin Sheen, Mark Wahlberg, Matt Damon (I'm Matt Damon!!), Leonardo DiCaprio...among an excellent collection of more minor characters - all superb. If I had to make one critical comment, it would be that one character (I won't say who) does not pay off at the end, which could have cut maybe 20-30 minutes from the film. But who cares - even among the GREAT movies this stands out - among the Deck served up 99% of the time nowadays, this is the Apex of Film-making.

You will NOT want to miss viewing this on the big screen!

title: The girlfriend (spoiler)
review: Did it anger anyone that she cheated on Matt Damon with Leonardo Di Caprio just like that? Matt Damon was all charming and seemed to be perfect to her in the beginning while Leonardo Di Caprio seemed like a nutcase ready to lose it. So what does she do the day she's supposed to move in with Matt Damon? She sleeps with the nutcase. Do you think him not being able to get it up had something to do with it? hehe. Anyways, I don't like how she acts all holier than thou at the end even though she is a cheater as well. Everyone in the movie seemed to be a rat, so I'm glad they all died in the end, but maybe she should have died too hehe.

title: A Great Movie
review: Martin Scorsese has directed a modern classic, with a well written script which recounts an enthralling police/crime drama. The actors gave stellar performances, including a quirky, demonic, at times humorous, and consistently brilliant character study by Jack Nicholson, who can add this role to his many classic portrayals. Both Matt Damon and Leonardo Di Caprio gave complex and riveting performances. I have admired Di Caprio ever since he played the developmentally disabled young man in "What's Eating Gilbert Grape?". He brings a depth and sensitivity to his roles, and in this film, surrounded by great actors, he is the focal point. He gets across volumes in a facial expression, and his complex hero is fed by many hidden springs. He deserves many awards for this extraordinary piece of work, including an Academy Award. Hopefully, Martin Scorsese will finally receive that much deserved Academy Award for his magnificent work as director. I highly recommend this film.

title: Scorsese at the Top of His Game
review:
Martin Scorsese has returned to the top of his game with "The Departed," which is his best work since "Goodfellas." I wondered going in whether the 149 minute running time of the film might be excessive but it is not. It is a sophisticated, complex tale, which, because it takes its time is clearly understandable. Nevertheless, it moves without a lag.

The cast are uniformly wonderful. Leonardo DiCaprio, as Billy Costigan an emotionally crippled undercover cop, gives the finest performance of his career. Matt Damon, who just seems to get better and better, is also outstanding as Colin Sullivan, a state police sergeant who is also a mole for a big time mobster, Frank Costello, played by the always terrific, Jack Nicholson. Nicholson is alternately funny and creepy, in a way I can't imagine any other actor being able to pull off.

I had not seem Vera Farmiga, who plays Madolyn a state health professional who treats both police officers and paroled convicts. Hers is a very important role because she treats and develops a personal relationship with both Costigan and Sullivan, with fascinating consequences. Madolyn is both vulnerable and a risk taker. Farmiga made me care about her.

"The Departed" is the best movie I have seen this year, and maybe in the last two years. I hope that Scorsese ends his Oscar shutout with this one. If he does it will have been a well deserved victory.

title: Very Good Remake
review:
Some people from the production said "this movie is not a remake, it's inspired by Infernal Affairs". But i can assure you, this movie is a remake of a great Asian movie "Infernal Affair". A lot of the scene are taken from the original movie. I assumed that Hollywood ran out of original ideas. But as a Director, Mr. Scorcese did a very good job on remaking this movie. He suceededly transform the world of cop and triad into the world of cop and mafia. But the real show of this movie comes from jack Nicholson and DiCaprio. Nicholson back to his root where he was good at, being a bad, crazy, yet charismatic guy. and for DiCaprio he's been very good acting in every character since he join and become Scorcese's golden boy. I wish that the academy committee will finally give the Oscar to DiCaprio. and for Nicholson, he could get his fourth Oscar. And for this movie despite of this is an Infernal Affairs remake, is a very good movie. "You could become original or a copycat. What iam saying is this, when you're facing a real moviegoers what's the difference".

PS : Watch the original after you watch the Departed.

title: Martin Scorsese's best work since Goodfellas...
review:
We all hoped, prayed and wished that someday, Martin Scorsese would wonder around familiar territory again with his previous works like Mean Streets, Goodfellas and Casino. Well, it has taken a little while, but he is back on that familiar territory and that its territory that he knows best and loves.

"The Departed" is set in South Boston, where the state police force is declaring war on organised crime. Young undercover cop Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio) is assigned to infiltrate the mob run by gangland chief Costello (Jack Nicholson). While Billy is quickly gaining Costello's confidence, Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon), a hardened young criminal who has infiltrated the police department as an informer for the mob, is rising to a position of power in the Special Investigation Unit. Each man becomes deeply consumed by his double life, gathering information about the plans and counter-plans of the operations he has penetrated. But when it becomes clear to both the mob and the police that there's a mole in their midst, Billy and Colin are suddenly in danger of being caught and exposed to the enemy and each must race to uncover the identity of the other man in order to save himself.

Scorsese has constructed a work of pure brilliance. Some of his trademarks are all still present here with the at times dizzying camera work and the sharp quick fire editing, which come courtesy from his stalwarts Michael Ballhaus and Thelma Schoonmaker respectfully. William Monahan's script is sharp, quite witty and beautifully paced, but it is the actors who have a field day with his script. You get the feeling at times that the three main leads are all vying for contention. Its extremely difficult to single out an outstanding performance, in fact it would be unfair to do so, as Jack Nicholson, Leonardo DiCaprio and Matt Damon are all on fine form.

It would be unfair also to pick out flaws with this film, but there are two and they are albeit minor. Ray Winstone's (Mr. French) accent is extremely dodgy. I don't care what is said, it is hard for an Englishman to master any type of American accent. Also The Departed is not what you would call Oscar friendly. The Academy does have a tendency to shy away from work of this nature. I sincerely hope they don't. I hope the Academy will have the courage to finally bestow the ultimate accolade to a director who is as diverse as they come. After the body of work Martin Scorsese has made, it is very much overdue.

With those two minor flaws aside, it doesn't affect the outcome of my rating for this gleaming piece of cinema. Quite simply, outstanding. *****

title: This Is One Of The Best Films I've Seen In A Long Time.
review: In my years working at a movie theater, few films that I have had high expectations for have actually in the end, met them. "The Departed", however, surpassed my high expectations and kept me interested, enthralled, and in suspense till the end of the film. DiCaprio's performance was spectacular. In fact, there wasn't a single member of the cast who didn't give an amazing performance from start to finish. I highly recommend you see this film. It is one of the first Oscar worthy films I have seen this year!! This film is full of twists and turns and is a guaranteed adrenaline trip you won't soon forget. In fact, there are few movies that I would rate this highly.

title: Some good performances....
review: I had watched Infernal Affairs I and II a while ago and I couldn't wait to watch "The Departed" when I became aware that Martin Scorcese (MS) based his film on IA. Well, I like the movie, though I feel MS could have done a much better job had he also stretched the story over 2 or 3 parts. Like IA, "The Departed" is a good movie and must certainly be watched at least once. Very good performances by Jack Nicholson and Leonardo Di Caprio. Matt Damon was OK and I liked Mark Wahlberg's small role and good delivery of his snappy dialogues. And the movie's got a fair share of F*$#&* language. Most of the movie is ditto to the original Infernal Affairs series....but an English version and some good performances by Hollywood folks warrant a viewing.

title: A departure from sub par 2006 cinema
review: "The Departed" is outstanding. Leonardo DiCaprio sets the screen on fire, along with Matt Damon, Mark Whalberg, and, of course, the legend Jack Nicholson. The sold out audience I saw it with laughed hysterically at the funny parts (which there is a surprising number of) and became dead silent at the intense parts (which there is, unsurprisingly, a lot of). Mr. Scorsese once again raises the bar that he set years ago, and proves to us that when it comes to smart, ultra-violent films, there is no equal. If you haven't already, go see this film, I haven't been a huge fan of Leonardo DiCaprio's work in the past, but he absolutely floored me in this one, everyone on and off screen was playing their "A" game. GO SEE THE DEPARTED!!!

title: The Departed is one of the best movies I've seen in years!
review:
Whoa...I read the reviews on Ain't It Cool News and I have to say, despite their hyper-active vocabularies, they nail it.

More appropriately, Scorcese nails it, as does Jack Nicholson, Matt Damon, Mark Wahlberg, Leo DiCaprio, Anthony Anderson, Alec Baldwin and pretty much everyone else in the movie.

This movie rocks and rolls and it kicks ass so completely I was shocked. I mean, I went to see a Scorses gangster flick. I didn't expect a gangster flick the sits up there with The Godfather.

In a lot of way, Boston is getting a lot of attention from gangster cinema. I mean, I just got done watching Brotherhood (really good TV) and this is like that but a much bigger picture. Departed is the ultimate cop/rat movie and I hope Scorcese has a dozen more in him just like it.

I won't go into details but Baldwin, Sheen and Wahlberg are amazing. Nicholson gives an unbelievably believable performance and scared heck out of me. And for once, I'd actually like to be friends with Leo DiCaprio. That last is a minor miracle...I never saw what anyone else ever saw in the guy. Not till last night.

Enjoy it...I know I did and I'll watch it a dozen times in the future, enjoying every moment.

title: The best film of 2006; Scorsese's best work.
review: The Deaparted is arguably the best film I have ever seen to come from Martin Scorsese. In my opinion, it is the best film I have seen in 2006, and I think it deserves at the very least nominations for best picture and best screenplay. This film is a no-holds-barred mystery/cop/thriller/drama that had my full attention the entire 2+ hours length of the film. There is not one boring moment in this picture; every detail had good reason to be there. The acting is superb, and it is second only to the brilliant story unfolding on the screen under Scorsese's masterful direction. 10 out of 10 stars all the way.

title: Violence Violence and More Violence
review: However, one of the Best films I have ever seen. My wife who has a career working in emergency rooms cried after this picture. The violence was a little over the top for her. I myself thought that it was a great film. In movies past when you have seen such star power the film has come off clunky and disorganized. Not this one. The director using his experience and discipline pulled this movie off flawlessly. Only Jack could play such a lowlife scumbag with such conviction his performance is really tour DE force. Of all the performances of the new breed I feel De Caprio was the best in the film with Damon a close second. Damon's performance stood out in my mind because of the fact he has played good guys his past several films he makes the transition of going to baddie flawlessly. De Caprio portraying an undercover cop especially a rookie was very real. My sister in law was a undercover cop. The only casting flaw was Balwin. I feel that Affleck could have done better. Anyway, this movie is the best of the year by far. I highly recommend it but KEEP THE KIDS AT HOME(HIRE A BABY SITTER)

title: no goodfellas
review:
I folk can remember the impact of Scorceses (spellink?) Goodfellas and a fine (if violent) film it is. The Departed will probably be hailed as a return to that fine form, but I hope folk are paying carefull attention, because apart from a few notable one liners, it really is too much the remake and not an individual film.

The story is complelling enough, but not enough twist potential is made of the rich characters created in this version - which has always been the directors strength. Jack Nicholson, however, seems a bit reigned in, leaving acting credits to Leonardo for the main cast, but the supporting cast pulls some surprising irons out of the fire. Alec Baldwin as the furious sweaty police captain and Martin Sheen as the proverbial good cop show there is more to casting than who is popular at the time.

Good but not fab.

title: Excellent
review: I loved this movie, from start to finish. I've been waiting a long time for a great Irish-American mob movie, and this is it. The cast is as incredible on screen as it is on paper, and the dialogue was perfect. Also, if you have any interest in Whitey Bulger, The Departed has more then one parallel to his story. I've lived in Boston for my whole life, and Southie for a few years and i can tell you that they really captured the city in this film. The accents were thick, but not exaggerated (Matt Damon's has improved since Good Will Hunting). And the scenery was perfect. If you're a fan of mob movies, see it. Fan of scorcese? see it. Or if you're a fan of any one of the amazing actors that took part in this movie, see it.

title: A Departure From the Original
review:
First of all, "The Departed" is not as good as the film it was based on, "Infernal Affairs," which is one of the best Asian films of all time. Still, "The Departed" is good entertainment in it's own rite.

The first 2/3 of "The Departed" does not follow the original very much. It is mostly background information about the characters and while at times it is amusing, it is also sometimes boring. This film is about an hour too long. But once you get to the last hour, it is one of the most entertaining films of the year.

The last part of the film follows the original pretty faithfully and turns a mediocre film into a very good one.

Leonardo DiCaprio gives the best performance of his career. Matt Damon is the weakest link in the film. He is okay, but does not convey the complexity of the same character in the original film. Jack Nicholson gives a grizzled version of the character that he played in "Witches of Eastwick." The supporting cast is full of actors that are used to being the stars and they are great! The acting is alone is worth the price of admission.

The biggest difference between "The Departed" and "Infernal Affairs" is that the remake is much more violent and has many obvious attempts at humor, while the original was fully serious and much more subtle.

While it doesn't fully live up to the original, "The Departed" is first rate entertainment if you can stomach the extreme violence and obscenity. If you are looking for a first rate adult popcorn flick, "The Departed" can be a good diversion.

title: Best film I've seen this year so far
review:
I went to watch The Departed last night with friends and I was amazed with film Martin Scorsese does it again.

I think this is a must see for everyone who is over 18.

Absolutely great acting from Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Jack Nicholson and also Mark Wahlberg.

Between the half of the film it gets you thinking where the story is going and why all this and that happens however at the end it blows your mind when you see how well all the characters and things are connected together.

This is one the films that I will go and see it again and not get tired even for one minute!

title: Another Oscar Nomination for Scorsese and Nickolson.
review: The movie was vintage Scorsese, but slightly more stylized  it should get him another Oscar nomination, and I hope he wins this time. I can see why Paul Thomas Anderson tends to follow his style. Excellent story, full of great characters and dialogue. Jack Nicholson is incredible (Oscar Nomination for him too). He was both menacing and funny  great casting move there. I loved Dicaprio in this movie. I consider it one of his best performances. Great editing  love the juxtapositions. The movie reminds me a lot of Scorsese's earliest work - namely Mean Streets. I loved the thugs in this piece. Scorsese does not hold back on the violence, of course  clubs, guns, the whole works - well executed and impactfull. As for the ending, well, all I have to say is that I absolutely loved the twists. The most important thing about this movie is that I cared for all of the characters. As I watched, I could not wait to see what happens to them. Very satisfying!!! Would definitely see it again  can't wait for the DVD!!

title: Brilliant and Brutal
review: This movie is one of my favorite Scorsese films. Top 3, definitely. The violence is brutal as well as the language, the characters are intriguing and flawed (not a single "good guy" exists in the movie), the humor is deliciously dark, and the directing, as always, is simply phenomenal. But what I like even more than the directing is how multi-layered the film is. You'll have to see it twice to even begin to take everything in. There are simple lines of dialog that are vital pieces of information. That's what I love most. The movie contains so many different dimensions, that it simply blows away other mono-layered films. Scorsese doesn't hand feed you everything. You have to make the connections yourself, and that's why I think the majority of the youth either will not understand it or they won't be able to appreciate the brilliance and depth of the film because their standards have been trashed due to the commercial crap films Hollywood is spitting out drastically fast. Nevertheless, this film is amazingly good and don't let any schmuck convince you otherwise.

title: Really Good
review:
This movie is so good, I have heard good things but it exceeded my expectations. I love all of the actors and they play perfect roles. Leonardo DiCaprio really stole the show for me, he is known for doing period pieces but even nailed this one, showing he can do almost anything. I'm not so sure about his new movie with the Australian accent, but who knows...

Martin Sheen was great also, I am not sure why his name wasn't in the trailers. He had a relatively large and important role, did really well playing it, and was way better than Mark Wahlberg.

Like I said in the beginning, this was a great movie. I recommend it to everyone I know and will definitely buy it.

title: Instant Classic
review:
2 hours and 20 minutes feels like 20. I did not get up once. It is an instant classic not to be missed.

Jack is back at his most evil best. Think Joker and Johnny combined. Instead of 'There's a bat in my belfry', you've got 'There's a rat in my crew.' Vile, evil, obnoxious and sexually excited by violence - who could ask for more in a godfather? Better than Good Fellas w/some Reservoir Dogs to end it.

Leonardo, Damon and Marky Mark we're all on their games. I was even able to stomach Martin Sheen. Throw in Baldwin looking like a bigger version of Blake (Glengarry Glen Ross) (1992) and you've got a superstar cast.

Not to be missed. One of my favorites...ever.

title: Pure Awesomeness
review: Edge of my seat the whole time, so cool, acting was superb. Highly recommended. Leo, Jack, Martin, Matt and company were amazing. Even though many people were a little iffy on the ending I thought it was well done and realistic. I could tell the whole theater was completely ingulfed by the plot and its characters. It was a little complicated but most can handle the plots complex twists and turns. This is definitely the must see film of 2006, because we all know this year was nothing special. I hope this film is recognized by the academy (Best actor/supporting/director/film). Not recommended for kids, very violent, bad langaege, and some sexy scenes.

title: Another legendary mob/cop movie
review: I've only watched 3 other Scorsese films, and loved all 3 of those but this one takes the cake. I've never would of believed jack Nicholson could be that bad, besides the shining of course, Leonardo DiCaprio was the star, this was his best performance ever, even next to jack Nicholson he did so good. Matt Damon did a really great job as well i was convinced to hate him. The script and the story line were well written... would i watch it again? YES!! This is a go see movie.. from beginning to end its one of the best movies i've ever seen. Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio make a really great team I hope they both get their Oscars for this one.

title: Sensational film from Scorsese
review: Having seen The Departed, it simply shows us why Martin Scorsese is still one of the best directors working today. The pace, music, characters, action, dialogue, and casting are all perfect - you would not expect anything else from the director who has brought us some of the greatest films in modern film-making history. Following on from Gangs of New York and The Aviator, the Scorsese/DiCaprio relationship is at its strongest with this tour de force from both - anyone who may still doubt Dicaprio's acting ability need look no further than his first encounter with the police psychiatrist (Vera Farmiga)and his the 'Cranberry juice' scene - reminiscent of Joe Pesci at his uncontrollable best. The inspired choice of Jack Nicholson is something film lovers have been waiting to see for many years, and under the masterful eye of Scorsese, Nicholson is able to give a performance that is both menacing and dangerous with flashes of brutality which are utterly believable. Matt Damon gives, what I think, is his best performance since Goodwill Hunting. Perhaps overshadowed at times by DiCaprio, but any Damon fan will find him a delight to watch. The same must be said, too, of the supporting cast - Mark Wahlberg is excellent in his support role and has some of the films best lines which are delivered well. Alec Baldwin does the role of Police chief with ease, and Martin sheen is, as always, terrific. I urge any fan of great storytelling and character-driven cinema to see The Departed - Scorsese's best film since Casino. 10/10

title: Simply The Best Movie of 2006
review: To be honest all to often a big name cast is mixed with a high budget movie to hide the poor quality of the movie itself, but in The Departed the cast works wonderfully together to make what I see as the best movie of 2006, and what should rightfully be Martin Scorsese's first Oscar. From the very get go he movie has you picking sides, and swings you around from all different sides of the story, as most if not all of the key characters are really well developed. In the theater my friend and I were split between the different sides of the law, which is a testament to the development of the characters because it left people very sympathetic towards even the bad guys. GO SEE THIS MOVIE

title: An Amazing Movie, Even if You Don't Like Violent Films
review: I wanted to see this film in part for the high praise, and the recommendation from Oscarwatch.com, which has always been a good source to me. I was thrilled with the cast and had high hopes I would enjoy the film and that I would do my best to deal with the violent themes. The film is violent for sure, but the story is thrilling, unpredictable, but yet you wanted the good to win in the end. I personally found this movie more exciting and interesting than Mystic River which has a similar bad cop good cop theme. I do think that this movie could produce a few nominations for both lead and supporting actors in this nearly all male cast. I really enjoyed this movie, and was surprised at how funny and emotional the film would be.

title: Scorsese is back, dammit!
review:
It's true. All the reviews talk about this film being his best since "Goodfellas". Every single one is right. I'd like to keep the review pretty short and to the point, so I'll say this much:

  • All of the actors were great in their roles. The three principals plus the supporting players, Baldwin, Farmiga, O'Hara, Sheen, Wahlberg, among others) were a joy to watch. Gotta love those Boston accents!


  • This movie is two and a half hours and not once did it drag. That's saying something.


  • Things I didn't like? Maybe the only thing was that I think at some points, the acting wasn't as subtle as it should've been at times. It seemed to me that every time the word "rat" was said around Costigan or Sullivan, they looked like they were trying not to crap in their pants. Plus, Jack Nicholson came a little close to overdoing it but he was still a sight to see. Just a minor beef and nothing that came close to ruining the movie for me.


  • Does it live up to the original? I think it does. I rewatched "Infernal Affairs" last night as well and I have to say that the original is probably a little bit tighter in spots but they're both great representations of what is essentially the same story.


Scorsese has returned to do what he does best. This is a damn good film and I'm recommending it whole heartedly. At this point, the man doesn't need an Oscar. We all know that he's one of the best out there, if not the best, and I don't think a crummy Oscar is going to matter. I just hope he continues to make films of this caliber from here on out.

I don't think I'd be exaggerating by giving this movie five stars. It was absolutely fantastic and the most enjoyable, entertaining film I've seen this year.

RATING: ***** out of *****.

title: Scorsese scores big with the departed..
review: When one thinks about Scorsese and the films he's brought to American cinema one would think there can't be anyway to top Raging Bull, Goodfellas,Casino, Taxi Driver, Cape Fear, etc..etc.. The Departed does just that. This is the finest film Scorsese has made in years. Dicaprio is nothing short of amazing and the great thing is he is no longer the young pretty boy he once was. He has found his way in this film and shines brightly. All of the performances including the wonderful Jack Nicholson, Ray Winstone, and Mark Wahlberg are all incredible. I think if ever this is the Oscar film for Scorsese. I haven't been so excited watching a film in a long time and I watch a great deal of cinema. In my opinion the Departed was more fun to watch than the original Infernal Affairs.

title: So Amazing
review: I thought this movie was awesome partly because I'm from Boston and I drive by the places where the movie was shot everyday. I thought the whole plot was awesome although it was extremely violent and there was a lot of swearing.I think that Jack Nicholson plays an awesome mob boss and Leo and Damon both played fantastic roles. I think the Boston accents were pretty accurate except for Martin Sheen. Nobody but Bostonians can do a Boston accent. This movie was Wikid Pissah thats what I'm supposed to say right? Stop reading my comment and go see the movie you'll like it especially if you're from Boston. *Caution*: Don't eat before watching this movie and don't bring people that are easily offended.

title: Great Movie
review: I'm not going to spoil this movie or give any details but it is a GREAT MOVIE! One of the best movies I've seen in a long time. Leo is great, he was on growing pains! now most of his work is quality work. And Alec Baldwin is funny but Mark Walhberg is sooo hilarious he comes in and steals every scene. this movie is really good. i usually don't go around singing movies praises but in my opinion this movie is that good. And Matt Damon making affleck look bad doing good movies with bug good actors.honestly everyone in this movie is good it has funny parts as well as serious parts. its not big on action but its great on suspense, shockers and dialogue. this is a really great movie. GO SEE IT!!!!

title: What a film - Scorsese you legend!
review:
The film was fantastic. 'Di Craprio' actually put in a performance worthy of recognition come awards season. This film works because it combines playful police office banter, coming from prominent actors such as Baldwin, Damon and 'Marky Mark' Wahlberg, with a more dark tale of disloyalty and corruption combining the Boston State Police department and their dealings with the Irish-American gang run by Frank Costello (Nicholson). The film gradually reveals the lengths that either side will go to infiltrate the opposition. As Costigan (Di Caprio), the mole within the Costello's gang, and Sullivan (Damon), within the Police department come closer to finding each others identity the film becomes tense, even to a point of being unbearable at times, leading to a somewhat surprising conclusion.

To some the ending might seem slightly quick, with too many shots and expirations, but as the film develops to a gritty and startling finale, this ending is the best and only one the film deserves.

Also it was great to see Ray Winstone in the mix as Mr French, he was also excellent.....

title: Great movie (With an interesting plot hole)
review:
Great movie, no doubt about that. But wait a minute, did the Matt Damon character really believe he could "delete Costigan's existence" without Marky-Mark Wahlberg's character coming back to ream his butt? Tjis just did not make sense to me.

Spoiler warning****

The fact that Marky_Mark's character winds up wasting him in cold blood, just back up my thesis.

Usually I just see a film and go along for the ride, I can 'suspend disbelief' and all that other cool stuff. Just seemed to me this was a huge plot-hole and there were several other minor ones in the mix as well. Okay, some minor flaws in a very very good film.

title: perfect in every way The master has returned
review: He has topped himself yet again. The cinematography, the acting, the writing, SUPERB! I cannot tell you loud enough to go see it. If you like suspense, and a great storyline go see it. It is a little realistic when it comes to violence. GO SEE IT!!! he starts off in his normal fashion of painting the perfect picture for you with great detail and precision. Then before you know it you 2 and half hours is gone, your on a roller-coaster of emotion and you are too caught up in the movie to even think what is going to happen next. The acting by Jack, Leonardo, Wahlberg, and the supporters was just awesome I had my doubts about Leonardo and Wahlberg but I would have to say this is one of their best works without question. I have been waiting for a good movie compared to all the nonsense that is out there now. This will leave any movie buff completely fulfilled and walking right out the door only to buy another ticket.

title: Just keeps building and building and building! Definitely worth seeing just for the superb performances of a dynamic cast.
review: Suspense and acting at its best. DiCaprio, Nicholson and Sheen, Wahlberg and Damon all superb roles well played and well cast. This is one of Scorsese's finest pieces since Casino and a nice change, stylistically speaking, from his latest period pieces. The subtle foreshadowing and symbolism along with knockout punch action keep you wrangling in your seat in this latest criminal thriller.
