What i find a lot is that mat daemon is doing a lot of action movie nowadays, i'm not saying he not the right person for it but i'm finding it hard to imagine mat daemon as a action type of person. i can understand STUCK IN YOU, he did a perfect job in that one. But by all means mat daemon is doing a good job at a action type character. Cheers to the movie and cheers to the actors

thank you

title: twice the length, half the fun
review:
finished downloading this movie the other day and it was a torment watching it way too long for its own good

first of all, crappy cast (excluding Nicholson)

DiCaprio - teenage boy with no pubes, who can believe he threw any of the punches in the movie Damon - too cocky (not script cocky) and fake (trust me there are parts of my life ya don't wanna know about) check that scene

lame jokes - 'hows ya mother, tired from f@#$ing my father' who the heck is lame enough to say that

unoriginal - first off to all ya Whites thats still in denial, yes it is a remake of 'infernal affairs' (even if its been altered quite a bit) secondly, Nicholson at the start giving money yo Damon and acting like a big shot, (go take this money buy this buy that blah blah blah) and all the super cocky super nice 'gangsta' type (the people who don't like me...well...lets say *smiles* pop pop then jokes about it wow...been done too many time already

definitely not a movie ya can enjoy again and again

on the good side, i'd give Nicholson my 3 stars flopping a black dildo at Damon (i would of done the same for DiCaprio just to turn him on) and the last star goes to the Scorsese great taste in picking a movie to remake, he just didn't do a good job in this one

title: Simply superb
review:
This was a consummate piece of filmaking. Everything about it - the cinematography, acting, dialogue, pacing, and of course, the directing, was superlative. Easily the best film I've seen some time, a first best picture nominee of the season. Alec Baldwin was witty, slick self, and matt damon, leo dicaprio and Jack Nicholson were outstanding and completely believable of course as well.

The ending may lack one small scene tying it together, but other than that, this film was simply flawless, and totally satisfying and riveting. I swear, there was almost NO talking during the movie, and people who couldn't sit down were standing in the hallway watching in awe. Don;t think about it - go see this movie NOW, dammit!

title: The best film of the year?
review:
I *really* enjoyed this movie. The first time I've been wowed at the cinema this year.

The acting is excellent, aided by a fantastic storyline. Each character is given substance and life, and you become aware of unspoken relationships between them. Special mention should go to Jack Nicholson, who really brings depth and life to the bad guy.

The backdrops are gritty and real, the language coarse and vulgar. The police offices are just as dark and sinister as the gang hangouts. If you stop paying attention for a moment, you'll miss the pithy dialogues. And the plot is deep and twisted, definitely not an after-work relaxation flick.

My only complaint (and I might be alone here) is that Leo DiCaprio and Matt Damon look too much like one another. I initially got very confused because I couldn't tell the two characters apart. Fortunately DiCaprio's tortured character quickly develops facial hair, and it was easy to follow after that.

The way the story ended was also a little disappointing, but it was faithful to the original film.

Thoroughly recommended.

title: One Of The Best Films Of The Year
review: The Departed is a superb film which takes place in an Irish neighborhood in South Boston. Matt Damon stars as Colin Sullivan, a young criminal working for Frank Costello, an Irish mafia figure played by Jack Nicholson. Costello assigns Sullivan to infiltrate the Boston police department. Leonardo DeCaprio plays a member of the Boston police department, who simultaneously is assigned to infiltrate the mob syndicate run by Costello. Both the mob syndicate and the police department soon realize there's a mole in their organization. Both mole's paths cross in a fantastic, interesting, and somewhat complicated and violent tale of deceit, murder, and mayhem. The Departed is filled with great lead actors as well as supporting actors such as Mark Wahlberg, Alec Baldwin, Martin Sheen, and Anthony Anderson. All of the actors are at the top of their game in this film, and Martin Scorsese deserves an Oscar as Best Director, which he will most likely win. This is one of the best films of the year. This is what going to the movies is all about.

title: thanks for nothing
review: This is a big thumb in the eye from New York to Boston. The fact that Boston actors participated in such a cavalier, irresponsible glorification of violence that perpetuates negative stereotypes about the city and its people is surprising. The real story Scorcese should have brought to the screen is why there are more than 70 unsolved homicides in the city and why the police get so little cooperation from public. Why it took so long to finish this movie is the real mystery, not the intrigues going on in the bumbling police department. The one redeeming thing is Jack Nicholson's performance. No one else in the movie comes close to his genius. He owns the screen.

title: Fun--for awhile
review:
This is a fun movie for about 2 hours, but unfortunately it goes on for another half hour. The ending is entirely unsatisfying. But let's talk about the acting--Nicholson is mesmerizing as always. I don't know that his character makes a whole lot of sense, but you can't take your eyes off him when he's on screen. Alec Baldwin shines in a small part as a captain. Matt Damon is serviceable enough, but then he doesn't really have much range as an actor anyway, does he? The mystery here is the praise being heaped on Mark Wahlberg who is not only out of control, screaming every line, but often indecipherable. Bad role, big ham.

But the movie belongs to Leonardo Dicaprio. He's just great, well-deserving of any awards he receives. The whole point of watching the entire film is to find out what happens to his character, thanks to his emotionally-wrenching performance.

A big bounceback for him from the nightmare that was "Gangs of New York." For Scorcese, at least this isn't a debacle like that one. Thankfully no sign of Daniel Day-Lewis's ridiculous mustache (I do believe it's now starring on "My Name Is Earl," pasted on Jason Lee's face.)

title: Best Friggin Movie of the Year!!!
review:
Scorsese scores again! Man, from start to finish this movie had my eyes glued to the screen and I truly felt I got my money's worth! Damon does a good job shedding his Ocean's character for a more Bourne type man. Leo, although I'm not a fan, did well.

Gotta hand it to the veterans, though: Nicholson and Wahlberg stole the show with the most a-hole characters that really, really served their purpose. The plot is brilliant and the movie was shot well.

I suppose you could not like this movie. I mean, if you're strongly sensitive to violence and/or language, I'd be wary. But honestly, if you're above the age of 15, this movie is for YOU!

Enjoy it, See it again, Buy and own it...it's going to be a classic, folks!

Bravo! Encore!!!

title: best movie of the decade
review: The best movie of 2007 and the best mob/cop story since Heat(1995). In my opinion its Martin Scorsese's best film. Jack Nicholson is brilliant and I believe that Scorsese has found his star for his big time movies in Leonardo Dicaprio (as Robert Deniro was for a bunch of his movies). Matt Damon plays a great role for the crooked cop. Leo is the typical cop who is an informant to the police in how he is always fearing for his life and always nervous. To me the movie is one of the top 30 movies of all time even though the accents of a Yankee are kind of not good at times. But the movie keeps you at the edge of your seat. A must see movie for people who are in to gangster movies and for people who are just into movies period. The best movie I have seen this year. The best movie of the decade.

title: Scorsese's best!!!!
review: This is definitely one of Scorsese's best films. Unlike the direction he had been taking in making more historical films like the Aviator, this brings him back to the real, early 90's Scorsese. Take all the best elements of Goodfellas, Casino, any pre-Gangs-of-new-york-Scorsese, and you have The Departed! The cast is phenomenal!!! Jack Nicholson plays the perfect Mafia boss, and Matt Damon opposite Leo Dicaprio works perfectly. Although the plot is foreseeable from the very first minute of the movie, you never know what to expect from scene to scene. The movie kept me excited from beginning to end. Mr.Scorsese, you've done it again!!!!!

title: Gobsmacked by how good this film is
review: There is only one word to describe this film and that is astounding. I thought the first one was good but this surpassed my expectation. In the original Infernal Affairs the sound was its meal ticket every thing was Sharpe and clear bullets going everywhere,music playing and ring-tones echoing in your ear i am glad the American version this version live up to that standard because it was done to perfection.what else can I say the cast was brilliant what a combo of star actors and the good thing was they all got there fair share of input into making this film ingenious.individually Leonardo DI Caprio should be nominated for best actor at the Oscars hell they all should jack, mark, Matt ,martin and Alec they all were excellent in this film. Also i am making a personal recommendation for martin Scorsese for best director at the Oscars and if he loses it has got to be rigged against him.everything about this films was great the music,actors,action,story,directing,and of course the fact that they were Irish made it even cooler.

title: a competent remake
review:
This is more of a original-vs.-remake review, so you may not get much out of my words if you haven't seen the original. Anyway, having already watched "Infernal Affairs", I was pleased to realize Hollywood didn't completely muck it up with "The Daparted" remake. Here's a brief comparison, bluntly delineated for brevity's sake.

Parts where "Infernal Affairs" is better:

  • Shorter. Although "The Departed" doesn't noticeably lag, the difference in pacing and intensity between a 100 minute and a 150 minute movie is huge.


  • The two lead actors are better than DiCaprio and Damon. That's a big claim, since the two American actors put in excellent performances, but the original's portrayals are that much more powerful. DiCaprio's Hong Kong equivalent in particular (Tony Leung) does a far more nuanced fall into the hopelessness and depression of an endangered undercover agent.


  • Much more realistic about undercover communication. There's this wonderful Morse-code scene that's far more clever and believable than I'm-behind-a-corner-typing-text- messages.


  • Jack Nicholson is over-the-top-Jack, and while that's entertaining, it's noticeably inferior to the original's evil crime boss.


Parts where "The Departed" is excellent:

  • Marky Mark's cursing role that's so lovably a**holish.


  • Alec Baldwin's lightning-quick streaks of witty profanity. The script's dialogue really does have some brilliantly funny and clever lines, so you walk away from the movie feeling you've just seen an intelligent brand of violence.


  • The fact that people get beat when they need to; any time I thought 'that guy's acting like he deserves a beating', he promptly got a pummeling the movie really flows.


  • The great choice of music, played at the appropriate times. Rolling Stones, and 50's pop played to sardonic effect how can you go wrong?


  • The move to Boston adds a social commentary perspective that the original doesn't have. Granted, the original didn't suffer from its focus, but the remake's adding of a more complex setting adds an enjoyable layer.


  • The complex storyline isn't dumbed down, and that really impressed me, as I was left thinking 'the filmmakers must have some real confidence in the American public'. Sadly, having read some of the more negative reviews around here, it's apparent some people had some real problems following the movie's plot. Rest assured it's your own failure, not the movie's.


Parts where "The Departed" plainly sucked:

  • What's with the useless FBI side-plot? It contributes absolutely nothing.


  • The ending's final death. Cleaning up after itself like American movies tend to, it leaves none of the bitter complexity of the original. Having a guilty man walk around with his guilt, while a good man lays unavenged, is a more multifaceted than the tacky "bad guy dies" of the American remake.


Overall, "The Departed" is still a wonderful movie, and different enough from "Infernal Affairs" to be its own movie worth watching.

title: Best Two and a Half Hours you can spend at the Movies
review: I had VERY high expectations going into this film, they were easily surpassed. First off, don't shy away from this film because it is two and a half hours long, it's so engrossing the time flies by. The plot is simple to follow but complex in nature. The acting is stellar, Nicholson is especially entertaining. The music is fitting and truly represents Boston. What makes this film truly special, though, is the editing and direction. Scenes are spliced and mixed in unique, yet, fitting order. It adds to the emotion and feeling of the piece. Now the only reason I am giving this a movie a 9 is the ending, (it's not a bad ending, just not what I was hoping for.) This film should easily reach the IMDb top 250 and should definitely be considered come Oscar season.

title: If you are a movie fan at all you have to see this movie
review:
I am not a Martin Scorsese fan, not at all, so I'm surprised to be here telling you that I really liked this movie. Let's get a few things out of the way first. I can't stand Matt Damon. So I'm pretty much going to leave him out of this review. Leonardo DiCaprio, I've thought has been underrated for a long time even with the praise he's gotten recently. I thought he was one of the best actors out there going into this movie. Also, I didn't get to see 'Infernal Affairs'. I meant to and when I can get my hands on an undubbed copy I will.

DiCaprio definitely did not disappoint and acting-wise I think he basically wipes the floor with the rest of the cast. This is no diss on Jack, because Jack is Jack. He can walk on water basically but in the scenes with them together as a movie fan you think to yourself "is Leo going to be able to handle it?" and somewhere in the middle of the scene you realize he's the one commanding it. Really if you are a fan of movies at all you have to see this, for the performances alone. Some of the accents were a little iffy but that's to be expected. I mean everyone here does good work but you can sell repeat tickets on the scenes with Jack and Leo. Think Pacino/DeNiro in the movie 'Heat' but better and more often.

The movie is about Boston cops trying to take down a titan of the underworld. Nothing new here, but the story has, not twists but, double crosses and synchronistic incidents that baffle without being contrived or remotely ridiculous. I can't imagine any crime fan not enjoying this movie and wanting to see it again right away. I'm not going to go into the plot anymore because you need to see it. But with all that it's not confusing, or every critics' favorite word lately, incoherent. You know who's who and what's what the whole time. You are completely on the edge of your seat and some things are predictable but it's the stuff that you don't want to happen. So you sit there with your stomach in knots hoping it doesn't. Is it violent? Of course, but it's nothing we haven't seen especially from Scorsese. Actually the scene that for me was the most excruciating to watch involved no blood at all.

A few minor complaints. I don't understand Martin Scorsese's use of music. It seems like he likes to drown out his dialogue, and then using the same songs repeatedly, I mean, who does that? And I'm a hater of remakes so I have to take one point off for that. Some old ladies coming out of the theater complained that there was too much unnecessary swearing, but really, consider the source.

Now back to the guy I don't like. The reason I don't like him is the same reason that I thought this was perfect casting. I kept hoping and hoping for other actors to take a swing at him. And I can tell you that this was the most fulfilling thing about the movie for me. I felt vindicated because someone saw what I've seen in him all this time to cast him in this role. And I got to see people I like much better beat him up a little bit. I may just by the DVD for that reason alone.

So I'm thinking this will get nominated for Best Picture. I personally would like Leo to win a cumulative Oscar with this one. I'm thinking the Scorsese fans might finally get their win in the Best Director category. And if they do, I'm cool with it. This was his best in my opinion since Taxi Driver.

edit: I have seen Infernal Affairs now and I thought they were equally good and different enough that The Departed still deserves the praise it's received.

title: Best Picture For 2006
review:
After seeing The Departed and having seen many of the other great movies of 2006 thus far, I can safely say that this movie in my books is the best movie of 2006. In fact not only that, it is one of the best movies I have ever seen. It is certainly another great chapter in the career of a brilliant director.

The authentic Boston accents in this movie were perfect. They weren't non-existent like you see in some movies set in Boston and they weren't exaggerated either. The cast was so full of stars that it would rival pulp fiction and each and every actor in this movie brought their A game to this movie.

Probably what I enjoyed about this movie the most was the script writing and the character development. Each of the characters were so interesting and so obviously unique in their own ways and the script writer brilliantly captured that element.

All in all, this was a brilliant movie that keeps you at the edge of your seat the whole time and it had one spectacular ending.

title: Superb Film......Don't miss this
review: superb Film...Puts Black Dahlia and Hollywoodland to shame...Nocholson at his very best with Damon and ID Caprio running along side...Saw the first showing in Edmonton and will be going again...Blink and you miss something violent.Walburgh is slowly gaining a big reputation as a very slick actor...Scosese at his very best,it shows up the Boston Police dept a little as being corrupt but its a great story that keeps you glued for 2h 25m.Jack Nicholson should be up for Oscar but the will probably give it to some bum film that only a few will have seen let alone heard of....Di Caprio come out of the film with full credit as he has suddenly grown up from good looking parts to a down and out thug...Go See ...ENJOY

title: First hour is quite violent, but plot pays-off in second half
review: I was quite turned off by the close-contact violence in the first half of the film. In fact, at one point I considered walking out and waiting for my friend in the lobby. She was not bothered by the fistfights and other human cruelty, while I had to cover my eyes and hope the sounds weren't too disturbing! Having said that, as the plot developed in the middle third I began to enjoy the complexities of the plot. I would have preferred an "edited for content" version with most of the beatings cut out. It was difficult to keep the relationships and "who knows what" straight, and I was afraid at times that I was missing something, but all-in-all I kept up with the plot without any major missteps. Early in the film it was often difficult to keep Damon and DeCaprio straight, and I had to say, "Oh, that's Matt", or "Oh, now that's Leo." I'm not saying it wasn't possible to tell them apart, but thinking of the characters as the actor's names didn't really do much to help me become absorbed into the world of the Boston Irish mafia. Also, Jack Nicholson was always "Jack" to me in this film, never completely becoming Costello.

title: A 10 from 10 for Scorsese
review:
With a cast full of top class actors it would have been so easy to let the script just fade away and depend on the location - Modern day Boston and pirouetting actors, but no, Scorsese, yet again, proves he is still a force to be considered.

The Departed has the grittiness of Gangs of NY, a storyline to match Casino and a script that makes Goodfellas look like just another movie! Oh, and did I mention the location?

DiCaprio/Nicholson/Damon/Wahlberg all give excellent performances, but with a back-up crew of Baldwin/Sheen/Winstone(Henry VIII - Sweeney Todd)/Farmiga(The Manchurian Candidate - Touching Evil) all putting in performances that would, in any other movie, earn them top billing, the first line crew are pushed on to be amazing. There's no over-acting here, just the cream of Hollywood doing what they do best, better than before.

At 2 1/2 hours you might expect the script to run out of steam, but at the 120-minute mark I was still wanting more, and did Scorsese give it to us. The ending, though almost predictable, still contains that shock factor. You leave the theater wondering what message the film left you with? Who should you feel for? Who demands sympathy and who was the real villain?

I rarely give a film 10/10, only Crash has received that in the past year, but The Departed is a must-see, 10 from 10, Oscar-winning film in all departments.

See it and may not need to see another film until the next Holiday round appears. Miss it, and you will miss one great film.

title: Greating writing, great acting
review: I haven't liked all of Scorsese's films (such as Gangs of New York), but The Departed is a clear winner. Great writing and great acting usually produces a good film, and the results are very evident here. DiCaprio gives an Oscar worthy performance as an undercover cop in a situation he desperately wants out of. Definitely the best male performance I've seen this year. Matt Damon is also very good as the bad cop, and Nicholson gives his normal over-the-top performance as a mob boss. The editing is very effective, cutting between DiCaprio's and Damon's intertwined situation. No doubt a finely crafted near-masterpiece...

title: Self-Parody, Empty Bluster
review:
It is frankly bizarre that after so many better films from Scorsese that the Oscars decided to reward this misfire. The film is entertaining enough but then again so are train wrecks. There are too many twists, too many spies. When everything is fused with duplicity there isn't anything to grasp onto. Meaninglessness follows. The film plot renders any meaning pointless to try to discern. Why bother? It is nonsense.

Maybe I would be kinder on this film if all the characters weren't such overblown Massholes all the time (through weirdly none of them seem to like the Red Sox). Filled with cheap machismo, insecurity and bloodletting this is the sort of film that is mistaken as "serious" when it fact it is just silly men not realizing they are wearing funny hats. And dear god the accents all seem put on. The characters are almost as overcooked as the writing.

Probably the saddest aspect of this is how Scorsese, who should know better, used forced mise-en-scene throughout this film. To name two quick examples: A woman is holding a banana when she is implying male impotence, The last image you see is a rat. It feels much more like someone trying to copy Scorsese than himself.

I guess the Oscars were afraid Scorsese was about to die given how much this film got away from him. That explains this career achievement this film got.

title: Good story waste
review: One thing the story is good but amazing actors are waste hell climax boring action no thrill

title: Another Great One From Martin Scorsese.
review: This is an all around great film. It has the perfect cast, the perfect plot, the right amount of twists and action and it's perfectly written. An under cover cop and a mole in the police department working for the Irish Mob ends up searching for one another in this craftily written film. This film was directed by none other than Martin Scorsese, who brought us great films like "Goodfellas", "Casino", "The Wolf of Wall Street", and "Shutter Island". As I said before, this film has a great cast with Matt Damon, Leonardo DiCaprio, Alec Baldwin, Anthony Anderson, and Martin Sheen, but to me the star of this film is obviously Jack Nicholson. He brought his characteristic touch to this film which made it even more better. You can't go wrong with this one.

title: Most overrated film in human history
review: How ANYONE could enjoy this rubbish film is beyond me. They cast two actors who are 100% indistinguishable from one another, with the same hairstyle, wearing practically the same clothes through the whole thing. How ANYONE could follow the story with two identical actors playing (I assume) different characters just makes no sense. Honestly if they hadn't had scenes together I'd have assumed they were the same character. I suspect it's the emperor's new clothes syndrome writ large. Some rubbish crime film full of nails-on-chalkboard Boston white trash accents comes along and a few influential people proclaim it a work of genius, so every drooling yahoo of mediocre intellect is afraid to disagree. Thank god I'm blessed with the seemingly rare ability to think for myself, and can say with perfect conviction that the world would be a better place had this cinematic abortion never been released.

title: Scorsese's Boston gangster opera
review:
Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson) is a Boston Irish mobster. He mentors Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon) ever since as a little kid. Eventually Colin joins the Special Investigation Unit in the State Police headed by Captain Queenan (Martin Sheen) and the unpleasant Staff Sergeant Dignam (Mark Wahlberg). He works directly under Captain Ellerby (Alec Baldwin). He begins a relationship with police psychiatrist Madolyn Madden (Vera Farmiga). Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio) is a new police recruit from a family of lowlife criminals. Queenan and Dignam put him undercover. After serving some time in prison, he works with his petty criminal cousin Sean (Kevin Corrigan) and catches the eye of Sullivan's henchman Mr. French (Ray Winstone).

Director Martin Scorsese goes to Boston to film this gangster opera. The cast is second to none. There is great acting being done here. Leo is terrific holding up even against the peacock acting of Nicholson. Winstone is powerfully rough. Damon is twisting his sweet persona into something a bit more of a douche. There is a bit too much plot and sometimes, the movie tries to do too many things. For example, Scorsese doesn't need some of the camera moves or the back and forth editing which only distracts from staying with the plot. It may work even better with a simplified style. This movie is best at its bloody brutal core especially with Leo acting up a storm.

title: One of the best of 2006.
review:
The best picture winner in 2006 was The Departed. In my opinion, it didn't deserve best picture. My top three favorites of 2006 weren't even nominated for anything. Mt favorite film of that year, The Prestige, didn't win anything. My second favorite film of that year, Casino Royale, wasn't even nominated. My third favorite, V for Vendetta, wasn't nominated for anything either. But The Departed, won a lot of stuff.

Martin Scorsse's The Departed truly is a fantastic film with fantastic performances. There were some that shocked us all. Like Mark Whalberg. Leonardo Di Caprio was fantastic also. But to me, the best performance goes to Jack Nicholson. Nicholson plays Frank Costello, and he is an evil bastard. The ending to The Departed came as a bit of a surprise.

I know that the film deserved the Oscar buzz that it got. The Departed truly is an excellent film. But I think that The Prestige is better, and that deserved more nominations. I really did love The Departed because it is such a clever, bad ass film. The Departed was one of the best films of 2006.

The Departed:****/****

title: Nothing but quality
review:
This film is one of the best films I have ever seen. It has made multiple top 10 list sand has won 4 Academy Awards, but this is not why I was drawn to this film. Scorsese directed it but thats not why I wanted 2 see it. I went to see this film because I wanted to see the cast. Di Caprio, Damon, M. Sheen, Wahlberg, Alec Baldwin and of course Jack Nicholson made me think that even a shoddy script that has been rendered from a Chinese classic would make for a decent and worthy film.

The film surprised me as it was more than decent. 20 minutes in and i was on the edge my seat. i was completely immersed in the film. The film was fantastic to watch. The cast was fantastic, the direction was stunning and the script was top drawer quality.

The film successfully shows the effect of being a mole in some sort of organization on different people. Billy Costigan, the undercover cop, is constantly in a battle of wits with a criminal genius. He respects his foe, this is shown by his multiple acknowledgments of his abilities. An example of this is the scene at the bar in which Costello tries to figure out whether Billy is the rat. Billy shows a sign of fear which gives the audience a sense that he knows that Costello is on to him. Colin is different he isn't battling peoples wits he is simply manipulating peoples actions and ideas on criminals, often he is following Costello's orders. Where these two show their biggest difference is their goals. Billy is all about bringing Costello down despite the bonds which seem to grow between them. However Colin gets agitated with Costello and changes his goal from aiding Costello to bringing him down. This is one of the reasons I fell in love with this film.

Another reason is the direction Scorsese uses slow motion, shadows and steady-cam sequences for dramatic effect brilliantly. The shot of Capt. Queenen (M. Sheen) being thrown off the building is heart stopping, this effect is achieved bu the slow motion. I don't think anyone in the cinema didn't say "oh my God" at that moment. much kudos to his director of photography for composing the shots so well.

Overall this is one of the best films ever made. A worthy remake of Infernal, in my opinion, despite what has been said on these boards. The film is as good as Goodfellas and Taxi Driver, what I consider to be Scorsese's best films.

title: The Departed (2006)
review:
The Departed was a great movie that deserves it's title as the "best picture of 2007." The cast is first rate including Jack Nicholson, in an over the top performance as the villain, Jack Costello. Leonardo DiCaprio also turns in an Oscar worthy performance as undercover cop, William Costigan Jr. Matt Damon is also very good in his role. Mark Wahlberg who was (surprisingly) the only nominee out of all of these actors also does an excellent job in this film. Even the supporting actors are good, including film veteran Martin Sheen in a good performance, and Anthony Anderson in a rare break from his usual comedy routine that turns into an overall good performance. In other words the acting was great, one of the best casts in recent years. Martin Scorsese's direction is very good. Although this is not his best work, it is still proof that he is a film making legend and he always will be. Many people say that he ripped off the Chinese movie Infernal Affairs, but in many ways this movie is better. What Infernal Affairs does in 10 minutes, The Departed does it in 30 minutes. This allows a lot more room for the actors, and much more characterization. In conclusion, The Departed may not be Scorsese's best movie, but it is nevertheless a superb effort and perhaps his best effort since GoodFellas. The performances in the movie are great, and should have been recognized more commercially. It is the deserved winner of four Academy Awards, but in my opinion should have won more.

10/10 Rated R for Strong Brutal Violence, Pervasive Language, Some Strong Sexual Content, and Drug Content. Canadian Home Video: 18A Run Time: 151 Minutes.

title: Instant Classic!!!
review:
The departed is one of the greatest movies ever made!!!, since i saw it, i am 100% fan of Scorsese, in fact i'm going to follow more nearly his career from now on,. Why??

Because:

1.-It has change my entire opinion about Dicaprio's acting; before the departed, he was just another cute little boy who couldn't cut his hair of, if you know what i mean.

2.-The entire cast give us brilliant performances,(i thought that Whalberg was excellent in a supporting role).

3.-The script was too good written, you can understand every detail in the movie.

4.- THE ENDING WAS JUST... GREAT!!!, that's what Hollywood needs in this days, some real and tragical stories, far away from "Disney endings", in my case when Dicaprio is killed, first i got shocked, like i got hit by a bus, then i got angry , but at the end i just thought: "this is brilliant".

I hope new Scorsese movie (rise of Theodore Roosevelt) will be like this... but meanwhile, if you have not seen this movie i have something to say to you:

GO SEE IT!!!!!!!!!!

title: The Departed- Mr Scorcese I am now your fan
review:
Before I watched this movie I had read mixed reviews about it, instead of putting me off it made me even more curious. I am glad that I took a chance on it. To be honest I can't understand why people didn't like it. It is a superb drama about undercover cops. Scorcese has managed to assemble a superb class of actors, including Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Jack Nicholson and Martin Sheen amongst others. DiCaprio has finally got rid of his pretty boy looks by having a more rugged look in this movie. Add to that a twist in the tale and you have a absolutely compelling drama.

To be honest I have not watched any other Scorcese film apart from the Departed, after this movie I want to watch all his other classics. This was easily the best movie of 2006, Mr Scorcese you should be proud.

title: An Exceptional Gangster Movie
review:
I am now a huge fan of Martin Scorsese. Before seeing this, the only other films of his which I had seen were Gangs of New York and The Aviator. After watching The Departed, most other films pale in comparison.

The Departed is a example of sharp, fearless and taut storytelling done right. Scorsese keeps the story moving with thunderous momentum and stylish realism which puts almost all of his competitors to shame. In other words, I doubt that anyone could have made this film half as well as Scorsese.

The cast is also perfect. Leonardo DiCaprio turns in what is potentially his best performance to date, thoroughly convincing the audience in his role as Billy Costigan, an undercover cop posing as a member of gangster Frank Costello's (Jack Nicholson) crew, as well as showing the character's eroding confidence and hard-boiled charisma with breath-taking realism and smart vulnerability. As he realises that he is close to being caught by Costello, DiCaprio uses cleverly restrained panic and anger to amplify the impact that he has on the audience. His character is satisfyingly complex, and DiCaprio breathes utterly gripping life into all of his scenes.

On the other side of the coin, Matt Damon is equally impressive as Colin Sullivan, Costello's mole in the Boston police department. He is an individual desperate not to be caught, which smartly parallels with Costigan's situation, yet he is nowhere near as close to that danger as Costigan is, meaning that he is under much less physical and emotional pressure. DiCaprio, Damon and Scorsese draw powerful and ironic comparisons between the two characters. However, in spite of the similarities between Sullivan and Costigan, Damon still manages to create an individual and human character, giving an incredibly confident yet intriguingly layered portrayal of a terrifically flawed character.

The only other real lead is Jack Nicholson, and he is typically brilliant. Striding through the film like an old pro, he naturally swipes the screen from under the other actors noses like a seasoned professional, and it is tremendously enjoyable to watch him apply great intelligence and unrivalled, bloody charm to his character.

The supporting cast is also outstanding. Martin Sheen, Alec Baldwin and Vera Farminga all seize their screen time and run with it, creating thoroughly individual, compelling and entertaining characters. However, the biggest plaudits must go to Ray Winstone and Mark Wahlberg.

Winstone is a force to be reckoned with as Costello's right-hand man Mr. French, delivering a jagged, wild and superbly coloured performance. He is on top form here, and proves that he is more than just your average actor once and for all. Surprisingly, he, along with the rest of the cast, are truly eclipsed by Wahlberg, who delivers a phenomenal, career-defining performance. Swearing with unstoppable gusto almost every second that he is on screen, Wahlberg also shows gritty intelligence and a spectacularly street-wise attitude which dramatically enhance the impact of his character. His performance is unbelievably thrilling to watch, and cements his character as one of my favourite movie characters ever. If I had a say in the matter, he would have waltzed home with an Oscar.

The film's crew also knows how to entertain, and do so to the best of their abilities. Technically, the film is stylishly brilliant, with some pinpoint sharp editing and excellent cinematography highlighting some superbly suspenseful set-pieces. One great sequence shows Costigan tailing Sullivan on the streets after just seeing him meet with Costello, with several nail-biting moments of grand tension. There are moments like this scattered skilfully throughout the movie.

There is also a brilliant soundtrack. Combined with another fantastic score from Howard Shore, there is some terrific background music to get your teeth sunk into. I can't get Pink Floyd's "Comfortably Numb" out of my head.

The script is terrific. William Monahan's dialogue mixes incredible smarts, laugh-out-loud humour and gritty intellect all into one, to create a perfect mixture. The words coming out of the character's mouths never feel unrealistic or out of place in the character's situation. If the script hadn't been written with such knowledge and skill, then Wahlberg's Dignam wouldn't have had any near the number of classic one-liners which define his character. That is how perfect the script is.

Crafting the whole affair with unrestrained style and realism is Scorsese. His direction is superb, and ensures that the film's quality never slips. He also keeps a close eye on unwanted sentimentality, creating real characters in a superbly intense environment. He makes the audience feel for the characters, yet he doesn't manipulate them. He understands that the story is really an epic tragedy in the disguise of a gangster movie, and allows the audience to be helplessly drawn into the unstoppable catastrophe, along with the characters. Every decision that Scorsese makes enhances the visceral intensity of the movie. Here is a master at work, and Oscar rightfully awarded him.

This is a classic achievement, and a terrific example of how to create a modern masterpiece. Well done to the cast and crew, most notably Mark Wahlberg, William Monahan and Martin Scorsese. And, as one critic put it, "Long live the rats!"

title: best movie of all time
review: This was the one of the greatest gangster movies ever. I would cry if Martin Scorsese ever topped this movie. The only thing that wasn't good in the movie was that it wasn't based on a true story. I still classify this as his best film to date. The movie is amazing. the ending is the best ending to movie thats ever been made. Its hard to find a movie with a good ending. My top 10 movies with good ending are The Departed, No Country For Old Men, Pulp Fiction, American Gangster, Edward Scissorhands, Pirates of The Caribbean 3, Spider man, Harry Potter and the Order of the Pheonix, A Lot Like Love, The Lake House. But The Departed is the one most underrated movies. Its should be top 10

title: compared to Goodfellas
review: After hearing that it surpassed Goodfellas and the great reviews everyone had been telling me about, I went out and bought the special edition DVD without even watching it. Not the first time I'd done that and made a mistake and apparently not the last. I swear I'll never do it again. This movie is good, compared to other movies made nowadays. But, comparing it to fantastic movies of the 80's and early 90's is like comparing an alley cat to a jaguar. This movie was nothing special! Yes, the acting is solid, and that was a relief, but beyond that there was nothing in depth or fantastic about the story. It's all been done better before and the violence just seemed gratuitous, rather than well placed. I'm in the dark why anyone is raving about this movie. Watch Goodfellas or Casino for true character development and a story that actually holds your interest and hasn't already been done a thousand times.

title: Overrated.
review:
This movie could have been so much better.

How to waste the talent of actors like DiCaprio and Damon? Load a movie with blood, vulgar language and ruin the two main characters.

This movie is based on Infernal Affairs, an excellent Asian movie with Andy Lau and Tony Cheung, two of the best Asian actors out there. The plot is essentially the same, aside from a couple details, but it's close enough.

The biggest difference is, the Asian version managed to be a lot better in many ways. They didn't feel the need to swear every five seconds, or use c*nt and f*ck every sentence. They didn't need so much violence or to feel forced to put sex in it. The result is a classy, thrilling suspense with actors who are incredibly better than in the American version. There is no morale in The Departed, while Infernal Affairs ends with a huge lesson and a character who actually regrets betraying. Unlike what most American can think, death is not only way to pay or crimes. Infernal Affairs clearly show that.

If you want a movie that is actually watchable with your family, with actors on par or better than those in The Departed and a story that is overall a LOT better, I recommend you watch Infernal Affairs first. The Departed is nothing but a cheap, bastardized version of Infernal Affairs and I still cant believe they gave an Academy Award to Scorcese for this sub-par movie. Nicholson's acting is top notch as expected and all the supporting actors are great. But Damon's character is hollow, and DiCaprio's character is lacking the strenght and mystery that made Tony Cheung's character so believable.

Another example of a bad remake of an excellent movie.

title: Great movie, bad ending.
review:
Simply, a very entertaining and intelligent crime movie, partly ruined by an unbelievable, almost ridiculous, shoot-out ending. It's as if they spent a year intricately and passionately working on the film, ran out of time and came up with and shot the ending in one final week under a rush. It left me disappointed that such a materpiece would end so cheesily.

Leonardo DiCaprio and Matt Damon both perform excellently opposite each other and I found myself rooting for both of them equally to overcome each other, which is what really drove the movie for me. The Departed has a good balance between a likable "good guy" and a sympathetic "bad guy," and that is what makes the movie entertaining to watch.

I won't buy this on DVD unless there is a director's cut with an alternate ending.

title: What a mess!
review: While the acting was good, the direction and editing were purely awful. What a mess! Mark Wahlberg was irritatingly funny and Jack Nicholson simply does what Jack does best. Leonardo DiCaprio and Matt Damon both did good acting jobs and the supporting cast was solid. The problem was not with their performances but with what Scorsese did with it after shooting ended... Vanity shots that served no purpose other than to look "cool" were thrown in. It was chock full of messy edits that weren't even remotely stylish, and it was a poor mish-mash of attempted styles.... not to mention a lack of imagination in the structure of the film. This movie could have been SO much better and I can't help wondering how much improved it could have been if someone like Quentin Tarantino or even Bryan Singer had been able to do it. Martin Scorsese has deserved an Oscar in the past but certainly not for this jumbled mess. The actors deserved better.

title: very interesting
review: Jack Nicholson is superb in this movie but I liked the original more. Matt Damon is great. Very good music. Very interesting directing. Fantastic screenplay. Photography is outstanding. It was a real pleasure. Special effects are of a lesser quality. Jack Nicholson is superb in this movie but I liked the original more. Matt Damon is great. Very good music. Very interesting directing. Fantastic screenplay. Photography is outstanding. It was a real pleasure. Special effects are of a lesser quality. Jack Nicholson is superb in this movie but I liked the original more. Matt Damon is great. Very good music. Very interesting directing. Fantastic screenplay. Photography is outstanding. It was a real pleasure. Special effects are of a lesser quality.

title: Plagiarism
review: This movie is a plagiarism of the Chinese film "Infernal Affairs (Mou gaan dou)" of the directors Wai Keung Lau and Alan Mak. I don't understand the nomination for the Oscars of Martin Scorsese for a non original film. Martin Scorsese don't have any merit. The only thing that it's original of Scorsese is the end of the film. And the end of is the worse thing of the movie. Martin Scorsese copies entire sequences of the Chinese film. I believe that if they give him the Oscar it will be the worst ridiculous one of the history of the American cinema. I believe that great people believe that Martin Scorsese has returned, but nothing has done more that to copy.

title: Extremely Disappointing
review:
Having seen INFERNAL AFFAIRS and how mesmerised I was by its telling, this is by far a definite disappointment. All this star power comes to zilch because Scorcese and the writer miss the basic of what IA was all about. Honor, integrity and loyalty was what IA was about and Scorcese goes and messes with the main storyline by having the gal be a shared meatpiece(sorry for the crass metaphor).

I wonder if Media Asia Films(who own IA) knew about this interpretation which in my opinion should absolutely have not been allowed !!!! Watch at your peril of a movie gone bad in Hollywood. Instead save your money and catch the original which is a fantastic film!

title: Scorsese Is Back To His Old Form & Gives Us The Best Film Of 2006.
review:
Billy Costigan is an undercover cop who gets thrown into the hands of a notorious gangster, Frank Costello. Colin Sullivan is a member of Costello's gang who is a mole in the Boston police department. Once word gets out that there is a mole in the police department and a rat in Costello's gang, things begin to heat up as they try and smoke out the other.

Infernal Affairs blew me away a couple years ago, then I heard that one of my favourite directors was doing a remake. I was a little hesitant at first, I didn't know if I was going to see old Scorsese (Goodfellas, Casino) or the recent Scorsese (Gangs Of New York, The Aviator). Granted the films under his belt as of late are not horrible, in fact they're great, they just don't have that old school touch that made Scorsese such a great director. With The Departed Scorsese is back to his old form and gives us the best film of 2006.

The Departed is full of old school tricks from Scorsese. From an Iris Out and that classic Goodfellas feel, it makes for an intense thrill ride that will have you on the edge of your seat. With the crop of films this year not being all that great (save for a select few), The Departed blows them all out of the water. It's brutal with it's violence and doesn't hold back on anything.

DiCaprio and Damon both shine in their roles, with DiCaprio having the more intense part and more screen time. I only favour DiCaprio a tad more because the scenes with Damon and Farmiga are a tad boring to watch. It was a joy to watch both of these characters slowly lose their minds being on both sides of the fence. Although they both shine in this film, they can't touch the great Nicholson. He is absolutely astonishing. He owns every scene he is in, even when he starts acting like a rat. He has this evil presence about him in this film, but he plays it with such a comedic tone, you can't hate the guy, but you can fear him. After seeing how great he is in this film I'm left wondering why Scorsese and Nicholson haven't worked together before now.

Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen, Alec Baldwin, Vera Farmiga and even Anthony Anderson all blend well together to bring the cast of The Departed full circle. Wahlberg stands out in this list, he is just as mean and foul mouthed as Nicholson and can actually hold his own with such a prominent actor as Sheen sitting right beside him. Alec Baldwin is a joy to watch as he spits out his comedic lines left right and centre and Martin Sheen brings the missing piece that fits the thrilling puzzle that is The Departed.

There are numerous violent scenes that scream Goodfellas or Casino and it's nice to get that old feeling back. The film is gritty, brutal and violent and doesn't let you sit there and feel comfortable with any of it. People are getting shot left right and centre, beaten to death, hit numerous times with coat racks, beaten with shoes, stabbed, thrown out of buildings. The blood splashes all over the screen and with people getting shot in the face everywhere, you feel the uneasiness that Scorsese wanted. It's not as brutal as the one infamous baseball bat scene in Casino, but it ranks up there.

The film does tend to drag on in certain areas, but that's expected. With it's fast story telling pace, Scorsese slows it down a bit so we can get to know more about who these two characters are. He keeps us on the edge of our seats wondering if their cover is going to be blown cause it can be blown at any point in time. Even after watching Infernal Affairs I was still tense, wondering what was going to happen next. That is the work of a great director.

The Departed will get recognized by the Academy, but I doubt it will win anything. Scorsese is after 0/5 in that race. One can only hope though, cause he deserves it so much. This film, although definitely not his best (I don't think anything he does will surpass Goodfellas) packs one hell of a bloody punch. It has strong performances and a dark comedic tone that will have you laughing along with it. In the hands of any other director, it could have been a mess. Thank you Mr. Scorsese, for letting me have fun at the movies again.

title: this one will keep you awake,,,
review: Martin Scorcese has scored again,,the film was both exciting,violent,, if vulgar language bothers you, this is not the film for you to see,, The film reminded me of L.A.confidential,combined with Goodfellas and/or A Bronx Tale,,the acting was very good, with Jack Nicholson, Matt Damon and Leonardo DiCaprio at their best, but I was not convinced by Mark Whalbergs performance,, Alec Baldwin and Martin Sheehan both gave credible support to this film,,, there were however a number of weak spots, from time to time, that were confusing or unconvincing,,, the film overall was full of twists and turns which require the viewer to stay alert,, above all, expect the unexpected!!!

title: blood, f***, great acting, silly story, don't take mama
review: This is not the greatest movie ever made as some suggest. It has a story that could never happen - except in Hong Kong. Acting is top notch. Nicholson is as usual; should have been shot early in movie. Only one girl in show but since she sleeps with everyone, only one is needed. Lots of f*** to where it really doesn't mean anything (sounds like real life, doesn't it). You won't get tired and it is a great story to watch for action. It is a city Italian cowboy western. I do not think many women will enjoy it. I did but it isn't a really great movie. Peckenpaugh lives. I've finally accepted Damon as a tough, mean fighter but it has taken a long time. Where is Orlando Bloom to add to the violence?

title: Good, but not as good as Infernal Affairs
review: Based off an Hong Kong movie, The Departed transplanted the story into an American background. However, it is not as good as it's original.

title: Very Bad Movie
review: Don't waste your time on watching this illogical movie.

title: Confusing yet thrilling plot
review:
This is one of the best gangster movies, I've ever seen. The story is quiet confusing but at the same time really conclusive.

In the beginning there's nothing really special, you see a young guy (Matt Damon) infiltrating the Massachusets States Police and delivering information to his friend and boss of the Irish Mafia Costello (Jack Nicholson). But not long after he is grouped into a new unit, an other young guy (Leonardo DiCaprio) begins to work for the Police and in turn infiltrates Costello's gang. That's when the story becomes exciting. As the two characters get used to their new environments, the viewer often doesn't really know anymore who is the good guy and who the bad guy. You might not know who is more sympathetic to you until the end which is very abrupt and, in my opinion, a little bit special.

Although the plot sounds really nice (and it is of course!), also this movie has its faults. The two main characters advance in their ranks really fast, which is not really realistic. Also both of them work straight for their side. I think good and bad can't be defined like black and white, but like tones of gray, and so the characters should act too.

There are negative points in this movie, nobody can deny it. But the positive side of the movie is clearly dominant. It's a must for fans of gangster movies and I totally recommend it to everyone who likes a thrilling plot and lots of action.

title: Scorsese never disappoints
review: This film is intense,entertaining, and will keep you on your feet, anything you'd want in a movie, right? You cannot look at the cast and think it'd be any different, getting great performances from DiCaprio to Baldwin. But of course, at least for me, the biggest name on the credits is Martin Scorsese, the director. I can honestly say it's my favorite Scorsese film, which is saying something considering he is the director of movies such as Goodfellas, Gangs of New York, The Taxi Driver, Raging Bull, and The Aviator. If someone said, "Recommend me a couple of movies", this movie would be one of the first, if not the first, to come out of my mouth.

title: Outstanding
review:
"The Departed" is a 2006 Martin Scorcese film, based on a film out of Hong Kong, "Infernal Affairs." I haven't seen the latter, and from reading, I can see that some people liked that film more, some less. I only know that I loved this movie; the script, the performances, and the directing style were all excellent.

"The Departed" is about two men who are leading parallel lives. One, Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio) is a graduate of the police academy, and, connected from the old neighborhood, is sent undercover to infiltrate the organization of Costello (Jack Nicholson). Another graduate, Colin (Matt Damon), working with the special investigations unit, is a mob informant. Their lives connect via the police psychiatrist (Vera Farmiga), who becomes involved with DiCaprio, though she's living with Damon. Nicholson is desperate to know who his mole is and puts pressure on Damon; Special Investigations knows they have an informant and want to catch him. The situation becomes more and more tense.

The cast is superb - besides di Caprio, Damon, and Nicholson, Martin Sheen, Mark Wahlberg, Alec Baldwin play the top men in the special investigations unit.

Scorcese does a masterful job with this film, cutting back and forth between the two men - in the hands of a less expert director, this might be confusing, but in his hands, it's not. He also builds the suspense and tension very well.

Di Caprio is sensational as a hot-tempered, stressed out cop who more and more is in danger of being found out; Damon is excellent as the charming, collected Colin who, as he continues to move up in his department, comes closer to finding out the identity of Costello's mole.

Martin Scorcese is no stranger to violence, and there's plenty of it to be had in "The Departed." It's not everyone's cup of tea, but it's very strong. While I might argue with a few plot flaws, they didn't detract from me being totally absorbed in this film.

title: Greatness by Scorsese
review:
Did not disappoint - if I may begin with a mother of all understatements. Now THIS is quality film-making, folks. Quite surely one of the best crime thrillers I have ever seen, along with for example Kurosawa's High and Low - and yeah, I actually wrote so. Both are that to me for different reasons: the latter for its realism plus subtle and brilliant portrayal of social divides, the former perhaps mostly for its awesome-beyond-words suspense. However, The Departed also manages to give a satisfactory account of organized crime, both in the larger social context and on the human mind especially. Unlike so many crime movies today, there is plausible realism found here, and that added substance clinches the film into masterpiece category.

In the real world, anyone can get unceremoniously killed in an instant if they surround themselves with these kinds of settings. It also doesn't matter squat whether you die deservedly or not, or whether you get a parade or get thrown in a dumpster afterwards. This is a fact one has to come to grips with as a mobster. Scorsese has been saying this through his films for years, he shows killing usually briefly and in an almost matter-of-fact way. There is zero glorification, and this applies to The Departed maybe more than to any other work of his. In addition, the excellent script (by William Monahan) also found room to display thought-provoking similarities between the very macho and homophobic cultures found not only on the wrong side of the law, but the police force as well. This is just one of the tools in blurring the classic good/bad dichotomy, which (among all other things) is done very well in the film.

Two points of caution if you plan to watch this, though. This movie is a nerve-wreck par excellance, and a duration well over two hours can get to you. Also, if you're into that particular field, try to look past the fact that there just might be a few times when the worn cliché Psychology=Freud surfaces... But yes, this is arguably the best or, at the very least, definitely one of the best pictures Martin Scorsese has ever made.

title: Extremely Intense
review: Martin Scorsese has made an extremely intense and well made film since his Goodfellas epic and Casino. I love everything about this film that hurts. The acting, the screenplay, the direction and everything else. This is one those unique films that I can watch over and over again, and still can't get tired of it. It should be in the 20's up in IMDb's 250 top movies. The Departed is flawless, riveting, and has lots and lots of style to go with it. It really is the best picture of 2006. Exstravangtly professional gangster film. Leonardo DiCaprio has always been better, Matt Damon is spectacular, Jack Nicholson never fails, and Mark Walhberg knocks it right out of the park! It has a lot of twists and turns that will rev up the audience and shake em' to its core, with a mind-blowing ending that you will never, ever forget. I am most certainly glad it won its four Oscars because it completely deserved them. This is an absolute instant classic. Well Martin Scorsese, you've done it again!

title: Star-Studded to the MAX
review:
The Departed

By Daniel Rosado

Directed: Martin Scorcese

Cast: Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Jack Nicholson, Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen, Vera Farmiga, Ray Winstone, Alec Baldwin, Anthony Anderson, Kevin Corrigan

4out of 5 stars

The Departed is about two cops on opposite sides of a battle between the police and Irish Mafia. Matt Damon and Leonardo DiCaprio star as cops in this star studded movie. Jack Nicholson puts on a memorable performance as Costello, and one of my more favorable performances by Mark Wahlberg.

In the film there are two cops, Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon) and William Costigan Jr. (Leonardo DiCaprio). Sullivan is a cop that rose quickly through the ranks, but he's secretly working for Costello (Jack Nicholson), the head of the Irish mob. His job, as a cop, is to bring down Costello, and try to find Costello's "rat" in the police department. Sullivan is careful to make sure no one realizes his true alliance, and he also makes sure Costello is always one step ahead of the cops.

Costigan is sort of in a similar situation, but very different. Officers Dignam (Mark Wahlberg) and Queenan (Martin Sheen), think that Costigan is a thug, because of his father's past. In order to prove his allegiance with the police, he has to give up his identity, and go undercover, working for Costello, and getting whatever info he can get from him.

The Departed is a good movie that keeps you thinking, "What's going to happen next?" You know that eventually everyone's going to figure out whom Costigan and Sullivan are really working for, but you want to know how is it going to happen. You also wonder what it's going to be like when they encounter each other.

The Departed had so many great things going for it. Its cast full of great actors, from past movies or shows. They were considered some of the best actors throughout their careers. The score that was playing during The Departed was perfect. They couldn't have possibly had better music for the movie. Especially the Irish rock song, I'm shipping off to Boston, by: The Dropkick Murphys.

Overall The Departed was a good movie, at times I was a little bored waiting for something exciting to happen, but when there was action, it did more than make up for the boring parts.

title: Scorsese scores yet again with his best to date.
review:
Martin Scorsese has finally won his Oscar for the brilliant, intense and powerfully, courageously acted film, "The Departed". Like the film "Internal Affairs" (the film prior this of which it is adapted) the viewers are, most likely, going to have a hard time following the plot, because there is so much constantly happening there is no time to catch their breath.

The plot is actually rather simple. Billy Costigan Jr. (Leonardo DiCaprio-in a role that he got snubbed by at the Oscars, if anyone in the cast, even a dynamic Mark Walberg, he deserved it the most) is a temperamental kid with aspirations to be a police officer for the Staties, the Massachusetts State police department. But he is assigned a job as an undercover who will be sent to jail again, and then released to get inside of the Irish mob led by the feared and yet aging Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson). However, on the other side of the universe, Colin Sullivan is a seemingly normal, hardworking citizen (Matt Damon) who is a shoe-in for the rank of Detective. But this man is not who he seems. Costello corrupted him as a kid, intelligently using quotes from political people and pop culture references-a theme often used in the sub-text of the film- and now, the detective for the Boston Police Department is the mole inside the special investigations unit. This is when the plot begins to spiral out of control. Sullivan is assigned to find the mole in Costello's crew, and at the same time trying to find himself, the rat in the Special Investigations Unit. The real nightmare, is the horrors that Billy Costigan faces as he is tortured by the subtle messages and disregard to him by the mob. And as Costello begins to act more sinister, Costigan then realizes everything is not as it seems within the grainy and dark depths that is the Irish mob.

Dicaprio plays a role that easily should have granted him an Oscar nomination. Being the kid that could never murder, but is surrounded by an environment that calls for him to require the stomach to handle such regression, and only able to spill his guts to a police shrink, played very well by new comer Vera Farmega. All he wants is to get pills so he can sleep, to be out of his situation and to finally be in the position of Sullivan. Costigan had a rough childhood, and faced with this conundrum, he resorts to using his intelligence to gain Costello's trust before it is too late. Many scenes are brilliant and truly say something about what fear, danger and intimidation can do to us. There are times where Colin Sullivan sits in his office with the lights off, and silently ponders the thought about quiting his position. Billy at his lonely and grainy home, looking at old photographs of his departed family. Frank Costello, talking to his men with the pride and bleak intellect that he brandishes within his wealth.

Martin Sheen, (Especially) Mark Walberg and Alec Baldwin play great roles as two men who work in different positions at the Boston Police Department. Sheen and Walberg are the captains who are in charge of the undercovers, Sheen being the mentor of Billy, and Walberg giving him the 'tough love' a rookie like Billy needs to get ahead. And Baldwin is the head of the Special Investigations Unit, and the boss of Sullivan. The two sides of this brilliant film is one rough exploration of the Irish Mob and the other more smooth, discrete look at the pain and suffering that rats, moles, leaks and snitches experiences on both sides of the law. And after all, cops or criminals, when facing a loaded gun, what is the difference?

Winner of Best Picture, Director, Film Editing and Adapted Screenplay. Also in my opinion Scorsese's best mob film ever. Just viewing the emotion, fantastic acting (fitting the bill for a genuine look at the depraved forces driving our cities into epochal chaos) and brilliant acting. A great sigh of relief for fans of Scorsese, when he finally got his well deserved Oscar. Funny.

title: Great Movie
review:
I haven't seen the original Infernal Affairs yet but after seeing this and loving it, I will definitely check it out. The Departed was a great movie that kept me entertained for the whole two and a half hours which is very rare for someone like me who usually likes his movies an hour and a half or under. This one did well though.

All the actors were fantastic except for Matt Damon, not that he's a bad actor, he just always seems like the exact same person no matter what character he's playing. The story was awesome with some brilliant plot twists. I also loved the blood and just the overall look of the film. Not a bad way to spend an afternoon.

If you're into crime/thrillers, this one is definitely for you. Don't miss it!

title: Scorsese's Best?
review: The Departed is an extremely well done suspense film about an internal struggle on both sides of the law. Leonardo DiCaprio gives an amazing performance as Billy Costigan who's struggle to keep his true identity hidden from his crazed boss Frank Costello(Nicholson), and Agent Sullivan(Damon) produces a edge-of-your-seat experience leading to an explosive conclusion. This movie most certainly deserves the recognition it received and Martin Scorsese never looked better with his return to the crime genre. The Departed could very well be Scorsese's best film and deserves a spot next to other great crime classics such as The Godfather and Goodfellas.

title: Scorsese gets his Oscar but, for the wrong film
review:
Here is a cast of heavy hitters that was good to see in one film. Jack Nicholson's body of work is as thick as a New York City phone book and he has the hardware to back it up. Leonardo DiCaprio and Matt Damon are two of the finest young talent we have today. Martin Sheen and Mark Walberg also have proof in their pudding when it comes to their great careers. Alec Baldwin seems to show up everywhere these days. I was glad to see that Scorsese cast Vera Farminga as Damon love interest. I liked her in the short lived TV cop series "Touching Evil." This complex detective show lasted only one season, I wish USA would have given it more time. Apparently it was too complicated for today's TV audience whose brains have been turned to mush by the onslaught of imbecilic reality television. She is beautiful and sexy and I look forward to seeing more of Vera Farminga.

Martin Scorsese finally won the Oscar he so richly deserved although there were so many other films he should have one for. The world would never have balance without an Oscar in Scorsese hands.

As fares as this movie goes, it stinks!

title: Best movie of the year.
review: I would rate this movie a 10/10 but there are some things that don't really seem to show superb acting/directing/writing. First of all the plot really is a very intense plot that the viewer really needs to think about. Movies are suppose to be captivating and complex to a perfect medium. The Departed did that for me. I don't feel that the writing was particularly incredible because I don't think saying "F***" every other word shows realism. Plus, the last scene where Leo, and Matt's loyal troopers are killed the scene is way to rushed. And when Mark kills Damon I thought what motive does he have to kill him. Nothing was even mentioned about Mark knowing that Damon was the mole. He just held a grudge. As for those few things that bothered my about The Departed I am a fan of classic, organized crime movies, and this one with a delightful twist on it, one men lost between his two supposed loyalties and almost destroying himself over it and Damon trying to cover his own ass (sorry for the language). Still i like the genre, and I like violence. So if you agree with what I said, this is definitely the movie for you!

title: terrible- and i'm not joking
review:
Throughout Scorsese's film career, his films have been so over rated. Let's tear this film down. Jack Nicholson- same old performance, different guy. The problem with Jack is that he acts because he wants Oscars, not because he is great, or even cares for acting. Secondly, how many times have I heard him talk the same way- pulling a joker on us. Leonardo DiCraprio, as usual, crappy, over rated performance. I swear that Scorsese has something going on with DiCaprio. He just is not a great actor and I must admit his performances make me laugh. He has a Bostonian accent, then an American, Bostonian, American- give me a break. I remember how Titanic was nominated for 14 Oscars, NEARLY EVERYTHING, except Dicaprio's performance. Hmmm, I wonder. Mark Wahlberg and Matt Damon- crappy acting again, only saying the "f" word every other word to get a ridiculously stupid point across. Many people failed to see how this film robbed another movie- Infernal Affairs- which is much better than this film.

Why was the film met with so much praise? Because of the casting and direction. Believe me, if Scorsese hadn't directed this and/or if this film didn't have an all-star cast but still had the same look- it would have been seen as a "B" movie that would go nowhere. And that is what it is. Completely over rated, just like Goodfellas, but only ten times worse. The story was crappy, and the ending was very stupid and ridiculous. Scorsese needs to pack up his stuff and go home. He is in a desperate search for Oscars, which resulted this time in pity for him. The only reason Scorsese won was because of POOR MARTY, NEVER WON AN Oscar. LET'S GIVE ONE TO HIM SO HE DOESN'T FEEL BAD AND REALLY KNOW THAT HIS WORK SUCKS. As for Best Picture, I am really disappointed with the Academy. Another sympathy award for the years of crappy films of Scorsese- and to illustrate this further, JACK NICHOLSON PRESENTED THE AWARD WITH DIANE KEATON! Again, sympathy for mediocre actors just so we could see their faces light up- so Jack Nicholson may wrongly think inside that he is the main reason the film was great and should've been nominated instead of Wahlberg. BS! We must admit that Clint Eastwood is the master but was pushed aside this year all because of a sympathetic academy and many other as well. Little Miss Sunshine and Letters from Iwo Jima were the best films of 2006. Screw the wannabe mafia movie that can't even top the Godfather.

title: Awful!
review:
The original (Hong Kong movie) is much better than "the departed"... there are just too many Fxxx words and too much unnecessary violence in this movie...

The Departed comes by its puzzle pieces honestly  the movie, with an outstanding script by Kingdom of Heaven screenwriter William Monahan, is a relatively direct adaptation of Infernal Affairs, a great 2002 Hong Kong crime thriller steeped in Chinese conundrum and Hong Kong aesthetics. But where Infernal Affairs is less interested in psychological nuance than in Eastern-style elegance of action, Scorsese and Monahan showcase Western-style, actorly character building at its most enjoyable. DiCaprio's adult intensity as a young man agonizing over the disappearance of his real identity under the weight of playing someone he isn't is matched by Damon's thoughtful restraint. Wahlberg  a charismatic, always underrated natural  digs into his own Mean Beantown Streets background and comes up with surprising fury. Sheen, freed from West Wing presidential responsibilities, imbues his cop captain with a surprising pathos. As the one woman in an all-male saga, Farmiga's Madolyn hints at female secrets and personal sadnesses probably not necessary to the film but welcome nonetheless. The learned (or, in the case of Wahlberg, resumed) Boston accents sound ripe but right, with Baldwin adding his own audience-pleasing oomph to the exercise.

That said, however, as I said at the beginning, just too much unnecessary violence, and the cast is not really "believable"... I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone. :(

title: The Departed has the worst cast in history
review:
The Departed is one of the best films of Scorsese since Goodfellas but if the cast wasn't so bad it could be one of the best movies of all time, no bull. I'm not writing this to say who would be a better option, I'm doing it because most of these guys are very poor actors: Leonardo DiCaprio: I think is time for Scorsese to stop trading "special favors" for gigs in his flicks, here he's a tough guy, the only movie in where DiCaprio was alright is Catch me if yo can. He did Titanic which is the biggest piece of .... I've seen, The beach that was a ruin, Gangs of New York that was awful, The Aviator that was a torture to watch it until the end, and... oh yeah and the Man in the Iron Mask where he did OK because the character is a push over.

Jack Nicholson: He was tolerable but nothing special, I'm tired of him doing the same role of a psycho, he's done.

Marky Mark: This rapper/actor/joke is better known by his album called ... well who knows, I think he has like a third nipple and a brother in New Kids on the Block, yeah a real success. How does this guy can be on serious movies? Is like Vanilla Ice making the part of Sonny Corleone in the Godfather. This guy is awful.

Anthony Anderson: You know him, the black dude from Scary Movie, the boring one. Who I'm kidding they all were bad, that flick was terrible. Anyway, what was Scorsese thinking, why did he put a bad comic in the move, a rapper and a psycho weren't enough, he just had to put the comedian? This guy can't act to save his life.

Alec Baldwin: I have to be honest, this guy actually makes me laugh in the Saturday Night Live rejects show, 30 Rock, good show. But in this movie, oh man. How does this guy get so far in his career with just one character? He's useless in a drama because he has been in too many comic shows now and is not like he has diversity in which he transforms himself, no, he's the same guy every time. Or maybe is the haircut, who knows.

The rest were great: Martin Sheen, Matt Damon, Vera Farmiga and Ray Winstone. Man Scorsese ruin it with the terrible casting, just awful. The movie storyline, music, script is all great, is a great story. But what happened to Harvey Keitel, Robert DeNiro, Ray Liotta, Juliette Lewis, James Woods and Daniel Day-Lewis? He used to cast great actors.

Too bad that the movie is a rip off from an Asiatic flick called Infernal Affairs, so Scorsese really didn't do anything, any half with could direct that movie with references like that, he didn't write anything and the only job he had was to pick the right actors but he couldn't even do that right, Scorsese is a sham.

title: This movie gets a big F for abusing the F-Word!

There is also way too much blood and splatter and mindless violence. The characters portrayed in this movie seem to act impulsively without any self-control or remorse for their actions (both the "good" guys and the bad ones).
