Leonardo DiCaprio excels here as Billy Costigan and is simply mesmerizing whenever he is on screen, causing you to care about him, allowing us to sympathize with him due to the psychological and bodily pain he must endure and shows us how it would feel to be wedged into a network of unfamiliar but relentless danger, while at the same time, he's attempting to find his way with whatever clues he is able to find. DiCaprio may have been loathed for his pretty boy looks, but he has become an accomplished and adaptable actor and The Departed allows him to showcase more of his acting greatness. Matt Damon also delivers a brilliant performance as Colin Sullivan, having great assurance in himself as well as Scorsese putting Matt's traits into a character that isn't compassionate in the slightest, something Damon did in Syriana, but takes it to a greater level in this film. We don't really feel for Damon, and you desire to see him get captured, yet at the same time he's not a typical cardboard villain, and Matt does an incredible job showing us a man who has lost his ethical compass, but is still tore about his twin personalities regardless, and isn't content about the brewing conflict. He is an obsessive liar, but is openly hurt when his untruthfulness affects his relationship with his girlfriend.

I can honestly say that The Departed is a perfect film in every level, and while some viewers may find the plot confusing and the whole who is back-stabbing who hard to follow, this film is still worth watching. It's well paced, has great suspense, brilliant acting, tight editing, a killer soundtrack and is shot wonderfully. So do yourself a favor and go watch this film, it's the true definition of a masterpiece.

title: Revisit the old school of cinematic nuance.
review: Simply superb!!. Brilliant screen writing together with intense direction and acting clubbed with tight editing makes it top class.The pace of the film is what you grips in. Starting from the first shot the story telling is of the highest level where the characters are on this thin line of good and bad with each surpassing the other territory sometimes briefly or sometimes permanently.The biblical themes of crime punishment and redemption gives the plot an interesting look. Martin Scorsese getting an Oscar finally for direction and remarkably what a fine film to be the medium.An ensemble cast together with technical expertise makes it a definite watch for all those who cherish good cinema.

title: Maybe. Maybe not. Maybe go FCUK yourself.
review: The first time I watched "The Departed", it was because a friend told me that it was the best ensemble cast and the most original story that he had ever seen. After watching the film, I did agree that it was a terrific cast but it did remind me of a film called "infernal Affairs". I honestly do think that "The Departed" is a great remake of a solid Hong Kong film, but I will say that I do get bothered when people tell me that it is a movie based on Whitey Bulger. Jack's character could possibly be a reflection of Whitey, but the story came from "Infernal Affairs" most definitely. "Black Mass" is a movie based on Whitey. "The Departed" is great fiction with elements taken from reality. Also, I would like to point out that even though all the performances were beyond amazing. I thought Mark Wahlberg's performance, as small as it may have been, was one of my favorite characters from "The Departed".

title: superb acting, and the only American reboot i LOVE
review: Now I know that 'The Departed' is based off of the Hong Kong movie 'WuJianDao' 'Infernal Affairs', but Scorsese really grabs hold of a great story and brings it to the American Screen. My father grew up in Boston and when we walked out of the theater he couldn't stop talking about how authentic the environment and attitude was. Then there's the acting in which the lead actors (Nicholson, DiCaprio, Damon) not only give stunningly entertaining performances, but you become engulfed in each one's perspective and dilemmas. The smaller roles that of (Baldwin, Walberg, Sheen) are supporting roles that remind me of Jesus Quintana from 'The Big Lebowski', by this I mean that their screen time is limited but they make lasting impressions that you cherish each and every scene they are in, Alec Baldwin especially. The story itself starts off with the basic intro of the players and the setting, but you'll find yourself slowing following each and every plot twist and rooting back and forth for the good guys and for the bad guys. If you're a Scorsese fan, which I am, I think you will appreciate this film. You can clearly see the Scorsese touch ranging from the cinematography and of course the music, it's great to hear "Gimme Shelter" again, but "Comfortably Numb" played in so well. It's another gangster flick from Scorsese, yet this one stands alone because feels so fresh and most would agree Scorsese does gangster films the best; so why not let him. Oscar worthy, the acting I certainly hope; this is DiCaprio's best role since 'The Aviator' which was his best role since 'Gangs of New York', am I seeing a pattern here. But my lasting impression wasn't concerned with the politics of the golden statue; my lasting impression was that I had sat through 2 and half hours of brilliant and especially entertaining storytelling. Thank you Mr. Scorsese.

title: Scorsese' Best Movie and DiCaprios Best Performance
review: Despite having four decades worth of competition The Departed in my opinion is the greatest movie Martin Scorsese has ever made because it does everything that movie needs to be good and much more. Leonardo DiCaprio was simply incredible in this movie it's not only his best performance but it's one of the best of all time as there is a story on his face and a variety of emotions with every new scene. The film also have layers upon layers of tension in every scene making it truly unpredictable right up until the very end. While out shined by DiCaprio the rest of the cast give fantastic Performances particularly Matt Damon who also gives the best performance of his career. While it's always going to bug me that Mark Walberg was the only actor in this movie to be nominated for an Oscar he was still fantastic and was the comic relief of the film. The film is quite simply directed perfectly channelling the chaotic and unstable themes of the film ensured Scorsese his best director Oscar. This is one of my favourite movies of all time and it truly is a masterpiece.

title: Incredibly paced and interesting, though with a slightly disappointing ending.
review:
You will either be completely intrigued by this movie or completely turned off by it. If you don't mind gratuitous amounts of profanity and some brutal violence and love a complex plot, it's great fun to watch. The first hour is a roller coaster of intercuts and setups. I don't think there is a conventional continuous scene until the point where the story lines meet up in Costello's exchange with his Chinese trading partners. The only way to tell when a real "scene" is over otherwise is when the soundtrack changes songs.

In some ways I kind of wish this had been made into a TV series because we would have gotten all of those smaller moments that weren't important enough to show in 150 minutes. For Sullivan and Costigan to be so trusted by their superiors, there had to have been hundreds of other cumulative events that made Costello and Ellerby to not suspect them of betrayal. As it was, we get some great and interesting scenes on this topic. One would think that there would be no suspense if we already know who the moles are, but the suspense comes from the question of how they will be discovered and how they can uncover each other.

For this reason, much of the plot is character driven. You'll have a favorite and least favorite character by the end. But it seems that they want you to side with Costigan rather than Sullivan. Costigan hates the crimes he has to take part in, whereas Sullivan works for Costello by choice and mostly for his own benefit. Aside from them, the supporting cast is not presented in an overly positive or negative light. Even Costello and Mr. French are not made so despicable that they cannot be liked. I wasn't huge on the main characters getting gradually killed off in the last 45 minutes of the movie, but it does result in some good twists.

There are not many movies that top this one in technical execution. Sure there are big budget CGI action movies and such now, but the raw trade of filmmaking is at its best here. The pacing of the script and Scorsese's work directing as well as the great use of music are excellent and make a good story into a great movie. The acting is pretty good, though it wasn't Damon's best performance and Wahlberg was not Oscar worthy as Dignam. However, DiCaprio and Nicholson were great in their roles.

If you plan on going into the filmmaking business, this is a must-see. If not, it's an interesting watch or two hours of torture. I know some people dislike Scorsese's style and think it's unpleasant to watch, which is understandable. But in some ways, it's good to know that the sort of crime that goes on in mob movies is very real. The one thing I can guarantee you will not be is bored. Overall Rating: 8.6/10.

title: I'm departed!
review: Who doesn't love Leo, Demon and Jack the great Nicholson? All together in a one classy crime drama in which you'll love all the characters with their intensity. Vulnerability of all the characters makes the movie more entertaining as well as touchy. I can't simply forget the lovely face of Vera Farmiga with whom I was in love when she approaches Leo in his vulnerable state. Mark Wahleberg is an additional feature of this film and leaves an effect of a rough cop! Jack like all his great characters, lives a true godfather person and nearly threatens you to your neck. Direction of Scorsese is really well and we can feel the bloody streets and creepy laughs of the criminals and dirty guys. But the real drama is within the inner minds of the each characters whether it is the hero or villain. I suggest you to watch it if you're looking for classy crime drama!

title: Dicaprio should have gotten the Oscar
review:
Although Dicaprio now has his Oscar, it's come 10 years too late in my opinion. He should have gotten it for his role as Billy Costigan in the Departed. He is brilliant in this. In fact, the whole film is brilliant. It is a raw and brutal portrayal of Irish organised crime. Jack Nicholson was fantastic as the antagonistic mob boss Frank Costello.

One thing I didn't like was Martin Sheen and Mark Whalburg as Billy Costigan's superiors. To me they bordered too much on the good cop/bad cop stereotype and I think that Mark Whalburg was far too over the top in his role as the bad cop.

Read my full review here: http://goo.gl/zsjgUV

title: Good ... not great
review: I like this film, but I certainly don't love it. My biggest problem with it is that I just don't like Nicholson in this one. It's not that I think he gives a particularly bad performance. I just think he's the entirely wrong person to be playing this part. (Is there a right person to be playing an apparently Irish gangster named "Frank Costello"? Where the hell does that name come from?) He really seems to be walking around in a different film from the rest of the cast. His giant presence seems to pull the focus of the film away from where it should be sitting with Damon and DiCaprio. I have a few other small issues. Scorsese's usually infallible feel for music seems to have let him down here since he includes both the intolerably awful Dropkick Murphys and a terrible version of "Confortably Numb" by Roger Waters with Van Morrison's band (???). I do like Vera Farmiga quite a lot here, but I'm ultimately unclear why her character is in the film.

title: nice story but end of its not good
review: story is going well until its end. poor ending for me. Jack and Leonardo acts so good.The Departed is a thoroughly engrossing gangster drama with the gritty authenticity and soupy morality we come to expect.Most of Martin Scorsese's films have been about men trying to realize their inner image of themselves. That's as true of Travis Bickle as of Jake LaMotta, Rupert Pupkin, Howard Hughes, the Dalai Lama, Bob Dylan or, for that matter, Jesus Christ. "The Departed" is about two men trying to live public lives that are the radical opposites of their inner realities. Their attempts threaten to destroy them, either by implosion or fatal betrayal. The telling of their stories involves a moral labyrinth, in which good and evil wear each other's masks.

title: Replication
review: After watching Infernal Affairs (2002) its really unacceptable that legendary Director like Martin Scorsese just copied the screens, scripts, story of the whole movie. My little man inside of me wants to know the reason. Moreover I watched The departed in 2012 and Infernal affairs in 2016, Director even not acknowledge the credits of that movie. Shame for Hollywood to appreciate such movie in the Oscar and so far other awards like Golden Globe. The story was a one twisted piece of mystery and director copied it. Its beyond my belief Director such as him done it. The juniors who will watch this review before watching Departed, I want to suggest them to watch Infernal Affairs first and then Departed. I am not going to change my previous vote until its rating downs. One vote is a nano matter against millions of votes but its also a symbol of millions of conscience.

title: For those who STILL haven't seen it yet.... SEE IT!!
review:
Here is one of those movies that prove that there is no other person who can do Police/Gangster dramas better than Scorsese. Among the fast-talking characters, the bloody violence, a plethora of quick- paced, fast-cutting montages, and other of Scorsese's other filmmaking quirks, this is easily the most grounded, most clever, and most engaging of these movies rarely replicated even today. With solid acting, a tangibly gritty New York atmosphere, and a whole lot of blood, THE DEPARTED is as good as you heard, and easily the pinnacle gangster movie since THE GODFATHER.

What comes into play is the dynamic between both the undercover cop, the head cop, and the mob boss. The two know who he is, and are always under tension from whoever takes him down. All of it adds up to some of the bloodiest, coolest gun battles and punch-throwing I have ever seen.

The cast is terrific as always. Scorsese uses his actors to their fullest potential and they all shine. DiCaprio may seem like his pretty-boy looks does not fit this movie, but it works; a troubled undercover detective caught way over his head with both the dangerous mob scene and the detective work that may or may not be using him. Matt Damon is as charming as always, and there is always some fun to be had with Martin Sheen, Mark Wahlberg, and even Alec Baldwin. But hands down the best performance is the great Jack Nicholson. For such a rotten, pride stricken mob boss, he is clearly having fun as always.

Outside of that, there really isn't much to say that requires a spoiler warning, so yeah. GO SEE IT! The cast is great, the story is lean and simple yet engaging, Scorsese directs the hell out of this with his usual style, and it is all around a bloody good time!

title: Great direction, writing and acting make this one a definite winner
review:
With The Departed, Martin Scorsese does that thing has done so successfully over the years where he takes what would ordinarily be pretty basic genre material and injects it with his particular dynamic style, elevating the resultant movie in the process. This of course was the film where he finally got the Oscar he so obviously craved and while this is certainly not his best film, it's still a very good one indeed. Its set around the Boston organised crime scene and it examines the blurry lines that exist between how the good guys and bad guys go about their business. To this end an undercover agent is sent to infiltrate the Irish Mafia, while in reverse the gangsters send in one of their young affiliates to enrol and work for the police department, with the purpose of reporting back to the gangsters all police activity. Before long their paths gets dangerously intertwined.

Aside from Scorsese's typically energetic and lively direction, this one is notable for its extremely good cast. There are so many top performers that it feels like an ensemble film. Leonardo DiCaprio and Matt Damon play the two undercover men at the heart of the story and both actors offer up multi-dimensional portrayals of their characters. Its top drawer stuff from the two principals and it really helps draw the viewer in but there are so many other top actors putting in high calibre work here that it's impossible to mention them all in proper detail. But suffice to say Jack Nicholson is at his charismatic best in the role of a somewhat unsympathetic and nasty crime boss; Vera Farmiga is luminous and magnetic as a police psychologist who is the object of affections of both undercover men, while Mark Wahlberg puts in an absolutely hilarious turn as a police boss with a decidedly confrontational manner.

This is superior stuff essentially. Despite its many characters and plot avenues, it's so very well written that it is always compelling and involving. Along with the later The Wolf of Wall Street (2013), it showed pretty conclusively that, despite his advancing years, Scorsese was still at the top of his game and had certainly not mellowed with age.

title: The Departed is better than your average film but that is only because Martin Scorsese is better than your average director.
review:
Strip away the glossy exterior of possibly questionable performances by an all-star cast with the direction of a stellar director and you are left with mordantly skewed dialogue from an unoriginal (adapted) script written by the infamous William Monahan who destroyed Ridley Scott's filmography with 'Kingdom of Heaven' (39% RT) and 'Body of Lies' (54% RT) a year or two after some of Scott's greats such as 'Gladiator' (76% RT) and 'Black Hawk Down' (76% RT). Spoiler Alert: His other movies he did the screenplay for: Mojave (2016) got 31% RT (Mark Wahlberg was in this one too). Edge of Darkness got 56% RT. The Gambler (also with Mark Wahlberg) got 46% RT. THESE ARE HIS TOP FILMS. Also I can see Wahlberg trying to get that Best Supporting Actor Oscar with his harlotry by working with Monahan seeing as The Departed got him a nomination for the Best Supporting Actor Oscar that year. If The Departed was written so well why then has Monahan shown that apart from a stolen script he cannot make a proper script? If the Departed was written so well then why has Scorcese refused to make The Departed 2 (Monahan had made a script that would involve bringing back the actors)? If The Departed had such a good script, with so many good actors, with such a large budget for its setting (half of it going to the actors), and Robert DeNiro being in 8 of Scorsese's films with most of them being classics why then did Robert DeNiro decide to decline the offer to star in the film and make another? These aren't conclusively damning questions but watching the movie itself conclusively damns the script...

Also, read the first paragraph of the reviews from the Top Critics of Rotten Tomatoes. Most of them praise Scorsese, the actors and how funny the movie is. Only a couple of the Top Critics praise the plot and screenplay. Only one praises Monahan. Also about 8 out of the 44 demonise the film itself.

Everyone was too eager since Casino (1995) to see another true Scorsesian movie and jumped on the bandwagon of this one thinking it was what they needed. In the past 10 years this has been a truer Scorsesian movie just not a great one. Also, swearing and profanity doesn't pass for a good script either. In fact you are more likely to use these tools when you don't have a good script.

P.S. % RT = Rotten Tomatoes critic ratings.

title: Great Crime Film
review:
In The Departed every actor plays to his strengths and it's a film that's worth watching just for the performances. The casting is just perfect. Leonardo DiCaprio is at his best playing the kind of character he was born to play. Matt Damon adds his typical humour to the film.

But besides that this is a film you would expect from Martin Scorcese in its combination of violence and comedy. It's a gritty crime thriller with just enough pictures of the real world to make it feel realistic.

The story is top notch. It keeps you on your toes as you observe its every twist and turn never knowing in whose favour the story might end. The characters play a cat and mouse game with one another with the roles often switching. And of course you can't not mention the music. The film's theme song is one of those catchy tunes that sticks in your head for a long time.

Perhaps the only thing I didn't like about the film is the ending which seemed abrupt. Other than that The Departed is a great film and a must see for all crime genre fans.

title: good cop and bad cop
review: I think the Departed was a thriller from the beginning. Two young men attend Highway patrol academy and become outstanding cops in Boston. Dicaprio and Damon go different directions Costigan really good and Sullivan goes bad working with Jack Nicholson as Frank Costello The movie was very long but action packed. Big time criminals but Frank does his own collection work. They have played roles similar to this movie. The sound was superb with all the bullets flying could have edited out some scenes to shorten some but I like a flow of Action moving pacing the scenes yes the theme fits the bill as crime don't pay Martin Scorsese has another successful movie. Anyone who likes this director has got to watch this bloodbath.

title: Excellent! Just love it
review: I am a big Leonardo DiCaprio fan and have almost watched all his movies.The Departed is a mind blowing thriller based on the 2004 Hong Kong movie "Wu Jian Dao".Mark Nicholson really made me laugh for about entirely the whole movie.Other top actors such as Walberg too added grace to the film and kept the momentum going.This film overall was the complete package for me.It is simply based on cops and Irish gang who each have a mole in their side and they try to figure that out till the end.The movie brilliant.Background scores perfect,loved the track "I am shipping up to Boston" by Dick Murphy.The actors have acted brilliantly.Overall I would recommend each one of action thriller junkies to definitely watch this no matter if you already watched the original.Just go for it its even better.Hats off to Scorsese who really pulled it off

title: Amazing Movie
review:
Martin Scorsese is put on this earth to make such movies.

The casting and acting in general is "something". From Jack Nicholson, playing his amazing self, to Matt Damon, I'm always in control, just ... perfect. Trust me this deserves his own point, Leonardo DiCaprio. I'm not gay but I've got a man crush on him. You couldn't avert your eyes from his performance, even if you tried. As far as directing is concerned, while this is not the best movie Scorsese ever maid, for me the honor belongs to Goodfellas, it is a really close call. Why then only 7 out of 10 stars. This movie is a remake out of Infernal Affairs. In its own right an amazing movie even with the cultural barrier, being an foreign movie. But with the talent involved it is a little bit sad to only create a new version instead of something original. That being said, this movie will grab your attention and never let go for 2,5 hours. Quite the accomplishment given the usual average movie length. I recommend this movie to not only the thriller genre fans, but to everybody who is not afraid of violence in movies. You will be glued to your seat.

title: The best and the only one western remake of Hongkong "Infernal Affairs" movie
review: The most interesting and emotional movie which keeps you in the stress over the whole movie till the end! Dedicted to drama and criminal lovers! The movie is about Irland mafia in Boston. Their hard life, most of them couldn't find good job and decided start doing criminal affairs. "The Departed" breaths of Irland culture, Irland people's life in USA (Boston). This is about friends relationships, about friendship and treachery, love and hatred, criminal insider life. You should be ready that this is remake of one of the bet criminal Hongkong movie calls "Infernal Affairs" (2002). So if you already watched this movie be ready that they practically fully carry the plot from Hongkong into Boston (USA). That is the really classic story of "Good Cop, Bad Cop"!

title: Extremely recommended
review: Mr. Scorsese had his ups and downs throughout the career. In both cases it was somehow extreme. This one is definitely in the "ups" and of the best he has ever made. Supported by excellent cast of peers (noone really stands out, except maybe for Jack Nicholson being over the top at moments), with fantastic cinematography and editing, Mr. Scorsese shows everybody how to tell a story. Fantastic editing and direction, with subtle messages through music and details in scenes, makes this movie one of the best ever made in the genre. Here one finds everything that makes a good old-fashioned rich movie experience: deep plot, twists and turns, tense, emotions and something I call "unpredictable predictability" (when one knows what is going to happen but not how and when). Excellent job, everybody. Now, watch the movie and give credit where the credit is due.

title: The Departed
review: The Departed is one of the best thrillers that I have ever seen. Martin Scorsese choose well when he teamed Matt Damon, Leonardo DiCaprio and Mark Wahlberg up against each other and the good and bad guys. The good cop that went bad, the good cop that went good, and the jerk in charge of it all, all showed up for work on this picture. The movie had me wondering but not most of the time and before I knew became sexy. It captured my attention throughout but even though I paid close attention, I felt like I missed the story. At one point, two points, three points, it broke my heart. Nothing like Shakespeare but it did share a story of reason against the unreasonable, and I think that's what won out.Reason - possibly good, not great!

title: Superbly executed!!
review: The Departed is an excellent film with an excellent casts with each actor playing their role with utmost sincerity and intensity . It is undeniably one of those few films that keeps you on edge of your seat all through out the screen-time. The characterization is superbly executed, along with the direction in which the film is projected, with some over the top , unexpected funny moments thrown from time to time that helps us stay sane and relaxed. And the best thing is the film gets more intense as the story moves forward and we can't help but want to see what happens in the end.... n.b. Jack Nicholson stands out as the best character!

title: One of those movies that gets better every time you watch it.
review:
I am not sure if this review contains spoilers but to be on the safe side I checked the box.

A Boston State Trooper goes undercover to infiltrate a Boston crime boss. A Boston crime boss has one of his loyal followers go into the State Police. Each looking for who the rat is. Does that sound confusing? It should be.

When fantastic actors, like Matt Damon, Jack Nicolas and Leo DiCaprio play the respective "rats" and one of the best directors to ever walk the face of the earth at the helm makes this a non-linear story line that is surpassingly easy to follow. We follow DiCaprio and Damon as they go through Police Academy and choose what side of the law they will be loyal to.

Other actors like Martin Sheen and Mark Walberg just elevate this story line and every part of this narrative. Themes of brotherhood, father and son relationships as well as loyalty to the law. Scorsese has had a lot of hits, too many to name, while his early work like "Raging Bull", "Taxi Driver" and "Goodfellas", will go down in history as his best, his later work like "The Departed", "Hugo" and "The Wolf of Wall Street" are fantastic as well and will probably age just as well as his other films.

This is a long film, with a running time of 151 minutes most filmmakers would loose focus and pacing, Scorsese is one of the few great directors who is up for this challenge. Like Eastwood in "Mystic River" this is a movie that should be lost in the undercover cop genre but with expert acting, directing, cinematography, and editing make this a must see for any film fan.

Mikes Movie Minute

title: This is some tense stuff
review:
I'd heard a major spoiler before seeing "The Departed" several years back, which I honestly though ruined the movie. But the death of that primary character was only a small piece of it. Most of the time with this movie, you're just wondering which "something bad" is going to happen to DiCaprio. I mean, the walls just do not stop closing in on this guy. Scorsese lays on the dread something fierce. But those last ten minutes of the film are on twist after the next, just one character turning on another. And even today, I was caught right up in it, as if I'd never seen this before.

Plot twists aside (and they happen like shotgun blasts), "The Departed" sells itself with its roster of actors. I mean, just look at this cast. Not to mention the sizzling dialogue. I dunno if crime epic is the right phrase for this, but it's definitely a killer cop/mob movie.

8/10

title: Martin Scorsese has done it again
review:
The Departed

Martin Scorsese is a genius. He shows detailed stories about mobsters in carefully crafted pieces of artwork. But this time, he has outdone himself. Featuring legendary performances by Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, and the decade defining Jack Nicholsan. Martin Scorsese stuns viewers with great camera shots, many sided characters, and an excellent soundtrack. I even liked this more than Good fellas. One gem in this masterpiece is Jack Nicholsan's performance as Costello, a violent mobster. When people look back, this will be known as a great American classic.

title: Favourite dicaprio movie
review: This movie is really good. I really wanted to see it when I first heard about it and I thought it would be brilliant and when I watched it I realised I thought right. Scorcese is a great director and this is probably my favourite one of his movies. Leonardo dicaprio, Matt damon, Jack nicholson, Mark wahlberg, Alec baldwin and Martin sheen are very good in this movie. I loved the scene where Billy beats up the guys in the shop and the best part in the movie is when Costello dies even though he was probably my favourite character. The end scene on the roof was really good and I thought it was quite sad when Queenan died. If you love Scorcese movies then you should definitely watch this movie

title: Scorsese's ''Goodfellas'' spirit comes back in this.
review:
This brought director Martin Scorsese back into the organized crime genre, which I loved, so much.

As for The Departed? Probably still to this day one of the best crime movies I have watched in the 2000's, to date. This movie is magnificent in every level.

Billy Costigan is hired as a undercover cop playing mole for the Irish crime boss Frank Costello, while already a high ranking cop Colin Sullivan who works in the same PD as Billy does, is actually the real mole for Frank Costello. The story was already brilliant (giving credit where it is due, this movie was inspired by Chinese movie Infernal Affair).

The acting was very good too, with Leonardo Dicaprio at his best in my opinion. I was never a huge Leo guy to be honest, but when I watched this my opinion changed very fast. The same thing for Matt Damon, he surprised me in this one too. Though the best of everyone in this movie has to be in my opinion Jack Nicholson as Franky Costello. Man, Jack is back and more psychotic than ever! He is one of the most charismatic actors I have ever seen. All and all, The Departed is a very thrilling movie that will leave you satisfied.

title: The Last Great Crime Movie
review: Six. Six times I have seen this movie, and six times it has left me with my jaw on the ground and rubbing my eyes in amazement. The plot, the writing, the directing, and the acting, are all beyond exceptional. Incredibly in depth, the film is perhaps Scorsese's most underrated, a movie that belongs in the archives. While many crime films have plots whose holes are crudely filled in with blood and action, this is delicately laid out and executed in the most satisfying way. While faint shadows of Goodfella's can be seen throughout, DiCaprio and Nicholson's performance make this film their own. This movie forever changed criminal cinema in the millennium.

title: Talent was well used
review:
My immediate reaction is: Wow! There is a lot to process.

I'd heard about this movie and actually saw a bit of a spoiler from WatchMojo. I never bothered to watch it before because I understood it to be a drama and I usually need to be in the mood for dramas.

With a movie so star studded it got me thinking about other star studded movies that actually delivered. First, let me qualify "star studded". I mean a movie having four or more actors/actresses that are legitimate "A" listers: e.g. Ocean's Eleven, Rat Race, Casino, Pulp Fiction, Independence Day, Blues Brothers, and Roots. I'm sure there are at least a couple names I'm missing but these were the ones that immediately came to mind. I'd now like to add The Departed to that list.

Some of my least favorite star studded movies are: Armageddon, Be Cool, Grown Ups and Soul Plane to name a few. With star studded movies there are usually high expectations. With high expectations there is either a meets, outperform or underperform. It's so easy to underperform because the bar is set so high.

This movie did not disappoint. It was very cleverly written and of course, well acted. I would say that they all performed well but DiCapprio delivered an even better performance than the rest. Scorcese did not waste the talent he had to work with.

title: Simply brilliant quotes and superb acting
review:
The departed is like old wine which get on you as many times you watch this movie. Acting by cast is brilliant especially Jack Nicholson and Leo Every quotes is worth remembering. You cant single out a moment where u feel the movie is dragging. The editing is crisp with many twist and turns. Matt Damon is brilliant. he can proudly show this movie in resume high up in list.

what baffle me a bit is ending, it could be more towards what a viewer want it to be, nevertheless the movie scores high on keeping the tension high throughout.background music is in sync with movie. Martin once again proved himself to be brilliant storyteller

title: Not Scorsese's Best But Still Wonderful
review:
Fantastic, gritty cinematography compounds with an excellent story and great cast to give us The Departed, one of the best crime dramas of the past fifteen years. The police send a mole into Jack Nicholson's crime syndicate to get evidence against him while Jack has a mole in the police. Each mole is trying to find out who the other is as the police and the criminals get closer and closer to a confrontation.

I wouldn't say this is a really intense thriller as it didn't leave me at the edge of my seat, but it was a very good one that kept you watching to the very end. The ending may be shocking to some, though I found it to be what I expected (and this could come from my recent run-through of all of Tarantino's movies).

The X's all over the movie give snobs something to think over while the movie is engaging and interesting enough for anyone to enjoy. Be prepared for a cameo by Jack Nicholson's pecker, something I'm sure will be remembered forever.

Overall, a fantastic crime thriller that any fan of adult in tone films will enjoy.

title: A Gangland Masterpiece for the 21st Century
review:
The Departed is one of the best cop movies I've ever seen, and one of the best gangster movies I've ever seen. I cannot remember any movie that has kept me more on edge and for a longer period of time than this film. Even now, writing this, my nerves are shot, and not just because it's finals week.

The situation is that the Massachusetts State Police are finally closing in on Boston's top gangster, Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson). They've finally gotten an undercover officer (Leonardo Dicaprio) into his gang. But Costello's got a mole of his own (Matt Damon) in the department. And both sides realize they've been infiltrated. So like the best spy thriller, it becomes a race by the two sides to find the rat in their midst. And the stakes are life and death.

There are so many close calls in this movie that it's just unbelievable. There are so many times when Damon and Dicaprio almost get a bead on each other, so many times that doing their job requires them to come within a hair's breadth of blowing their cover, so many conversations where we're thinking "This is it, the hammer's gonna drop." There's a million ways either man could get found out, and no margin for error. The result is more tension and suspense than any movie since High Noon. In that movie you knew nothing was going to go down until the end. There's no such guarantee here, and it's absolutely nerve wracking.

And none of it would work if the actors weren't absolutely on top of their game. DiCaprio has never been more physical or more on edge than he is here. As Billy Costigan, he's wound up tighter than a watch spring, likely to explode at any moment, verbally if you're lucky, physically if you're not. If you look closely enough, you can tell it's an act, but one that's being put on for the gangsters, not us. He radiates stress and an increasing aura of dread. He knows that he can't stay undercover forever, and it's absolutely driving him up the wall. He's got to let off steam, and if it adds to his cover as a loose cannon, all the better.

In contrast, Damon's character is much smoother and under control. He's in a role that he's been playing his entire life. And he's in a position from which he can turn attention to anyone but himself. But under the front of calm professionalism, the tension is always there. Because it's not just the police he has to worry about, if he doesn't deliver, he has to deal with Costello. And Costello is a man you don't want to deal with. Ruthless, amoral, borderline psychotic, and with a massive entitlement complex, he's the archetype of the Boston gangster. He's as smart as they come and surprisingly charming for a scumbag, and no-one could have played him better than Nicholson.

As with any of Scorsese's gangster films, there's a powerful atmosphere to The Departed, one of danger, corruption, and decay. Graphic violence and language are everywhere. Costello and his crew whack people for the most trivial of reasons, then dump their bodies as nonchalantly as if they were taking out the trash. Cops and criminals alike drop F-bombs like they're paid to say it. Crumbling brownstones, smoke filled bars, and the grim expressions of the locals paint a world where life is cheap, every road is a dead end, and the law is just a bunch of big words. This is the closest to the Boston projects most of us will ever want to come.

The Departed is what every thriller hopes to be. It's smart as it is intense, it has great shoot-outs, it maintains an incredible level of suspense, and it keeps you guessing with unexpected twists. It's the mark of a great director to consistently put out great movies decade after decade, and this is one of Scorsese's greatest.

title: My favorite movie of all time
review:
The Departed is my favorite movie of all time. Besides an all-star cast, the plot is terrific and full of twists.

The setting is so interesting; being from LA, I never realized that Boston's mob scene is just as alive and kicking today as it would seem from the movies!

The soundtrack is great and I discovered some new favorite artists, like the Dropkick Murphys. Any time I hear "Shipping Up to Boston" I have an insatiable urge to go watch the Departed.

I have shown this movie (repeatedly) to everyone important in my life and they all love it too. The perfect movie-night go-to.

title: The mob movie
review:
I always have a hard time getting into mob movies and this was no exception. The first hour did have me glued to the screen but after a while all the violence and f-bombs blurred together and I stopped paying close attention. I also got fed up with all the flip phone action (were they new and cool in 2006 or something?) Anyways they drove me crazy.

The cast is a veritable whose-who; Jack Nicholson is, Jack and he's awesome, as are Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon and Mark Wahlberg. They play two sides of organized crime in South Boston as the state police wage war on Irish American organized crime. A young undercover cop Billy Costigan is assigned to infiltrate the mob syndicate run by gangland chief Frank Costello (Nicholson).

Despite the two distinct sides portrayed here I still felt everyone was bad, just bad for a different cause. And the ending, "head shots" the first one was completely brilliant and surprising in a WTF just happened kind of way by the 3rd or 4th time it was just overkill (pun intended) and lost its value. 09.13

title: The Departed is one of Jack's classics
review: I watched The Departed on UK television last night, and it brought home to me what Jack is all about...He is just the best guy on the planet. He brings such wisdom and intensity to his roles in film. He can make you want to root for him and want to see him crushed within minutes as he plays out his role. The Departed will always stand the the test of time as one of the understated great ones, bringing the harsh realities of gangland life to the screen. Loved it. Leo is becoming a true acting legend of our lifetime. Taking on this role, he manages to step away from his pretty-boy looks role and really shows his true talents. Well worth its Oscar. GK should stick to what he does best, making this type of gritty crime drama.

title: Scorsese's Best
review: Watched one my favorite films thats The Departed one of my favorite Crime Dramas Films Featured an Amazing Performance from a Stellar Lead by Oscar Nominee Leonardo DiCaprio(Blood Diamond) as Billy Costigan , Also Featuring Matt Damon(Good Will Hunting) as Colin Sullivan, Mark Wahlberg(The Italian Job) as Sean Dingnam,Martin Sheen(Apocalypse Now) as Oliver Queenan,Ray Winstone (Cold Mountain) as Mr. French,Alec Baldwin(30 Rock) as George Ellerbu Also Featuring Ukranian Beauty Vera Farmiga(The Manchurian Candidate) as Madolyn Madden also Starring The Great Jack Nicholson(The Shining) as Frank Costello. The film is filled with twist and turns also is suspenseful also it is intriguing its not your typical crime drama which makes it great also Amazing Performances from Leonardo DiCaprio and Jack Nicholson, Amazing Screenplay by William Monahon(Kingdom Of Heaven), Costume Designs By Sandy Powell(Shakespeare In Love) and Direction By Martin Scorsese(Goodfellas) Defenitley This Is His Best Work 9/10

title: The Departed
review:
The Departed directed by Martin Scorsese takes place in Boston Massachusetts following the lives of several underground criminal figures and those dedicated to bringing them to justice. The criminal underworld is brought to life with characters such as Jack Nicholson, playing the part of Frank Costello a violent unhinged criminal boss who has managed to infiltrate the Massachusetts State Police. Matt Damon's character Collin Sullivan a corrupt police officer helping him further his criminal interests. The members of the State Police have a suspicion that Costello has a propensity to avoid them so effortlessly that he must be receiving information from an informant or "rat".

The State Police's special Investigations Unit is headed up by Martin Sheens character Captain Queenan and Mark Walberg's foul mouthed Staff Sergeant Dignam. Devising a plot to implant a State Police undercover agent into Costello's organization they enlist the help of Leonardo DiCapreo's Billy Costigan. Costigan's family has a long history of crime in the Boston area and a loose association with Costello's outfit, making him ideal to infiltrate with raising much of a concern from the leadership element the Boston Underworld. The film is revolving around the theme of moral implications and human struggle. The moral implications are put to the viewer as the actions of both parties continue throughout the film. Human struggle is clearly a central theme in the film in the sense of "good vs evil" and the toll it takes on the individuals caught with in the struggle.

Proving himself through smaller criminal endeavors such as collecting and enforcement Costigan proves he is a "trustworthy" criminal associate, leading to him delving deeper into Costello's world. Costigan has had his identity as a State Police Officer totally erased and reports only to Cpt. Queenan and Staff Sergeant Dignam, playing the part of this criminal begins to have effects on Costigan in a mental and physical effect. Costigan is able to discuss these issues with a State sponsored psychiatrist Madolyn Madden played by Vera Farminga who coincidently has an ongoing relationship with Det. Sullivan. Madden begins a physical relationship with both men, not being aware of the fact that Costigan is actually a Police officer, his cover has a parolee states meetings with her are a condition of his parole. Through a botched sting attempt that Costello escapes with the help of Det. Sullivan the two informants begin to suspect that each other exist. A dangerous game of cat and mouse then ensues as the two men attempt to reveal the others identity to their respective handlers, leading to the inevitable clash of "good vs evil".

The Departed is fast paced and easy to become immersed in, well written and directed the cast of Hollywood heavy weights carrying the film makes this film a must watch on multiple genres of film. Shot on location throughout the city of Boston the scenery lends to the reality of the film.

title: Okey!
review: "Most of Martin Scorsese's films have been about men trying to realize their inner image of themselves". Roger Ebert. This is partially true with all due respect. This is the film remake of 2002's Hong Kong based crime thriller movie "Infernal Affairs". I am not going to compare these two film because there is none! These two film is the overrated successful on their own attitude and altitude! But on the aspect of Mr.Scorsese's "Goodfellas" and "Shutter Island", these films is no better, although those are the first class movie to me. "Departed" is extremely enjoyable for those if you are a film buff. For those who are not, is not going to enjoy that much but apparently it is a good movie, better than so many. Hope you'll find out on your own. Thanx for reading. Watch & enjoy!

title: Awesome Crime
review: The departed movie is a awesome movie to watch. It has a little of everything; romance, drama, action, and crime. The casting is spot on. Leonardo DiCaprio does a great job playing an undercover cop slowing breaking down since he been under covered for so long. Jack Nicholson was so compelling to watch making me believe he's actually the head guy for real. Matt Damon, Martin Sheenan, Mark Wahlberg, and a lot of other people did also did a great job in acting in the police force or some other part they played. The ending actually shocked me since Mark Wahlberg's and Vera 's characters were the only ones left alive. If you're a fan of Goodfellas, Casino, and Gangs of New York you should watch this because Martin Scorsese directed this.

title: Really unexpected ending
review:
Nice film however the ending was really really unacceptable as Billy was immediately shot in the head when the elevator door opens, which led to several really really surprising killings. Nearly all main characters were dead.

The Departed does reflect quite a few interesting problem in society, such as Costello has something to do with FBI or more than one under-covers at among polices.

One thing is different with the original work is that in the book there were two main female characters while in the film there is only one, Madolyn. I can't accept that she slept with both Billy and Sullivan.

Don't trust anyone, is something the film is trying to convey. You'll never know who is on your side. Some people were just pretending to be loyal, while some are righteous although they seem rude.

title: Martin Scorsese Does An American Remake Right
review:
After seeing this back when it was released and being blown away, it literally got me wanting to check out the original Honk Kong thriller "Infernal Affairs" (2002). Andy Lau & Tony Leung are fantastic performers, and the movie definitely helped bring a sense of originality at the time. Only someone like Martin Scorsese could surpass the original source material (And only just).

The original is a fantastic concept and Scorsese's efforts make it one of his finest, finally winning an Oscar for directing that was long overdue. An Irish mobster plants a mole in the Police State, whilst the Police also plant an undercover agent to infiltrate. When both sides realise the situation, both men try to discover the others identity before there cover is blown.

Hands down another amazing performance from Jack Nicholson, who is as always perfectly casted and steals the show. I also give credit to the chemistry between both Matt Damon and Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt's performance is incredible and this is the kind of movie that Leo excels at. Thumbs up to Martin Sheen, Mark Wahlberg, Vera Farmiga and a great supporting cast of too many to count.

Final Verdict: Definitely one of the few remakes worth checking out. 9/10.

title: The ending was very poor for what was a very good film.
review: I give a 1/10 for the ending alone. It is like baking and sampling a delicious delicacy intended for a shop window of a bakery and then stamping on it in mud and petrol covered tatty leather boots. For what was a pleasing film visually, story line wise with good character profiles , the conclusion to this piece of cinematography is literally murdered and crushed and burnt by a horrifically composed, abrupt, unfitting and distasteful end to a good story. For 2 hours and 30 minutes I enjoyed watching this film until the abomination of an end, I would recommend watching this film, but only for 2:30, decide the ending yourself rather than having the pain of viewing it.

title: Scenario is good, director is great, acting is perfect
review:
The Departed, is a US version remake of Internal Affairs, which is a Hong Kong film. Martin Scorsese is a great director. This film is his second best film after Goodfellas. Jack Nicholson, Leonardo DiCaprioand Matt Damon was perfect.

There was also actors/actresses like Martin Sheen, Vera Farmiga and Mark Wahlberg. This film, is the The Godfather of Irish mafias. If you are fan of gangster films, you should definitely watch this film, right now. This film is a masterpiece. Character designs, directing and acting is like i said, really great.

And finally, the original film has got 2 sequels. But I am not thinking that Scorsese is going to make sequel to The Departed.

title: thrilling and indulging movie with a weak ending.
review:
i decided to watch this one for just one reason, it's IMDb rating.and honestly i had a great time. The movie works for various reasons stating - 1. terrific acting by both the leading protagonist. 2. awesome background score and great cinematography. 3. this movie does really binds you and keeps you indulged till the very

end. 4. a concept not being explored often.

the only weak point about the movie is it's ending,The movie ends abruptly.My only question is if it's so goddamn easy to put bullets in someone's head (just like what happens in the end)first Leonardo dies then one cop is shot then a rat dies then after that Damon dies within 3,4 minutes,the why don' Dignam goes and shoot the Jack Nicholson before the climax when he sees him. Apart from this movie works great and very thrilling as well and i would rather just a "must watch".

title: My favourite film of all time
review: Absolutely amazing film on the whole. I only watched this film a couple of years back, but as soon as i saw it for the first time, i watched it a further 3 times within the week. I was mentioning it to everyone praising the film. Firstly on the face of it the cast is tremendous and compliment each other brilliantly. Being a huge fan of DiCaprio i really appreciated his role as to me this is one of the first films I've seen him possess his aggressive side, and it was a tremendous performance. Mark Wahlberg and Matt Damon also brilliant actors, making this film evermore appealing to watch. As well as Jack Nicholson playing the head of the gang and enforcing Matt Damon as the rat in the police crew. There is no other film like this in my opinion. The tension that builds up to who will find the rat in their crew first (DiCaprio being the rat in Nicholsons gang) is enthralling. Directed by none other than Martin Scorsese it is the absolute perfect combination.

title: A Modern Classic...
review:
Director Martin Scorsese delivers us a modern classic, a masterpiece, with superb acting, excellent cinematography and brilliant music...

Do you want anything better than that... Starting with the cast, which features an excellent dedication by the actors involved, specially from Mark Wahlberg, you really feel his character evolving as the story develops with him as DiCaprio's and Damon's characters as well.

The music is top notch, which ads an awesome "Touch" to the movie... All of this contributes to the movie's climax which will really stun you. After All...

IT'S AWESOME!!!

title: Scorsese's best mob film since that of Goodfellas
review: Martin Scorsese's The Departed is an excellent movie about an undercover cop named Bill Costigan played by Leonardo DiCaprio who has infiltrated an Irish mafia and a mole in the same police force working for the exact same crime family. That mole in the Boston police force named Colin Sullivan is played by Matt Damon, ant the mob boss who he is working for is played by Jack Nicholson. This movie also had good cast members such as Ray Winstone, Vera Farmiga, Mark Wahlberg, Alec Baldwin, and Martin Sheen. Director Martin Scorsese has crafted one of his best movies as a director throughout his entire career, and goes on a par with mob film such as American Gangster, Bugsy, and Goodfellas. Also it goes on a par with police movies such as The French Connection, Lethal Weapon, Die Hard Dirty Harry and many more.

title: Solid crime thriller delights
review:
I liked this film a lot - there's a lot to like about it - but I want to address the minor concerns I had with it first.

In honesty, they're the usual problems I have with the more recent Scorsese films. Much like Shutter Island, there's a twist at the end (although admittedly far less important to the narrative as a whole) that was actually fairly predictable. He seems to be obsessed with throwing something in there just to convince the audience (and maybe himself) that he's very clever and in truth the stuff he comes up with isn't as clever as he thinks it is. The other is the creeping sexism again - the female characters are cardboard cutout plot devices and again he thinks he can 'even it out' by throwing a penis in there (that shouldn't be a spoiler if you know Scorsese), but no, it doesn't work like that, and the penis is pointless.

But despite all that, it was not enough to ruin my thorough enjoyment of this movie. The story is very strong and actually gives you plenty of plot twists and turns (which just make it more frustrating as to why he thought he needed to put in that obvious end twist), and the lead performances are judged expertly by Leonardo Di Caprio and Matt Damon. I'm not a fan of either Jack Nicholson nor Mark Wahlberg, but they're convincing here in their respective roles as the sleazy crime boss and the bad cop.

The double agent setup plays out fantastically well and kept me entertained and curious throughout, and even when it is slightly predictable, it's just done so well that I didn't even mind. There's not actually much else to say without giving something away other than a recommendation to go and see it if you want a well paced, thoroughly entertaining crime thriller. 8/10.

title: The Departed
review:
The Departed is a 2006 American crime thriller film directed by Martin Scorsese and written by William Monahan. It is a remake of the 2002 Hong Kong film Infernal Affairs.[2] The film stars Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Jack Nicholson, and Mark Wahlberg, with Martin Sheen, Ray Winstone, Vera Farmiga, Anthony Anderson, and Alec Baldwin in supporting roles.

It won several awards, including four Oscars at the 79th Academy Awards: Best Picture, Best Director (Scorsese), Best Adapted Screenplay and Best Film Editing. Wahlberg was nominated for Best Supporting Actor.

The film takes place in Boston. Irish Mob boss Francis "Frank" Costello plants Colin Sullivan as a mole within the Massachusetts State Police; the two characters are loosely based on famous gangster Whitey Bulger and corrupt FBI agent John Connolly, who grew up with Bulger.[3][4] Simultaneously, the police assign undercover trooper William "Billy" Costigan to infiltrate Costello's crew. When both sides realize the situation, each man attempts to discover the other's true identity before his own cover is blown

title: Brilliant, a rightful masterpiece
review:
Lots of people bash The Departed for being a complete rip off of the Hong Kong film 'Internal Affairs' with no credit to its source material but, if you manage to see past that, you will discover a masterpiece which has rightfully earned its place in cinema history. Just as a start, the environment and the characters feel so authentic and real, and each actor delivers a awe inspiring performance, some of their best. Even the actors who had limited screen time (Mark Walberg, Alec Baldwin) completely won over me when they were on screen. Jack Nickolson plays the suspicious, evil and cunning Frank Costello with such authenticity and flare, he and Matt Damon steal the show in this crime epic. Martin Scorsese strikes again with his top notch film making, each scene, each element has meaning and it is his finest work since 'Goodfellas' , as you can see gangster films, is where he in his element, its tense, exhilarating, character driven and every second of this two and a half hour film is worth watching and you will absolutely not regret it. It is one of the most spectacular films ever created and deserves every bit of praise it gets.

10/10

title: Without question, the best film of my generation.
review: Some people like movies because of the emotion they elicit, others love to follow the story and some even consume the script word by word. Some people are looking for the lesson to be learned to carry with them after the credits roll. However, rarely does a film run on all cylinders; weaving all of these things(plus more) together simultaneously, delivering all of the above to your senses. The Departed is one of these films. I would argue there are only a handful of films that have ever been made that can lay such claim. Many of the top 250 films have flaws yet their unique nature and/or individuality of the film transcends any rating and makes such an impact on the viewer that the viewer must throw a rose on stage and clap, bravo. The Departed is brilliant in every aspect and for my measure, flawless. Few movies "have everything." This film makes its magic in the details and extension of basic ideas. From the lingo on both sides, drenched in black humor and voiced by local accents of the area to the suspenseful uncertainty that develops throughout the film, the viewer feels as if they belong IN THE FILM. I won't say too much but, by the end of it, you are left analyzing the people around you in your life you see every day; at least, I was the first time I saw it. Isn't that the point of a movie? Stop reading. Cancel any distractions preemptively and enjoy the greatest film of the last twenty years.

title: A lot of great actors together.
review:
What this film offered us was a very interesting plot together with a lot of good actors all together trying to snatch that Oscar(s).

As far as the plot goes, it is a very interesting idea and you have to push yourself together paying close attention in order to follow the plot. It is obvious that this film was carefully made in order to win some awards, and I have to say that I am glad that it did win some Oscars, although I am not sure that it deserves all of them.

When you put all these great actors together you will obtain some great acting, but I have to say that Jack Nicholson is my favorite. I am so glad he did not end up like Roman Polanski when all that case evolved.

All in all I recommend this film, although I do not think it is a must see.

title: The Departed one of Scorsese's best.
review: Matt Damon is Colin Sullivan, a Massachusetts state trooper who's been groomed since childhood to infiltrate the Boston Police Department by his father figure, mob boss Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson). Quickly rising through the ranks, Colin provides Costello with vital information, while manipulating the system for his own success. Colin learns, however, that his police unit has planted its own mole in Costello's crew. Working deep undercover, officer Billy Castigan (Leonardo DiCaprio) has infiltrated the group and earned the trust of Costello. As Colin and Billy attempt to uncover each other's identity, things are further complicated by a beautiful police psychiatrist (Vera Farmiga) who unwittingly becomes involved in their lives. Scorsese embraces the contrivances of screenwriter William Monahan (Kingdom of Heaven), creating a film that mixes genres with wit and grace. The Departed is equal parts character drama, cop thriller and police procedural, and though the plot is sometimes overly complex (particularly in the final act), Scorsese keeps things tense. Though Damon and DiCaprio share almost no screen time together, Scorsese masterfully juxtaposes their scenes to play off one another. Their intertwined fates and inevitable collision are engrossing, blurring the lines of identity. Damon is the slick snake in the garden, charming us with clever banter and altarboy good looks. DiCaprio is the good cop, losing his soul little by little as he bloodies his hands with ever- darker crimes. Amid the first-rate cast, DiCaprio is the unexpected standout. His third appearance in a Scorsese film is his best performance to date, capturing the tortured desperation of a man who fears he's reached the point of no return. His vulnerability, rage and paranoia are all well-earned, and DiCaprio never overplays his hand. Damon's performance, on the other hand, is believable but hits only one note. There are glimmers here and there of something bubbling beneath his well-varnished surface, and Scorsese gives him lots of screen time, but we never really get close enough to peer inside. Predictably, Nicholson steals nearly every scene he's in. There's no denying the electricity of his performance, but it's not the three- dimensional character some critics would have you believe. Except for About Schmidt, the actor hasn't adopted a flesh-and-blood persona in years, and his turn as Frank Costello is no exception. As an aging gangster who's achieved so much success there's no place to go except crazy, Nicholson tries to inject some heart and nobility into the madness but can't resist a few unhinged gestures and a drunken rat imitation. Scene by scene, Frank's insanity grows as his Boston accent slowly disappears. The rest of the cast is terrific. Alec Baldwin is hilariously self- satisfied as a police unit commander, proving once again he's one of the best character actors around. Martin Sheen brings decency to his small police chief role (a part originally intended for Robert De Niro). Mark Wahlberg follows in Nicholson's scene-stealing footsteps as a savagely foul-mouthed detective, and Ray Winston oozes menace as Costello's second-in-command. As the film's sole female lead, Vera Farmiga salvages her contrived role — a beautiful psychiatrist caught in an absurd romantic entanglement between Billy and Colin. In Scorsese's moral universe, the divide between saint and sinner is slight, and The Departed makes clear which side the director is most comfortable with. Costello's criminal world seduces us with its instant camaraderie and brutal loyalties. But the world of the law, where Colin is forced to make his home, is depicted as a soulless collection of self-righteous cynics and foolish do-gooders. The message is clear: It's not the world that corrupts the man, but vice versa. As Costello states in the beginning of the film, "I don't want to be a product of my environment. I want my environment to be a product of me."

title: A thrill from start to finish
review: Boy, what an awesome plot. So for those who are confused, and I know there are some, here it is: Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson) is the leader of the mob in Boston. His protégé, Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon), becomes a Mass. State Trooper in order to work as a mole in the force for Costello. Cpt. Quellan (Martin Sheen) and Sgt. Dignam (Mark Wahlberg) begin to develop the theory that there may be a rat working for Costello. So, they enlist former cop-trainee Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio) to go undercover and infiltrate Costello's gang. Billy succeeds and Costello welcomes him. Meanwhile, Sullivan is put in charge of finding out who the rat is (NOBODY KNOWS HE IS LOOKING FOR HIMSELF). And Quellan and Dignam inform Costigan that he needs to find out who the rat in the police department is. As the movie intensifies, Costello understands that he has a rat in his gang. Costigan convinces Costello that he is not the rat, and Costello believes him. On the side of all this, Costigan nails Sullivan's fiancée. Now for the Climax: Costello's men throw Cpt. Quellan off the roof to his death. Then, Sullivan learns that Costello talks with the FBI, so he kills him. Sullivan is heralded as a hero around the office, but is still aware that Costigan, who appears at the station, isn't good news. Costigan, via looking at a very important envelope on Sullivan's desk, learns that Sullivan is the rat. Sullivan, simultaneously, learns that Costigan was Costello's rat. Costigan hunts down Sullivan, but is shot dead by Sullivan's men. The movie ends with Sgt. Dignam waiting in Sullivan's apartment. BANG. Sullivan is killed, and Dignam walks out. The camera then focuses on a rat on the balcony. SUCH A FANTASTIC FILM. 10/10

title: Top Notch
review: I loved this movie, it was outstanding. Yes it was from infernal affairs but it only used the basic idea of infernal affairs. In no way was it a remake like the girl with the dragon tattoo or 3:10 to yuman. It is just passing and idea and incorportating into what i say a better movie. I mean the screenplay the plots and the twists. And it has emotion to it, costigan the cop is torn as he develops a bond with costello the crime boss. whilst trying to take the mob down. But what costigan isn't aware of is that all there information in the police is given away due to a mole in the police known as sullivan. Who whilst trying to protect costello is losing his faith as costello becomes more of a risk taker. and the ending was spectacular. This movie is one of the greats along with GoodFellas, The Untouchables, The Godfather and Once Upon A time in America

title: Martin Scorsese has done it yet again
review: I must say, Martin Scorsese has done it yet again. The cast is unbelievably amazing. Though it saddens me that Leonardo DiCaprio has declined enlisting himself as the main lead which would've made him a potential Academy Award winner. Speaking of which, I would be focusing this review on the talented (and love of my life) Leonardo DiCaprio. The man is such an incredible actor - very professional and very dedicated to his craft. After devoting myself to a bunch of Leonardo Dicaprio films, I would like to join the bandwagon and start of by saying that this guy needs his proper recognition for working his ass off for almost two decades. Of all the films DiCaprio has worked with, 'The Departed' has to be the one completely out of consideration as a letdown. Hands down to the amazing Martin Scorsese as well, who has been creating real entertainment for the betterment of this century.

title: In the future, I tell ya to do a thing, you f*cking do it, you got that?
review:
I started my day with 2046. I won't recommend that film to any but fans of Tony Leung, Li Gong, and Ziyi Zhang. The music was excellent and Tony Leung's performance was spellbinding, but the movie was hard to follow. I only mention Tony Leung because his performance in Mou gaan dou was on my mind as I watched The Departed, which is a remake of that film.

I wish I had a copy with me to watch again and remind me of why it is such a favorite, but I have seen it enough times to know that it still stand above the new version.

I just couldn't wait any longer, so I bought my copy yesterday and sat down with some chips to watch. Leonardo DiCaprio was magnificent. I have never been a big fan of Leonardo. I really liked him in Gangs of New York and Catch Me If You Can, but this performance was over the top.

Having said that, I can't really think of another character's performance in The Departed that is worth mentioning. It ran 50 minutes longer than Mou gaan dou and the extra time was really a waste as it did not add anything to the film.

The setup in the beginning was really a bore. Scorcese did so much better work in Gangs of New York and Goodfellas, one of my favorite films. I really don't see him winning an Oscar for this film, though they will probably give it to him for ignoring his earlier and better work.

title: Outstanding Performances All Around,
review:
The Departed is a brilliant movie with a very well developed storyline and a fantastic cast. Martin Scorsese hits it out of the park once again in one of his most impressive movies to date, it combines all the aspects of film that he is fantastic at directing, character development, action and strong dialogue based scenes, it all comes together to make an instant classic, he may have done gangster and mob films before, but this film stands out as very original and intriguing two and a half hours. My only real criticism for the film would be that it focuses on Matt Damon and Leonardo DiCaprio's characters too much, I understand that they are the main characters, but there were many other terrific characters that were left feeling underdeveloped, particularly Frank Costello and Dignam, they were both the most engrossing characters, mainly because of their outstanding portrayals from Jack Nicholson and Mark Wahlberg, and I would have loved to have seen more from them. The performances in this film are outstanding, there isn't a single example of poor or mediocre acting here, everyone gives it there all, the film isn't really driven by one character, it's driven by many and thankfully everyone knew what they were doing. Intense, very well acted and engrossing, I would recommend the Departed to anyone looking for a good drama or crime film.

After two cops working for both the police force and an Irish mob gang learn they are in the presence of a rat, they race to track down one another.

Best Performance: Jack Nicholson

title: well acted, well told story by the Master
review:
Scorsesse's films, when they're done right (and they usually are) grab you within 1 minute! That's certainly what happens here.

We meet a diverse handful of characters in their younger years and we know that we'll follow them throughout their careers and that no matter how different divergent their paths are, that they will intersect...

...and that they'll intersect in an explosive way.

Double crossing, double identity, you name it, it's all here. And then there's Jack. I was hesitant at first about seeing a movie like this with him as the heavy....wondering if he had it in him to make this guy different than the other heavy's he's played.

He does. Jack as Costello looms over every scene. His presence is that strong. There are some people who get destroyed, some who flourish, some fairly, some unfairly...

But it's a hell of an entertaining ride.

title: Martin Scorsese's The Departed: The Perfect Bait To Catch The 'Oscar' Shark
review:
'Lies, Betrayal & Sacrifice. How far will you take it?' the quote clearly describes Martin Scorsese's exceptional cop thriller 'The Departed'. Martin Scorsese voted as one of the best directors ever to be gifted to the film industry, returns back to the gangster genre after a span of 11 years. Goodfellas (1990), Mean Streets (1973), Casino (1995) are few of the illustrations of his master hand in this genre. Inspired from 2002, Hong Kong movie 'Internal Affairs ' The Departed makes the viewers witness assembling of an astral cast altogether. I mean who won't give a nod to the movie which has Matt Damon, Leonardo DiCaprio, Jack Nicholson & Mark Walberg in decisive roles.

Screenplay crafted in a well paced & witty manner by William Monahan, the film begins with the director playfully shooting Nicholson in the dark for few scenes as you can just glimpse his out-sized silhouette while everyone else is in the clear view. Scorsese simply wants to symbolize through this that he is the driving force of all the mayhem & destruction; the monstrous devil. 20 minutes post the film starts, you get to know about the title of the film but by then you have already crafted a general picture of the film's plot in your mind; An outstandingly clever move by an outstandingly brilliant director.

Frank Costello (Nicholson), the Irish-American Mafioso is the only powerful man holding the reigns of organized crime in Irish neighborhood in South Boston. He influences Collin Sullivan (Damon) by seducing altar boy by few gallons of milk & comic books & Sullivan is trained to be his very own secret agent in the Massachusetts State Police department; the department run by Queenan (Martin Sheen). On the other hand, Leonardo plays Billy Costigan, an honest person from a dishonest family who cannot make it to being a cop owing to his austere family background finally agrees to Queenan's urge for him to be his undercover informer in Costello's gang.

After a failed sting operation in spite of Billy tipping the police off, the State Police Department grows quite suspicious of a rat in their own department. Thanks to Sullivan from State Police, even Costello is tad convinced that even he has a police informer in his gang. The entire movie is about how both the organizations make their best to find out the moles around them, finally leading to some shootouts, body counts and unsurpassed scene of carnage. Matt Damon who appears to be a well behaved & a neat cop pertaining to his clean shaved look but sadly isn't. He gets involved with the cop psychiatrist Madolyn (Vera Farmiga) and gets into a live-in relationship with her but finally the love tapers towards destruction in the end. The film however gets us the glimpses of some heart-warming intimacy between the couple.

The Departed is a complex story of a paralleled infiltration of organized crime and the police department narrated rather simply as it showcases the idiosyncratic performances of the lead actors & the strong masterstroke of the director. It makes a complicated and potentially convoluted story and delivers it to the audience with sterile clarity. It has the same violence & tension from Goodfellas & Casino minus the narration. However as expected Scorsese has managed to explore the gangster world ahead of the vision & delivered a kaleidoscopic masterpiece. Needless to say, in my view this happens to be Scorsese's best gangster movie till date.

title: Epic !.. What Epic ?!
review:
Sometimes, the Oscars, and the film critics, agree on one opinion. Sometimes, I disagree with that. This time is one of their biggest!

(The Departed) is a crime thriller. And coming from such an honored director, such as Martin Scorsese, guarantees thrill and possible substance. However, it wasn't that excellent, and had many problems.

The time-line wasn't taken care of; suddenly, within 2 ordinary scenes, not even a respectable montage, a year passed by! The doctor is falling in love with 2 police officers, where their second is undercover, and no one knows about it; whether their first, or the mob?!! While Jack Nicholson's character, Costello, is a mafia lord, who makes international arms deals, he's still running around the streets, collecting protection money; so is he a mafia lord or a small time goon?!! Mark Wahlberg's character can't be the relief, can't be convincing, and - to tell you the truth - can't be bearable either! The F word is given, every second, in a free and overabundant manner; they used it for a total of 237 times. Unlike Scorsese' other mafia movies, increasing the cursing or swearing wasn't made for the sake of enhancing a realistic atmosphere inasmuch as compensating the drama's weakness, which didn't happen. On the contrary, it added fakeness, bore and nervousness! And how in God's name a dangerous police mission, like sending a man undercover through the world of organized crime, is known by just 2 persons?!?!?!!?!

Who told Leonardo DiCaprio that the movie was a comedy? Because he acted exactly as if he was in one. By the way he looked and reacted, he was a scared mouse all along, so near of crying out loud: "I'M A POLICEMAN, KILL ME AND PUT ME OUT OF MY MISERY!!". Matt Damon is not charismatic enough, talented enough, and hence veracious or right. I didn't hate his character, rather I hated him being unable to make me hate his character! His flat face and cold reactions don't tell that he came from the bottom. Vera Farmiga is mediocre at times, and so bad at others. There is no love in her eyes, maybe tension and horror. There is not one atom of chemistry between her and her 2 co-stars. And there is no doubt that she seemed older than them! Martin Sheen was icy as usual, but this time I can blame the script as well; obviously, he had no character.

However, no one was more wrong than Jack Nicholson as Costello, to be the main course in this nonsense feast. Really what's worse than not understanding, feeling, or being persuaded by a character in a movie?! That Nicholson's Costello wasn't catchy, by any mean. And wasn't Irish either, by any mean! To add more and more fuel, Scorsese thought that talking dirty and loud, with some eccentric moves, make a unique evil gangster, but no such luck. So all the performance that I watched ranged between Jack Nicholson's Joker of Batman, and Jack Nicholson himself acting vainly. Enough to recall his scene with DiCaprio, while he was suspecting the latter; which was a complete drollery instead of a master scene!

Speaking about farce leads directly to the movie's own substance. It's bogus. When Ray Winstone's character, who's - by the way - an underdeveloped character, says in bitter wisdom: "A nation of rats..", you have to laugh sadly.
