"Laugh" since this is the script's way to insert policy, or social commentary in this already unthrilling thriller. And "sadly" because this adolescence comes from someone who used to be subtle like Scorsese. And it's the same adolescence which you find in the last scene with the rat. Ok, in regard to this, The Simpsons' Ralph Wiggum couldn't say it better: "It symbolizes obviousness!!". As a whole, the way this movie was made, doesn't turn it into a tragedy about the distrust in post-9/11 America, however maybe a farce about the same subject, especially with the end's farcical massacre!

In his worst movies, Scorsese is interesting. However, here, it is so bad I think. His directing didn't win any artistic top; and it's a rare time when he makes something that doesn't impress or affect. As many of his movies, it's fast-paced, but his sedate touch was missed. Originally, the script lacks the power of cogency, as if it has no time for anything, and gives us the news flashes only. So with frantic editing, the movie felt like a speedy trailer, becoming utterly delirious. Therefore, any intended serious theme or satire came to nothing, and all what remained was mediocre crime thriller of which you don't enjoy much, and regretfully say after finishing: "That could have been better."

All in all, in (The Departed) Martin Scorsese pulled off making uninteresting package of nervousness and adolescence, which has no relation whatsoever to his previous, and true, mafia epics like (Goodfellas) and (Casino). Although I may find explanations for choosing it as The Best Motion Picture of 2006 (America's bigwig critics are idiot, 2006's movies are horrible..), but I really don't know how the Academy gave Scorsese his first Oscar as a director for his so-called epic!

title: A crazy ride
review:
I saw Hong Kong crime thriller Infernal Affairs (2002) a couple of years before Martin Scorsese's Hollywood remake The Departed. I remember little of it now, but I do remember finding it to be an ingenious idea and a gripping little movie, albeit a little overrated. Scorsese obviously saw potential in the idea, as The Departed is admittedly bloated, but packed-to-the-gills with eccentric criminals, sweary 'cwops', and CGI blood, expanding the story and characters and executed in that uber-stylish way that the director is so well known for. I'll avoid comparisons to Infernal Affairs as the two share very little in common apart from basic story, and Scorsese makes this film very much his own.

Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon) is enlisted into mob boss Frank Costello's (Jack Nicholson) crime-ring at a young age, and is raised to be an informant in the Massachusetts State Police. New police academy graduate William Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio), a rough-and-ready type from a colourful family, is forced into going undercover in Costello's gang by Captain Queenan (Martin Sheen) and Sergeant Dignam (Mark Wahlberg). When a rat is exposed on both sides, the two must search desperately for the other before they are unwillingly revealed. Unbeknownst to the both of them, they also share a girl in psychiatrist Madolyn (Vera Farmiga).

If you go into this film expecting a gritty and realistic urban crime thriller, you will be disappointed. Although the subject matter is grim and it certainly doesn't pull its punches when it comes to violence, this is a shiny movie with explosions of bloodshed akin to the comic- book aesthetic of manga, and asks you to suspend your beliefs for the duration. I mean, Costello is a known maniac with no fear of dispatching his own, yet Costigan becomes his right-hand man within months even though he is known to be ex-police? There are plenty of plot-holes that I could mention but won't bother, as they are there for the purpose of telling an entertaining story.

This is Scorsese as unhinged as he's been in years, letting the story just unravel regardless of just how mental it becomes. Nicholson, an actor I cannot believe had never worked with Scorsese before, gets frequently mentioned as stealing the show. He certainly steals his scenes, and grabs the opportunity to improvise with both hands, waving a severed hand in a bag around in one scene, and inexplicably covered with blood in another. Costello wouldn't last a minute in real-life, he's just too obvious and psychopathic, but in this world he thrives, and is a memorable Nicholson creation. But it's actually Wahlberg that steals the show, getting lines such as "if you had an idea of what we do, we would not be good at what we do now would we? We would be c***s. Are you calling us c***s?". It's a testament to his performance that he has probably 10 minutes of screen time and received an Oscar nomination.

DiCaprio and Damon fill their roles admirably, the former being the incarnation of anxiety and the latter proving surprisingly slimy given his history of generally wholesome characters. But its the ensemble that really shines in this array of ridiculous and cartoon characters. By the end, questions of identity and who is really important to the story get blurred with a climax of endless bloodshed. The prize of Best Picture and Best Director now seem somewhat silly, and surely a sympathy vote for Martin Scorsese who has made at least ten other movies more deserving of rewarding his talent. But this is a crazy ride, and one that remains gripping and surprising throughout, bolstered by a smart script and a hell of a cast.

www.the-wrath-of-blog.blogspot.com

title: Infernal Goings-on
review: Wonderfully edgy and powerful remake by Martin Scorsese of Wai-keung Lau and Alan Mak's 'Infernal Affairs' (Hong Kong, 2002), an all-star cast is led by Leonardo diCaprio, Matt Damon and Jack Nicholson, and features Martin Sheen, Mark Wahlberg, Ray Winstone and Vera Farmiga. Among a raft of great performances, diCaprio stands out as the severely stressed undercover agent, while Damon reprises something of the supremely cold performance that we saw in 'The Talented Mr. Ripley'. Jack Nicholson verges on over-the-top at times, but is good value as the gangland supremo, while Martin Sheen exudes integrity as Captain Queenan. It's a tour de force with some great sequences and plenty of intrigue, and Scorsese is predictably adept at infusing the piece with lashings of slow burning tension. Well worth seeing if you haven't.

title: "Goodfellas 2" only that they aren't friends
review:
34, 34 years of career as a filmmaker (one of the best who ever lived) Martin Scorsese after 18 films including masterpieces like "Goodfellas", "Ranging Bull" and "Taxi Driver ". In 2006, "The Departed" was the film that not only and finally gave the Oscar for Best Director to Scorsese, but it was the tribute that Scorsese did to all his work and the elements of his films that made him one of the greatest filmmakers of all time! The story takes place in the south of Boston where we find the police waging war on the Irish-American organized crime, and in the midst of all we found the rookie cop Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio) who gets in the investigation department of the investigators Queenan (Martin Sheen) and Dignam (Mark Wahlberg) and is assigned to infiltrate the mob syndicate headed by the crazy and smart Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson). Meanwhile we have the agent Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon) the protected and informant of Costello, who joined the police to be Costello's contact inside the police, where Colin throughout his career start winning important position to gather and inform Costello plans and counter-plans against Costello's business mafia. But barely both moles know that the intrigue that connects both is much more dangerous than expected and it is all connected with Costello who has more secrets that they can imagine.

"Departed" at the same time it is a new genre that Scorsese (who already had explored mafia thousands of times; the "real " death of Christ; a war hero that works in a cab and speaks to himself wearing underwear; boxing black and white; knights without armor with cars destroying asphalts; one film director who becomes schizophrenic pilot; the first new Yorkers gangs; and so on) were he gets in to, here he not only explores the genre of cop-thriller perfectly, but also makes a tribute to his old, violent, humorous style (not Tarantino, better).

Since the beginning, the film follows with a fast pace, a real pace of a thriller, but thanks to the superb script of William Monahan the movie at the same time does a certain homage to "Goodfellas" which also had a fast pace and was full of a hilarious black comedy, just like Departed. Also exploring the language and curse-language of Boston, but also the Irish language and their curse language, (one thing that at a certain point it had been explored in "Gangs of New York").

Not only is the script that makes a beautiful tribute and gives the film a great quality, but also the direction (truly deserving of an Oscar) from Scorsese, showing various places in the city of Boston and its culture (thing Scorsese has always done in his films, ALWAYS).

Direction and script on top quality, but did the cast put up with the movie? Actually they carried the movie on their back, everyone simply phenomenal: Jack Nicholson nor comments, just put another role in his resume of exuberant performances; DiCaprio as ever with a stunning performance by giving the perfect Irish Americanized accent to his character; Matt Damon fits perfectly in his role as dirty-cop since the looks and sadistic smiles; and Mark Wahlberg was the only one to be nominated by the Academy (leaving the three monsters of acting film overlooked by the academy) but it wasn't for nothing delivering a superb performance from start to finish giving the perfect Boston accent.

Hilarious, dark, nail biting thriller, the Masterpiece in which Scorsese pays tribute to his entire lineage of classic films presenting us with a beautiful direction, superb script and a luxury cast, "The Departed" it may not be the best of Scorsese, but he showed us why we love him so much and his old and many more to come movies! 10/10

title: A masterpiece
review:
I've been a movie buff all my life and have seen some excellent works by great directors, but Martin Scorsese is beyond any doubt - a cut above the rest. The old storyteller has variety, and that is what makes him so special - it's like he's a boon for Hollywood.

The Departed is one of those movies which I saw in a near empty theatre (all alone) and I am glad I did that, because if I would have taken my girl along with me, she would have dumped me for not looking at her even once in the entire 150 minutes of pure awesomeness. I was so engrossed in the movie that I nearly chewed all my fingernails down to the bone, and somehow I felt like a part of the movie.

Exceptional performances by Jack Nicholson and Martin Sheen are ably supported by the rest of the cast. Not to forget a role of a lifetime by Vera Farmiga, the most beautiful actress in Hollywood.

The best part of the movie however, is Scorsese's direction. The man is at his best throughout the movie and some brilliant editing gives the viewers a mouthful of breathtaking action sequences.

The movie is a 10/10 on each and every account. Arguably, it is the best action thrillers in the age ruled by batmen and ratwomen.

title: Scorcese Strikes Gold Again. (No Spoilers)
review:
I can't shake the feeling of how much this movie reminds me of "Goodfellas".

The Departed is a slam-bam thriller, exceeding my expectations, which were already very high. The way Scorcese moves between scenes and plays this movie up is genius.

The script is excellent, providing rich dialogue to move the gripping story along, and the cinematography is just wonderful. The angles and style of filming that Martin Scorcese is famous for emanates here, shining brighter than films of kin.

The acting is just amazing, with a star-studded cast that delivers the goods, and then some. I enjoyed Matt Damon in the title roll, and Leonardo DiCaprio trails right behind him. Jack Nicholson brings charisma to the roll of Frank Costello, and executes with Oscar-worthy style. I especially liked Mark Wahlberg and Alec Baldwin's loose cannon-like characters. They provided a stunning edge to an already sharp blade of a film.

I can go on and on about everything else that is good in this movie, how it all clicks together, but I suggest you watch it for yourself if you haven't already, and find out what all the hype is about! I would give it more than 100 if I could.

HandHStudios Rating: 11/10 :-)

title: A remarkable remake; Scorsese's return to the mafioso genre
review:
'The Departed' focuses on two characters: Billy Costigan (Leo DiCaprio), an undercover cop in the Boston Irish-American organized crime, and Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon), an undercover criminal in the Boston police department. As their actions intensify and they rise in position in their hidden roles, a hunt begins on both the police and the mafia to find the moles.

The remake of the already excellent Hong Kong crime thriller 'Infernal Affairs' makes use of director Martin Scorsese's legendary aptitude for gangster films, relocating the story in order to reference the Boston organized crime scene. While still not as good as his masterpieces of the genre, like 'Goodfellas' and 'Casino', 'The Departed' is far from a stain on his filmography.

As usual, the dialogue is good and flows in a very natural (and aggressive) way. The characters, likewise, are very interesting and well represented.

Both Leonardo DiCaprio and Matt Damon feel a lot more mature here. I still can't shake off the image they constructed by playing cheesy, lame pretty boys (and, in Damon's case, troubled lame pretty boys) in films such as 'Titanic', 'Romeo+Juliet', 'Good Will Hunting' or 'Rounders'. It takes a director of Scorsese's caliber to put them in line, and it shows. Both of them give excellent performances, and for the first time ever I sympathized with a DiCaprio character.

The supporting cast is also top-notch, in special Martin Sheen, Ray Winstone and Jack Nicholson; possibly his best casting choice since he last cast Robert De Niro. Possibly the weakest link of the movie, Mark Wahlberg had a bad tendency to overact at times.

On the other hand, the love triangle subplot involving Vera Farmiga's character was totally unnecessary and just a waste of time; likewise, the Costello twist also served little to no purpose other than confuse the slower viewer. The cinematography, while not bad, feels too artificial (a common occurrence in his recent films) and does not convey the level of realism Scorsese's gangster films usually have.

While not on the same level as his masterpieces, most likely thanks to his recent venture into larger scale works ('Gangs of New York', 'The Aviator'), 'The Departed' is Scorsese's best film in over a decade of mediocrities and a great entry in the gangster genre. Now, if he only kept doing mafia and casting high-level actors such as Nicholson and De Niro...

title: Simply brilliant
review:
With Scorsese being my favourite director and some really talented actors participating, I simply couldn't wait to watch this film.

Perhaps the greatest advantage of 'The Departed' is the performance of the actors. All - I mean all - performers did great, including those with lesser roles, such as Anthony Anderson and David O'Hara. I can't imagine this film with other actors. The music once more added a lot to a Scorsese project, with 'Shipping Up to Boston' becoming a mob classic.

The story itself was simple, yet excellent. However, I found it really hard to follow the plot some times and this is a serious disadvantage of the movie. And it is perhaps the only reason why this film isn't included in my Top 20 Favourite Films.

Some people say 'The Departed' is overrated. What I got to say is that it's a film you have to watch multiple times to understand its magnificence.

title: The Accent - Please make it stop
review: Aside from the native Bostonians in this movie, the others don't even try to have a Boston accent. Why do you suppose that is? It causes one to be tripped up by the actors halfhearted attempt at sounding authentic. If the movie were based in NYC or Texas you had better believe they would be spot on. What the director and producers fail to realize is that people from Boston do not talk like they're from California half the time, and the other half as if they're from Boston. It doesn't happen. We never say "Baaah-ston" when we mean Boston and for the most part, we never use the letter R in any words. Ever. If you're going to create a movie about my hometown, you need to have your on screen cast perfect the accent or hire native Bostonians. Period. In one scene the lead actress, Vera Farmiga suddenly adopts the accent but throughout the rest of the movie sounds like she's from Los Angeles. This is typical and annoying and because of it, it throws off the movie's "honesty". Unfortunately the movie comes off as halfhearted and not believable to those of us from Boston. It's too bad Martin Scorsese didn't care enough to make his actors get it right. If it was a NY movie, you know they would have.

title: Over-rated?
review:
Says the Buddha "He who is in Continuous Hell never dies. Longevity is a big hardship in Continuous Hell"

I found these lines from Infernal Affairs.I watched Infernal Affairs with subtitle but still i was impressed with the expressions and visuals and the pace of the movie. But there was not much of this content expressed in the departed. First half was slow and slippery. Ending was horrible. All i was hearing is Foul language throughout the movie.

Apart from good casting, i didn't find anything done to improvise the original script from Infernal affairs. Rating The departed over Infernal affairs in IMDb top 250 is Extremely disappointing

title: Fantastic movie keeps you on the edge of your seat
review: Growing up in the Boston area I can only love this movie because every time the camera angle changes I can recognize something in the background. All that aside This movie is based off a real gangster that ran Boston for a couple decades and was at one point right behind Osama Bin Laden on the most wanted list. You have secrete informer from the Massachusetts State Police working in the mob, and a mobster working with the Massachusetts State Police. The whole movie the gang always seems to be one step a head of the police. But in the end justice was served. This movie is perfect because there is only one like it and you wont really find any movie like it. Keep in mind that this true stuff. This is what Boston was like throughout the 70s till mid 90s. ENJOY

title: monkeytastic analyze of the departed
review:
Movie-Gorilla vs Movie-Ape Hate it Like it

Movie ape: Whats wrong with you man! I have to say I don't like Martin Scorsese that much,but The Departed is one of the best movies I have ever seen

Story:7/10 Acting: 9/10 Effects: 5/10 Action: 7/10 Badass factor: 9/10 total: 37/50 Great

Movie gorilla: I don't like to be the critic but the Departed is one piece of s**t It's like a two year old made the story and Martin Scorsese wanted to test how much Bulls**t people like. I hope you didn't like the Departed or You fell into the dumbest trap ever made by a human being. It's just not good

Story: 1/10 Effect: 0/10 Acting: 4/10 Action: 0/10 Badass factor: 1/10 Totall: 6/50 Bulls**t

title: A split splat trash, without any sense
review:
We already have Tarantino for this who does a much better job, at least his movies give you a good laugh. This movie has been mediocre from start to end, the plot has been too much into violence, useless strong language and above all too much tied up into an illogical spiral of violent events barely credible like most of the action thriller Hollywood movies, not all of them luckily. The cast was overall good but they were all acting on the same path of the plot too much into their dude and rude roles, Nicholson was a complete square black box without any heart in it, just compare it to Shining and see the difference.

The only ones who have managed to do an inspired job in my opinion were Vera Farmiga and surprisingly Di Caprio.

title: Oh My God What Has Leonardo DiCaprio Done
review:
are you kidding me this is what movies are now i have not seen internal affairs but i will if i find the trilogy DVD.

this remake is called departed by director martin who made taxi driver & god fellas with Robert DE Niro the world knows those films

now look at the cast here its just i am so angry at this film jack Nicholson the joker guy from batman at his worst,Matt Damon the Jason Bourne dude is guy who cant decide weather he is good or bad when he was picking up & telling jacks location to the police Mark Wahlberg is a cheap guy cant act for nothing a stupid tough wannabe now my favorite actor Leonardo omg what was he thinking i had huge respect for this guy now i am about to loose it the whole time he was abusing & talking crap wow what a shame & embarrassment this production is.

The only guy i laughed at was the store owner telling gang guys his name name is not freaking babu its singh and he was right about whats wrong with this country everybody hates everybody it was pure hilarious.

the plot was about a guy who wants to be a cop enters a gang & is forced to choose between good and bad as must give info to the police about bad guys who are smuggling micro chips.but then somethings happen as both sides the police & the gang/mafia tries to figure out who is the mole among them.

I liker Vera Farmiga though she was nice .forget the story there was no action & in the film & at the end you see the big mess happened the movie needed serious editing anyway just don't see this film as i was watching this one a loud speaker just for laughs & my dad came i was embarrassed you can buy some tom cruise films but not this please.its disgusting.

my rating is 1/10.& how the hell did this junk won 4 Oscars.shame one everyone if anyone likes departed he should depart from this world quickly

title: Excellent film that is iconic for the kind of mobster genre of films that are out their. In a phrase one of the best 'no nonsense' films out there!
review:
This is a film that is fairly immaculately made, if it isn't the amazingly integrated music with its consistent inconsistency of when it starts and finishes, this is a film which doesn't waste time setting up the scene by showing you pan shots of the city, its instead a film that gets right into the thick of it and stays in it right up until the last scene.

This film does not even make the most common movie mistake that there is, ending the story when the main story line has ended, all plot lines are relatively ended by the end of the story, apart form maybe what happens to the unborn baby and what ever happens to Mark Wahlberg after his ending scene, but by this stage you don't really care, the rest of the story is so good that it is really overlooked.

The cast is excellent, being a huge Nicholson fan anyway, he is on form as always, as well as DiCaprio pulling off a deep and troubled character although perhaps a little bit too much time is spent on him being stressed without it ever really effecting the main story line. Damon's appearance is also welcomed although as the film goes on we are truly taken though the same experience as him as he starts with an amazingly confident performance, diversifying into a near nervous wreck towards the end. However if each of the characters acting was to represent the tone of their characters, this film is really one to watch for character development as especially DiCaprio and Damon's characters and completely different by the end of the film.

This is a true example of a no nonsense film and is welcome in amongst many films which focus far to hard on surroundings, this is the opposite, its all story, everything that happens is relevant in at least some way, and their is little you are left wandering, why was this put into the film?

And all round amazing performance by many actors, obviously Nicholson, DiCaprio and Damon but further I really enjoyed every moment of Wahlberg's no nonsense approach to every scene he is in, as well as also enjoying Baldwins performance and Sheens, who both acted as secondary but crucial members.

Excellent film that is iconic for the kind of mobster genre of films that are out their. In a phrase one of the best 'no nonsense' films out there!

title: A Brilliant Film
review:
'The Departed' is what Martin Scorsese claims to be 'the only film I've ever made with a plot'. It is excellent.

The plot itself is based on a Hong Kong movie 'Internal Affairs'. Having not seen the original version I cannot comment on whether 'The Departed' is better or worse but as a film on its own it is brilliant. The story makes sense and is really intelligent. It's surprising just how many times the story can shock you with lots of twists and turns towards the film's climax.

The cast on paper looks excellent and it certainly does not disappoint. Matt Damon rarely plays an antagonist but this film shows he is capable of just that. Leonardo Dicaprio gives a powerful performance and deserved an Oscar nod for this. Jack Nicholson's performance is one of the best of his career; his sinister portrayal of Frank Costello is certainly worth watching. The best performance however was that of Mark Wahlberg who's character provides so much comedy and gravitas to this film. He definitely stole the show here and overshadowed a lot of other great performances like those of Dicaprio and Martin Sheen.

Overall, this film is fantastic. It's one of the best modern films I have seen in a while and it really did surprise me. A truly brilliant film that everyone should see

title: The Departed
review:
This was an excellent movie, on par with Goodfellow's and better than Casino. The acting was superb and a great cast, though I'm a huge Jack Nicholson fan and he is as magnetic as ever, Martin Sheen was great as well as the two main characters. This movie was Scorsese at his best.

Though you knew from the beginning of the movie who were the good guys and who were the bad guys so there was no major twist or surprise at the end. I would highly recommend any Scorsese movie. I can't believe he never got an Oscar for this or Casino. I don't think there is a director that can do organized gangster crime movies finer. The ending of the movie though was not as good as any of the other Scorsese movies and seemed to be a bit of a cop out. This was made up by superb acting.

title: Not your typical gangster movie
review:
If you're a fan of movies with unpredictable movies, this is a must see. Matt Damon delivered a superb performance here. Best I have seen him perform. Leonardo Dicarpio also delivered here and Jack Nicholson showed he hasn't lost a step and why he is a legendary actor.

Its a movie that will have your attention all throughout. Its one of those star studded film where every star delivered. The characters are mysterious and interesting; not you're conventional bad guy, good guy or your typical cop versus criminal movie. Its shows the hardship of both sides: cop and criminal. ITS A MUST SEE especially if you're a fan of gangster movies. Hollywood did not disappoint here.

title: Great Film
review:
I've been going to school for media arts, and have recently been watching older films - taxi driver, easy rider, deer hunter, etc. good ol' classics. This film ranks right up there with the best.

It took me about 45 minutes to realize I had seen this film before - maybe six or seven years ago. That is how intricate and intense this movie is - it keeps you on the edge of your seat and guessing until the very end. I briefly looked over some of the other reviews - especially the very negative reviews, and I am astonished that someone can dig up some pathetic excuses as to why this movie is bad. I mean c'mon, I don't see your name at the end of a blockbuster film - who do you think you are criticizing an amazing screenplay. Sure there are some minor imperfections.

In my mind, from the movies I have seen - new and old, everybody dies in a great movie, and this is yet another example reaffirming my theory; except in this one, more than your average amount of people are shot in the head even characters who haven't been introduced, unnecessary?

Say what you will, but if you are giving this movie a one star, then you just woke up on the wrong side of the bed, or have had a bad day. I don't particularly admire Scorsese, or any of the actors, so I can say without a doubt that my vote is unbiased and quite accurate - just ignore those who obviously have a biased unrealistic opinion.

title: Simply one of the best films of all time
review: You know when I rate things, anything I never give a 10, mainly because my belief is that nothing in this world is perfect, their is always some small if not insignificant gaff, goof, imperfection whatever. Now with that said I of course give this movie a SOLID, and I can't stress that enough "Solid 9", it is as close to a cinematic masterpiece as there has ever been, Outstanding Writing, Direction, Production, Unbelievable Soundtrack, The acting by this great, and one of a kind cast is nothing short of pure Gold. So why not a 10 you say??? Like I said nothing known currently to mankind is perfect, but it sure is nice to know that there is once in a great while an attempt to achieve the impossible, and that it is always striven for, which in the end is why we get great final outcomes, and unforgettable outcomes such as this movie.

title: Excellent Boston-based thriller
review: Martin Scorcese won a long overdue best director Oscar for this, his first movie with a plot, and if not entirely deserved the honor was not entirely misguided either. The Departed is a tightly made LITTLE crime/suspense thriller, basically a very good modern film noir (note the use of bled out colors to evoke a noir sensibility) with two strongly drawn drawn main characters driven by contrasting needs and ambitions and nicely creative supporting work by Nicholson especially and Baldwin to a lesser extent. (No kudos for Walberg. The screenplay gave him a unique patter, as baroque as it is foul-mouthed, but the performance is all in the writing. Walberg adds nothing in the way of nuance. Can he spell 'nuance'? One wonders. How does this guy manage to sustain a career? Must have one hell of an agent...) Anyway, the entertaining main story line twists around and around like a caduceus to the point of seeming overly contrived, especially as regards the psychologist character who winds up getting involved with both of the lead characters, one of whom is a patient - a professional no-no, and highly unlikely anyway even if he is Leo Dicaprio. If you can get past some of the more extreme manipulations of the plot, this is a richly enjoyable movie.

title: Captivating!
review:
The Departed contained great dialog, cinematography, and lighting as well as fantastic editing by Thelma Schoonmaker. Not as long as Gangs of New York (2002) but it still contains the action and clever plot twists and general excitement found in most Scorsese pictures.

The Departed is authentic, captivating and heart felt. At the time, I predicted Globe and Oscar nominations for Mark, Matt, and Lenonardo. Martin Scorsese's brilliant mind as a director shows up in this work of art, and I rate this film 9 out of 10, a superb masterpiece of "Crime Art" as i call it. Better than Casino (1995).

The film kept the entire audience intrigued and amazed at the hard depiction of corrupt Boston police, and an eye opener to modern Irish gangs. A grand remake of a Hong Kong film called "Wu Jian Dao". The Departed is fantastic.

title: The Departed (2006)
review:
Probably very unnecessary to write a review of 'The Departed', as I would almost go so far as to say it is one of the best films produced in the last decade or so, and by now you've either seen it or you haven't. That is probably not very far from the truth though, 'The Departed' is truly Scorsese's masterpiece from beginning to end, it is clear to see from every angle, as was with 'The Aviator' two years prior, that every single one of our cast and crew members are true experts at what they do. Our four male leads DiCaprio, Nicholson, Damon, and Wahlberg all carry themselves nicely throughout the film. Witty, intelligent dialog galore, Wahlberg truly impresses us here, as does Alec Baldwin who doesn't seem to be overplaying himself and doesn't deliver any of his lines as if they were his last words.

The complex story never really lets us down, no time to stop and take a breath, this is the type of film that demands multiple viewings. If you haven't seen this yet, you should probably get on that, as this is precision filmmaking at it's finest. I couldn't believe how unaware I was that I didn't know Scorsese had won himself an Oscar over this one until moments before writing this, and I have to say that would have to be the film he would win for. It's like required that a film so good should be recognized. 'The Departed' is essential viewing along with most of Scorsese's body of work.

THE DEPARTED -----10/10.

title: Love this movie!
review: This is far from the typical gangster movie. It has an AMAZING cast. I found it to be highly suspenseful and there seems to be little to no characteristics that separate the so-called good guys from the bad. With every call or text you think this could be it and someones cover is about to get blown. I'm not going to write a 20 paragraph review but I will say that if you like suspense and gangster movies this is the movie for you. Other reviewers complained about the number of F bombs that were dropped in the movie and felt it was unnecessary - technically cursing is never "necessary" but that is how people in this lifestyle communicate. The last 10 minutes of the movie was all shock...we try to guess how a movie will end but I had it all wrong.

title: A film for people who like to see people get shot in the head
review: I am not a big Scorsese fan. This is a quality film, no doubt, but seems to have a fixation on people getting capped the same way Gangs of New York had a fixation about people getting stabbed in the abdomen. The plot is very complex, perhaps overly so. One is reminded of the phrase, " A long way to go for not very much." Dedication to the cause of revenge, double crosses, hidden motivations, etc., are all over the place in this film. But it always ends the same: with a bullet in the brain pan. The final scene is a gangster version of Hamlet, without the "good night, sweet prince" eloquence of Bard Will. Everybody gets a 9mm lobotomy accept Mark Wahlberg's character. Bottom line: Watch Goodfellas again instead. That's a true masterpiece!

title: He's still got it
review: Billy and Colin graduate from the police academy at the same time, and are both hired by the SIU, a group assembled to take on organized crime. The former goes undercover, to work for the Irish mafia. And the latter... he's an informant for selfsame mob. Duality is the main theme here, and it is explored well(it's no accident that these two leads look so alike). Both are affected by their double lives, and both try to get help by, and subsequently get to liking, cop counselor Madolyn. Nicholson does impeccable, one of his best recent roles. Wahlberg is quite impressive, which is a bit new to me. He also comes off really cool, which goes for, well, all of the main cast. Di Caprio and Damon are fantastic. Sure, the Boston accents are over the top(well, Matt's and a few others... Baldwin appears to think he's portraying a Kennedy), but that's easy enough to look past. The slang is convincing and comes off mostly natural, sprinkled across the sharp, witty and swift dialog. Characters are credible, well-defined and nicely developed(through short, effective scenes that set things up). The pace is tight, and the two hour 25 minute running time is packed. This is directed superbly, and the editing and cinematography are amazing. The tension is thick and built expertly. There is a lot of strong language, bloody, gruesome, gory violence, and a little sexuality in this. The DVD comes with five trailers, one of them for this, the others being for The Painted Veil, The Reaping, 300, Blood Diamond. I recommend this to any fan of Scorsese, crime dramas and/or the actors. 8/10

title: Yes, well... departed is right.
review:
This Scorscese good cop-bad cop opus is a pretty terrible film. Yes I know it won Oscars as sort of consolation for Scorscese not winning Oscars previously, but, erggh, THE DEPARTED was not the film to be handed them.... THE AVIATOR is the film that should have won the Scorscese Oscars not this horrible film. Jack Nicholson's truly terrible idiotic clichÃ©d performance is possibly the worst since THE SHINING with silly grimaces and Huntz Hall mugging. The shabby restaurant scene when he impersonates a rat is simply woeful, an insults the ticket-paying audience who have trusted the film makers and actors to deliver something a lot better.

If you want to see imagery of your most admired young male actors having their brains splattered on a wall, this sadly is it. As usual over violent, and that as usual marrs most Scorsese films: idiots with guns, swearing and urban decay. Not much has changed from MEAN STREETS. The DEPARTED is a major disappointment. Not as groanworthy as GANGS OF NEW YORK which is simply THE CAT IN THE HAT meets MOULIN ROUGE with a cleaver. Think about it.

title: Terribly Good!
review: I've watched this movie 4 times because I loved it so much, but the one and only thing that I still couldn't accept is the horrible ending. I mean, could somebody just tell me, WHY in the world was Leonardo killed!? He and Queenan was the two, who I think is the best characters in this movie, and guess what, they all DIED! Not to mention their doing, trying to uncover the Colin rat (who I hated from the beginning) was, in the end: NOTHING, that Dignam guy (I call him Dicknam), put a bullet into Colin's head and that's it! What the hell, If I was him I would have put two bullets in each of his foot and drag him all the way to the SIU team and then uncover him and then KILL THE RAT. Yeah! that's how it should be, AND I WANT LEONARDO TO BE ALIVE, and live happily ever after, with the Shrink! But despite that horrible, disturbing ending, the movie was rather very very interesting, 4 Oscars in 1 year, well, that's what the movie deserve.

title: Never saw a movie like this
review: It's not a true story. Or is it? With the recent arrest of Whitey Bulger, who was reportedly a partial role model for Frank Costello, the Jack Nicholson character, the movie comes back to life as a testimony to recent historical events. What amazes me is how deeply I was drawn in to what is supposedly a fictional story. If these characters are made up, the screenwriter is, well, actually better than Shakespeare. That, or he knows the place, Southie, so well its molecules ooze out of his skin and just telling what he knows. The placement of literary devices, betrayal, suspicion, tension ratcheting scenes is so precise, so well planned you have to cancel all your calls for the afternoon. It's ridiculous. Never saw a movie so tightly planned, so well played, so unforgivingly methodical in its creation of character. The actors, of course, deserve credit. But hey, they're reciting lines written by the writer.

title: "Martin Scorsese's Masterpiece"
review:
"Martin Scorsese's Masterpiece"

From Direction to Acting to story everything's just perfect.Every time you watch it you see a new different thing which you haven't seen in the previous watch,very few movies deserve more than 1 watch.This movie is very intelligently made,no one can say that if this thing made in that way it would be good.

I think it's better than "infernal affairs" from which it has been remade.We can call it a "complete entertainer" ,it remains into your mind for hours after watching.Actor Jack Nicholson deserves an Academy Award Nomination for his performance.

If a list be made for "The Best Films of the Decade(2000-2010)",it should be in top 25.

title: Phenomenal Directing, mild overacting
review:
Summary

This particular film focuses on the Boston police force and their attempts to infiltrate and destroy an Irish-American Mafia family within the city. Jack Nicholson appears in this film as Frank Costello, the head boss of an organized crime family. A new graduate from the Boston City Police Department, William "Billy" Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio), goes undercover and infiltrates the crime family in order to build a case against its top members. Billy soon finds out that Frank Costello has someone inside the police force working for him. Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon) is Frank's informant and holds a position within a Special Investigation Unit. Billy was convinced to go undercover by Capt. Quenan (Martin Sheen) and Staff Sgt. Dignam (Mark Wahlberg). These two agents are the only ones within the police force that know the true identity of William Costigan. Billy works extremely hard in order to build his case against Frank Costello while Colin Sullivan frantically attempts to foil all of Billy's hard work. With the help of Collin, Frank discovers that someone in his crew is working against him. With their lives in danger, the focus for both sides then shifts to discovering each other's informants before their true identities are found out.

Theme

The central theme of this movie revolves around the identity issues that the three main characters faced. William Costigan had a very sketchy background. A few members of his family were involved in organized crime, most of which were dead. He had a lot of resentment towards these members of his family, which may have possibly driven him into police work. In the beginning of this film, he was faced with the difficulty of losing his mother. He gave the impression that he was trying to find himself and he was hoping that the police force would assist him on his journey. William's path was riddled with prescription drug abuse, violent depression, anger and psychological slipping. Next, from the time the Colin Sullivan was a small boy, he longs for a father type figure. He found this in Frank Costello. He was constantly trying to please Frank. Throughout the film, he referred to Mr. Costello as "Dad." He was constantly trying to live up to his father figures expectations of him. He wanted acceptance and unfortunately he went looking for it in the wrong person. Frank Costello was a man who knew exactly who he was and did not try to hide it. He was proud of the stature that he achieved and was very boastful of what separated him from most people. He was very forceful with his views, his words, and his actions. Frank was a very violent, sociopathic, and untrustworthy individual. Although an unsavory character, Frank was very sure of whom he was and the direction he wanted his life to go. He believed that he was very in control of his life, his destiny and other people.

This film was very much about good versus evil as well as individuals internal struggles. William and Collin both struggled with internal conflicts. Each chose their own method of dealing with this conflict. Both of these characters sought out who they truly were, but in opposite directions. But Colin and William also shared a similar interest in the same woman, which led to an interesting love triangle throughout this film. Unfortunately, in a twist ending, William and Collin met their fate in order to achieve the initial goal of dismembering/disrupting the crime family.

Take On the Film

This particular film had a modern-day Goodfellas (1990) meets American Gangster (2007) feel to it. There were definitely twists and turns to it they gave it its own unique feel. Martin Scorsese did a phenomenal job with the various editing techniques in order to give this film an upbeat and intense tempo. Through the use of the introductory monologue and various lighting techniques, he set the stage for Frank Costello, his choice mob boss for this film. The Departed was a fairly ordinary and common detective-goes-undercover story. Martin Scorsese sets this film apart from the rest through his phenomenal directing. The plot is thick, filled with constant action and suspense. It culminates to a plateau near the ending and then surprises the viewers with a twist ending.

The two downfalls I observed in this particular film were occasional overacting and ending that seems slightly disappointing. Within a few key scenes in this movie, especially involving William and Frank, it seemed like the actors were trying to be overly convincing of their role. Some of the emotions displayed seemed irrational and had a swing of emotion that seemed unnatural. This film comes to a peak when William Costigan attempts to arrest Colin Sullivan. The viewer finally gets the feel that good is going to triumph over evil. Then it seemed like the story was attempting to surprise and shock everyone and just abruptly ended in a blaze of glory. The entire two hours leading up to the final scenes had the viewer wrapped up in every moment of the plot and then the story just ended in the credits began to roll. This was a very mediocre ending to an otherwise phenomenal film.

Additional notes

An underlying moral of the film is loyalty. After all, the only survivors are Capt. Wllerby (Alec Balwin), who was completely amoral, and staff Sgt. Dingam (Mark Wahlberg), whose rigid sense of right and wrong get him suspended from the force. He then turns into a killer, out of a misguided sense of loyalty to "the law", he breaks the law in the film's final scene.

title: A Cinematic Masterpiece
review:
I thought that this movie was extremely good. The action filled plot kept me attentive throughout the whole movie, and the actors played believable roles that helped carry along the movies plot. This movie had many strong points such as directing, cinematography, editing, and the soundtrack. There were a few small weaknesses in the movie that most critics overlook, but the pros outweigh the cons. Overall, I greatly enjoyed this movie, and I think it is one of the best movies of all time.

I thought that the Cinematography and Editing in this movie was very good. The dark, grainy camera shots perfectly describe South Boston, and the different symbolic camera shots, such as the rat crawling across the balcony in the end, make this movie watchable ten times over. The sideways camera zooms on the main characters, like in the scene where Captain Ellerby and Sergeant Dignam are talking back and forth; highlighting the main characters, and making you feel like you are there with the characters. The quick camera flashes during fighting and chase scenes keep your heart rate up during the movie, and they greatly help to keep you interested throughout the movie. The editing in the movie is pretty good, but there were some scenes that seemed unnecessary, like the scene where Costello his talking to his semi-love interest while snorting cocaine. The movie is over an hour and thirty minutes long, which is tough to fit in a single night of movie watching.

The acting in the Departed is excellent. It has a very strong cast, and some new actors that really seem to shine in this movie. It seems like every role in the movie greatly contributes to the movie throughout, and that great detail went into creating every one of these characters. Leonardo DiCaprio plays William Costigan, a bright young detective who wants to be a cop and nothing else. DiCaprio is excellent throughout the movie. He has to master a South and North side of Boston accent, because his character is a cop in the North but an undercover gangster in the South. He perfectly interprets his dark, moody character, and successfully reveals all of the stresses in his role that go with being an undercover agent. I think that it was his best performance since What's Eating Gilbert Grape? and he proves once again why he is regarded as one of the best actors in Hollywood. His performance feels extremely natural, and shows his overall quality as an actor. Another great actor in this movie is Jack Nicholson. Nicholson is an extremely famous actor known for his roles in movies such as One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, A Few Good Men, and Chinatown. Nicholson, in my opinion, does the best acting in this movie. Nicholson plays the hardcore gangster Frank Costello, a man who has no moral limits. Nicholson successfully portrays a crazy old guy, and captures the audience with his stellar performance of the role. His witty but dark comedy also makes the movie a lot more enjoyable. Nicholson shows once again why he is one of the best in the business.

The Soundtrack in The Departed is one of the best I have ever heard in my life. Artists such as The Rolling Stones, The Allman Brothers, The Dropkick Murphys, and John Lennon make this movie what it is. One of the best scenes in the movie is where Costigan is riding with Costello and the gang and the song I'm Shipping Up To Boston is playing. This song's traditional Irish sound makes this scene, and other songs like this one help make the movie so wonderful. The Sound Effects in the movie are also brilliant. Sudden crashes and noises during scenes keep the audience alert at all times. Different cell phone rings tell you what character the cell phone belongs to, so you know instantly if that character is in an ordeal. Overall, the sound effects in this movie are great, and they help turn this movie into the masterpiece it is.

The directing in this movie is very good. Martin Scorsese, one of the best directors of all time, masterfully handcrafts this movie into what it is. Many details in this movie make it what it is, and the extreme importance of these details help guide the story. Scorsese once again makes another gangster movie, but he makes this movie so much different from his other movies that you don't even associate it with being a Scorsese movie. This movie has a lot of twist and turns, unlike Scorsese's other movies with very solid, unmoving story lines. One problem I had with the directing of this movie is that Scorsese doesn't do a very good job of creating a love interest within the movie. The main girl in the movie, Sullivan's girlfriend, cheats on Sullivan with Costigan. This scene is very symbolic, but you feel almost no attachment to this woman character. Besides this, Scorsese does a wonderful job portraying the South side of Boston, and makes a wonderful and thrilling movie that gets better every time you watch it.

title: Good but.....Foul language spoils it.
review: I was looking forward to watching this film, how could it fail with such a cast and a great director, well for me it did fail, in fact i came near to turning it off half way through and putting it on the 'reject' pile. So what was the problem? Well for me it was the barrage of unnecessary swearing, F**K, Fu***R, C**T, was all I was hearing in nearly every piece of dialogue. How on earth did 'Madolyn' (Vera Farmiga) fall for 'The Rat' when faced with such a foul mouthed lout. Also Matt Damon and Leonardo Dicaprio look so much alike, and even dress alike, that it is really difficult to tell what is going on, as, unless you are familiar with their work, you keep getting the two characters confused. However i am glad that i stuck it out to the end just for Jack Nickolson who was as flaky and demented as ever, though even he was reduced to saying C**t in every sentence. And the final shot with the rat...well that was unnecessary and cheap. I will certainly watch it again to see if it improves with age. In the meantime i am going back to watch 'Goodfellas' again.

title: 'Someone had to die. With me it tends to be the other guy'
review:
'The Departed' is an excellent film. Director Martin Scorsese, who won the Best Director Academy Award for this movie, has assembled an incredible ensemble cast headed by Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, and Jack Nicholson. I can not praise DiCaprio's work enough; as an actor he just gets better and better. It seems that he has become Scorsese's latest muse, a role filled in past years by Robert De Niro. Everyone acts up a storm, actually, and Vera Farmiga is especially good as Madolyn, who forms a bizarre love triangle with Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio) and Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon).

Billy Costigan is an ambitious young Boston cop who goes undercover in order to infiltrate a criminal fraternity headed by the charismatic and philosophical Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson). At the same time, Frank has a mole working for him inside the Boston Police Department in the person of Colin Sullivan. Colin tips off Costello whenever the latter is about to be busted, allowing Frank to stay one step ahead of the cops. So Billy must uncover Colin's identity while Colin is trying to uncover Billy's. Cue a breathless and mesmerizing flick, filled with intrigue and numerous close calls.

First rate support is offered by Ray Winstone as Mr. French, Costello's right hand man. Winstone does not even have to open his mouth - his physical presence is intimidating enough as it is. And Mark Wahlberg (as the profane Staff Sgt. Dignam), Martin Sheen (Cpt. Queenan), and Alec Baldwin (Capt. Ellerby) round out the cast, while it is great to see Anthony Anderson in a serious role as Brown. Anderson proves here that he can do more than just comedy.

Nicholson is great as always, and he is pretty frightening and totally believable as the crime overlord. This is another triumph for Scorsese and, while it is perhaps not quite up to the standard of 'Goodfellas', it is still highly recommended viewing.

title: Hands down best crime drama ever!
review:
Scorsese's all time best film ever made says nothing. This is one of the best directed, acted, produced, and written films made period. Scorsese never fails to impress us, and proves it greatly in this. An all out full cast: Jack Nicholson, Matt Damon, Leonardo DiCaprio, Martin Sheen, Mark Wahlburg, Alec Baldwin...the list goes on.

A lot of people compare this to the Asian 2002 classic "Infernal Affairs" with it's identical story. This film not only tells it better, but does it better in general. This film includes some of the best performances iv'e ever seen in movies. Every role is convincing as it can be, and every second keeps you on edge until the very end.

The story starts out simple, but quickly goes into complex situations that will have you on the edge of your seat. The film takes place in Boston, Massachusetts, where Irish Mob boss Francis "Frank" Costello plants Colin Sullivan as an informant within the Massachusetts State Police. Simultaneously, the police assign undercover cop William "Billy" Costigan to infiltrate Costello's crew. When both sides realize the situation, each man attempts to discover the other's true identity before his own cover is blown. Not only a clever story, but it stretches the idea of story telling to incredible boundaries.

Leonardo DiCaprio's performance is without a doubt the most underrated performance ever. I honestly think he should have gotten an Oscar, but his highest achievement was a Golden Globe nomination. He's good in the entire movie, but his true performance begins when he starts working with Costello. He becomes psychologically tortured by watching all these innocent lives being tortured by the Irish mob, and by the fact that any minute, his cover could be blown and he could die at any moment. His performance dragged me into the film so much, that I felt so bad for him to the point where I almost cried. Not really, but I felt like it. Everyone else is amazing also, but I think Leo's performance truly puts you in the position of a tortured soul. Jack Nicholson is hilarious as Costello. He's ruthless and violent, but keeps his cool when he needs to. Obviously he's the bad guy, so Leo is always on edge when he's around him. Then when Costello is acting goofy, Leo doesn't know what to do. He pretty much acts like a standard mob boss...having no worries in the world, wanting money and sex. Matt Damon is pretty interesting to watch, because he actually starts to work like an actual cop and help track down Costello, as if he changed sides. Martin Sheen and Mark Wahlburg pretty much work as a group. They're the only ones that know William is undercover, so they pretty much have to babysit him the whole time. Wahlburg is a huge prick in this film, but trust me when I say by the end of this film, you'll love him. But what I don't like is that out of all the amazing performances in this film...He's the only one who gets an Oscar nomination. Really? Out of all those, you chose him? I'm not saying it's not good, but Leo's was way better, I think they all should have gotten one, and if just one, then Leo. I don't get what the Academy liked some much about Mark's performance, but I have to say it's a little overrated. Martin Sheen has a pretty good character. Since Costigan's dad is dead, Sheen treats him like a son, and becomes a father figure. Alec Baldwin is just there for laughs in my opinion...that's about it. Oh, and you got the cop shrink who starts dating Damon, then dating Costigan. She's all right, but she's not all that important.

The film combines itself well with comedy. It knows when to be serious, and can be pretty hilarious at times. The funniest performances are probably Baldwin and Nicholson. Oh, and as far as dialogue goes, as long as you constantly say the "F" word, you pretty much filled in half the script. Not even joking. Too many of them to count.

I don't how to describe how brilliant this film is. Scorsese is a mastermind, and knows exactly how to please me every single second, (no homo) If you haven't seen this...SEE IT RIGHT AWAY! It is without a doubt the best crime drama film ever. An 11/10

title: Its no Goodfellas, but it will keep you entertained.
review:
Thankfully Martin Scorcese returned to the contemporary street crime genre in 2006 after some showy epics like Gangs of New York and The Aviator that sort of disappointed. You couldn't ask for a better cast in this fast-moving tale of the Boston underworld and those intending to take it down or keep it going in perpetuity. The primary characters are Matt Damon as a corrupt MA State Police big shot who has acts as an inside man for a ruthless gangster (Jack Nicholson), and Leonardo Di Capprio as an undercover cop working in Nicholson's street crew. Damon tips Nicholson off about the cops' every move, and DiCapprio keeps the police up on the gang's dealings. The plot isn't difficult to follow, and most of the action is punctuated by gunfire and cell phone usage. Though it isn't a high tech thriller, it depends on our current wireless technology and telecommunication laws.

There are a lot of characters to keep track of from the countless police big shots to the scores of low-level street thugs. Also both primary characters are romancing the same psychologist. There is a lot of inter-lapping between good and bad. And most of the people are either flawed or the complete personification of evil. Nicholson's Frank Costello character is perhaps too evil to be taken seriously. Apparently he was allowed to improvise some of the more bizarre behavior we see on camera. If anything, Nicholson physically looks like actor Rip Torn in any of his recent mugshots. The acting is uniformly excellent, with some of the older characters shinning in their smaller roles. Honestly, have either Alec Baldwin or Martin Sheen even been more believable? Damon has grown into quite a talented actor. Dicapprio has been worse, but one still has to wonder why Scorcese won't make a movie without the guy anymore. The only major weakness is with the plotting. We never really do get a true feeling for Dicapprio's motivation. Why does he agree so readily to put himself at such a risk going undercover in Nicholson's gang? Is it to honor his dead father who was the only honest man in the old neighborhood? Or was it for a handsome tax-free payday? Did we ever learn how much he was getting paid? Even with a head shrinker assigned to him, we still never learn that much about the guy. Anyway, this film is too entertaining to let a couple of plot holes (including a ludicrously violent last five minutes) bog it down. It is thoroughly entertaining, and you will probably love every minute of it. 8 of 10 stars.

The Hound.

title: Solid
review:
As for anything 'deeper,' in a film like this one cannot really dig into issues like cultural identity, or masculinity and violence, because, while they are there, they are there at such a superficial level (as opposed to, say, the same theme of violence in Taxi Driver or Raging Bull, explored at a far deeper level). On a technical level, the film does employ music well, and the film succeeds with its many quick cuts, even if more longer paced scenes should have been interspersed to let the actors truly act and cogitate on their lives, beyond the overacting DiCaprio does on Fermiga's couch. Cinematographer Michael Ballhaus does his usual competent job, especially in the retro look of some scenes, which open and close with irises.

The two disk DVD, by Warner Brothers, is naturally bloated. There are not enough extras to need a second disk, and furthermore, for a two disk set, they commit the ultimate crime: no film commentary by Scorsese nor any of the leads. There are nine deleted scenes prefaced by Scorsese's reasons for omission, a profile called Scorsese On Scorsese, a documentary on the criminal this film was based upon: Boston crime kingpin, James 'Whitey' Bulger, a documentary on what influenced Scorsese's crime films, and the theatrical trailer. Solid stuff, but for two disks, more- especially an audio commentary, should be standard issue. But, were the movie better, the gripes re: the DVD package would be minimal.

As it is, The Departed is good Hollywood fluff, yet, given that it's Scorsese, more is expected, although I have the sinking feeling that, like Woody Allen, he will never produce another masterpiece. This film follows a standard cops and crooks formula, which, in and of itself, is not a bad thing- consider the 1997 crime masterpiece, L.A. Confidential. The difference is that where that film took a genre formula and twisted it from pulp melodrama into real drama, via the writing and performances, as well as ending the film with a satisfying twist that was unexpected in the small, even if expected in the large (the good guys won), The Departed does the inverse, never rising above melodrama (even if good), and ending the film with a bad twist, of the worst deus ex machina sort. If you watch the film, don't expect much of an aesthetic not intellectual rush, only some mildly entertaining moments, crafted really well. If you want the former, go watch some earlier films from the Scorsese canon. Unfortunately, given his recent output, that last line was also likely seen coming from a mile away.

title: Best Scorsese Film Since Goodfellas!
review:
I did not get to watch this for awhile, last year to be exact. I at first did not understand why people were saying this was amazing, but after a few more watches this became one of my favourite movies of all time!

I could not believe all the great performances in this film, Mark Wahlberg in my opinion had the performance of his career, Leonardo DiCaprio was just Superb, Matt Damon was also great, and Jack Nicholson had the performance of the decade for him.

The directing was amazing, Martin Scorsese made it feel gritty, and rough around the edges and I loved it! Definitely a huge achievement for Scorsese and a well deserved Oscar on his part.

The writing was also great, the characters felt real and the dialogue definitely kept the movie rolling along smoothly. This is the best film in recent memory (The Prestige Comes Oh-So Close!) and was the obvious choice for best picture.

This Film is all around perfect and gets a 10/10 a rating I don't give out too often. This Is A MUST SEE!

usualfilmfan

title: Simply Masterpiece....Matt Damon, Leonardo & Nicholson are Outstanding...
review:
What can i say about this masterpiece...Its a Classic which every movie lover will have in their library...Martin has previously delivered great movies but this movie is Classic in his kitty..Direction & Screenplay is terrific...Dialogues & punchlines are kicking & rocking specially the ones that are delivered by Jack Nicholson...He is simply apt for the character of Costello...Leonardo as usual is so intense & complete in the character of Costigan that u simply forgets u r watching a Hollywood superstar...Matt Damon's character demanded him much & he doesn't disappoint us & delivered one of his excellent performance till date after bourne series...

Watch this movie to understand what is called A Masterpiece...

title: Martin Scorsese at his very best!
review:
The Departed is in my opinion one of Martin Scorsese's best films yet (tied with Goodfellas). Along with The Godfather it is one of the best crime films of all time.

The Departed begins with showing Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon) as a kid. Sullivan is accepted by Boston crime-lord Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson). The movie then jumps to Sullivan graduating the police academy. In the meantime, Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio) plays as a young undercover cop trying to infiltrate Costello's organization.

As Costigan moves closer to Costello, gaining his personal trust, Sullivan is promoted into the Special Investigations Unit. Costello fears he might have a rat in his group, while the Police Chief also believes there is a leak in the Special Investigations Unit. This provides plenty of tension for the rest of the film.

Even though The Departed uses the 'f' word more than 236 times in the script, and is rated R for bloody violence and some sex, this film still managed to get several Oscar nominations and wins. The Departed won Best Picture, Best Director (Martin Scorsese), Best Film Editing and Best Adapted Screenplay.

I think that The Departed deserves every one of those awards. This film is simply brilliant, I loved it. Leonardo DiCaprio is an amazing actor and once again shows this with another great performance. He is very believable as a cop who's so screwed he's in with the bad guys. DiCaprio shows a wide variety of emotions including anger, fear, hate, desperation and some slight charm.

However, Matt Damon is the more charming guy in this picture. His character begins the film as if he rules the world. He's moving up in the police force and he's gaining cash from informing his friend Costello. His personal relationships also begin to evolve as he moves in with an attractive therapist. By the end of the film, Sullivan is so worried he will be found, and is worried the police might find Costello, he begins yelling at people and losing his cool. Matt Damon also puts on a great accent for this role which fits the part of his Irish character (even though he is from Boston).

Jack Nicholson once again demonstrates that he can play the creepy crime lord perfectly. If you need an example watch the scene where he talks to DiCaprio about the rat in his group. Martin Scorsese has hit another home run movie, and has returned to his familiar genre of crime-drama. This film is a must-see, and perhaps the best film of 2006.

title: One of the best films ever!!!
review: So put together one of the best directors ever if not the best, then put some amazing actors, then add an amazing story and yo will have The Departed. Dicaprio show in this movie why he is one of the biggest actors in this time, probably his second most impressive performance (after The Aviator) Nicholson is also amazing, but honestly Wahlberg steals the show as agent Dignam he's funny , clever and an ice cold son of a $%&$%. The story is quite simply, the police has an agent inside the Mafia, and the Mafia has a guy inside the Police. Maybe this is some kind of clichÃ© inside the movies, however the best thing of The Departed it's not the story, not the sideplots, this movie is all about performances and how well timed the movie is. All the movie is fast, violent and surprising at the same time, this is probably the best 00's movie and if you consider yourself a movie fan, this is a must-see.

title: Apart from Goodfellas, this is Scorsese's best work easily
review: You can easily argue that Martin Scorsese is one of the best directors to ever offer his work to the cinematic world and the fact that the Departed was his first Oscar is a shame to us all. Personally he should have won 4 already, Taxi Driver Raging Bull Goodfellas & Aviator (you could also make a case for Gangs of New York), but we have to accept that he did earn it rightfully so w/ Departed. DiCaprio was easily snubbed from a Best Actor nom. as was Nicholson. Apart from Chinatown, this was Jack's best performance (I didn't care for Cuckoo's Nest if that's what you're wondering). But what I enjoy about Departed is the fact that since most famous gangster movies, Godfather & Goodfellas, take place in the past but Scorsese makes the up to date gangster flick very enjoyable. See This Movie!

title: Scorsese's Return to Form
review:
This has got to be the best film that Martin Scorsese has made since Casino with De Niro in 1995. He's made some good films since then but nothing of the calibre of his earlier collaborations with De Niro. Here Leonardo Di Caprio, one of the best actors working at the moment, gives an outstanding performance making Costigan's guilt and inner conflict completely convincing. Billy Costigan starts off as a police officer in the Boston Police Department, but he apparently washes out, has a spell in prison before joining the ranks of the Irish mob run by Frank Costello.

Costigan is in fact a mole in Costello's organisation and in a quite brilliant concept, taken from the original version of this film Infernal Affairs, Costello has a mole in the police department, Colin Sullivan. Matt Damon's performance as Sullivan is almost the equal of Di Caprio's creating another great character.

They're not the only two, Jack Nicholson gives perhaps the best performance of the film as the mob boss Frank Costello, he's obviously having a great time here by turns funny, furious and psychotic. De Niro was originally down to play this role but due to his directorial effort The Good Shepherd it wasn't possible and Nicholson stepped in. I for one am glad, De Niro, one of the greatest actors whose ever lived despite the awful films he's been churning out in the last 10 or 15 years, can't possibly have matched the intensity, charisma and sheer brilliance that Nicholson brought to Costello.

To discuss the plot any further would be to spoil it, but suffice to say it is rather brilliant and there are many changes if you have seen Infernal Affairs, it is altogether a more complex affair. The supporting actors Mark Wahlberg, Vera Farmiga, Martin Sheen and Ray Winstone all give stellar performances that help make The Departed one of the best films of the decade.

title: And thats how perfection is defined !
review: The Departed is a Martin Scorsese's film,where once again the greatness of this director is proved.Leonardo DiCaprio is obviously his unspoken muse which i respect completely.Anyone who says that Leonardo is just a pretty face with no acting skills,has no clue about movies or actors.His magnificent performance is going to leave you with your mouth open and probably will make fall of your chair.I put this movie along with "Usual Suspects" as one of the greatest thrillers ever made. The story follows two policeman working for or against the government.If you think the story is already seen,think again.Scorsese manages to develop intriguing and unpredictable history of movies. Every character is prepared and worked out with great amount of dedication and hard work.Jack Nicholson (you can love him or not ) but his craziness and eccentricity work unbelievably in this motion picture.A role of a mafia boss is so suitable for him,that afterward you won't be able to picture him differently. I must say,Matt Daemon is not my favorite actor,but this is the movie where i changed my opinion.He is brilliant! The music is amazing.You will hear great Irish sounds mixed with a dose of hard rock which suits the movie perfectly. Martin Sheen is another perfect contribution to this movie making it complete and amazing.Still,my favorite character in this movie remains Mark Wahlberg that will "wow" you with his extraordinary performance and great,funny,but meaningful dialogs. This movie does deserve to win not one,not four but many Oscars and to find its place in the "best movies of all times" list ! One of the greatest movies ever ! A true masterpiece and definitely a must see !

title: A Great Thriller and A Great Remake
review:
After years of rejection one of the greatest filmmakers in history won his well-earned Oscar for The Departed. Martin Scorsese, could, and should have won for Taxi Driver, Raging Bull, Goodfellas, Casino or Gangs of New York, but he has at least avoid being in the ranks of great directors who never won an Oscar like Stanley Kubrick and Alfred Hitchcock. The Departed is based on a brilliant Hong Kong film Infernal Affairs, which was itself was attempting to be a Hollywood thriller. Seeing that Infernal Affairs was a brilliant film which had two good sequels Plan B Entertainment did the wisest thing it could, get the best writer and director available, William Monahan and of course Scorsese.

South Boston is a famously Irish Catholic area of America, it's underworld is run by Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson), a ruthless gangster who gets up to usual activities like drugs trafficking, extortion, theft, etc... He recruits a boy who trains to be a police officer, Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon); who becomes his mole within the Massachusetts State Police. Another recruit was Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio), a young man whom family is notoriously dodgy. He gets recruited by Captain Queenan (Martin Sheen) and Staff Sergeant Dignam (Mark Wahlberg in his best performance) to go deep undercover and infuriate Costello's organisation. So the mob and police have moles in each other, and both men raise up the ranks within their organisations. Sullivan does well for himself, joining a special unit, making money, has a good apartment need the state building and forms a relationship with Dr. Madolyn Madden (Vera Farmiga). Whilst Costigan has to deal with the stress of being undercover, having live in a violence world, deal with the enforcer Mr. French (Ray Winstone) and has to see Madolyn. Both the mob and the police discover they have moles in their organisations and a deadly cat and mouse develops as the two men have to find out who the other is.

These is an excellent remake, translating the setting well to America. It keeps the basic plot of Infernal Affairs, adding a few elements from Infernal Affairs 2, but Scorsese and Monahan ensure that they make their own film: an excellent thriller, not just about crime and police investigation, but about the ideas of identity, betrayal and the psychological strain this world would have on a person. Both the mob and the police are very macho worlds where people need to be tough to survive. These are complex characters in a difficult world, where loyalties can be made and broken. Scorsese and Monahan also tells a complex plot with a number of things going on. It is a film about the conflict between the police and organised crime. Scorsese also shows his skill behind the camera once again, showing some excellent images and a world of violence. He brings you into this complex world.

They is a great cast in this film, Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Jack Nicholson, Martin Sheen. As stated, Mark Wahlberg was in his best role and could have won an Oscar for Best Supporting Actor: a shame he torched it all in 2008. There is also a good comic moment between Wahlberg and Alec Baldwin. Vera Farmiga also shows her talent and is now doing pretty well for herself.

2006 was an excellent year for film: The Departed, Casino Royale, Children of Men, Pan's Labyrinth, The Lives of Others, The Last King of Scotland, Letters from Iwo Jima, all worthy films that could have won awards at the 79th Academy Awards.

title: Scorsese's best? No...but still enjoyable
review:
Well, I am just after seeing the title page and was quite shocked to see that the reviewer on show had stated that Martin Scorses's 2006 crime thriller The Departed was the directors finest.

Wrong. Very wrong. I'll admit, this film is very impressive in a lot of aspects. It does tick a lot of the boxes. It has some of Hollywood's finest giving admirable performances, mainly Jack Nicholsen as Frank Costello and Mark Wahlberg as the tough but strong-minded staff Sergeant Dignam.

In addition, it boasts an on-form Di Caprio as the undercover cop Billy Costigan, who infiltrates the mob syndicate run by boss Costello (Nicholsen), and Matt Damon as Colin Sullivan who turns out to be the rat as the story unravels.

Nonetheless, this film fails to live up to the towering standards firmly set by Raging Bull, one of the most poignantly powerful films of all time with an unstoppable performance by De Niro, whom I believe to be much more effective in collaboration with Scorses than Di Caprio. Along with Bull, Goodfellas is arguably the greatest gangster film of all time and Taxi Driver is what made a star out of Scorses and De Niro.

However, this is a dignified effort by Scorsese and his production team and welcome return to form on the back of the monumentally long-winded Gangs of New York (2002) and Aviator (2004) which was decent but slow in parts, lacked authentic characterisation and was similar to Gangs of New York in the sense that it was unnecessarily long. No thanks, I prefer Scorses's earlier work as it is these films mentioned in the previous paragraph that provide a real insight into the particular topics. Raging Bull depicts the highs and lows of Boxing and Goodfellas' portrays the consequences of shamefully living life as a high-rolling, murdering mafia favourite.

Despite this, Scorsese delivers a good film, an enjoyable watch that kept me compelled until the end. I thought that Jack Nicholsen, possibly the finest actor of all time, was brilliant as Jack Costello and enjoyed the turns of Alec Baldwin, Martin Sheen and Ray Winstone as Mr. French.

I would highly recommend The Departed to anyone. It is intense, gripping and full of top-notch performance from a roll-call of Hollywood's finest past and present. However, if you are not familiar with the works of Martin Scorsese, I urge you to watch his true accomplishments. Taxi Driver (1976), Raging Bull (1980) and Goodfellas (1990) are probably the most intoxicating and wildly entertaining hat-trick of films your ever likely to see!

8/10

title: Legendary director Martin Scorsese takes the helm for this tale of questionable loyalties and blurring identities set in the South Boston organized crime scene.
review:
The Departed is director Martin Scorsese's most purely enjoyable film in years, but it's not for the faint of heart because it's rude, bleak, violent and defiantly un-PC. A young criminal (Matt Damon) is ordered by a Boston mobster (Jack Nicholson) to operate undercover within the state police, while a young cop (Leonardo DiCaprio) infiltrates the mobster's gang.
