This film is made into a movie of its own. Although based on Infernal Affairs (HK production), the story have been slightly altered perhaps to fit the culture of American street gangs. I do admit, there are many things I do not like about the film, being a fan of Infernal Affairs, it is more wishy-washy, and Jack Nicholson was... well.. not that wonderful. I read somewhere that apparently Jack Nicholson didn't even research for his role, so he just "naturally" played him.. so you can see, this character ended up being more of an "evil clown named IT", rather than the terrifying controlling leader of the mob. That really disappointed me, because characters in control (Chinese Triad bosses, Godfather, etc) are all very strong, controlling and more level-headed characters, whereas Jack Nicholson's character is more a clown than a boss. Another cringe-worthy scene is where they hired poor Cantonese speakers to act as triads from China (speaking Cantonese?? you mean they're from HK or Canton?). Any Cantonese speaker will cringe and laugh at how poorly they spoke Cantonese! I know that's not overly important for those who doesn't understand Cantonese.. but just makes the film more tacky.. you know... just unrealistic .. so it's tacky.

Leo DiCaprio was surprisingly good, hands down for his magnificent performance - a great mature comeback from his gone teen-heart-throb era.

Besides that, the story of course is brilliant. No one can deny or hate the story-line, as it is magnificent, unique, and clever both in the HK and the Hollywood version. My vote is given for the story line and Leo.

title: Good movie but not Scorsese's best.
review: I was all excited to see this movie but something about just didn't do it. In fact Im not sure where all the fan fair is coming from. Is it a good movie? Yes. A good Drama? Ya. But is great or a Masterpiece. I beg to differ with all the fan fair. The Italian Mob movies we have all come to know and love from Scorsese overshadows this piece by far. Perhaps the Italian Mob pieces are just more "colorfull". The closest you get to colorful in this piece is Mark Wahlberg's Excellent performance that in my opinion saves this film. So in short with all due respect please Mr. Scorsese stick to Italian Mob movies!! They are what you do best!!!!

title: Just very good
review:
I'd hail most other directors for this movie but as it's Scorcese, I've got to say: not as good as Goodfellas or Casino but still a very good movie.

especially the ending is outstanding. And there are really great pieces of dialog. I'm already looking forward to seeing the original version. It's a real waste to see that cast with their German voices (although they're not bad).

DiCaprio and Nicholson where good - of course. But it was Damon who surprised me, because I didn't think he was a real good actor before and he is just perfect here.

And Marc Wahlberg  unbelievable. He is even less likable than Nicholson - and that really takes something.

title: If only it had finished well...
review:
On the heels of the annual fall movie lull comes the beginning of Oscar season. And you know what that means: lots of pretentious films that aren't very good! Yay! First in line, from Martin Scorsese, the man who brought us the overrated borefest that is "The Aviator", is "The Departed"...or is it? Plow on, fair reader...

Generally speaking, Martin Scorsese's films all have a similar theme: exploring the complex lives of unlikeable people. His latest is The Departed, which follows two Boston police academy graduates who take drastically disparate paths. The movie is tortuous in every sense of the word. Plot twists are prevalent; people are not always who they seem; and deceit is the rule rather than the exception. Therefore Scorsese is the perfect director for this film, which can be neatly compared to a good piece of rope. (Go with me on this one, okay?) "The Departed" opens with a handful of story tresses that are related but different. Each arc appears to be going the same direction, although the connection isn't immediately evident. But the big picture soon begins to come into focus as the strands are woven together. The noteworthy editing of Thelma Schoonmaker, who has chopped most of Scorsese's work, contributes mightily to this effect. Early on the movie is nearly disorienting, jumping rapidly from story to story at almost random intervals, as quickly as second by second. This fitfulness soon settles into a comfortable equilibrium, in part because one becomes accustomed to it, and in part because the stories braid themselves tighter and tighter.

As the film finds its rhythm, it occasionally soars on the wings of its stellar cast. In their parallel roles, Leonardo DiCaprio continues to mature with his hard-edged part; Matt Damon plays an interesting spin-off of his altar-boy image, and as a local crime boss, Jack Nicholson is...well...Jack Nicholson. Even though the hard-nosed characters are not particularly likable in themselves, Scorsese takes the time to provide glimpses into the quieter parts of their lives, not just the adrenaline-pumping moments. Like the characters or not, this makes them more human, more interesting, and more worthy of sympathy. It also produces the movie's best moments, which are not entirely congruous with the rest of the film.

As a Boston-based crime drama, "Departed" virtually demands comparison to 2003's stellar "Mystic River". Clint Eastwood's film holds a few things high above Scorsese's, namely a soul. Like Kevin Bacon's detective, Vera Farmiga's fresh-faced police psychiatrist brings some semblance of a moral center to the project. But as she is sucked into the vortex of chicanery, she slowly blends into her surroundings like Darwin's peppered moths. Another key difference lies in the closing act. River didn't wrap things up cleanly, but satisfyingly left story arcs somewhat resolved while still open. "Departed", on the other hand, tries too hard to tie a pretty bow on this occasional present to moviegoers, and that is where Scorsese's project disappoints most.

Regardless of how strong a piece of rope appears at its center, the ends are what define much of its value. Likewise with a film, if the final act isn't finished well, the film loses much of its punch, as "Departed" does. Rather than tie off the end or perhaps unbraid the story lines, Departed instead sloppily hacks off the end of the stories that pull the viewer along. The final scenes may seem like an acceptable finish upon initial glance, but a closer inspection reveals not a snip and a solder, but a absurdly quick chop-chop, a slovenly deus ex machina that jarringly diverges from the slow build of the previous two-plus hours. It almost feels like one of those wisely discarded alternate endings on a DVD, like something someone jokingly threw out as an lazy way to conclude matters.

With its frequent outbursts of intense violence and words, hard-living characters, and twisty story lines, "The Departed" is a Scorsese work through and through. At times the director, aided by a loaded cast, provides wildly entertaining moments and scenes. But like a couple of Steven Spielberg's recent movies ("War of the Worlds", "Munich"), the discordant final act prevents this movie from attaining greater heights. Perhaps Departed could have joined the pantheon of mafia-type films ("Godfather I/II", "Goodfellas"), but the late shortcomings prevent it from reaching even the strong second tier ("Untouchables", "Road to Perdition", etc.).

Bottom Line: A slow but steady start, a strong middle third, and a weak last act make "The Departed" recommended only to those interested in seeing it for genre- or Oscar-related reasons. 6 of 10.

title: Imagine a great bicycle kick, now imagine it hits the post..
review: I can not believe the difference of the satisfaction level between the first and the second halves and there's one obvious reason for that: The screenplay!! Even before you have read or seen any comment about this movie, your expectations are high since the cast is amazing and it's a cop vs mafia( although you really see it's not that black and white when the movie starts) situation where you think that the names in the cast will pull out a great job right? Well, THAT, you got!! Even more than you think which is easily realized by the outstanding Di Caprio performance( which however i believe is boosted to its limits thanks to Nicholson more than Scorsese). The movie gets you right where it wants starting from the first lines in the means of direction, acting, pace etc.. It sets up the story, neighborhood, main characters perfectly.. It builds up beautifully with its storyline and even the choice of music adds up to your inference power about the events. However, you start to raise your eyebrow to some small mistakes characters start to do towards the end. A little bit of chin scratching is added to that when the mistakes become more obvious and you find yourself praying not to walk out with an awful ending. Finally, the screenplay collapses towards the very end. I mean, what the heck was William Monahan thinking? The original Infernal Affairs screenplay was much better. I believe he also wrote the screenplay for 'Kingdom of Heaven' which I think was also lame. I am giving some serious thinking on not to reach to my pocket to buy a movie ticket if i find out that this guy is involved! You simply don't have the luxury to make mistakes in a screenplay where reality, accuracy or consistency affect the overall rating of the film more than the average. This is no 'Daredevil' or some other kind of fantasy movie and i definitely can't show the same tolerance as a viewer. But STILL, it is a great movie and I definitely recommend that you see it and decide for yourself but beware for it's like watching Ronaldinho perform a great bicycle kick which hits the post, having an amazing foreplay without a happy ending or meeting the girl of your dreams and then finding out she's a lesbian.

title: terrible overacting, heartless
review:
orlando jones once said: "Someone I met years ago explained to me the difference between a personality and an actor, a personality being Eddie Murphy or Roseanne Barr, and an actor being Morgan Freeman and Alfre Woodard or Marlon Brando. And in the shrinking world of sound bites, the Internet, and other mass media, there were going to be fewer actors and more personalities." (From PopMatters interview, 2000)

if you apply this to "the departed", you'll see that there are hardly any actors in this soulless and empty piece of Hollywood entertainment.

granted, the craftsmanship of scorsese is evident and made me sit through the 140 minutes of this film.

is it a masterpiece as some here said? definitely not! art is supposed to make you think or feel on a higher level. this film does nothing of the kind. it leaves you empty because it is without any heart or soul.

as for the acting: dicaprio's performance was just embarrassing. terrible overacting! i couldn't believe it.

matt damon was as he usually is. this guy just cannot act. period. he's a good-looking "personality", but not an actor by any stretch. he often compensates by overacting.

same goes for wahlberg. emberassing overacting. who hired that guy?

sheen was decent. he is an actor.

i was surprised by jack nicholson, however. he has never really been an actor but a very interesting personality. but there are scenes in this film where he actually acts well! seems he took some acting lessons in his old days.

the plot was very convoluted in the setup but got more streamlined in later parts.

this was not a good movie by any means and certainly no masterpiece. just another piece of empty, soul- and heartless Hollywood "entertainment"

4 out of 10 for scorsese's craftsmanship.

title: Typically American
review:
The movie starts and develops really well up until the last quarter or so.

Then, a well built and interpreted plot crumbles completely in an exaggerated and senseless series of killings.

The movie should have ended when Sullivan kills Costello. Then, Costigan should have nailed Sullivan and it would have ended in a "round" way. I'm not typically for "happy endings", however, in a search for an "European ending" (un-happy), Scorcese ends with a stupid one: the writer's and Scorcese's options were absurd and an absolute disaster, peaking with the pitiful scene of rat walking on Sullivan's balcony.

title: Martin should get an Oscar or else we will have no more "Raging Bulls"
review: I saw "The Departed" yesterday with my wife, and we both quite enjoyed it. Getting my wife to the cinema isn't an easy job, and getting her to enjoy a movie is almost a "mission: impossible".. SO: "The Departed" is a very good movie - well written, well acted, well photographed. Martin Scorsese knows his job. BUT (and it is a very big BUT) - Where is the thrill and chill I used to get from Scorsese's movies? There is no comparison to his early work like Taxi Driver, The Raging Bull or The good Fellas. It seems to me that Mr. Scorsese tries too hard to be liked, to humor the Academy. The outcome is a very mainstream movie. A very good one, though. Come on Martin - Get the Oscar and Get a grip already!

title: Scorsese is back
review: Martin Scorsese and his wonderful editor Thelma Schoonmaker, certainly know how to open a film. The degree of visual energy and panache in the first twenty minutes of The Departed is absolutely glorious, beautifully thrilling. I wish I could say the same of the rest of the movie, which, while enormously entertaining, has so many twists and turns, and is so long that after a while one would like to get off the fun ride. It is extremely violent and as happens with all movies that depend on intrincate plots, at a certain point one asks very logical questions of things that are not happening but should. Such as "how is it possible that the Irish mafiosi controlled by a fun, over the top Jack Nicholson haven't figured out by now who the rat is"? The Departed is delightful because everybody in it is a pro: Nicholson goes to town hamming it up, but his relish is contagious and he is wonderful. Matt Damon is extremely fine as a cold, professional, ruthless villain. I'm glad he was cast against type. Di Caprio is quite good as his counterpart, a mole in the mafia. And the rest are adorable pros: my beloved Ray Winstone, Martin Sheen, Alec Baldwin, and even Mark Wahlberg, trying real hard to come up with the goods and acquitting himself nicely. The Departed touches upon recurrent themes in Scorsese's work: true morality, human hypocrisy, the corruption of the soul, how easy it is for evil to run rampant in this world, how very f***d up is human nature. The movie, as entertaining as it is, has substance, and is the best thing Scorsese has done in years. The one weak link I found was the subplot with the female shrink, played, not too convincingly in my opinion, by Vera Farmiga. She falls in love with both Damon and DiCaprio and to me that's already gilding the lily. Still, if you want to see what a master of movie making can do, run to The Departed and enjoy the mayhem. One big nitpick: too much rock and roll music in every scene.

title: Departed II and III
review: The Departed must be a success story, it has all the ingredients in this respect. So it is natural to suppose some follow-ups will come in the near future. However, while I do not see anything wrong in making follow-ups as long as you have something to say, and you're not only for the extra-money on viewers nerves, I just wonder how will Departed II and III look like? Will they copy Mou Gaan Dou II and III as closely as the first departed? I must confess I'm a little disappointed by the lack of imagination in US movies these days.Watch Mou Gaan Dou to see the original, the Departed is a mere fake. Ironic, isn't it - the US multibillion movie industry fakes the Hong Kong one, the rest is all wrapping with success ingredients?!

title: Good, if you haven't seen the original
review:
Unfortunately for this film I have recently re-watched the original: Mou gaan dou (Infernal Affairs 2002).

The original film is a wonderfully engaging and thrilling film, where the viewer is constantly comparing the two lead characters. Which is the good one, which is evil - does the end justify the means? More importantly the film has these two characters questioning their own existence, questioning their own motives, questioning whether you become the lie that you live.

The Departed on the other hand seems to focus on the success or failure of each character - not the internal struggles that made Infernal Affairs great. The result is a rather bland action film, with some mild tension towards the end (with a decent amount of blood and profanity). Many things, like the "Irish Mafia" seem tacked on and incidental to the actual story - we see nothing of this "Mafia" beyond our chief villain Frank Costello. It seems a fumbled attempt to set the film in an American setting.

Overall this film was a disappointment to me, since I knew what the film could have added - those who hadn't seen the original on the other hand enjoyed this film for it's merits, not it's short comings.

If you're going to see the original, then give this a miss - if you don't like subtitles then this one's for you.

title: A shame-full copy of a way better movie.
review:
At first I hadn't seen Infernal Affairs, movie from which departed is copied poorly. Then, I didn't realize that this movie was never supposed to have been done. It's an outrage to the actors and producers of I.A. to make this movie. It's is just a lame copy, with worst changes possible and famous people. Really terrible that Americans have to do such things. Just go and watch Infernal Affairs and never waste your time on this Departed stuff. Who in the hell would believe in Leonardo Dicaprio is a bad mob man, that would kick anybody out? No one. He's a shame to himself, it's a shame that Scorcese have dragged a very good Nicholson and Marky Mark into this crap.

Shame on you, Scorcese. Infernal Affairs Rule!

title: Classic
review:
The Departed is a cop movie, through and through, with almost as much mafia flavor thrown in. It could be considered part of the gangster genre, I suppose, but with the double agent detectives being the major players (DiCaprio and Damon), I stick by my original classification. So yeah, this movie has a little bit of everything. Not in that it seems mashed together, but in that it feels real. The characters are deep, constantly living even when they weren't on screen, and the plot line is rich. There's plenty of emotion, both raw and tamedfor those people that like to cry or clap at the end of a movie, lots of guns and blood, and laugh out loud humor delivered via Alec Baldwin and Mark Walberg. Acting is excellent, as to be expected. It hooks you from the moment you sit down andas clichéd as this may beit never lets go.

My only qualm would have to be that the editing was as choppy as a baboon's arse is red. Martin Scorsese, the director, didn't finish the editing until a week before the release, but I would have been happy to have had it delayed a month and seen it at its best. At many points you see characters from an angle and then the angle will change and they will be standing somewhere else. I expected more in that department.

It's a must see, though. A classic for decades to come.

title: okish remake...
review:
Pretty good remake of the 2004 Chinese film -infernal affairs.

to my mind not as good as the original but still a film worth watching regardless.

Shame that there must be so few good scripts around that the film industry has to rip-off films made in other countries and so recently as well.

I'd advise people to watch the film this was remade from first and decide for themselves.

Before seeing Departed a friend at work was telling me about it and we almost came to blows over the film's name as almost scene for scene it is so similar through much of the film in it's rip off.

Would be nice if more credit was given to the film that was butchered here.

title: Well, at least it's better than Gangs of New York...
review:
This is by no means a terrible movie, and indeed if you haven't watched the Infernal Affairs trilogy, or just don't believe in having to do anything that resembles reading when watching a movie, then it certainly works. The best moments in The Departed pretty much coincide with the best moments in Infernal Affairs, and all in all the movie benefits greatly mostly from the ingenious concept behind the movie.

Perhaps the most damning criticism I can think of with regards to Scorcese's remake is that apart from the montage of archive footage at the very beginning of the movie (possibly an after-effect from the cut and paste job he did on No Direction Home) there was nothing else in this movie, cinematically speaking, which marked it as a Scorcese movie. To me, it felt like this movie could have been shot by any director in Hollywood. Even Scorcese's gift of "right song, right moment" seemed to be on the wane.

But special mention must go to Jack Nicholson for the most outrageous, over-the-top hamming up I have seen in the cinema for some time. Never the most restrained of actors, Nicholson clearly relishes the opportunity to play the trademark "Scorcesean Bastard", and the man chews the scenery like a dedicated gourmand. One expects a runner to be on hand to give the man indigestion tablets at the end of each scene. I found myself actually pining for the less-showy and thoroughly reliable blandness of Alec Baldwin after a few minutes of Jack. Everyone else turns in perfectly decent performances, but was surprised to find that it was Mark Wahlberg who steals the show with a memorable performance, without having to stoop to Nicholson's exaggerated theatrics.

All in all a rather disappointing effort, and certainly not the return to form that many critics seemed to be saying it is. It's certainly better than Gangs of New York, but really doesn't even compare to "The King of Comedy" let alone "Taxi Driver" or "Raging Bull". I would urge people willing to enjoy a genuinely original and innovative film to check out "Infernal Affairs". The mere fact that Martin Scorcese was pulled on board to direct the remake surely should tip you off that it really is something quite special.

title: Gooooooo & Seeeeeeee
review:
The Best Thing in this Film if SomeOne Ask U " Tell me The Story " U'll Stand Like a Dead Man & U'll say Nothing Except "Go To the Cinmea & See the Movie"

it's Really Great Movie (Actors, Scrpit, Director, Music, Camera,... Everything & the Most Beautiful Thing That it's New Not A Traditional Story

I'm Sure We'll See it in the Oscars ....

Leonardo DiCaprio Oscar Best Actor

Matt Damon Oscar Best Actor Second Role

Martin Scorsese Oscar Best Director

& Of course Best Script & Writing

GOOOOO & SEE It

title: Film Noir for the 00's
review:
Yes, I dare confirm it. Better than GoodFellas, by far.

A great script full of beautiful, naturalistic dialog and a plot where nothing is unnecessary and nothing is missing. DeCaprio shines, I wasn't able to catch him in a fake moment. Nicholson at his Nicholson persona, nothing new there for me - I prefer him in movies where he awes us with his gift like in About Schmidt - Sheen, Damon and Baldwin delivering solid characters and Whalberg in a knock out performance that I'm willing to bet will get him at least the Oscar nomination if not the win.

Scorsese masterly blends the script with sounds, images and an editing that makes everything lean and fast. Mr. Scorsese has better Mr. Scorsese and I thought that it was impossible for anyone, including himself, to do that.

My bet is that this film will score nominations for Picture, Screenplay, Leading Actor - De Caprio, Supporting Actor -Whalberg and Nicholson, and if the Academy really, really likes him, Scorsese will finally take Oscar home, and sweetly, it will be for one of his best oeuvres.

title: Best remake ever...
review:
What can I say,I hope Scorsese will live for another 30 years,Nicholson too...

The Departed is better than the original,really the best remake ever.

Maybe not Scorseses best movie but finally he should get his Oscar.Nicholson,Di Caprio and especially Wahlberg should get nominated,and of course a nomination for best adapted screenplay.BY far the best movie this year...

For the first time in my life people applauded during the movie in the theater,including me.Even if I watched it I will buy the DVD and I will watch it again...

These lines are written after the Oscar ceremony,it makes me proud that i have made the right predictions but i don't know why i forgot to say that it deserved the best picture Oscar...

title: Continuity Problems, Etc.
review:
I liked this movie a great deal, but there were continuity problems that really annoyed me. For example:

The scene where Madolyn (Vera Farmiga) is moving into Colin's (Matt Damon's) condo. He pulls a picture of her (as a child) out of the box. They talk about it, then he says it's going to hang in the bedroom - and takes it in there - presumably to hang it. Later in the film, Billy (Leonardo DiCaprio) comes to Madolyn's apartment where there are still boxes of stuff being readied for her move - one can only assume she needed to make multiple trips. Billy and Madolyn talking and he pulls a picture from one of the boxes and comments on it. But it's the same picture that has already been moved into Colin's condo!

Also, there's a scene where Billy gives Madolyn a package with instructions on what to do with it if he is killed. You never hear anything more about it. The contents of the package are never revealed, but it's obvious it's something that will clear Billy and divulge who the "rats" are. However, since there's never any mention of it after that, it seems totally unnecessary to the film - more filler than anything else.

I also have a problem with the ending (this is not a spoiler). The appearance of a rat on the balcony was the hokiest thing I ever saw. I can't believe Scorsese would stoop so low. What the Hell was he thinking?!!

title: The popular Hong Kong police-triad drama "Infernal Affairs" has a solid screenplay, enabled "The Departed" a worthy adapted version with its stellar cast
review:
When I saw the trailer for "The Departed" - just snippets from the movie, I thought how very much like Hong Kong's "Infernal Affairs" aka 'Mou Gaan Dou' 2002. There's no mention up front that it's a remake, but the impressive quadruple leads with Jack Nicholson, Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Martin Sheen plus Mark Wahlberg, under Martin Scorsese's direction is simply irresistible. For first-time viewers who didn't get to see the original Hong Kong's "Infernal Affairs," the western back-story, characters and screenplay adapted to U.S. setting as a police-Mafia movie can stand on its own.

For those who have appreciated "Infernal Affairs" Hong Kong delivery, subtitles and all, with the irreproachable Tony Leung Chui Wai (in many director Wong Kar Wai's films: 2046; In the Mood For Love; Happy Together; Chungking Express) playing opposite the ever versatile singer-actor-can do no wrong Andy Lau (in "Full-time Killer" and many popular Asian romantic comedies, love stories, action drama, period or contemporary) - there is no comparison to the superior original. The layered plot line, the subtle performances from both cop & mole 'undercovers' - the literal translation of the Chinese film title can be 'no defining boundaries/rules' - a cop as mole and a mole as cop mixed in the police and triad worlds. How the writers came up with such an intriguing plot is beyond fascination. (Dialogs in 'The Departed' mostly can be picked up as direct translation from the Hong Kong version; the female part is expanded more for Vera Farmiga, just as Wahlberg's role is more fleshed out and critical, too.) The collaborative efforts of co-directors, Lau Wai Keung and Mak Siu Fai, with strong supporting cast, namely Anthony Wong as 'Wong Sir' who knows, understands Tony Leung's cop character, while Eric Tsang as 'Hon Sam' the villainous boss that appears to be amiable yet 'black-faced' in an instant - truly made "Infernal Affairs" an unforgettable Hong Kong film experience. Highly recommend - available on DVD.

On remakes in 2006, director Tony Goldwyn's "The Last Kiss" adapted by writer Paul Haggis (again), who provided steady ingredients for Zach Braff to shine in the leading role, and quite an opportunity for Blythe Danner paired with the ever so nuanced Tom Wilkinson as the parents - the remake version is actually satisfying with a more fulfilling ending than the rather abrupt one in the Italian original "L'Ultimo Bacio" 2001.

title: The only other Scorcese movie I've really liked
review: Cape Fear was the first and only and as of today, The Departed is the second. A great crime/thriller, talking about an insider for the mob in the police force(Damon) and a insider for the cops in the mob(Leo DiCaprio). It doesn't hurt to have also a great cast including the likes of Martin Sheen , Alec Baldwin and Mark Whalberg and of course, Jack Nicholson who plays the Irish mob's big boss. Add also great dialog(the movie's pushes swearing like there's no tomorrow and Alec Baldwin's character's remark towards the Patriot Act was priceless) which will provide you with a couple of chuckles and a plot filled with twists and turns(the last 10 minutes might will be a major shock for the audience). Acting is great, though you'll notice that Jack Nicholson once again plays that type of character you'd come to expect from his movies, slightly more tamed, but steals the show nevertheless. Leo plays pretty much a similar role as seen on Gangs of New York(a movie which I strongly disliked), but was well suited here. Matt Damon seems to be having fun with his role as Costello's(Nicholson) insider pulling all the strings making sure his father-figure(it's explained in the beginning of the movie) stays untouchable and in turn making life a living hell for our undercover hero(DiCaprio). My only gripe was a few soundtrack complaints(that Irish hardcore mix got a little on my nerves), the only lead female character who doesn't do much but is connected to the two main characters and some Chinese gangsters look pretty silly but that's pretty much it as far as flaws go. One last note, do not let kids see this, it's extremely violent and foul language roam free. Crime movie buffs will get their guaranteed fix.

title: Excellent.... but.....
review:
I watched it because I liked to see how a Hollywood adaptation of a HK flick comes out. I watched the Infernal Affair years ago and still enjoy the DVD.

The adaptation is really well done to fit American audiences. Compare to the original Infernal Affairs, it misses the subtle tension and the melancholy portrayed by the original. In the original, the relationship between the mole ( as Billy in The Departed ) and his boss in the police ( split as Dignam/Queenan ) was a very strong one. This piece is especially missed. Also, the scenery played in HK is very different from that of Boston. It is somewhat surrealistic in the original scene where the crime boss was finished off. On the other hand, the ending of The Departed is more convincing than the Infernal Affair.

What can I say, difference in movie culture makes two epics of their own.

title: Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants, Falling Short Of The Height
review:
The Departed is a film I wanted to fall in love with. Instead, I ended up having a prolonged, non-committal fling with it.

The cop-criminal crossover film genre has an impressive benchmark already, namely De Niro and Pacino in Michael Mann's Heat. Scorsese was brave to tackle similar territory in the first place, although granted The Departed takes a vastly different approach to the subject.

This is not a film that will spoon-feed the audience. Any knowledge of the broad plot before you see the film is a bonus, but be wary of spoilers. One cannot fault either the screenplay, something which treats the audience as intelligent, nor can one grumble about the work Scorsese does, as excellent as ever.

The problem comes in with the cast. Why Scorsese is so hot for Di Caprio is beyond me - I will confess this is the best of the Scorsese-Di Caprio films to date, but still all too often Di Caprio looks just out of place and out of his depth. He just does not have the range nor the appearance to pull off the character he portrays.

Conversley, Matt Damon's boy-next-door appearance works to his advantage in this one. I trust that this film opens up some doors to rather more substantial film parts in the future.

Jack Nicholson is good in this. He does not give "the performance of his lifetime". He does not give "one of his top five performances". He probably has done enough to get a number of "supporting actor" awards here, there and everywhere. If this is Jack symbolically handing over the reins to a new generation of actors, it is a misguided one.

Perhaps the biggest disappointment in the casting area is the lack of use of real gems. Martin Sheen, possibly the best actor in the world today to cast as a head or chief of any Police division, seldom does more than sit at a desk. Mark Wahlberg gives a Grade-A, Boogie Nights level performance that suggests maybe he should have been given one of the two leads, but then again who would play his important part in his absence? Finally, a round of applause for Mr Alec Baldwin - a great, understated delivery of a support role that indicates he has at last matured into one of the leading character actors of this era.

Sigh, Oscar talk. If they give Scorsese awards for this, it will just underline the injustice for him not being given such things for Taxi Driver, Raging Bull and so on. If Stanley Kubrick never got an Oscar for his directing, then no director really needs one for any reason other than a nice ornament.

I find it hard to imagine where, with the cast, crew and director involved, anyone who would want to see this film would trouble themselves with a review beforehand, but if you want an opinion then it is to see the film, but hold no expectations of greatness.

title: The envelope *kinda spoiler*
review:
What the heck was in the envelope that Billy gave to the shrink? At the end he gave her a yellow envelope and told her not to open it until she heard from him in two weeks or if he "departed". So... what the heck was that about? That was the only real head-scratcher that I left the movie with.

I also kind of wonder if maybe the movie had a lot of un-used footage at the end. It seems like the end of the movie had a couple of odd loose ends... for instance, the shrink is pregnant. How does that play into anything? Is it Colin's, or possibly Billy's? Why do they inform us of this? And didn't one of the police sargents ask about a wedding? I think we all missed something - but what?

title: This movie is impressed, but Hong Kong version is a lot better.
review:
Hong Kong actor and singer Andy Lau comment on the new Martin Scorsese film 'The Departed' last Friday in Hong Kong. Even though he gave the movie an 8 out of 10, he didn't have a lot of good things to say about the Hollywood movie.

'The Departed' was adapted from Lau's crime thriller 'Infernal Affairs', which topped Hong Kong box office records in 2002. Lau said that the Americanized version has too much foul language and not enough female character. He even compared himself with Matt Damon, since both played the same role. 'I focused more on my character's psychology and made my role not such a bad guy superficially, while Damon's portrayal made the character absolutely evil! --------------------------------------------------------------------- This movie is impressed, but Hong Kong version is a lot better.

title: Nice action film, but not much more
review: Scorsese does a good job in making a sassy action film, but the story line is not incredibly sophisticated. There are too many "main persons" involved in the plot, and the dynamics between them are more sketched. The different events are loosely connected, and one gains the impression that the film just moves from one setting to the next without any good story underneath of it. Additionally, once scene can be seen as condescending towards other cultures, when Costello emphasizes three times towards foreign criminals how "things are done here", in the States -- like, we are gangsters, but we still have a better culture. Poor is also the way Scorsese puts the only women into place -- even though being a psychologist, and in touch with the key persons, she remains passive throughout the movie. One can only think, how would that be if the role was played by a guy? On the positive side, however, the film has some great acting to offer. Especially DiCaprio sticks out and really being Colin Sullivan, authentic to the smallest detail. Vera Farmiga, within her role, also plays wonderful, and Jack Nicholson is in his best as a bastard. So, four points for that, but to be a really good movie, but a lot is missing for it to be a really outstanding movie.

title: Good, but could have been better
review:
The trouble with watching a Scorsese film is that your expectations shoot up tremendously. So you do not expect the movie to be good, but you expect it to be brilliant. But here lies the problem...The Departed falls short of being called a great movie. Its good, story is brilliant (had to be as it was based on a superb script of 'Infernal Affairs'), actors are very convincing as well, dialogues crisp, scenes and situations well thought out..hey, u would be wondering then where did it lack...this question is troubling me as well...why did I not enjoy this movie as much as say a 'Goodfella'?...what was it that this movie lacks? I do not have a very clear answer for that..but my guess is that probably it is a combination of many factors..Too many characters..too many co-incidences...and I feel there should have been more time spent on building up the characters..showing more of their childhood events...I have always felt that by doing so, you can grab the audience attention very well..here it was just 1 minute sequences shown here and there...nothing that can hook up the audience...

But hey it still is a good movie...DiCaprio has really matured (and this performance should finally answer his critics for good), Nicholson is Nicholson..always in his own zone...and a surprise package in the form of Mark Wahlberg..a very good performance...probably his best performance yet.... So do watch this movie...you definitely will like it...but do not have expectations of a movie which is in top 100 of the IMDb 250 list...:)

title: ... what's wrong with ending of this film??
review: ..................................................................... ..................................................................... i see that for a lot of people DEPERTED is a very good film near a perfect, i don't wanna argue with anybody cause everybody have his own taste. This film may have a potential, have good actors, great scenes but when i watched ending i was shocked and disgusted. too straight, too stupid but to that unfortunately moment film was good, interesting and from that fact i give DEPARTED note 6. ..................................................................... .....................................................................

title: Dully Departed
review:
Scorcese is a wonderful director. I will always go and see a Scorcese movie and that's that. But this is a weak Scorcese movie. It is not a bad movie by any means. I mean, it engages your attention and you can watch it all the way through. But by Scorcese standards it is passable. Merely passable.

Apparently there isn't much to choose between the ItalianAmericans and IrishAmericans. So who cares that these people are IrishAmericans ? Apart from the accent they may just as well have been ItalianAmericans. Apparently there isn't much to choose between cops and crooks (although which of the two would you prefer to respond to your 911/999 calls ?), but the movie doesn't really bite the bullet on this. Really, it just takes a long convoluted route to saying: good guys win in THE END.

Considering the gory body count of people who get their heads blown off, this is dull, routine stuff. Going through the motions. Overlong. The attempted 'love interest' was borderline silly with both 'cop' and 'crook' falling for the same woman. It added nothing, it subtracted credibility. Better to have left it out altogether. What on earth was the point of that episode with the Chinese gang and the microprocessors ? Presumably it was some kind of reference to the original (which I haven't seen). All this communication by mobile phone stuff just seemed annoyingly modish (and surely not a secure means of communication for crooks who know they are under high-level surveillance). These bits and lots more could have been cut. It should really have been a 93 min movie not 150 min. The acting is non-descript at best, at times just plain naff: Nicholson badly over-indulges himself in a couple of scenes; Damon is as wooden as ever (he'll never match the best part he ever played - which was in 'Team America'); DiCaprio was the best but didn't have material of enough subtlety to work with - the psychological effects of being under deep cover like this is potentially fascinating. Again, the movie never really gets to grips with what it has taken on.

Whilst watching this movie I kept thinking this COULD have been a really good movie. And I was thinking: I must finally get around to seeing Infernal Affairs. I wonder whether Scorcese hasn't so much lost the plot these days as simply lost his place. Violence has been done bigger, smarter, wittier and more stylishly by Scorcese himself (Casino, GoodFellas) and the likes of Tarantino and Cronenberg and many others since. Likewise the blurred moral distinction between cops and crooks. And everybody knows there are far too many dubious re-makes these days. We don't need the likes of Scorcese wasting his talents on them as well.

title: Good movie, but not among Scorcese's best
review: Any movie having as high-profile cast as this one is bound to generate interest. Being directed by Martin Scorcese is just the icing on the cake. However, if you're expecting a classic comparable to 'Raging Bull' and 'Taxi Driver' then you'll be slightly disappointed. The plot twists and turns its way through a myriad of sub-plots and the 'who's chasing who' story comes to a terrific head when both sides meet at the building where Martin Sheen comes to meet his informant. Jack Nicholson was superb, as always, playing the dirty scumbag role in which everyone loves to hate him. Matt Damon revel led in his shady and slimy role, Di Caprio gave another example of his growing stature as a decent actor while Baldwin, Wahlberg and Sheen all played their part reasonably well. The sudden downfall of Nicholson and the abrupt ending slightly damages the movie's credentials. However, the mole-chasing-mole story is excellently depicted and this movie is definitely recommended for all the Nicholson or Scorcese fans out there.

title: Good Cop Very Bad Cop! Only So-So Scorsese,
review:
'The Departed' borrows it's premise and set up from hong Kong's cop trilogy, 'Infernal Affair's

Scorsese's usual trademarks are present throughout including his trademark camera work, it's also the fifth time he's ditched his trademark aspect ratio of 1.85.1 for the epic 2:35.1 ratio,

Scorsese has a fine cast assembled but sadly The appearance of Mark Wahlberg, feels as if his performance belong's to an entirely different film, Jack Nicholson, Makes his first collaboration with Scorsese,

Current Scorsese golden boy Leornado Di Caprio, is intense, as is Ray Winstone, Complete with Convincing accent, Alec Baldwin, and Martin Sheen, also appear, Matt Damon, is great as always,

It's all too apparent that Scorsese, made some final additions to this, Long time Scorsese editor Thelma Schoonmaker, should have finely tuned the edit a little more delicately.

title: Internal affair or Mou gaan dou ..
review:
Just watched the movie and am still bitter...Is Hollywood in dearth of Inspiration.. It cant even be called an adaptation of the 2002 hong Kong movie Internal Affair (Mou gaan dou). Its a scene by scene copy. The characters of matt damon and Leonardo in the original movie are played much better..I don't want to spoil the movie by giving out the plot (fr those who did not see the HK movie), what i think is matt and Leo's characters should have shown tremendous pressure coz of their jobs in the movie but they seemed quite casual throughout.. The HK movie was a notch ahead in the tech department too..The most high tech gadget shown was a camera cell phone..

For those who have not seen the HK movie, Departed would stand out because of the plot and thrill..but i cant rate it more than 4/10, it being a xerox..

title: I miss the great pride deeply inside DiCaprio's character
review: The only serious complain I have may be that in the original Hong Kong version, there was a high sense of honor and great pride deeply inside DiCaprio's character, which served as his only psychological balance when he was forced to do dirty works. Because he had been undercover for so long, his only wish, the only thing kept him going, was the promise that someday he will be a regular policeman and will be able to shout to bad guys: Police! That was also the reason he joined the police academy. I think this is essential to make the character believable. A minor complain is that Damon's character should have some sense of guilty. After all, before he was promoted so that he would be truly useful, he only worked as a policeman as others. Not all his work could be in conflict with his dirty interests. He should have some internal struggle for quite a while that he would be at least less willing when he leaked the critical info.

title: Infernal Affairs is much better.
review: Most people don't know that 'The Departed' is a remake of the absolutely excellent 'Infernal Affairs' Hong Kong thriller. I saw the original film a few months ago, and it was excellent. I must say, we Americans know how to screw up a perfectly good movie. Most of the characters in The Departed are so over the top and unrealistic, it's set in Boston so everyone has the obligatory horrible Boston accent. And whats up with Mark Whalberg and his hair-doo and unnecessary bad attitude?? Most of the Police characters are running their own Departments and they are relative children, so it seems unrealistic, even for fast burners. Matt Damon and Mark Whalberg are waaay too young to run those Departments, barely old enough to be street Cops. Anyway, where-as the original was a Masterpiece of suspense and betrayal, The Departed veers off into unnecessary directions, with unnecessary characters that add nothing to the story. Jack Nicholson as the crime Boss who still does the lowly shakedown at 60+ just seems crude, when he has so many henchmen, but his acting was spot-on as usual and needed more dialog. The Departed was OK, but the original was so much better so I suggest you see that and then come back and see the departed for some perspective.

title: Great crime drama but no "Goodfellas"
review: This isn't Scorsese' best but I do recommend seeing it while it is still in the theaters. It is worth it. It's nearly impossible to make a bad film with this cast (Maybe if we resurrected Ed Wood?) "Goodfellas" is probably "The Departed's" closest relative in the Scorsese catalog. It has a similar tension and pace but isn't quite as intense as "Goodfellas." Much of "Goodfellas" was based on real historical events, which gives the story more gravity than "The Departed." I wasn't enthusiastic about the ending but the ride was fun enough. This film is a good solid crime drama. It blows away the competition even though it isn't Scorsese' best. But that is an awfully high bar isn't it!

title: Better than GoodFellas?
review:
That's the question I keep asking myself.

People have different tastes. Not everyone is going to like this film as much as I did. But, man, did I love it.

I had to think about this statement for awhile before making it: This is the best movie to hit the theaters since Return of the King. But with all due respect to the LOTR trilogy, which I adore, The Departed, on it's own, is probably better than any single part of the Rings trilogy.

Then I moved onto Scorsese's other movies. Without question, GoodFellas is my favorite, and is second only to The Godfather in the mob-movie genre.

Is The Departed better? It's probably unfair to say until I see it 10 more times like GoodFellas. But I can't stop thinking about how awesome this movie is. I'll be sorely disappointed in the Academy if this doesn't win Best Pic. It's unquestionably deserving.

title: Movie of the decade
review: Starts with a furious pace. Slows to a much needed dreary middle containing some of the best acting ever put on a screen. Finished with a fury that will get to everyone. Scenes that rival "The Godfather." One scene in a bar between Leo and Jack that will be talked about and used in the classroom. A great role for Mark Wahlberg. Damon was perfect for his character. This movie is one of the greatest of all time. You almost HAVE to watch it a second time to truly gather in it's special moments. Do not make the mistake of missing out on this one. Go see it on the big screen. Martin will be robbed if he does not receive multi awards for this masterful movie.

title: Infernally disappointing
review:
A lot of good reviews and positive comments have been made about this movie. Unfortunately I don't think the movie lives up to most of them. Its difficult for me to review this movie without referring to the Hong Kong Super original which is a classic in its own right, Infernal Affairs. The Departed literally takes the exact same storyline and swaps the Chinese Triads with the Irish Boston underworld. The story revolves around to central characters Sullivan (played by the wooden Damon) & Costigan (the awesome Di Caprio) both are having there strings pulled, one by the gangster boss Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson) and the other by the Police Departments undercover chief Quinnin (Martin Sheen). Both characters are effectively "rats" for the bad guys and good guys. The interesting part of the story is when the line between good & bad starts to become blurred and each undercover doesn't know where they stand. This part of the storyline was done with great impact and good characterisation in the Chinese original. As often happens with remakes, re-works or re imaginations upon an original, The Departed doesn't do this too well. In fact it tries to hard to adapt the storyline to suit the American audiences. By throwing in a love interest for both central characters to chase and also have characters like Mark Whalberg's comic police officer (although he does this really well). Its quite funny Scorsese is one of the greatest directors of all time and for him to take an existing storyline and take the good bits and copy them and leave out the excellent bits and replace them with mushy justifiable movie going fare is just a bit of a cop out. Don't get me wrong, for those of you who have never seen or heard of the original or never even knew The departed was even a remake they will probably love this film. But for those of us fortunate enough to have seen the great Infernal Affairs will think what have they done to my classic Hong Kong Thriller. Scorsese films usually have memorable scenes, but I can only think of a few, memorable lines are even more sparse. Where as his classic "Goodfellas" begins with a truly memorable line "As far back as I can remember, I've always wanted to be a gangster". One trait Scorsese keeps from goodfellas, Casino, Gangs of New York is the use of a great soundtrack and The Departed doesn't disappoint with the Boston Irish Bagpipes used to aplomb. It maybe a bit "heavy Metal" but it works well with the theme. The huge collection of quality actors from Jack Nicholson, Ray Winstone, Mark Whalberg, Martin Sheen, Alec Baldwin all do well but none are a patch on Leonardo and they are all let down by the po faced Matt Damon and his unemotional turn as Sullivan, though it could be argued his character has been so drained of emotion his own life it just adds to the performance. Compared to most of the trash out in the cinemas right now namely "Borat", I'd give the Departed some time if you want to go to the cinema, but to wait for it on DVD isn't a bad thing either. Never thought I'd say that about a Scorsese film but its true.

If you want to see a great performance with a good but not great storyline and have no expectations in comparison to the original then you'll enjoy, what more can I say !

title: The type of movie they don't make anymore (Spoilers)
review:
All I have to say is, I left the theater in awe. This is a movie that will be talked about for years to come. Ranking and maybe even surpassing Scorsese's "Goodfellas", "The Departed" has so much going for it.

Number one, is Jack Nicholson as Frank Costello. Is there a better actor than Nicholson working now? After you see this movie, if you weren't convinced that Nicholson is the master, maybe you need to quit watching movies. The man is pure evil, and is absolutely menacing. Every scene Nicholson is in magnetic. Scoreses' use of casual violence is always shocking, and this is no exception. Life ends suddenly and violently in the world of "The Departed"

The rest of the cast is superb. Matt Damon plays a thoroughly corrupt State police investigator who is in mobster Costello's pocket, feeding him information from his position as a mob detective.

The other main character is played by Leonardo Dicaprio in the role of his career. Playing Billy Costigan, a neighborhood kid who is plucked from the State police academy to infiltrate Costello's crew. Playing the role of a man on the edge, and in constant fear of his life if he is discovered, Dicaprio nails it. There are many twists and turns in this great movie, and I don't want to give away too much, but this movie is one for the ages!

title: Its an American remake of a Chinese movie...
review:
The departed is a remake of a Chinese movie called "Mou gaan dou" or "Infernal Affairs" for its American title. I give the original 8 stars, and highly recommend seeing it. I have yet to see "The Departed", but plan on checking it out to see if it is as good as the original Chinese version.

Basically the mafia and the police both send a mole into the others organization to try and thwart the others plans. One to try to help catch the mafia lord.. the other to keep the police from catching his boss. Neither knows who the other is, but eventually begin trying to find out one anothers identities.

title: Plagerism
review: This movie is fantastic, and one of Scorsese's best until the end. I won't go into specifics. I don't want to spoil the movie, but I have to point out the one scene in the movie that was lifted out of the movie, "The Third Man". Remember when Holly Martins (Joseph Cotton) gets out of the jeep and waits for Anna (Alida Valli), and she walks right past him without acknowledging his presence. It was the greatest brush off scene in movie history, and was beautiful to watch. Well, Scorsese puts this exact scene into this movie, and without giving anyone credit. Shamefull. Also, I can think of several endings that would have been more intelligent than the one they came up with.

title: Mesmerizing action flick
review: As a native Bostonian, I was amazed at the authenticity of the locale, the interplay of believable characters, and the fast paced dialogue and action. Your mind doesn't wander to the popcorn concession during this brilliantly directed Scorsese film. Wm Monahan's writing coupled with his ability to deliver a genuine Boston beat to the film reflects his Beantown roots. De Caprio is totally credible in the hard-ass undercover role yet easily betrays a vulnerable sensitivity to his therapist. A Sean Penn Oscar should be his though comparisons to Mystic River may dim his just award! Damon is truly outstanding in a role as a tough FBI agent whose connection to South Boston overpowers his potential decency. Of course, Nicholson is, well, Nicholson, the consummate actor who owns every role and scares the bejeezus out of everyone, including some in the theater. I loved it! I'd see it again.

title: I was never a Leo fan but...
review: ...I came away from The Departed with the firm conviction that he should win the Academy award. His Character Costigan is so memorable, poignant, tough, smart and tragic. By all means, all the acting is great. Kudos to Wahlberg, Sheen and Damon. Jack Nicholson is over the top but so what. The film is full of tension yet it's not the kind that makes you nervous but rather it's the type that is thrilling and exciting. There are not many films made today that I can sit through twice but I'd sit through this one again and again just to watch Leo deCaprio act. I'm looking forward to his Blood Money film for the same reason.

title: Absolutely amazing
review:
I am reluctant to give any movie a 10, but this one deserves it. Not only is it well-acted, the plot (though a tad difficult to follow for those unfamiliar with Scorcese) is exceptionally engaging. You do have to suspend your disbelief when it comes to Nicholson's on-again, off-again Bostonian accent, but who cares? I thought Titanic had tanked DiCaprio's career, but this film shows his true talent as an adult actor. The same can be said for Wahlberg, who proved himself years ago with Fear and Boogie Nights and continues to be a true pleasure to watch. Matt Damon, Martin Sheen and Alec Baldwin give performances unlike any I've ever seen from them, and I've seen 'em all! If you can't see this movie in the theater, rent it as soon as it's available.

If I were able to ask Scorcese one question, it would be, "What's with your attachment to the Rolling Stones, huh?"

title: Scorcese creates a whole new classic
review:
The Departed will hands down become an instant classic further positioning director Martin Scorcese in the cinema hall of fame. This is Scorcese's biggest public hit now grossing over 100 million dollars. The cast is brilliant, an ensemble the likes we have yet to see this year. The story is gritty, violent and captivating. Despite a bit of a dragging tempo it only leaves you open to be more blind sided by the shocking twists when they do happen. The climax and the end of the film will literally move you to the edge of your seat as it all boils over. It's a thriller, crime drama, mob story and delivers everything it promises and best of all it seems to be simultaneously a critical and viewer smash success and I predict certain Oscar wins as locked in the bag perhaps even a nomination for long overdue Leonardo DiCaprio. I won't say it's one of my favorite films of the year, in fact I toyed between 8 and 9 but the film has to be given respect and points for it's cast, gritty direction and style while I still sit on top of the opinion that it flows a little slowly and almost predictable at times.

Leonardo DiCaprio sincerely knocks one out of the park as young, if not slightly naive rookie cop Billy Costigan. Despite this huge incredible ensemble cast DiCaprio stands out as really doing an amazing job. Forced undercover in this brutal Boston mob war he struggles on the line between good and evil but holds his moral ground when all is said and done. If DiCaprio doesn't get an Oscar Nod for this portrayal there is something wrong!! Matt Damon plays DiCaprio's counterpart in more ways than one playing slick and dirty cop Colin Sullivan. Whereas DiCaprio is undercover on the mob side, Damon is undercover in the police precinct for the mob. Damon's character is almost the mirror image opposite of everything DiCaprio's character is as they play this cat and mouse game with each other without ever really coming into contact until the final scenes. It's brilliant and wonderfully played out. I found Damon a little much, almost over acting, but still his character was a sleazy bad guy that you definitely detest. And then there is Jack. Honestly...what can you say about Jack Nicholson. The guy is an icon, he's a master, a genius and rumor has it that Scorcese even gave Jack full authority over his lines in the film telling him to go with it...I mean he's Jack!! He plays the head of this crime family Frank Costello and although he is portrayed as the incarnation of evil he doesn't really come across as overtly brutal but a leader nonetheless. He ups the ante to this story by leaps and bounds and DiCaprio and him are brilliant together. Mark Wahlberg plays a smaller supporting role as Detective Dignam, in charge of DiCaprio's undercover work. His role is a brutal, mouthy, loud man who just really wants to get the job done and make sure the undercover work is not being screwed. All in all Wahlberg gets everything he wants but his role is unfortunately small. I think he has really done some terrific work as of lately and this is a great performance by him. And finally the terrific Martin Sheen in an unfortunately small supporting role as Oliver Queenan, the aging detective who convinces DiCaprio to go undercover. Sheen is terrific on screen and could easily hold a leading role even in his aging days but he gets a supporting role that is decent.

If nothing else The Departed has plenty of surprises in store for you. It's not like it has a twist to it...the story is almost predictable but nonetheless you will find yourself shocked by some of the outcomes the scenes involved. Just when you think you're in for a heavy handed drama the guns come out blazing so to speak. If nothing else this could the crime drama of the year considering the slightly disappointing Black Dahlia and Hollywoodland. The Departed is a throwback to the great films of the eighties with hundreds of foul words used, brutally bloody violence, and an almost film noire feel to it. Scorcese has this picture locked up because fans of his say this might be his greatest to date and I say it's absolutely worth seeing for the cast and for the story alone!!! 8.5/10

title: Scorcese is back to his compelling best
review:
There happens to be one director in the modern times who can extract the best performances out of actors who were previously only considered for their star quality. Scorcese gets the best out of Alec Baldwin, Matt Damon,Mark Wahlberg and we all have to ask why has it taken so long for Jack Nicholson to come under the master's direction.

The complexity of the story and the riveting and unpredictable second half leave you feeling it was worth the effort and price of admission to go and see this movie.Even Martin Sheen excels in his minor but most important role and that is what makes Martin Scorcese the most formidable director of our time; the bit parts are sometimes the glue that holds all the major players and script together. THIS IS THE MUST SEE MOVIE OF 2006!!!!!

title: Nicholson, DiCaprio, Scorcese remake a Hong Kong film
review:
The Departed is a remake of a Hong Kong film "Internal Affairs." Having not seen that film I can't compare the two movies.

Leonardo DiCaprio plays a mole who is tight with mobster Jack Nicholson while Matt Damon plays a mole in a police force unit headed by Martin Sheen and Alec Baldwin with Mark Wahlberg as a cop. Vera Farmiga plays a love interest.

The plot is essentially a cat and mouse game between Nicholson and the police as they try to bust him.

The acting is first rate, as you'd expect, with Nicholson perfectly cast as a crazy-eyed genuine nutcase, creepy to the max, always dangerous, and very vicious. Vintage nutso Nicholson as we've seen him before in many films.

There isn't much character development in the film with little background information given about Nicholson, DiCaprio or Damon and this hurts the film turning it into basically a cat and mouse plot. There are plenty of graphic shootings and spattering blood and, since the characters are people we care something about at least, the violence hurts, unlike the cartoonish violence of a horror film.

This is not a great movie by any means or even one of Scorcese's best and it certainly does not compare to Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather." With the exception of one scene where Damon and DiCaprio follow each other, Scorcese's direction is not very exceptional or remarkable.

I would recommend this film but it is brutally violent so beware.

title: the departed, the copied.
review: I am sure that most audiences who have seen Hong Kong "infernal affairs" would not feel satisfactory with this new US version. "The Departed" copied most of the HK "Infernal Affairs": the same story, except for the ending. However, the actors' lines are full of dirty words, which is a complete difference to that of "Infernal Affairs" with deep content. In addition, "the Departed" is ending rapidly. Several roles were shot in no more than five minutes, without any close-ups or slow motions, making me feel the director ends the story too roughly.Furthermore, the music in "the Departed" is not attractive at all. On the contrary, the music and songs in "Infernal Affairs" have then won a lot of reputation and rewards and population and still i can recall the astonishing scenes when I once heard of the music. what i feel after i saw this movie is that i strongly believe that "infernal affairs" is a HongKong Classic that no other copies or versions can compare, no matter how much the script is adapted or how bigger or famous the cast is.

title: Big Rip off!!!! check this out!!!
review:
Hi all,

Although I agree with the people who liked this movie, i cannot stand the talking about what an original and cool movie Scorsese has made. It is cool, but should Scorsese's masterpiece (Like the big comment above) not at least be an original?? I saw this movie just 1 day after the following movie. A hongkong Andre Lau production....An I was even a bit angry about all the good comments The Departed gets now. Don't get me wrong, I really like the 'Ámerican'version, but prefer this one!

Please take the time and check this movie out:

Infernal Affairs (2002!!!)

and tell me what u think ;)

greetz Helsen

title: Good, but by no means brilliant
review:
What's happened to the Scorsese of old? Is this the same director of Taxi Driver, Raging Bull and Bringing Out The Dead? With his last two films being fairly mediocre, I didn't go into this film with high expectations. Being based on a Hong Kong shoot-'em-up, there were no illusions that this would be high art. Still, the film just didn't work for me.

The relationships depicted were not convincing and virtually all the female roles women were simply obligatory window dressing. Vera Farmiga's role was weak, and there seemed to be little chemistry between her and Matt Damon's character.

There was a tangible sense of tension, particularly for DiCaprio's character, and he played his part well. Mark Wahlberg is an actor that always seems to shine, and doesn't seem to get much screen time. Mostly the performances were good, but there were too many flat spots that broke the tension, and the film would have benefited from being cut to two hours. However, the film did move at a fast pace, and this helped to mask some of the many implausibilities. I found neither the violence nor language offensive, and quite appropriate for the genre.

Scorsese is renowned for his technical excellence. There seemed to be none of the stylish use of camera work and long takes of his better films. With this and his previous two films, it seems to me that Scorsese is struggling to find his earlier creative core. There are some great crime films done previously (some by Scorsese himself). The best for me was Takeshi Kitano's Hana Bi, which has a lot in common with Scorsese's earlier work.

Perhaps the director is suffocating under the expectations based on his previous great works. Perhaps he is caught up in a sense of self-importance. Maybe he would achieve a better outcome if he didn't depend so much on big name actors and big budgets and got back to his roots. The film is not bad, but it's not that good either. It's my least favourite of Scorsese's.

title: excessive violence
review:
I enjoyed Nicholson's acting, he plays the megalomaniac criminal boss so very well. There was too much blood and violence, especially at the end. After the first two head shots, I just got numb. Maybe this appeals to some , who like to see violence for its own sake. Whatever point was to be made by the blood and violence could have been made fully with a lot less.

Would a psychiatrist get involved so easily with one of her patients? I suppose it happens , but I just didn't buy this romance.

The conflicts felt by Billy and Colin were believable and interesting. The acting here was convincing.

It seemed that Costello trusted Billy, a former police cadet, too soon, but maybe I didn't notice the implied passage of time.

title: I've seen this before
review: I saw this movie two years ago when I rented it from Blockbuster. Only it wasn't called "The Departed," it was called "Infernal Affairs." you can look it up here: http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0338564/ - Infernal Affairs was produced in Hong Kong in 2002, and is much more riveting, I think. Change the Triads to the Irish mob, and Hong Kong PD to the Mass. SPD and you have The Departed, literally they are the same movie, right down to the elevator scene at the end. To be fair, the work is not stolen, the same people wrote both scripts, but in my opinion, the original is the best. So, go out and rent Infernal Affairs, and save yourself some money.

title: No,No,No,No,No,No,No.....did I miss the meeting on this one?
review:
No,No,No,No,No,No,No,....did I miss the meeting on this one?. Did everybody get together behind my back and decide this was a great film.....before they had actually watched it?.

Lets just take a look at it.Scorsese doing a remake of an excellent Infernal Affairs.A Remake!Scorsese doing a remake!What was up with the original?Is his ego so inflated that he actually thought he could improve on the original?

Jack Nicholson being just a few lines from bursting into the Joker , "wait till they get a load of me!". Leonardo playing a shy,misunderstood loner that every girl just wants to be with...exactly like he was in Gangs of New York only its Farmiga now in place of Diaz.Matt Damon playing a different character than he is used to...not!He plays the only character he can....straight laced,clean shaved,cold and ruthless underneath with his sideways toothy smile.Mark Wahlberg plays.....well just think of his last few performances and you have it.The only thing Alec'Glengarry Glenross'Baldwin is missing is his brass balls from from that film.Someone should have woken Martin Sheen out of his coma for his scenes and Ray Winstone is.......well ...Ray Winstone. Scorsese definitely dropped the ball on this one and at best it is a decent cop movie with some good scenes and OK soundtrack,5 out of 10>

title: A Scorsese triumph
review:
An intriguing plot that twists and turns and has you on the edge of your seat at times; an all-star cast (mainly male though); some truly excellent special effects and, as you might expect from director Martin Scorsese, a wonderful sound track.

These are the ingredients that combine to make this a truly memorable picture. The central plot deals with a corrupt Boston police force and a mobster, played by Jack Nicholson at his demonic best. The police have an undercover operative in the mobster's gang, and he in turn has a snitch with the cops. The best scenes of the film occur with these two, portrayed by Matt Damon and Leo DiCaprio, trying to discover the identity of the other, while the audience tries to work out which of the two is the real villain.

There is also a common love interest (which reminded me somewhat of LA Confidential) and plenty of gory action. The supporting cast is great, and includes William Baldwin, Ray Winstone (does he ever turn in a below-par performance - I think not!), Martin Sheen and Mark Wahlberg who has the best role of his career as a menacing police detective.

The movie runs for about 150 minutes, and yet it easily maintains interest and suspense for its whole length. Although superficially a cop flick, the principal three characters provide plenty of depth and complexity, and like a good wine, this movie can be savoured to the last drop.

title: One weak point
review: His best since Goodfellas. DiCaprio has finally come of age and fulfilled the promise of Gilbert Grape. Nicholson is outstanding and Wahlberg is priceless. Even Matt Damon pulls off a cracking performance. It's long but perfectly paced and never loses momentum. This is the best Irish film I've seen since The Wind That Shakes The Barley. (Although the Wind gets it for best film this year.) There's very little wrong with it. OK it's not completely flawless, the scene where Nicholson walks back into the bar (Who let this IRA motherf*cker in?) and then says "slainte" is the only weak point. It's pronounced "Sil-on-cha" you White Lace Motherf*cker!

title: Not terrible, but massively over-hyped
review:
For some reason, this movie seems to be getting praised left, right and center by both the critics and regular folks. I can't really see why, other than the fact that it's a Scorcese flick. But honestly, it's just not that great, and doesn't even compare to such previous Scorcese gems as Taxi Driver and Goodfellas.

There were things about it that I liked, such as the soundtrack, which was heavy on classic rock (with "Gimme Shelter" being used twice!); the hot therapist, who I could have ogled for a long time; and DiCaprio's performance, which was the latest in a string of great performances. But overall the movie seemed like a convoluted, confusing mess, which failed to engage me much beyond wondering when it'd be over.

I found the plot to be rather confusing, or at least, it took far too long for things to get going. I kept thinking to myself, "when is something going to happen?", and "am I missing something?". But in reality there just wasn't that much going on for large chunks of the film. In essence, it was just way too long.

Also, I thought that this movie couldn't really decide what it wanted to be. There certainly were a lot of comedic moments for a dramatic film, although I'm not sure how many of them were intentional. Either way, the audience was laughing out loud during many scenes. And if this was supposed to be a suspenseful film it failed miserably. By the two-hour mark I didn't care what was happening anymore, I just wanted it to end so I could go home.

Other than DiCaprio's performance, the other characters were fairly one-dimensional, with Jack Nicholson turning in a particularly uninspired performance. It must have been a nice payday though.

One of my friends liked this movie so much that he went and saw it twice, but there's no way I could sit through this convoluted mess again.

To sum up, it's not a terrible movie, but it is massively over-hyped. And you can forget about that elusive Oscar, it ain't gonna happen with this puppy.

title: Bit of a chore to watch
review: Not a standard storyline. Went because of big names, but it was too long. A lot of the bad language seemed to be there just to impress. Could have got rid of at least half of it, and the impact would have been the same. The scriptwriter does not appear to have a very good grasp of the English language. "For dramatic effect insert as many F's and C's in the script as you can" does not really cut it for me. Maybe he is more suited to an action/explosion film. At least Leo is starting to look like an adult, and can now pull off these parts. Also the continuity of sound levels was bad where I watched it. Highlight was definitely Vera. Stunning!! Can't believe I missed her in movies before. Big screen movie? No. Wait for the DVD.

title: weird
review: i thought this movie was really good the plot that two guys are in the same force but in different side and there both consider as rat and hero at the same time is pretty cool. but when they started killing everyone in 5 minutes ur like wait wait what just happen? i know i was like that i was wondering wait you had us going for about a hour and 45 minutes and then u kill everyone after in the 15 minutes left of the show that was pretty weird. but dame i wanted him to know that it wasn't his kid (people will only get this if they see the movie). another prombelm i had was they said f### EVERY SECOND. another prombelm is that they had to pick all the people that look identical in the movie so u don't know who is who. and every character wasn't just a good guy it was bad but sometime good then bad that was confusing. but i really think everyone acted really well and the plot was good so it was a good movie. i say watch it and see what u think.

title: Spoiler alert!
review: The script and direction of this film are impeccable right up to the last ten minutes, when it falls apart and turns into a cartoon! The story works fine, through the Third-Man finale at the cemetery( Protagonist leaves graveside, walks out toward main entrance to cemetery, stops, leans up against the cemetery gateway; love interest (Madolyn, played by Vera Farmiga) walks from same graveside out toward main entrance, passes him, pays no attention to him, in spite of the fact that she's PG with his baby.), Then, suddenly, it becomes a Spy-Vs.-Spy cartoon, with A shooting B, then C shoots A, D shoots C, etc. What is this? After a great script, suddenly we run out of ideas? What was in the envelope?!

title: A departure from reality
review:
''The Departed'' has been hailed as an emphatic return to form for uberdirector Martin Scorsese, and while it does contain moments of customary vividness and verve ( the music score alone is worth the cost of admission), ultimately, when set against its closest predecessor,"Goodfellas", it fails to convince as an authentic tale of gritty gangsterism, which is a shame as the film manages to evoke a credible sense of how easily the lines between good and evil become blurred.

The convoluted plot revolves around two rookie cops from the same underbelly of Boston. One of the new recruits, Billy Costigan (poignantly played by Leonardo DiCaprio), beset by rumours questioning his loyalty to the force, is coaxed and coerced by his superiors (Martin Sheen and Mark Wahlberg reviving the old good cop/bad cop routine to maximum dramatic effect) into infiltrating an Irish-American mob empire run by the slippery and elusive Frank Costello (a memorably malevolent, albeit hammy turn by Jack Nichoson; an X-rated combination of Jack Napier and the Joker - but one that, regrettably, for his character is purportedly based on a real life Boston crime lord, thrills rather than chills).
