The other new recruit, Colin Sullivan ( played with detached ruthlessness by Matt Damon), groomed from an early age by Frank Costello, rapidly gains promotion to a prominent position in the Special Investigations Unit hell-bent on bringing his shadowy mentor to justice; and to further complicate matters, his boss ( a bellicose yet comical Alec Baldwin), painfully aware that his own team has been infiltrated by a Costello mole, charges Sullivan - irony of ironies - with sole responsibility for flushing out the guilty party - himself!

This elaborate set-up - never, for one moment, does it feel real or ring true - certainly grips the attention, dragging the viewer headlong on a rollicking roller-coaster ride of a movie; but it does have an unmistakably ersatz quality to it: yes, the performances, with the possible exception of Nicholson's ill-judged grandstanding (don't rule out another Oscar nomination!) are uniformly strong and moving; yes, the screenplay, though it does suddenly, and violently, lurch from earnest realism to campy grand guignol, is riveting; and yes, Scorsese's kinetic direction, coming after his turgid Howard Hughes bio, is a sight to behold; nevertheless - and this has nothing to do with the fact the film is roughly based on a popular Hong Kong actioner/thriller - ''The Departed'' never manages to convince as anything other than an amalgamation of other, more illustrious gangster flicks. And none of them had such a weak ending.

After every new Martin Scorsese release, a single, hopeful/doleful question is asked: is this the one that breaks his Oscar duck? Well, as anyone with even the tiniest knowledge of the arcane Academy Awards voting system will tell you, the best nominees don't necessarily get to waltz down the star-studded aisle to the podium, gush sentimental thank-yous to all and sundry, and finally bag the gold statuette. Devoted Martin Scorsese fans - and I, for one, count myself amongst their legion - must pray that this perplexing pattern continues.

title: not bad but no so great
review: I m watching amazed how this movie has become so quick and so easy a masterpiece for hundreds of people.I love Scorsese s films for more than 25 years and, excuse me boys, but this is far from Ranging Bull, Taxi Driver or even Goodfellas.The directing is still brave, but the core of the film is less brilliant than in his old movies unless it is more "spectacular" and more enjoyable for the big audiences.Dicaprio plays at the top of his level, this mean GREAT, so Walhberg too.But unfortunately Damon does not reach that high an uncle Jack is overacted and his scenes only makes the film longer an gorier, not better.There is a fine piece of editing in this movie and the cinematography works really fine but there is a big trouble over there....a script that is plenty of holes and more worried of being thrilling than to go deep into the character and his lives.The best scenes are literally copied from Infernal Affairs and the new ones are meaningless.They told us a story 45 minutes longer than the original but without any real new content.That s a common problem nowadays, sometimes the economy of style is a forgotten virtue and Marty is every time more convinced that he needs to do films of more of two hours to convince us about how many things he has to tell.Good but no great.7 out of 10

title: Not what might have been
review:
This isn't a bad movie, but it's average and should've been much better.

Additions and deviations and from the original story are misjudged and not needed. At times this doesn't feel like a Scorcese picture at all, and even feels like a parody at times. Di Caprio plays well, but Damon is as wooden as ever and Wahlberg is simply a waste of space.

These things said, it plays quickly and the two and a half hours flew by and Nicholson is as entertaining as ever. We should be grateful for every good performance we get.

See the original, then enjoy it's sequel.

title: Enough about the "original" already!
review:
Well, my difficulties with this flick seem to veer off a bit from other reviewers on the site, so I'll just put in my 2 cents and leave 'em on the table: 1. Is it absolutely mandatory to have seen "the original" screening of the Hong Kong adaptation of this story? Filmland is full of different interpretations of the same source material, and I think one has to keep an open mind when viewing the latest. Many people dismissed the most recent reincarnation of "Vanity Fair" due to earlier interpretations of the story. As for myself, I found the 'Bollywood' additions creative and appropriate.

2. That said, I would have rather seen another director's reinvention of the tale, much as I'm often wowed by Scorcese. I keep thinking about Clint Eastwood's masterful production of the similarly-themed "Mystic River," and wonder if the story itself may have been more concisely told and still have retained the somewhat Shakespearean element referenced in this film.

3. There were some bothersome plot holes in this film that I kept waiting for some explanation for. Why did Costigan receive "therapy" from the police psychiatrist in the first place if only Queenan and Dignam were aware of his true identity as a cop? Where was there any evidence that there was another "rat" besides Sullivan in the department until the bloody end? How did Sullivan explain the bloodbath in the elevator exactly? Was the female shrink's baby fathered by Costigan or Sullivan? The subplot concerning Costello's role as an FBI "rat" may have been easier to swallow if there had been even one example of this particular treachery somewhere in the film. Oh, I could go on...

4. Many people didn't like the ending, perhaps based on the "original." I had mixed feelings, because I smelled it coming. Dignam disappears for an inordinately long stretch at the end of the film (and his exit was a mite unbelievable, as some have mentioned.) So I'm sitting there for 20 minutes or so thinking that Dignam will return to finish off Sullivan. No surprise there, and just one last body on the mounting pyre. Classic Scorcese blood fest. Liked it better in the underrated "Gangs of New York." Alright, So I've poked a few holes in this otherwise riveting gangster-cop saga. Overall, I agree with the comments applauding the cast, but I actually was relieved that Nicholson wasn't as "over-the top" as I feared he might be: just about right for the flamboyant character he played. And add me to the list of people who weren't big DiCaprio fans until this film. He should keep working with Scorcese, who seems to be guiding him well lately. I loved seeing fresh-scrubbed Matt Damon as another wolf in sheep's clothing (e.g., "The Talented Mr. Ripley"), too.

I'll keep watching Scorcese films, bloody and tragic as they are. But I still keep thinking he has at least one more coming on the level of "Taxi Driver." May it arrive soon!

title: The Departed
review:
One word. HUH? I have never been so shocked after walking out of a movie in my life. The different sequence of camera shots and character display confuses the audience right in the beginning of this movie. Then the slow paced confusing beginning just got more boring. I was about to walk out before the action started - which I may add took forever. This 2 and a half hour movie could of been shortened by an hour or so.

The police who were trying to locate and arrest the mob boss Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson) found that they have a mole in their precinct who is tipping off Costello leaving him a few steps ahead of the police. To Costello's surprise, he too finds out he has a federal undercover agent in his mob. With plenty of questions and scenes which leave you at the tip of the seat, I would say the ending made the film! Even though the ending of this movie was outstanding, the beginning really did lower my expectations for this highly rated film. I would give this movie an 7.5/10.

title: above average crime thriller let down by weak ending
review:
I saw this film a couple of nights ago and wanted to review it straight away. It was only then I realised it was a remake so I held off till I could see the original.

To start with, the acting is excellent. DiCaprio ,perceived early in his career as the teen-girl favourite, now has genuine presence and character. I started appreciating Matt Damon since his incredible performances as Jason Bourne, where he plays an action hero with genuine emotions. They were on par with the original leads; Nicholson was better than IA's Sam and the shrink made a much better contribution that the shrink and girlfriend together in the original.

Mark Wahlberg was entertaining as Sheen's sidekick but devalued from him and ruined the symmetry. There are two bosses and two protégées. Each of the protégées appears to be working for one but is actually with the other. This is much cleaner in the original. In the departed sheen is the join operator of DiCaprio and is the superior but not the boss of Damon.

The length of the remake allowed for better character development and better explanation of events. There was more time to develop the relationships between the leads and the shrink. The critical scenes were less rushed.

I was disappointed by the ending of the remake, in a meaningless blood splat. In the original, the bad mole gradually feels tormented by his actions, especially after sheen's death. He kills Sam in order to start a new life. I believe he would have let the good mole live and brought him back to the police force if it wasn't for the fact that DiCaprio saw the envelope. in the original, Damon is saved by the second mole. Damon terminates him so that he can continue his new life and salutes his counterpart at the funeral. In the remake, Damon is just pure bad and is cleaned up at the end by wahlberg, who reenters the film as abruptly as he left it after sheen's death.

In both films, the death of all (or almost all) the central characters prevents the realisation by the bosses of who the moles were.

There were also a couple of clues prior to the envelope about the identity of the moles. After their telephone call, Damon knew the moles voice and could have worked out who he was ( he certainly didn't sound like frenchy or ray winstone). there was a scene where Nicholson demands the tail car be pulled off and it happens straight away; at that point it is obvious that if you find the cop who gave that order you find the mole.

title: Not Original!!
review: Did the whole web page forget to state that the only reason this film is so good is that it's based on the hit Hong Kong film that later expanded into a trilogy? That is, in many people's opinion, still the best of the two? This film borrows way too many scenes and ideas from the original movie to attempt to be original in itself. Granted, the acting is excellent, but so were Andy Lau, Tony Leung and Anthony Wong from the original, against which I would say everyone but Leo DiCaprio just pales against. Also, the mirrored scenes lack the same punch as the original precisely because this is a Scorsese film. Characters die without the same punch to our guts; the same emotional shock that the original film's slow and music-heavy moments deliver, and that is it's greatest flaw as a character-driven film. I mean, the last scene * SPOILER * where three characters died consecutively * END OF SPOILER * drew more laughs from the audience than gasps! This, with the rushed ending that stinks of 'Aviator' lowered my opinion of Martin Scorsese, but my opinion on Leo just rose :D

title: I saw the original
review: Okay the Original movie the ending was better than this one. But is very good movie. If you saw the original. You will see some similar thing. But Acting was excellent. It also have the taste of the original and flavor of Boston. i did like the end because trying to fit the story very quick. the original leave it open. in this movies mix the first 2 movies in original into one. Tony Leung Chui Wai Vs Leornado DI Carpio. They Were very good at there version. Tony Give is character with more subtle way to want to get out. Leornado give is character little bit more expose emotion. Matt vs Andy i think they very good job in showing the character loving the new life.

title: It's an OK film
review:
I see that I am one of the few who didn't think this film was the best thing since sliced bread. Having seen the original I knew that the ending wasn't going to be a surprise but I was a little shocked by what I did see. Obviously some form of retribution was needed, why I don't know as it kinda ruined it for me.

Maybe I'm getting old but I found that there was just a bit too much swearing for me. I don't usually care about that sort of thing, but I found it just a bit too much and off putting. It made me think that the script writer was a 12 year old who thought that saying "f*ck" after every other word is "cool man!" The whole film left me wanting...wanting for what? Sympathy. What made the original so good was it's sadness and how you felt for the main characters. You did for Leo of course and at least they kept that. But Mat Damon character was a t*ss-pot, a homophopic numbskull and that ruined it for me. What about gritty realism I hear you say? Well yes this version is set in Boston as instead of Hong Kong so there are a lot of differences but I thought the point of the film was that both Leo and Mat wanted normal live. Mr Damons character seemed to enjoy his role a little too much.

Mark Walburg was great even with that really bad hair, I enjoyed his character to a point. Martin Sheen and Alec Baldwin were great too I really liked them. Jack Nicholson? Dare I say this aloud? I didn't like him at all, he was his usual type cast over sexed over dosed self and it was boring. He added nothing to the film and it concentrated too much on him too, he should have been a side character giving the orders. The though of him getting "c*nt" was just as sickening as hearing your parents do it at night. It's wrong and sick and we shouldn't have to put up with such nonsense! If it wasn't based on Infernal Affairs it would have been better. But it was and I think that it was rather bizarre that the script writer didn't watch the film just read the transcript....

Anyway my advise is make up your own mind, but do see the original it's charming and funny. But see this version too it's not bad if a little OTT at times.

title: Could of been a Classic!
review:
Started off OK, classic Scorsese, setting the story of how a young boy becomes involved in the underworld, the acting was great, except for the miss casting of Nicholson IMHO, and the pointless dildo in hand joke int he cinema. i found myself getting bored in the middle of the film, and in the end i didn't care which one of them would end up caught or dead, i just didn't get dragged into any of the characters. the symbolic ending with the dog turning away from Damon and then the Rat outside the window, was there any need for the symbolic rat, i mean they must of said Rat 252 times in the film already.

6/10 for me not in the same league as goodfellas or Raging bull

title: A clever movie
review:
Scorsese takes us into a violent travel into the crime and police environment. By making a remake from a series of three Hong-Kong gangster films, he staged some Irish characters in a violence that blast us out of our chair. We love them all. Any death become a sad event, and it doesn't happen only once.

Then, Scorsese edited it has a rapid series of events that flow into a back wall of songs (but it's used in a different way as Tarantino's Kill Bill, at last). The scenes are shorts and right to the point, always cutted to maximize the clever style of the film. We feel like the time is rapidly passing by, and the characters are developed by some quick details (like an Alec Balwin's dirty shirt).

So, this is a comic treatment of a tragedy, like the antics ones. And the actors are all in their best shape, I never liked DiCaprio, Damon or Walhberg before and then, suddenly, they play some Oscar roles.

Simply refreshing, entertaining, fascinating and clever!

title: you think you know
review: i think scorsese is a brilliant mastermind and i feel like he's done it again. i wasn't a huge fan of the aviator but he pulls leo's character through this movie like a rag doll. forcing him into a bad situation and making him run with it. jack's character costello was done beautifully. i really couldn't see him play an irish mafia man but he did and he played it so well. scorses goes for directions of his own drum so at no point can you figure out what's going to happen next which is what makes a great movie. even when you feel that's over, hold on to your seats because you're in for a treat. i will say this much, scorsese is the only directer that makes death look or seem beautiful. he did it in goodfellas and has done it again, with his choice of music and cinematography it's definitely a movie you don't want to miss.

title: Amazing
review: I thought this was by far the best movie of the year and the best film Leonardo Dicaprio has been in. His acting was amazing the way he showed his emotion with the character. Just sitting back and watching the emotion in his face and his eyes, he really gets into the character and the awful place he is living. I was a little confused by the ending, but felt the movie was amazing. I will be very surprised if Leo is not nominated for this movie. Martin Scorsese is known for making spectacular movies and this by far was one of his best! To get so many big actors on one movie and have it turn out this great is a huge accomplishment. I cannot say enough great things about this movie and the job that Leonardo Dicaprio did in this film....by far one of my favorite movies

title: Another guy flick
review:
I loved the story line and how close to getting caught the two 'rats' in the police and the mafia were. Everything was fast paced and complex. The thing that bothered me most is the mindless killings!! Honestly every main character was shot!! WTf?? And how many times was the f word used in there?? A lot. This movie over all is great, take away the mindless shooting and swearing and the movie is almost fantastic.

Leonardo DiCaprio did an excellent job portraying an inside cop with issues and pressure not to get caught. This is one of his better acting films. But of course he got shot, it was like watching Jack Dawson float to the bottom of the ocean again. Heartbreaking. But since everyone else dies, you barely notice he's gone.

Overall: exceptional, great story line, to much blood, swearing, too much violence.

title: Another Gem from Martin
review:
I have seen THE DEPARTED twice now(both opening weekend) and I have to say that it is without a doubt one of the best American movies to come out in the last decade. Everything from the ground up is top notch in this ultra violent crime thriller.The writing was superb, providing not just one cast member, but the whole cast a stream of clever and effective speech. The performances were nothing short of incredible. Leo and Damon act as the glue holding together this tangle of lies and deception, both providing plenty of raw emotion, and a noticeable realism to both of their characters. Jack as always rules any scene he appears in as the hilarious, yet psychopathic Frank Costello, and should be receiving without a doubt yet another well deserved Oscar nodd. The supporting cast of Wahlberg,Sheen,and Baldwin also provide authentic knock out performances that both enhance the films realism, and add to its' fun factor. The direction by good old Marty is BRILLIANT, as if we expected anything less. He somehow puts a creative spin on each and every shot, so the viewer is never left with a boring angle they've seen too many times before.The music used in the film is also pivotal as it strikes the right nerves in our bodies at just the right time(gimmie shelter,one way out,comfortably numb,plus an Irish jam from The drop kick Murphys). The plot is very intriguing as we follow two moles from both sides of the law set out to report on what they find. This film wonderfully pulls off what could have easily been too difficult of a plot to manage, and for that you can thank Marty. A lot has been said about the ending, and their seems to be varying reactions to it, however I felt it was very clever, and brought the plot full circle just in time for the credits. This movie will make you laugh, make you cringe, make you glad you are not undercover, and make you feel like you actually saw a film worth the price of admission.

Come Oscar season many predictions have been made. Having seen FLAGS OF OUR FATHERS already I can easily say that flags has no chance at the major Oscars. It was terrible. SUPPORTING:JACK good possibility LEAD ACTOR: LEO good possibility WRITING: MONOHAN most likely BEST DIRECTOR:MARTY I'd say so just so the Academy can get rid of him.EVEN THOUGH he more than deserves it. BEST PIC:THE DEPARTED We shall see, but some how the real best pictures never win. Advice from me? SEE IT. THEN see it again.

title: Excellent Remake with barely any flaws
review: Oh man, this is some serious good stuff. My parents did not want me to watch it since it was a remake and they are from Hong Kong.. duh..? So yea.. I went to watch it on my friends birthday and I found it quite good.. The setting was incredible.. which seems fit with all those bad words coming out of nowhere and all that. For a remake, I think it isn't bad at all compared to those other really bad remakes. Even so, I am born in America so I judge everything equally so don't go crazy on me. Even so, I find the hong kong version better because the actors seem to be more into it and showing more emotion. The storyline develops much better in the Chinese version so I suggest everyone to watch that with subtitles. Can't be that bad right?.. the Martin did buy the storyline to remake.. so you can't trash it xDD.. Anyway... the ending was a bit expected and all since when he bought the story, he didn't know there was a trilogy.. I didn't like how he died though... Also.. the lack of.. the use of moles were kind of a bit cruddy.. So a few text messages and stuff here and there.. I'm surprised he wasn't caught doing it.. oh well.. I am sure the Chinese figured it out much better..

title: Go see "State of Grace" instead...
review: Some understated performances from Damon and Nicholson do not make up for a non-existent script and a paper-thin plot that resembles all-too-much a dumbed-down "State of Grace". Aside from Damon doing a bang-up job of exuding the privileged arrogance and charisma of the "well connected" Boston cop, and Nicholson finally toning it down a bit, there just ain't much here. The dialogue is goofy and seems strung together only for aesthetics- so that Damon and the completely-unconvincing-as-tough-guy Marky Mark can rattle off their Bostonese at a machine-gun clip. But really, when you get down to it none of it makes any sense. Neither do the actions of the "love interest", Nicholson, or Walberg. At least, their motives are not at all fleshed out to the point where subtlety could make a meal out of these parts. But let's face facts- Scorcese is anything but subtle. However, for the Marty die-hards there is plenty of male posturing, violence, classic rock tunes, cursing, and minor plot twists (involving brutal violence, of course) to go around. To me though, the Maestro shoulda hung 'em up after Goodfellas....and The Departed is exhibit A.

title: The best movie that I have seen in years with brilliant story and top notch performances.
review: This is by far the best movie that I have seen in years. I was on the edge of my seat throughout the entire movie. Even my mother and grandmother loved this movie and agreed to overlook the excessive profanity. We all plan to see this movie again and again and can't stop talking about it. Every actor was in top form and deserves praise for bringing their characters to life. The plot was superb with an exciting and fascinating story line. Brilliant! I wish that the Oscar voters would finally give Martin and Leo their long overdue awards! Awesome job to everyone involved in this movie! Thank You for entertaining us with amazing talent and cinema!

title: One of the best movies of all time
review: This movie all around was just incredible. Incredible acting, incredible story, and just an incredible movie. I don't know if I can say it is as good as Goodfellas, which it is obviously going to be compared to, but it is probably one of the closest movies to it. It starts off right away with some great lines and great scenes, then after that it just gets genius. The contrasting roles between Leonardo DeCaprio and Matt Damon was one of the things that makes it so genius. How they are playing the same role working for opposite groups, each trying to find out who the other is. I suggest anyone to see this movie. Great plot, great acting, and great action, it just makes a great movie. The ending will have you on the edge of your seat also. One of the best movies of all time by far.

title: Must See
review: As indicated by my vote, this movie is excellent. It is one of those movies you hate to see end. Leonardo DiCaprio is tremendous in this film; as is Jack Nicholson, naturally. Matt Damon proves once again that he is one of the premiere actors of his generation. Mark Wahlberg also does an outstanding job in this film. If this movie has a flaw, it is the fact that Mark Wahlberg's character was under-utilized. The Departed is, beyond argument, the best film of the year. And a good argument can be made that it is the best film of the century. Albeit, this century is short in years, but this film is tough to beat. This movie ranks in my top 10 of all time. I urge everyone to go see this movie. I saw this film with my fiancÃ© and her mother and they both enjoyed the film as much as I. It is a film every adult can enjoy.

title: Everything you would want out of a movie
review:
Martin Scorese's new film "The Departed" is one of those rare Hollywood gems that defines all expectations in cinema today. There is humor, drama, action, violence, and character development.

I feel that this film can be broken down into three films as a matter of fact. You have, the original Chinese film "Infernal Affairs," Scorese's hints of "Goodfellas" inside, and an ending similar to Shakespeare's "Hamlet."

The original Chinese film lacks substance compared to Scorese's remake. This is one of those rare instances were the remake is better than the original. To name a few of my favorite remakes: John Carpenter's "The Thing", Gore Verbinski's "The Ring," and Don Siegel's "Invasion of the Body Snatchers." While in "Infernal Affairs" we are given abridged version of "The Departed." Another comparsion is like comparing Peter Jackson's remake of "King Kong" to the original. Although, in "The Departed" the extra minutes add to the film with character development and further plot points. "The Departed" is a spiced up version of "Infernal Affairs" to all means.

When comparing this film to "Goodfellas" you come up a little short handed. Although, you get an excellent performance from Jack Nicholson as Frank Costello. Nicholson's character belongs and could be from "Goodfellas." As an actor, It is easier to take Nicholson seriously now. I am comparing him to Robert De Niro, who has more share of silly movies added to his resume than Nicholson. Nicholson clearly sinks into that role of Frank Costello just as well as De Niro as Jimmy "The Gent." The two other characters, Decaprio and Damon fit into this film as if someone could replace them. Perhaps, Decaprio was better in his role than Damon, but I must say they played the parts well. They are not Joe Pesci or Liotta like in "Goodfellas"

I must say, is Decaprio taking DeNiro's place as Scorese's main man?

In the end, we overcome a huge shootout very reminiscent of "Hamlet." It becomes a tragedy in the final chapter, or does it? As a viewer of this film you sympathize with Decaprio's character immediately. Damon's character is viewed as a spy, and Wahlberg's character is viewed as an asshole. At the end of the film, we have our innocence lost after Decaprio's death, Damon venerating Decaprio, and Damon's death by Wahlberg. Is it fate for Damon to die? In "Infernal Affairs" Damon's character lives. There is no Mark Wahlberg character in "Infernal Affairs." I think Scorese gave his audience an ending without remorse. You don't feel angry about either of the main characters having known both of them are murdered.

So, we see an ending that is concluding and not depressing. Not many films can conqueror this. Well done Scorese 9 out of 10 stars.

-Review by Radley Silla

title: Greatest of the Year (if not more so)
review: "The Departed" is awesome. It is now my new favorite movie. Never have I seen so much good acting and great direction in one film that is not only cinema-graphically superior to anything else from 2006, but highly entertaining as well. The only two movies that even come close from this past year are "Inside Man" and "V for Vendetta." Unfortunately, Martin Scorsese has once again come up against Clint Eastwood. And not only that, but Eastwood is directing a "war at home"-style World War II movie that is guaranteed to win all the Academy's hearts. The point is that it's Scorsese's turn to win and he does deserve it. "The Departed" isn't a "Goodfellas Part Two" or a second "Casino" (thank God), it is a brilliantly thought out gangster tale that will keep you on the edge of your seat, when your not laughing at the dark, sarcastic lines. Great, great, great, great movie.

title: Best film this year
review:
Because this is a long movie it seemed the end was somewhat rushed. Some plot angles did not come together. For instance, what was in the envelope Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio), gives to Madolyn the police psychologist (Vera Farmiga)? Later he sends her a CD in the mail so that wasn't it. She put his name on the envelope before placing it in the desk drawer, leading you to believe her rat boyfriend Collin Sullivan (Matt Damon) would find it. That never happened. I think this is one place you're just left hanging due to the hurried nature of the movie's end. All in all though, this was time well spent at the movies.

The actors did an outstanding job of with the Boston accent. This can often separate a good actor from a great actor. Having stayed in Boston and worked in Maine, the New England accent is often mispronounced, to my ears, and can ruin a picture. I expect Matt Damon to get it right but was surprised with Walbergs' excellent portrayal in this area.

DiCaprio has out done himself on this one. It's easy to see why he sticks with Martin Scorsese.

title: The original movies are SOOOO much better
review:
As most people know, this is a remake of the excellent Hong Kong-movie, "Infernal affairs". No American remake of a movie from another country has so far been better than the original movie. You can compare with the fact that all the novels that has been filmed, the books are almost always better. Some things shouldn't be done.

When it comes to remakes, your opinion about it all depends on if you have seen the original movie or not. I must assume, because of the high score for "The Departed", that most of the voters on IMDb, have NOT seen the original.

The first "Infernal Affairs" was such success, that they made another one, "Infernal Affairs II"... Because of what happened in the first film, they had no choice than to go back in time and tell the background to what happened in the first one. And as the second one also was a hit, they followed up with a third one, now going back even further in time. After the third movie, they had told the complete story, there was no more to add. Some might say that you should see the third movie first, then the second, and finish with the first one. I don't think so. You can do whatever...

Anyway, the movie in question is "The Departed", NOT the originals, although it's impossible not to compare if you have seen them.

Jack Nicholson is one of the finest actors still alive. In this movie he uses every evil, mean, crazy face he can come up with. There is no good about him, he was probably born evil. The same person in the original movie is to begin with just an "errand boy" to mob leader. He's rather harmless, almost a friend to the police chief. He climbs up the ladder after the first mob leader gets shot. But he still isn't all bad, he's even to testify against the new mob leader, being on the right side of the law. But as things develop, especially after the second mob-leader being shot, he finds himself in some sort of dilemma. There is no natural "third" mob leader... He sees the opportunity to take over, to become the new boss of this crime syndicate. The temptation is too strong.

The original movies combines music/sound and picture VERY well, there is often no need for words, the pictures tells it a lot better.... There is too much talking in the remake, it's often also too slow... And as in most American movies, the violence has to be "more" than what has been done before... More close-ups of shooting, you must show a lot of blood... The more, the better? I don't think so... It's like "they" think that "they" must SHOW a bullet going through somebody's head, and later showing the same person laying in a pool of blood, otherwise the public will not understand what happened.

Martin Scorsese is NOT a bad director, making a remake of "Inferal Affairs" was a just a bad idea. See the original movies, no need for seeing "The Departed".

title: movie of the year
review: Scorsese has yet another masterpiece to add to his collection. I truly believe that it's his best since Goodfellas, maybe even Raging Bull. He resurrects Matt Damon's acting ability in this phenomenally cast movie. Jack Nicholson has one of the best performances of his career. The Departed really puts shame to other movies from the "gangster", "action" and "thriller" genres. Even the soundtrack is intense. Ranging from the Rolling Stones to the Dropkick Murphys to Nas, like the cast, it fits. The Departed is a movie that one can go see over and over again. It is full of symbols and illusions that if a viewer caught them the first time, I would be more than impressed. This movie is unreal. It is worth the $8.00 the theater charges, and even the $16.00 it would cost to see it twice. I guarantee that you will be blown away. I was left speechless. The glory days of cinema have returned...

title: Actors act; stars shine; Nicholson burns a hole in the screen.
review:
There are things wrong with 'The Departed' - mostly in the last ten minutes. Before that, however, there many fabulous performances, and there is Frank Costello: the most sleazy, loathsome scumbag of a crime-lord to hit the screen, possibly ever. Others have suggested that Nicholson is giving a mannered, unbelievable performance: maybe it is, but it is also a performance that leaves an indelible impression and which is given wings by a script that has his sewer-mouth gush endless cynical degrading filth until he is silenced with an expletive and a bloody fall into a digger's scoop. No doubt it may be accused of being written for shock value, but it isn't. The script embodies the values of someone who does what he does for the worst of reasons: he isn't even greedy, it's a life he chooses in perpetuity because he loves it. Nicholson's performance is a tour de force precisely because the physical embodiment of threat that we might expect is reduced to a portrayal of a very 'ordinary' old guy whose soul is so rotten that he corrupts everything he comes into contact with.

Martin Scorcese and his entire cast and crew have delivered a stunning visceral movie. It would be hard to imagine the film working as well without its very singular villain and it just proves that Nicholson is still 'the man'.

title: Best movie of 2006
review:
I was offered this weekend to go and see Children of Men featuring one of my favourite actors Clive Owen. Despite that i put my foot down and demanded we went to see the new Martin Scorsese film. I'm now so glad that I did, the film is sensational. With tremendous plot twists and hidden deception, The Departed is one of the most captivating films of recent History.

With such a star studded cast, including Nicholson, Di Caprio and Damon I was apprehensive about whether or not I was going to be blown away by the overall performance. As always Jack Nicholson lived up to his reputation as one of the best and delivered what i feel to be the best performance throughout the film, despite him being in a supporting role. Matt Damon tapped into all the acting talent he had and delivered the best performance of his career. However the biggest surprise for me came from Leonardo Di Caprio. Ever since first seeing him in Titanic when i was a boy I never really clicked with him as a viewer. However my respect and appreciation for his incredible acting ability was revived after this film. He delivers what I feel is the best leading role I have seen since Jonny Depp in the second Pirates of the Caribbean. His range of emotions and ability to manipulate my emotions as a viewer was simply breath taking.

The movie has a quite confusing narrative which is far from linear. However if you really get into it and don't twiddle your thumbs waiting for the credits you will find the film will grab you and you wont be able to loosen its grip until the final scene has ended.

An incredible piece of directing and editing that will be one of the best films you will see this year and quite probably for many years to come. A true master piece that will grab your attention from start to finish.

title: Wahlberg steals the show!!!
review: Martin Scorsese returns with The Departed an American version of the critically acclaimed Infernal Affairs. But Scorsese doesn't just return he brings with him an a list cast including Jack Nicholson, Leonardo Di Caprio and Matt Damon. All three burst onto the screen providing terrific performances but the standout display is provided by Mark Wahlberg. The Italian job star gives us a hilarious turn - ripping into both Di Caprio and Damon, but its all about the tension as far as the film is concerned. The guns kill and the blood spills - including a glorious showdown at the end, its without a doubt Scorsese's best work since Goodfellas - outstanding.

title: By far and away Scorsese's best movie since Goodfellas. A masterpiece. ******(out of five)
review: Based on the enjoyable, if flawed, Asian film Infernal Affairs Scorsese and screenwriter William Moynahan expand on that films neat premise and where that was a cops and robbers thriller here Scorsese has fashioned a gangster epic almost on a par with Goodfellas. Speaking of Goodfellas, this is easily Scorsese's best film since that 1990 masterpiece. Its as if Scorsese has rediscovered his youth with this film its sparky energy and style resembling Mean Streets. The acting as well as the directing and screen writing is outstanding. But what would you expect from a cast that includes: Jack Nicholson, Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen, Alec Baldwin and Ray Winstone. As for Oscars, personally I think it shows the idiocy of the awards that Scorsese who is undoubtedly one of the greatest directors of all time has never won an Oscar and the likes of Ron Howard has.So he probably won't win this year either. Nicholson may(deservedly) get nominated for best supporting actor but even though DiCaprio and Damon are awesome in this movie, they probably won't get nominated. But its Marty, Jack, Leo etc that will have the last laugh as I feel in twenty years time people will still be talking about this movie. Jack and Marty quite possibly the greatest actor and director of their eras have finally made a film together and they can add it to their already massive respective lists of masterpieces. ***** (out of five)

title: Jack Nicholson takes over.
review:
In The Departed, a legendary director came together with a legendary actor and the results will be, I'm sure, legendary. Legendary, I say, as a tribute to the gigantic excesses of possibly the greatest ego Hollywood has ever produced, Jack Nicholson.

Think about it, for a moment. The Departed features a stellar cast, including five of the best known actors working today: Nicholson, Dicaprio, Sheen, Wahlberg and Baldwin. Four of those five, including the hottest young actor in years, Dicaprio, subordinated their egos to the greater good of the project, headed by Marty, who has directed handfuls of the best known and most influential films of the last thirty years. One actor did not choose to subordinate his ego. One actor decided to turn The Departed into yet another tawdry and showy funeral monument for an acting career that died decades ago, dispelling the hopes for rebirth of his career that a few more nuanced recent performances have encouraged.

I read somewhere that Nicholson has boasted that he did no research for his character in The Departed. That's a funny thing to do, Jack, considering that The Departed is as wedded to the cultural specifics of its locale as any movie I've ever seen.

Many reviewers have complained that The Departed lacks the frenetic energy expected from a thriller, especially a thriller modeled on Infernal Affairs. I think they are missing the point, in that, while Marty blatantly teases us with thriller energy, backed up by the hard push of Boston irish punk, Marty's real point in The Departed seems to be that all the wild action of his cops and robbers ultimately sinks into a larger passivity, a miasmic sense that nothing positive can be accomplished, that no sacrifice and no outpouring of brutalism and violence can ultimately accomplish anything.

But if that point doesn't come across to viewers the way it should, the fault is ultimately Marty's. Marty, it was your job not to hire a one-man artistic trainwreck like Jack Nicholson, or to find a way to wring a great performance out of him if you did hire him. If you really believe that it takes a monster ego to play a monster ego, then please look back on Daniel Day Lewis' performance as Bill Butcher in Gangs of New York. The opposite is more likely to be true.

A train wreck performance needed a train wreck of a movie. The Departed has the former, by Nicholson, but isn't the latter.

I'm calling for a do-over. With more Boston irish punk, by the way!

title: Aewsome
review: Who knew Leonardo had it in him--he is excellent in this role as is the entire cast-... The ending takes you a little by surprise--but never a dull moment... This is one of the best written and directed films that I have seen in a long time--Jack is never disappointing and gives a commanding presence in this film---although none of the other actors are considered in his league (yet?)they definitely hold their own--perfect casting. Wish Mark Wahlberg had a little more screen time. Definitely a movie to go see and one to own to watch time after time. This is definitely a hit. I will be anxious to see if there is any Oscar buzz about this, it's creator and actors deserve it.

title: Fantastic Performances ............
review: Fantastic performances by all but Leonardo DiCaprio was a stand out Oscar worthy IMHO, the screenwriters also did an excellent job. Nothing more I can say except see it, just go and enjoy a fantastic movie with performances that will blow you away. This movie will IMHO garner many Oscar nominations. I would see it again, that's how good it was. Matt Damon has also done the best work of his career and Mark Wahlberg, Alec Badlwin and Martin Sheen put in very notable work. Jack Nicholson, is always good in most of his work but he was born to play this role he did an excellent job. Once again, Martin Scorsese turns in another winner. Cinematography was excellent as well, hard to find any fault with this film, in fact there is no bad part of this movie, unbelievably great ending. Movie keeps you on the edge of your seat without hyper anxiety and keeps you guessing.

title: best movie of the year
review: there is no doubt that the departed is a cameo, but after watching the movie, who really cares? this movie is only as good as it is because martin Scorsese used all of Hollywood's a-listers at once. jack Nicholson is perfect, Leonardo DiCaprio is believable, Matt Damon plays his usual bad-ass self and mark wahlberg swears a hole through the screen. these big names and others including Alec Baldwin and martin sheen all come together to make this film a masterpiece. it's comparable to such classics as the usual suspects and the godfather. i may even go so far as to call it one of the best films of all time. definite contender for best picture.

title: Amazing
review: This movie was absolutely amazing. It was so intense and throughout the whole movie it kept the audience. Leonardo DiCaprio was amazing and Jack Nicolson was perfect. They both created amazing characters and made them real. Jack Nicolson played his role like no one else could have been able to. His character was mean and intimidating, but yet he felt caring and friendly also. He seemed human At the end of this movie I was speechless. All I could tell anyone, was that it was amazing. Which is far from the real intensity of the movie. This movie was the epitome of a great movie. I advise everyone to go see; it will hopefully make you think the same way as I do.

title: A good move, not a great movie
review:
************* Warning: SPOILERS AHEAD********************

I feel that Departed was not excellent: I thought the film had

a) too many coincidences (2 moles passing each other on their first day, both fall for the same girl and sleep with her, good cop seeing incriminating envelope on bad cop's desk)

b) trivial things ala Hitchcock McGuffin in the form of 20 computer chips for $1million

c) confusing plot (and I'm above average in following them). Like: why didn't the police arrest Costello -- as the good cop said -- for the many things they had him on. In real life, Al Capone was put away for tax evasion.

It wasn't quite on the level of a James Bond flick where the villain says "I'm about to kill you Mr. Bond, but first let me give you a tour of my laboratory." (Gee: I am ambivalent if I should watch the new Casino Royale movie coming Nov 17 2006.)

On the other hand, I felt that it was a bit like "Easy Rider", which was called a mediocre movie with a great ending.

Yup, I felt that a top star dying before the end was incredible, just like "Dressed to Kill". The realistic ending of the cop who quits coming back using all his cop skills to act as an avenging angel was great. That showed real ingenuity and realism.

By the way, I apologize in advance for not reading the 53 pages of other people's reviews before writing mine.

title: Worth Seeing for DiCaprio's acting alone. Pretty amazing.
review: Double infiltration -- interesting movie. DiCaprio & Nicholson are amazing actors, no doubt. I give it a 7, because there are places that could have been much better directed in the telling of the story, but it was pretty killer overall - except for the fact that it leaves you feeling depressed instead of hopeful. Also- I left the theater right when they shot DiCaprio and the whole theater gasps in disbelief... I thought to myself: "yep- yet again the good guy, the glimmer of hope in all of this corruption get's wacked...in typical 'new Hollywood' style; it seems they like to have 'evil' triumph now-a-days. (I wish I'd stayed to see Walberg get Damon, but it didn't matter at that point, because a typical viewer is naturally pulling for DiCaprio to overcome the enormous dangers he's in and expose the bad guys. So when he get's shot - its like "crap- that sux - i'm outta here.") Oh well - I'll have to counter the psychological fx by watching a good indie film. lol . Enjoy -

title: Scorsese at his best.
review: Its good to see Scorsese making another film that will go down in film history as one of the best action movies ever made. It was especially nice to see an action like this because its been so long since any action movies like this have come out. The story was brilliant and captivating. The way that different characters develop and grow as the story evolves was amazing. The pace of the film was also very well set. And lets talk about the cast. This has to be Decaprio's best, and Matt Damon yet again shows his acting talent. And who couldn't love Jack Nickleson. This role was written for that man. It was like every character of the movie was written with a specific actor in mind. This movie is guaranteed to please. Anyone with any taste in movies will love this movie. I just hope that this isn't Martin Scorsese's last film.

title: What was with the music?
review:
I won't retread what everyone else is writing about...comparing it to "Internal Affairs", etc. Not fair. This was not a 'great' film, but just a really good film that was tense and very enjoyable, although about 20 minutes too long. Could have cut a lot of fat, Marty. The acting was terrific from Jack and DiCaprio, but how the Sheen and Walberg characters were developed made no sense. Or maybe it was that they under and over acted, respectively. Their opening scene together with DiCaprio was distractingly bad. I also didn't like to co-love interest angle at all...how many time have we seen that? And the ending, the last scene...was very confusing.

But what chapped me the most throughout this film is the music that ran through the background. It's like a jukebox was planted in the corner somewhere in the oddest scenes, playing the oddest songs. It was so distracting because you couldn't figure why it was there to begin with. In fact, it was so oddly placed in one scene that I honestly thought it was bleeding into the audio system from somewhere else. Unless there actually IS a jukebox playing in a diner scene, why would you overlay a song unrelated to the dialog or emotion of the scene. It works great in "Grey's Anatomy" and "Brothers and Sisters" but not here.

Despite my annoyances, overall I still liked it, but don't let anyone tell you it's the best film of the year.

title: Why a pregnancy? Possible spoiler....
review:
I loved loved loved this movie - what a roller coaster ride. Everybody was fabulous and I thought Mark Wahlberg stole the show. What a cast - it was just one big celebrity after another and everyone should be up for an Oscar. Maybe this will be the one that FINALLY gets Scorsese his Oscar which he so rightly deserves.

Imagine this actress, whom I actually don't ever remember seeing before, finds herself in a movie with all these big names. She's a terrific actress.

But I'm wondering what everyone's thoughts are on why they added a pregnancy there. Usually Scorcese has a point to everything he introduces in his films and I wonder what the point of that was.

Any thoughts?

title: Another TOUCHDOWN from Scorsese!
review:
Synopsis: The Departed is set in the heart of South Boston, where the Massachusetts State Police is waging war on the Irish Mob. As the family of newly-minted trooper Billy Costigan (DiCaprio) has a long criminal history, he is challenged by Captain Queenan (Sheen) and his second-in-command Sergeant Dignam (Wahlberg) to infiltrate the mob syndicate run by gangland chief Frank Costello (Nicholson). While Costigan quickly gains Costello's confidence, another trooper, Colin Sullivan (Damon), whose family, unlike Billy's, has no criminal history, is rising to a position of power in the Special Investigation Unit, headed by Captain Ellerby (Baldwin). However, he is a protégé of mob boss Costello from childhood, who has infiltrated the police department as an informant for the crime syndicate. Each man becomes consumed by his double life, gathering information about the plans and counter-plans of the operations he has penetrated. But when it becomes clear to the mob and the police that they each have a mole in their midst, Billy and Colin are suddenly in danger of being exposed  and each must race to uncover the identity of the other man first in time to save himself.

  • Scorsese has and always been the Master of making mob movies. Some of his memorable mob movies are Goodfellas, Casino and Gangs of New York. I personally believe that 'The Departed" is ranked upthere among them. His directing expert has really made this movie looks really BLOODY VIOLENT, which of course the major characteristic of mob movies. Jack Nicholson is back to his NASTY ass since his bad guy role as Joker in Batman (1989). Matt Damon is returning back to the future trying to be somebody that he actually is not in this movie like the character he played so marvelously in 'Talented Mr Ripley'. But the one that surprised me the most is Leonardo Dicaprio. This boyish looking guy oftenly played as a soft-charactered person in his past movies. However, you will see a different Leonardo in this movie. He kicks, he punches, he swears a lot, and he fires a gun, anything about him in this movie is that he looks really MAN. I think this was the first time Leonardo ever got to play in such role, and he excelled first time! I did watch the original HK movie 'Infernal Affairs', and I can assure you that the 'The Departed' is much better than the original and more attuned to American Culture. Who's gonna beat Hollywood anyway? A true MASTERPIECE from the master himself, Scorsese. I rate this movie 9/10 - A must watch!

title: scorese returning to what he does best
review:
A remake of any film is usually a woeful moment. Only a hand full have reached the mark of the original film, a few soaring above it. Hollywood has been pillaging the Asian cinema, with many remakes of their horror films and action/dramas. Based upon the Hong Kong film Infernal Affairs, The Departed looks to be exempted from this. While not have seen Infernal Affairs, the argues argument of comparing the films; "which one is better", is left muted, and all for the better.

It has been some time since Martin Scorese made his last gangster/crime film, with Casino back in 1995. During that time, his most major films Gangs of New York and The Aviator, where great yet muddled films. The Departed sees Scorsese returning to great form in a genre he does best. While not reaching Casino, Taxdriver or Goodfellas level, when the starting tune of The Rolling Stones Gimme Shelter rolls in, arms open saying 'Welcome back Martin'.

While it is rejoicing when The Departed starts, it dips not long after. The major flaw is the editing. Scenes run so lightning fast making a disjointed flow to the narrative. Scene cuts are erratic and images shoot past without time to comprehend what was shown. It's all the set up, Sullivan getting into the police to be Costello's mole, Queenan and Dignam setting up Costigan to infiltrate Costello's organization, you start to doubt whether Scorsese has dropped his form.

Yet things do settle, breaths are taken and proceeding calm down. Its the change from a urban setting. When both sides realise they might have moles in their midst, The Departed jumps tracks changing into one gripping and taut thriller. The intensity spikes and doesn't drop, with twists and turns, as Sullivan and Costigan hot on each others heals. Screenwritter William Monahan has succeeded in transfer the story into a complete American setting, with little presence of any Asian cinema influences, with Scorsese making it his own film to stand by itself.

Martin Scorsese's directing is impeccable, the shoot out between the police and Costello's drug shipment enforces this, perfectly executed and staged; though the editing during the first part does detract from his talent. Continuing his collaboration with Scorese from The Aviator and Gangs of New York, Leonardo DiCaprio delivers his best performance, growing better with each film he does. Matt Damon, while not his best, is great as crooked cop Sullivan. Jack Nicholson perfectly mixes comedy and vulgarity in Costello. Mark Wahlberg doesn't drop a note as fouled mouth, hot headed Dignam. Martin Sheen and Alec Baldwin are great in their supporting roles.

While not his best work, The Departed is Scorsese's best film in awhile.

title: Certainly not the best of M.S.'s movies...
review: The actors may have been the only reason to pay $7.00 to see this movie. Their charisma definitely lent to a story that only had one hidden moral: since every "warrior" dies in the end, the futility of joining one side over the other makes loyalty or morality ultimately worthless. A much cooler film "Reservoir Dogs" handles this with much more spunk and awe. Worth seeing, but not buying the DVD when it comes out. I think it was somewhat of a waste of Jack Nicholson's presence, but after "The Pledge" I think he's lost stock as an avante-gard visionary. Perhaps he has become too willing to do projects on the Director's past work to be judgmental or critical enough about his recent script picks. How many years does he have left to be wasting time on movies like About Schmitt, The Pledge, and Wolf. Mark Walberg came off as trying too hard to be a bad ass, the baby face didn't go with what should have been an older actor's role--someone with hair on their chest. Matt Damon and Leonardo Di Caprio were well peered, though. I found the energy levels seemed to keep the movie fresh even when the characters had all been done before. I hope Scorsese can find his way back to doing movies like Taxi Driver, Mean Streets, Cape Fear, and even After Hours--movies that created a new adventure upon unexpected paths.

title: Boo could've been better
review:
Personally I went to this movie not even knowing what it was about, I knew who was in, but knew nothing about it or the hype(if there was any??). The movie never hit the spot it should of, the idea was there, but I kept waiting for something to grab me and make me want to scream out yes. I then saw the credits rolling and thought to myself why, not only should it have ended 30 minutes ago, but since the movie insisted on continuing, why didn't something better happened that would give me my YES.

Not only did it not fulfill what I needed, but Matt Damon's character just seemed to dumb to me, and in the lead role thats not something you want. It wasn't his acting that I didn't like, he's a good actor, but he just didn't come off as a bright person. I also cannot believe his character could get a way with what he does for so long.

Now I know this movie is a serious movie, or supposed to be, but the characters kept cracking jokes lightening the mood, for whatever reason, I just never could take the movie seriously. I also couldn't take the ending seriously, but I'm sure some people loved it(it wasn't very clever). I always thought I'd love an ending like this one, but not from this movie.

Marky Mark also needed to be in the movie more, he was hilarious in it and should have been a bad ass too, but just didn't have a big enough part to make his mark.

Go see the movie or don't and you'll probably love it, but after seeing the first 10 minutes or so I expected a lot more. If you give me or anybody the set up to this movie, I'm sure we all could have wrote a movie as good as this one it would be different, but just as entertaining, it was the idea that made this movie watchable the plot just never went in the right direction.

title: Too bloody long... literally
review: By the time half of this very l-o-o-o-o-n-g bullets-and-blood saga has rolled by there has been so much violence depicted that the dozen or more graphically depicted additional killings lose most of their shock value. This movie should have been titled "Overkill." Also, it includes a tedious overuse of the f-word, now apparently Hollywood's go-to expression when the Muses fail script writers. Then, were one a Boston cop/detective/investigator one would have cause to be plenty miffed at having the police department portrayed, as done here, as being populated by a bunch of screaming bunglers who are badly in need of remedial investigation and surveillance skills. This movie is too long --by 2 1/2 hours. Better watch another "Law & Order" episode...

title: Sweet
review: This movie is the greatest movie that I have ever seen. There are so many twists and turns that you don't even know what is happening. If you see this movie, you do not want to see anything else! I have seen this movie about four times. I still get surprised in the end. Must See Movie! If this movie does not win the movie of the decade, then I don't know what to believe. If you like action, suspense, comedy, and everything else that makes a movie awesome, see this one. When it comes on DVD, I will probably buy two copies, one to look at and one to watch. It is that good! Martin Scorsese is the best director ever! If you don't watch it, you might as well kill yourself.

title: Let the Awards roll in
review: For fans of Troy Duffy's The Boondock Saints (2001), this movie returns to gunslinging Boston, Mass. for another parlay into a rain of bullets, but this time, there isn't the religious ethos eternally present. I have to say I didn't even know from seeing the previews that this movie took place in Boston. But was literally ON THE EDGE OF MY SEAT through two hours of this two and a half hour film. I found the fact that a plethora of not even a shred of Irish actors managed to put on the appropriate linguistic vowel pronunciations to sound the part, and that their jibes were effectively Irish and at the same time affectionate, something I consider not so easy to do. With an absolutely stellar cast of actors at the top of their game, this is a movie not to be missed as you will undoubtedly be left out of countless conversations regarding it. One of my fave parts of the film has to do simply with a suit. Jack Nicholson's character "Costello" is wearing a gray, micro-checked suit with what looks like a textured suede-cheetah print tie. FANTASTIC job by the costume designer on using the suit as a way of showing the immense personality and charisma that is presented through the character. I WANT that suit! That's how much I liked it. Amazing.

title: Asian Tale with American Life
review:
The 2 men behind the Hong Kong box office drama Infernal Affairs, Andrew Lau and Alan Mak, will be pleased with Martin Scorsese for giving new life to the Asian trilogy.

The Departed is an adaptation of Infernal Affairs Trilogy, where Leonardo DiCaprio's Billy Costigan is the role of Tony Leung Chiu Wai's Chan Wing Yan, while Matt Damon's Colin Sullivan reprises the role of Andy Lau's Lau Kin Ming. Jack Nicholson's Frank Costello is an Italian mafia, which is an answer to Eric Tsang's Sam, a Hong Kong trial society's kingpin. Martin Sheen's Oliver Queenan is the equivalent to Anthony Wong's SP Wong in the American adaptation.

Scorsese has given a new life to Infernal Affairs trilogy, where he concluded the whole story in 152 minutes, rather than making it into a trilogy adaptation.

Firstly, it was a full American flavored, where the story was presented in American context, instead of sticking closely to the Hong Kong version. FBI, Italian mafia and grocery store is the answer to Hong Kong Police Force, trial society and illegal gambling dens. By using something that is closer to home, Scorsese tells a story from Asia with American background.

Secondly, bits of elements from Infernal Affairs 2 and 3 was seen in The Departed, such as Costello being a womanizer and the short conversation between Queenan and Costello with Dignam (Mark Walhberg). This may not seem sticking close to the trilogy, but it shortens the time taken to know the tale behind the trilogy.

DiCaprio, Damon and Nicholson may be the whole focus of the film, but it was Walberg's Dignam that leaves the audience with the deepest impression. A hot tempered and fouled mouth inspector, he was not seen in Infernal Affairs trilogy, which adds a new twist to The Departed. Vera Farmiga's Madolyn is the combination of Kelly Chen's Dr Lee Sum Yee, the psychiatrist Chan was seeing, and Mary, the lover of Lau.

Scorsese ends the film with an unexpected twist, which has proved a success to The Departed. If Infernal Affairs has impress you, The Departed brings Infernal Affairs to a greater height.

title: I can't shout but I want to. Great Movie!
review: There is no way to explain this movie to any form of justice without giving away the movie. I can tell you this. I loved the usual suspects, I loved reservoir dogs, I loved Pulp Fiction...but, this movie was by far and away the best movie I've seen. It cost 9.00 a piece for me and my wife to go, plus popcorn and a drink at a raging 13.50. I can tell you after watching this movie it was worth 10 times that. It's not just a "man movie" as my wife who hates all the above movies loved it also. There were so many things that made this movie worth watching besides the unbelievable cast. Trust me, watch this movie and you'll be happy you did. I may go again to the theater (which I've never done) and I will buy this movie the day it hits DVD.

title: I have some questions
review:
Was Matt Damon his son?? I know he called him dad but at the end that dialogue confused me...

What was in Leo's envelope he gave to Dr. SLUT? Did Marky Mark kill Damon out of revenge for Martin Sheen getting tossed? If not what was his motive to kill Damon at the end? Why did Nicholson single out Damon as a kid and recruit him? Did Dr.Slut abort Leo's kid or Damons? What was that golden dome supposed to symbolize? How funny was Alec Baldwin!!!! HAH Was Matt Damon his son?? I know he called him dad but at the end that dialogue confused me...

What was in Leo's envelope he gave to Dr. SLUT? Did Marky Mark kill Damon out of revenge for Martin Sheen getting tossed? If not what was his motive to kill Damon at the end? Why did Nicholson single out Damon as a kid and recruit him? Did Dr.Slut abort Leo's kid or Damons? What was that golden dome supposed to symbolize? How funny was Alec Baldwin!!!! HAH

title: The Departed...
review: ...nothing more than PERFECTION! (I would rate it 10++++). One of the BEST movies I've seen within the last 10 yrs! There wouldn't have been a better cast. DiCaprio and Damon were at the best... It wouldn't have been the same without Jack Nicholson playing the villain. Add to that, Martin Sheen, Alec Balwin and Marky Mark???!!! WOW! AMAZING acting, score, script, cinematography, etc. It was beyond perfection! PLEASE, PLEASE do go see it if you haven't seen it yet! It was awesome... !!!!!! !!!!!!!!! !!!!!!!!!! !!!!!!!! !!!!!!!! !!!!!!!!!! !!!!!!! !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! !!!!!!!!! !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! !!!!!!!!!! !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! !!!!!!!!!!! !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! !!!!!

title: Best Movie of 2006 (11/10)
review:
When I entered the movie theater and bought my ticket with my friends, I was basically looking forward to a regular old action film, with people getting shot and the likes. The Departed is so much more. Of course, it contains everything an action-movie fan is bound to love, the engrossing plot is so deep, to such an extent that if you get out of your seat to get treats in the middle of the movie, you'll be lost in the intricate story line when you return. I have to admit, I'm probably going to be a little biased in my rating of the movie, because Mark Whalburg, Matt Damon, Leonardo DiCaprio all happen to be some of my favorites, and of course, do not disappoint me in this movie. All the actors reveal their utmost potential. Scorsese is a true genius, he blows all my expectations out of the water.

This really is one of the best movies of our 21st century, and it's worth your every cent.

title: Incredible
review: I don't have time to write a lot so I'm not. Better than ANY movie this year or last year and possibly the last few years. Utterly amazing. The directing, the cinematography, the out-of-this-world awesome acting, the score, and last but certainly not least: the ridiculous screenplay. ***SPOILER AHEAD*** NOTHING negative about this movie except Leo getting killed, that ripped my guts out, i really wanted him to make it through everything. But, hey, it was unexpected and really gripped my emotions so kudos for excellent film-making. My favorite character, however, was Detective Dignam (Mark Wahlberg). Mr. Scorsese, you never cease to amaze, entertain, and fascinate.

title: Respectful Departed
review:
THE DEPARTED Written by William Monahan Directed by Martin Scorcese

This is it, folks. It's the one you've all been waiting for. It is a true return to form, style and relevance. It has been all too easy, almost expected, to laud Martin Scorcese pictures with praise in recent years. The man has talent and has crafted some of cinema's landmark films, from TAXI DRIVER to GOODFELLAS. The industry was naming his last picture, THE AVIATOR, the film of the year. That seemed exaggerated, an all too safe a thing to say. To name the same of his previous epic mess, GANGS OF NEW YORK, was even more absurd. There seemed to be regret for not crowning him king earlier for more deserving efforts. The later pity praise felt apologetic instead of congratulatory. The films themselves felt manufactured for mass appeal, devoid of personal involvement and often a courting of industry acceptance. This time is different. This time Scorcese feels concise and calculated, like a man with a purpose, focus. This time Scorcese has left his hopes for accolades behind him and engineered his own cinematic rebirth. This time Scorcese says goodbye to his past and embraces THE DEPARTED.

Borrowing its intricately woven story from the 2002 Japanese film, INFERNAL AFFAIRS, THE DEPARTED stars Leonardo Dicaprio and Matt Damon as moles infiltrating both sides of a war between the law and organized crime. Dicaprio plays Billy Costigan, a Boston State Policeman with a family history entrenched in crime. As he is trying to make a new name for his family, he is thrown back into the world he worked so hard to escape. Costigan will go undercover and make his way into the confidence of Boston's biggest crime boss, Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson). Costello, meanwhile, has his own man on the inside of the Boston State Police, Colin Sullivan (Damon). Sullivan was brought under Costello's wing when he was just a boy who was doing well in school. Both Costigan and Sullivan sought power. Costigan's power lied in authority and changing his apparent destiny through hard work. Sullivan was seduced by a different kind of power. He still had to work hard but he had the muscle to back him up when he needed it. Dicaprio's and Damon's solid performances heighten the tension and make for insightful character studies. As Costigan, Dicaprio is anxious and unstable. Pretending to be a brute with nothing to live for and no reason to do bad other than it being his genetic makeup goes against everything he's ever struggled with. His eyes flare up and his whole body flinches every time he is around intense violence; he never seems to get used to it. As Sullivan, Damon is a confident, cocky liar who gets off on how many people he's fooling and just how well he is fooling them, from his colleagues on the force (a supporting cast consisting of Martin Sheen, Mark Wahlberg and Alec Baldwin) to his psychiatrist girlfriend, Madolyn (the relatively unknown and engaging Vera Farmiga). When it becomes apparent that both teams have been permeated, the game to catch the rat becomes tenser the closer each gets to figuring the other out. Amidst growing suspicion and fear of getting caught, THE DEPARTED becomes unpredictable and entrancing.

The surprisingly layered performance of Nicholson as Costello is one of THE DEPARTED's best features. I expected that Nicholson could pull off a mob boss in his sleep but he brings experience and the effects of time to the role. Like one would expect, one doesn't become a mob boss from being a nice guy. Costello is evil right through. He finds amusement in how a body slumps over to the side instead of forward when he blows a bullet through the back of her head. He has grown accustomed to getting everything he wants, to having no one stand in his way. To some extent though, he has grown bored and complacent with this lifestyle. He knows of nothing else but knows that alternatives exist. He seems to live his life appreciative of his position but with regret, or at least an awareness, that he did not make other decisions. When he speaks of Costigan's father as a guy who could have been a big boss if he wanted to but didn't, the acknowledgment alone highlights the power of choice. When he tells Costigan that he should go back to school, it highlights his own choices.

Something Costello is fond of saying is that "No one gives it to you; you have to take it." It is a mantra for Costello and it seems like one for Scorcese as well regarding his approach to this film. Scorcese's command of THE DEPARTED can be felt in the composition of each shot, in the energy of the omnipresent soundtrack and the grasp of the subject matter. Like Costello, Scorcese has been coasting in recent years; the results have been passable, at times solid, but always tired. THE DEPARTED announces Scorcese's return to making affirmative choices again, and the right one's at that.

title: Marvellous. Scorsese at his finest.
review:
First he sets the characters and the world up so vividly, so interestingly and with such finesse. You watch him stack the dominoes side-by-side, wondering where he's going, what pattern he's making. And before you know it, he knocks one of them over and you watch the domino chain fall in the most exciting and elaborate way. The tension in this film just rises and rises - it's so incredibly well structured and paced. The film becomes exhilarating - a word I too rarely get to use to describe a film.

This is an instant classic - a definitive crime film. The cast is fantastic - what a great ensemble piece. Scorsese is the best thing that's ever happened to DiCaprio - he turned the guy into a real actor and this is his best role so far. Damon is great, Sheen, Wahlberg, Baldwin...excellent. Nicholson is very entertaining - sure, he hams it up a little - but it's so well done. The cinematography is at the same time very visceral and immediate, as well as cinematic - capturing the excellent setting of Boston in a very unique way.

Sure, I was expecting great things - but not this good. Scorsese knocked this out of the park. I couldn't give this anything but a 10/10. This is a film that people will be talking about fifty years from now.

title: Don't Miss This One!!!
review: All I can say is what a movie!! One of the best I have seen in a long time! Must see! (as long as you can handle some bloody scenes!)It is a long one but you don't even notice because you are interested from start to finish! The acting by EVERYONE in The Departed was amazing! Jack was typical awesome Jack, maybe even better! Leonardo blew me away in this one! They were all just really great! Action packed! Great actors, Great Story. It really has everything! I love when a movie captures you from start to finish and you really get into it. That is how this movie was for me. Heartpounding. Just be warned that it is a little bloody so if you can't take that kind of thing either don't go and pass on an awesome ride or go and bring something to cover your eyes during some parts!! Enjoy it!

title: "The Departed" is an outstanding addition for Scorcese
review: Martin Scorsese has succeeded in creating a masterful thriller in his recent release of "The Departed". Jack Nicholson does another piece of perfect portrayal of Frank Costello, and underworld villain whom one loves to hate. Matt Damon is a cop who becomes an undercover agent on the dark side named Colin Sulivan. He too gives a thrilling performance and he leaves no stone unturned. Leonardo DiCaprio plays Billy Costigan the "good guy" cop with a distorted childhood. Martin Sheen is Oliver Queenan, the lead cop in the Boston patrol who organizes the sting, and gets tied up in his own plot. Alec Baldwin is the chief police officer on the Boston team in charge of the hunt for Costello. There are few moments that lack suspense, and surprises are abundant. It may be a bit too violent for the young, however, the violence is well performed and tastefully fits the tone. "The Departed" is a must see movie for 2006, so be sure to put it on your list now.

title: Scorsese Back To His Best
review:
After The Aviator, I wasn't overly expectant of anything from The Departed - and I'm glad to say I was wrong.

It moves along at a perfect pitch - and the 151 minutes drift by without a thought of popping out to the toilet or grabbing another box of nachos.

The twists and turns are carved out beautifully, and the acting is majestic for the best part.

Don't expect another Goodfellas or Mean Streets here - this is a stylish, polished to a shimmer tour-de-force from Scorsese that should finally earn him the Oscar he so rightly deserves. If you see one movie at the cinema this year, make sure it's The Departed.

Truly great stuff, Scorsese is back to his imperious best - at last.

title: Great thriller
review: I went yesterday to The departed's premiere and I really liked it.The movie is extremely fun and the violent scenes are very well filmed.Scorsese has a kinda irregular career:he made great films(Bringing out the dead,Goodfellas,Taxi driver or Raging bull), but also unsatisfactory movies(Kundun,The age of innocence or New York,New York).The departed belongs to the first group.The great Jack Nicholson makes a perfect performance and I think he needs to have another Academy Award nomination for this movie.Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon and Mark Wahlberg also bring excellent performances.The departed is a great remake that,without being at the same level of Infernal affair(the original movie),is very fun,with great moments of violence,with great performances and with very unexpected things for the ones who did not see the original film.

title: Someone once said that the only difference between cops and robbers is the badge.
review:
Well, in this movie, both the Good Guy and the Bad Guy have badges. Ben Affleck is the crooked cop, Colin Sullivan. He works for Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson), an Irish-American gangster whom Sullivan has both feared and idolized since childhood. And, he apparently measures success by how close he can live to the ritzy neighborhood where the Old Boston Statehouse is located.

Leo DiCaprio , on the other hand, plays Billy Costigan. An honest cop whose late father was apparently a nouveau riche gangster who married a Boston Brahmin debutant. And, so, he has spent most of his young life feeling like an outcast in both the blue-collar and green-collar parts of Beantown.

Costigan is recruited to spy on Costello's mob, so that Capt. Queenan (Martin Sheen) can finally send his old rival to prison. While Sullivan, of course, is paid to keep that from happening! In a way, then, these two young men are just pawns in a real-life game of chess, where Queenan and Costello are the players.

But, in a major piece of irony, the pawns _become_ the players after the deaths of both Queenan and Costello! And, caught between them is Madolyn, the psycho-analyst they both fall in love with.
