Martin Scorcese's The Departed is by far one of the best films hes done in a long time.Gangs Of New York was a great movie I just thought it was going to be better.The Aviator wasn't as good as this film either.The Departed is every bit as good as Goodfellas.I read somewhere that Robert De Niro was going to play Jack Nicholsons character and if that went along the film wouldn't be as good as it is now.Jack Nicholson is going to be nominated for his portrayal of Frank Costello.He plays it crazy and ruthless at the same time.He is hands down the best actor of the year.Leo Dicaprio and Matt Damon give easily the best performances of their careers.They shine on the screen and show audiences what good acting is.The supporting actors Mark Wahlberg,Martin Sheen,Alec Baldwin,Ray Winstone also left me with memorable moments when they were on screen.Wahlberg acts as good as in Boogie Nights and Ray Winstone gives an exceptional performance as Mr. French as he did in Sexy Beast which will always be Winstones best.Martin Sheen stood out in this film and was brilliant as well as Baldwin who left with a lasting impression and should have had a bit more screen time because he played his character so well.

In The Departed Scorsese and his quality of directing met eye to eye with his classic Goodfellas.Every shot every scene has his signature.I love his choice of music for the film as well. The Rolling Stones,Pink Floyd,Dropkick Murphys and tons more memorable pieces of music gave The Departed a great sense of style which Scorses wasn't able to do in Gangs Of New York or The Aviator.William Monohan's adaptation of the Asian film Infernal Affairs was great it took its basic plot of spys on both sides and that is it the rest was from his own creation and the dialogue is fantastic and very authentic and real to where the film takes place.One of the best written movies in my opinion ever since Micael Manns Heat.

In the end I see The Departed winning Best Picture because there hasn't been a film of this caliber in many years ever since 2000.Martin Scorsese will be nominated but i doubt he will win and get ripped off once again considering the amount of racial slurs and slang which is part of The Departed's realism which is also featured in Goodfellas is one of the reasons Scorsese will get ripped off again.The violence will also be apart of it because the Academy just cant stomach it. Best adapted screenplay definitely The Departed will win.In the actor category Jack Nicholson will definitely win I've haven't seen an actor so devoted and loyal to a character ever since Philip Seymour Hoffman in Capote.Leo Dicaprio and Matt Damon should also be nominated for best actor however Nicholson will get the nomination due to his age and time in the business of film.

-Don Logan

title: It is a great film.
review: I saw the departed yesterday. And instantly it became my top favorite movies of all time. This movie ranks with other Scorsese's classic like raging bull,goodfellas and taxi driver. This movie in no way can be compared to any movie Scorsese has done but it is a classic. I could have never imagined that any crime drama could be humorous, suspenseful as hell and have a tragic feel towards the end. I think it is truly a unique movie even though is it based on Internal affairs. The ending of movie is so different than we think it is supposed to end and that makes it great and that how Scorsese' movies are like. The movie has strength in directing,writing and acting along with editing. IT is truly a master's work, enjoy it. I think this movie will be nominated for best picture,best director,best screenplay,best supporting actor,and best leading actor. How many it will win we still have to wait and see.

title: Jon Monsarrat review: Fantastic in every way
review:
The Departed works as an action / thriller, but it is really a serious drama with the best plot line and action since The Untouchables. Every actor, including the supporting cast, is spot on and the plot keeps you guessing. The accent is a little overdone at times -- television and radio have cut into the traditional John F. Kennedy Bostonian accent and not everybody in Beantown speaks that way. But if that's the biggest gripe I have, the film must have been nearly flawless.

The film gives a sense of the underworld, and undercover investigations, without the flair and rippling muscles of Miami Vice. Nobody takes stupid chances to save the day because They're Just That Good. Nobody says "I'm too old for this s---." It's hard to say who's better, Matt Damon or Leonardo Decaprio... I'm not sure Matt could play a bad guy, he's just so clean cut. Leonardo is one of those actors who (unlike Tom Hanks who seems to play the same guy in every film until lately) really has no pre-specified film persona that scripts are "written for".

Every nuance of the film avoids being trite and campy, but it also avoids going into melodrama. There are no flying triple spin car explosion stunts, but the action is engaging because of the drama of the people involved. I'm usually bored right away when we dwell on the pain too much... this film did not do that. The musical score does not interfere with the mood; it stays in the background like good movie music should. This is what distinguishes the action flick from a serious drama; whether celebratory music is playing during the action. And none of the minor supporting characters get a plot; they are window-dressing and they stay in the background, too.

As a nice addition, much of the film is actually shot in Boston, where I live, whereas most films set in Boston (Blown Away, Good Will Hunting) have a few outdoor staging shots and leave the rest to Hollywood sets.

Who should see this film:

-- Everyone, if you're old enough to handle the violence, which is not Quentin Tarantino bad but there is plenty of it.

-- Whitey Bulger, wherever you are

I'll give this film an outstanding 10 out of 10, something I will do possibly 2 or 3 times a year, max. Note, it is kinda long, so don't forget to use the restroom beforehand.

title: Martin Scorsese's triumphant return to the gangster film.
review:
The Departed tells the story of a young mobster that is put through police training and becomes part of the Boston Special Investigations Unit so he can tip off his boss, mobster Frank Costello, when the police are tracking him. Meanwhile, a young cop is put undercover in Frank Costello's gang. Both Costello and the police captain realize they have a mole leaking information, and everybody begins to crack up trying to search for the rat. This amazing good cop/bad cop movie marks Martin Scorsese's triumphant return to the gangster film.

The second this movie started it screamed Scorsese. Gimme Shelter by the Rolling Stones is blasting as Nicholson narrates. I knew right away I'd like this movie. The plot and the script are absolutely top notch. Everything about this movie is great. I loved the dialogue. It is witty, funny, and realistic. You usually can't get all three of those in one. The story remains interesting and engaging throughout, and the twists and turns only make it more exciting. The direction style is genius, but of course we're talking about Martin Scorsese here. The only thing that keeps the movie from getting a 10 for me was that toward the end it started to drag a little bit, but not enough to make it boring.

The acting in this movie is great. Jack Nicholson is just as good as in any other movie. He's just an amazing actor. Matt Damon and Leonardo DiCaprio were amazing in this movie. Leo is quickly shedding that Hollywood pretty boy image. Alec Baldwin and Mark Whalberg were great when they bickered back and forth at each other.

Overall, this is the best movie of 2006 so far. I'm sure Scorsese will be jilted out of another Oscar, because the Academy doesn't recognize real art, but he is the best director of 2006 in my eyes. Utterly fantastic movie.

9/10

title: Best movie in a long time
review: This is quite possibly the best movie I've seen in theaters in recent years, if not the best ever. So far, this is my best picture of the year. Scorese is at the top of his game, as is the acting. The story is tough to follow at first, but it comes together well, reminding me of Mann's Heat. The acting is superb as well, with talents like Damon, Nicholson, Walberg standing out. The plot is set up neatly, and keeps gaining steam, up to the shocking ending. The departed is interesting, funny, dramatic, and much more. Again, this is a solid movie that is sure to pick up something come awards season. I highly recommend that you go see it.

title: Brilliant yet flawed
review:
The all star cast of this film does not disappoint with both Leo and Damon giving brilliant performances. I haven't personally encountered a Di Caprio character that is so deeply constructed since The Basketball Diaries.

However, the beauty about this film is the spectacular 'put ure money on him now for an Oscar' performance of Jack Nicholson. He gets the role of the slightly psychotic mob leader perfectly.

Scorcese builds the tension perfectly through deepening the characters and the plot in tandem, providing some moments of real tension. He also breaks much of this tension with some quite funny moments too.

This film does have an 'interesting' ending which will either delight of annoy many - in my case, I found it refreshing, compelling and chilling.

title: Good movie...mad about 1 thing
review: The plot was great, the acting was awesome, and overall it was a good movie. The one thing I didn't like is that Leonardo DiCaprio died. I loved the ending though. Mark Wahlberg was waiting for Matt Damon in his apartment and shot him. That was cool. I was hoping that the cops would get Matt Damon(Even though Wahlberg was practically fired). Jack Nicholson's acting was superb, but I wasn't surprised. If Leonardo DiCaprio survived it would have survived, it would make the movie much better to me. That would have made it my favorite action movie. There is a lot of blood and violence, but it wasn't over-the-top. The movie was funny too.

title: Best Scorsese film since Casino
review: This movie was simply amazing. I have been working for the past year at the movie theatre, so I see a lot of movies come through. This is without a doubt one of the best that I have seen over the time of my employment there. Its probably one of the best I have ever seen. It is a prime example of Martin Scorsese at his absolute best. With Scorsese as a director, and the all-star cast involved, there is no way it could be a bad movie anyway. If you have a chance, I strongly suggest you go see it. It is two hours and forty-one minutes long, so block out a little while in your schedule. I promise that it is amazing every minute though.

title: Short of a Masterpiece?
review: This movie makes you speechless. As my boyfriend put it: Nothing short of a work of genius. Every single actor has played superbly. There was never a faulty moment when you felt that it was overplayed or underplayed. Of course, as you leave there are numerous unanswered questions, but not the kind where you would want to poke wholes in the plot. In fact, there was no real plot where there was a definitive "Start, middle, finish". It was a very complex, intricate development of human relationships that makes you both associate and separate from the movie. And in fact, I loved that ending was not your regular Hollywood type ending - made me fell like there is still art to be had from the big motion picture producers.

title: This Would Be A 10, But They Screwed Up The Ending
review:
This script was absolutely incredible! The acting was absolutely incredible! The directing was absolutely incredible! The ending, however, left something to be desired.

This movie keeps you on the edge of your seat the entire time. You are so involved in the story that you feel as if it's real.

The ending, however, reminded you that this movie wasn't real.

It seems to me that the writer wrote this incredible script and then hit the end and didn't know what to do, so he said to himself "Hmm...what should I do now? Oh, I know! I'll simply kill off every main character in the span of about 10 minutes. That's perfect" Go see the movie...it's really good. I just thought the ending could have been better.

title: Jack and movie Best of the year!
review:
We start all of our reviews with the following information. My wife and I have seen nearly 100 movies per year for the past 15 years. Recently, we were honored by receiving lifetime movie passes to any movie any time at no cost! So we can see whatever we want whenever we want. The point of this is that CRITICS count for ZERO. Your local critics or the national critics like Ebert are really no different than you or me. The only difference is that they get to write about the movie and are forced to see hundreds of movies whether they want to or not.Therefore, it is our belief that if you get your monies worth for two hours of enjoyment that is good enough for us! We NEVER EVER listen or read the critics. We only care about our friends and those who we know like the same things as us. Well enough about that.

Simply the best movie of the year. Everyone in this movie could receive academy award consideration from the spectacular Jack! Jack at his all time best. Just Jack! Scorcese will finally get the Oscar. Matt Damon, Leonardo DeCaprio, Martin Sheen and the entire cast including Mark Wahlberg, Alec Baldwin make this the best movie of the year.

It is a gangster movie that is funny too. It has a great plot, not predictable and a complete joy. Don't miss it.

title: Harsh Lessons on the Mean Streets of Boston
review:
I felt somewhat traumatised walking away from this film. It was one of those ones that I needed to go and do something enjoyable after mulling it over before I could sleep properly. Indeed, watching a re-run of England beating Wales in the 2003 RWC just about did the trick, but now it is all coming back to me as I write this...

The story is compelling. Matt Damon is a superpoliceman/mobster mole tasked with essentially rooting himself out of the Boston PD. All along he is really trying to id undercover policeman Leonardo di Caprio for Jack Nicholson's nutter at the top Francis Costello. Di Caprio is posing as a mobster crew member trying to provide evidence to put away said crime boss away for life. So far so confusing? Not really. But what ensues is a taught ride of cat and mouse as each comes close to being discovered.

The acting is superb, the script, rude, crude, intelligent and at times very amusing. The action is shocking. Several cut away edits and scenes left me shocked to the point of forgetting to breathe. Without giving too much away, the showdown leaving 'Jed' flying and the aftermath of the lift scene where Matt Damon begs to be killed when the net tightens. It is cruel, blood splattered and superbly edited. Definitely recommended (but take a strong constitution with you).

title: Amazing
review:
This movie is amazing! The plot twists are intricate and the pace is fast. You will want to watch it over again the minute you come out of the theatre. Every character is brilliant and filled out. Every scene has purpose and amazing dialogue. This movie is a cut above any other movie I've seen this year.

Every Boston accent in this movie is flawless, and that takes a lot of effort. But no one slips up or drops the ball with the accent, you really believe that all of these characters are originally from Boston. You will also be surprised to see Mark Wahlberg pull off a very non-typical character for himself beautifully.

Watch this movie, it will be the best decision you can make.

title: A gripping and enormously entertaining movie experience
review: I'm generally not a fan of mob movies with an overdose of violence. But, this was different. Violence here becomes an inevitable part of a gripping, cat-and-mouse storyline. The movie reminded of the 'Fugitive' with its plot twists, taut editing and edge of the seat suspense. Both Matt Daemon and Leonardo Di Caprio have acted extremely well in atypical roles. I thought Leonardo had even outdone Matt Daemon, esp. towards the end. And, Jack Nicholson was, as always, peerless. You want to strangle him in almost every frame and that's his supreme achievement. The movie is surprisingly and genuinely funny at times. The dialog is not for the faint-hearted. It's coarse, foul-mouthed and makes you squirm. But, it still comes across as very natural and really sizzles with edge and intelligence.

title: Definitely worth a year to see
review:
Okay...I've been dieing to see this movie since like last year when I just had heard about it. Then I found out about all these amazing cast members and that really got me waiting. I saw it last night...and it definitely met my expectations and more. I thought there would be some parts where I would loose it and doze off...but it's 150 minutes...and not a dull moment!

My favorite performance was probably Mark Wahlburgs. I liked him and the way he played his character...and Nicholson better see at least one nomination! I saw Internal Affairs too, but I thought this was far more entertaining, mostly because I knew the actors and what not, but both should be given a shot, and The Departed is well worth the admission fee! 9/10

title: Bloody, Brutal, Brilliant
review:
"Huh, she fell funny", these are the words of Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson) as he casually executes a woman from close range. Costello is a show stealer, just as Bill the Butcher (Day-Lewis), Tommy DeVito (Joe Pesci) and 'Johnny Boy' (De Niro) before him. The audience have a new semi-psychotic gangster to root for, as he snorts, beats, kills and shags his way through the narrative. Costello is a cold character, larger than life and extravagant in every way, marvel at his brutality and dark humour because characters of this kind rarely grace our screens. This Irish mob boss is a leopard skin wearing, dildo wielding maniac who Nicholson and Scorsese clearly enjoyed bringing to the screen. This is not to say that Nicholson is the film's saving grace, he merely gives a stand out performance in a film overflowing with talent and in some cases genius.

Modern day, South Boston and two fresh faced State Police Troopers are about to embark on very different journeys. Colin Sullivan (Matt Damon) is a go-getter who quickly rises through the ranks and joins an elite group of detectives whose job it is to stamp out organised crime. Colin might seem like the trustworthy type, though he has secretly been groomed by Costello from an early age to infiltrate the Police and become a mole for the mob. Simultaneously, Billy Costigan (Leonardo Dicaprio) due to his troubled past has been planted by the Police within Costello's crew to act as informant on his dirty dealings. It soon becomes apparent to both The Police and Costello's gang that they each have a 'rat' working for the opposite side within their outfits, leading to Costigan and Sullivan embarking on a race against time to discover each others identities.

Loosely based on the Hong Kong classic Infernal Affairs, The Departed consciously maintains its individuality. This is not a remake, and in many ways Scorsese surpasses the tension filled Asian version, with his own brand of Cops and Criminals facing off against each other. Visually, Scorsese has recaptured the true menacing nature of the mean streets. One scene in particular perfectly captures the steam filled, neon lit labyrinth that Costigan and Sullivan negotiate whilst avoiding detection from each other.

Nobody does violence like Scorsese, The Departed is truly brutal and realistic; people are cut up, beaten to a pulp, thrown off buildings and shot in the head at a frantic pace. Marty himself says "Violence is part of who I am, if you're gonna see violence, you'd better experience it". The Departed unites a group of characters that have been rejected by society and dance with death on a daily basis. To label the film a 'cat and mouse tale' does not do it justice. The Departed is a slick piece of modern cinema that depicts extreme violence, alienation and the corruption of power.

If Scorsese is The Departed's brain and Nicolson the brawn then the heart of the film belongs to the excellent Vera Farmiga who plays the Psychologist Madolyn. Girlfriend to Sullivan and councillor to Costigan her Dr/patient relationship with Costigan is particularly complex and tender. As the only character in the film untainted by violence and crime, Madolyn provides some much needed emotional relief to the weighty plot.

The Departed is film-making at its grandest, a powerhouse script, precision directing and impeccable performances all round make this the film of the year so far. With a supporting cast that includes Ray Winstone and Mark Wahlberg The Departed's beefy cast cannot be faulted and makes the film one of Scorsese's best. The mono-browed auteur may have been courting Oscar with Gangs of New York and The Aviator, though The Departed sees him return to what made him truly great in the first place. Welcome back Marty, you've been away too long.

title: acting showcase
review: Be ready to hear DiCaprio and Damon up for best actor and Nicholson for supporting. I think DiCaprio would seize it, but no matter the outcome, the acting in this film is simply amazing. Wahlberg puts on quite a show as well, and you can't deny Baldwin his limelight. It was also an unexpected pleasure to see Farmiga as the leading lady. Immediately I recognized her from Dummy, and remembered I always wondered why I never saw her in anything else. She is quite charming. The film keeps your adrenaline pumping right up to the credits. Great writing. Of course, you can't see The Departed without thinking of Scorsese. The film certainly couldn't have done what it has without him. Best Picture of the year so far.

title: Excellent in all respects
review: It has been a long time since I have seen such an excellent movie. I would rate it up there with Godfather. The plot was definitely NOT formulaic. There was no way to predict the outcome. The acting was superb. It would be hard to pick a best actor from this all-star ensemble cast. Jack Nicholson was fabulous, Leonard DeCaprio gave the performance of his lifetime and Mark Wahlberg was incredible. The movie gripped you from the very beginning and would not let you go. Even the violence, which I usually abhor, was necessary to the story. The movie was so good that I do not want to give away one little bit about it because I want everyone to experience it as I did. This movie will definitely sweep the academy awards. Enjoy!

title: Fantastic Film
review: Just got back from what turned out to be another Scorsese masterpiece. The Departed is one of the best movies I have seen in years, and will surely draw some intense Oscar attention. The acting (including the bit parts) is absolutely superb. Leonardo DiCaprio proves himself once again to be one of the elite actors of our time. The Scorsese/DiCaprio duo once again delivers. The movie is full of rich dialogue, character development, and even sneaks in some humor (though usually in a rather vulgar form: see Mark Walberg). Though the film was a bit lengthy, it never seemed to slow down. This is the best American film this year and I hope that both Scorsese and Leo finally get the Oscar recognition that they deserve.

title: Something about awards
review: Its a wonderful movie....probably one of the best in the decade. The casting, the cinematography, the characters written so distinctly intriguing. I am only upset that Leo will probably get robbed once again of an Oscar. A Scorcese is a Scorcese, the movie is written so well and filmed so beautifully that each actor trumps the next. When you start to watch it you think Walberg will dominate, then you see Leo get tough, then you get amused by a surprisingly amazing Baldwin, then you see the master of Jack and the stability of Damon. Leo is good - not just as a character but as an actor - hes the only one who really reaches for something not easily attained. Leo should get an Oscar even though he plays a smaller portion than he did in Gangs of NY and the Aviator. The movie is brilliant, the story so close to the James "Whitey" Bulger story and something that every man and woman should see. This is a great movie.

title: Makes Goodfellas look like Sesame Street
review: This is by far the best work by Scorsese. From start to finish, he leads you on a tantalizing journey of humor, foul language, drama, and of course plenty of realistic mob killing. DiCaprio is again spectacular (as always) and Damon shines in the bad guy role. The entire cast is well chosen, with the best scene stealer's being Wahlberg and the ever versatile Alec Baldwin. The mental chase games between the good cop and the bad cop are tight and suspenseful in a way uncommon in big$ Hollywood pictures these days. Expect a little taste of L.A. Confidential in several key scenes, and dialog as crisp and volatile as classic Mamet (ala G.G.R.) This is a must see that I wish I could experience again for the first time.

title: disappointing ending
review: The acting in this movie, by an all star cast, was excellent and the twisting plots keep you thinking throughout the movie. The way the movie ended was a big disappointment. It almost seemed like this great movie was ended quickly to cut the running time of the movie down or something. The last ten minutes of the movie came across as an hour's worth of plot jammed into a small time frame. I would have more than willing to spend three hours in the theater watching this movie unfurl the right way. There was also too many unanswered question's that will not see a sequel. No one is left alive to be in a sequel. And what is in the envelope that the phsycologist has in her desk? I imagine the DVD release will have an alternate ending title.

title: Best Scorsese movie in 6 years
review: I've seen most of gangs of new york and i've seen the aviator. Neither hold a candle to this movie. It felt great seeing Scorsese going back to his gangster roots. It's what he needed to do. My friend did tell me it was the same exact premise of the Japanese movie infernal affairs, and as i looked up this movie after i saw it, i wasn't surprised to see that it was worked on by some of the same writers as the Japanese movie. So i guess this is just an American version of it, which kind of disappointed me that the idea wasn't fully original. Plus towards the end it gets a little TOO crazy. But i was still satisfied with the ending itself, didn't leave anything unanswered. So in the long run, i highly suggest seeing this movie, Its well worth the $8.25.

title: The Departed : A Sure Arrival of Martin Scorsese.
review:
Martin Scorcese's new film, The Departed, a remake of the 2002 Hong Kong hit Internal Affairs, takes the action from the streets of China and moves it to Boston. Although it was changed to an American film, The Departed still focuses on the same conflict between the state police and the local mob, in this case overseen by the old-school, charismatic, Irish mobster Frank Costello played by the delightfully maleficent Jack Nicholson. Double crossing and infiltration have been a classic setup within most of Hong Kongs gangster films, and this is no exception. Starting with the City on Fire remake Reservoir Dogs, America has been doing an excellent job of remaking, whilst simultaneously manipulating, and thickening these thrillers.

The Departed, involves two cops, both working for the Massachusetts State Department, and working both sides of the law for Costello. The problem is the two know nothing of each others involvement within the crime syndicate itself. William Costigan (DiCaprio) and Colin Sullivan (Damon) never actually cross paths until the end, and this evolves into a breathtaking plunge into the much anticipated climax of the film. And let us not forget the brilliant role of Mark Wahlberg, the always disgruntled, crudely blunt cop working with Queenen (Martin Sheen) in charge of the undercover unit. This team intelligently offsets itself, from the exaggerated bad cop role to the less intimidating, but sensible good cop.

Honestly one of Scorseses' best pictures since Goodfellas, The Departed is terribly engrossing with its double-crossing, not having a single scene robbed of suspense. The stellar cast brings together some of the best cops and robbers imagery we've seen since Narc, never having dull performances, or stealing the believability of the characters. Cutting between the lives of two "rats", living on the opposite end of the spectrum, Scorsese truly captures the fear and anxiety of the two characters, which is unequivocally unfathomable. I commend this film, in not only bringing originality in its dialog from a remake, but for its re-birth of the genre. There is nobody perfect enough to bring the life back into crime films, as the person who perfected it, Martin Scorsese. If there ever was a Kill Bill for the Scorsese fans, The Departed would be it, with a gun splattered stain around every corner.

title: A Masterpiece
review: Martin Scorcese has truly outdone himself with this one. In the tradition of Deer Hunter and Taxi Driver, Scorcese has again produced a masterpiece. Full of suspense,thrill, and superb acting. I found the long movie;2:35 minutes felt like half an hour as twist after twist unfolded. Nicholson delivered a brilliant performance as the crimelord Costello. But the other performances were excellent as well. I wont get into the nitty gritty plot but as far as I am concerned this is a much deserved Oscar calibur movie for Scorcese. If he doesn't win Best Director for this I will truly be baffled. 10 out of 10 stars. This is a must see if you are a Scorcese fan, or if you really like a movie with endless twists. This film is blessed with brilliant acting and a plot that's smooth as silk. I recommend it over all else at the movies right now. Truly excillence

title: Brilliant Adaptation, Departed is a Standout in its Own Right
review: Martin Scorsese has been very consistent thus far, what with Gangs of New York and The Aviator both having gotten such great critical reviews and Oscar nominations. But with The Departed, he has hit his critical mass, and I look forward to seeing Oscar time when the stars and director get their recognition. The Departed is based on the original Hong Kong film by Andrew Lau, Infernal Affairs, which starred Andy Lau and Tony Leung in the original roles that are played here by Matt Damon and Leonardo DiCaprio (respectively) in equally, if not beyond, excellent performances. Damon and DiCaprio both play undercover cops in the Boston Police who work to infiltrate a dangerous, vicious, and insane mob boss who has control of the South Boston crime section, played with wicked and equally humorous (at least to him) skill by Jack Nicholson. However, Damon's character, Colin Sullivan, is a supposed perfect cop who in fact is a mole planted by Nicholson's mob boss character, Frank Costello, and quickly works up the ranks. DiCaprio's character, Billy Costigan, finds himself kicked out of the academy and instead working as Frank's right hand man. But everything's for a reason, and Costigan's no different: he's a undercover agent himself, his identity known only to Queenan (Martin Sheen) and Dignam (Mark Wahlberg). That's as far as I go in terms of the story, which I give immense kudos to William Monaghan. The shortcomings of the original, though the best Hong Kong film I'd ever seen, was that it was far too complicated and complex. What Monaghan has written here is one that is straight to the point and gripping as well. The strong helping factor to this whole thing is, of course, the directing, in which Scorsese hits his high mark, and the performances by a massive, unbelievable cast. Damon and DiCaprio are great here, the latter in his best performance yet. Martin Sheen plays a great role as Queenan, an essential character in maintaining Costigan's sense of who he is. Of course the high marks go to Wahlberg, whose vulgar and sarcastic Digham is a scene stealer. But Nicholson's Frank Costello is one in a million. Nicholson goes completely over-the-top here, to the point that if he'd gone any further it would've been overkill. Costello is vicious and evil to the core, and yet he finds something funny about the whole thing nonetheless. Whereas the original villain in Infernal Affairs was minor, sometimes humorous at times, Costello is the main focus here, a perverse character who has killed and deceived so much it becomes almost mundane to him, and Nicholson savors every moment of it. This is the best film I've seen so far, and it deserves every Oscar nomination and win that it gets.

title: spectacular tension
review:
The plot grips your interest, the action raises your blood pressure and the main characters keep adding nuance over time. Very intense.

Di Caprio is just great and Nicholson turns in a fine performance.

The level of violence is such that this movie is not for the squeamish or overly sensitive.

Your comment does not contain enough lines - the minimum length for comments is 10 lines of text. Please see the guidelines. Attempts to pad the comment with junk words can result in your account being blocked from future submissions.

Apparently a succinct comment is not sufficient. I rarely comment on movies at IMDb but thought this early short review would be helpful to people looking for a quick opinion about a just released movie.

title: A Little Long, but Great Cast and Screenplay
review:
Really liked this movie: the cast and acting was superb! Leonardo DiCaprio has matured as an actor and excelled in this movie, as did Matt Damon. Screenplay was witty and well crafted. Although fast moving and a bit too long, the fairly complex plot was not too difficult to follow.

Jack Nicholson was brilliant in his role as a decrepit, corrupt, aging gangster. He was intense and his line delivery made the audience uncomfortable, with inappropriate giggles and laughter from them at his creepy delivery of lines especially when he didn't believe the information his underlings/thugs were conveying him: "Who was the undercover cop among them?" A mole among the underworld....

Further, the plot thickened: "Who was the mole within the police/FBI?"

In total, this is one of the better films in this sparse movie-year.

title: I was expecting to see the movie of the year......
review: I love Martin Scorcese, Goodfellas and Mean Streets are two of my favourite films, and I highly rate every known actor on the cast!!! Given the reviews, trailers and rumours I had heard about this movie (one even bettering Goodfellas!!!!) I was very excited, although I was careful not to over-anticipate! The film opens very well, and as soon as the first installment of the soundtrack started (a throwback to Goodfellas) I was smiling broadly! The film was very good, but I felt it could have been a cinematic masterpiece, which I don't think it is. I have seen the original Infernal Affairs, but didn't want to try and compare them, I wanted to see this as an original film. The story is a good one, the characters are good but are developed very quickly, I felt the opening hour was just a quick rush of the characters, trying to squeeze everything in. The performances, however, were generally very good. I felt the screenplay lacked something, though. Jack Nicholson's character didn't really work for me, a lot of things didn't make sense (no spoilers!!!) and especially with his character, it all felt a bit clichÃ©d. If anything, I felt the story and script may have been a little simplistic, there weren't really any twists and there was no suspense. There were a dozen great scenes, but they were well spaced! I didn't like the way the filmmakers felt they had to make the story so transparent and obvious, but that seems a general theme in Hollywood now.... I would definitely see this film again, hopefully I can enjoy it more, and would recommend it, but I feel a little disappointed that this wasn't the epic crime film I was hoping for.... I'd actually give it 6.5........

title: Madolyn - holy slut!
review:
hello, i'm from Taiwan and i saw the original HK version. it was great and the fact that both main characters have a female and not SHARING a female make it great because how do you know for sure that Matt's character's girlfriend won't turn Leo in. in Chinese culutre female are very loyal to their man.

i don't like the way that both man end up meeting the same girl and in the way share her! that make her look like a slut and in many Asian society, slut are...well, stone to death sort of speak and how do we know the baby inside her belly is Matt or Leo? how can anyone trust a slut? if Leo know her boyfriend is Matt, would he trust her with the evedinces?

i prefer the HK version where both main characters have a gf of his own and not somehow end up sharing the same women.

anyway, it is still a great remake.

title: Must See Movie
review: I saw this movie, expecting it to be great considering the reviews and the amount of top-notch acting and directing backing the production of this film. I have to say I went in there expecting to see the best work from everyone and I have to say I came out enjoying it more than any review or critic said they had. I was astonished with how involved I became with the film, watching every character grow and flesh out. Leo and Matt Damon were perfect and Mark Wahlberg stole the show with his lovable and kind(that's a joke) character. This was one film of the year that I walked away from with a smile and I recommend that everyone able goes to see this.

title: Oscar for Thelma!
review:
You'll read enough praise in these boxes of Marty. He is superb and we all know it.

This film is also superb. It's one of the only examples I can think of, even though I am a DiCaprio fan, sometimes it is unavoidable to be conscious that we're watching a performance and not a character. His work in "The Departed" is an incredible exception.

I'm just here to say that the editing work by Thelma Schoonmaker once again raises the bar so high its stupid. the film is edited so frenetically yet so deftly and light it is amazing to watch.

9 out of 10

title: Scorsese back on track
review:
I don't know if it was just me but I really enjoyed this movie.

Damon and DeCaprio operate on different sides of the undercover spectrum and Jack Nicholson adds to the mix in the style that has always served him so well.

Martin Sheen and Mark Wahlberg also play lesser but important roles in the film and Scorsese really hits the mark in my eyes.

The film is well shot and the violence within it only adds to the feel of the movie.

I found the time flew by and It was good to see all the actors vying with Nicholson whose sheer presence adds gravitas to a production.

title: ...but I'm a little biased.
review:
...because I live where this movie was filmed and took place, I may have a little biased edge in giving it 10 out of 10.

I was totally captivated throughout the entire movie. What a cast!!! Of course, it may be a TAD obvious as to why Damon and Wahlberg were cast as Massachusetts State Police UC officers. That's the EASY part. Two of the major characters didn't have to learn how to "capture" authentic Boston accents. It is hilarious to listen to Martin Sheen and Alec Baldwin (and sometimes Nicholson) try to do their best bad imitations of Jack and Bobby Kennedy. Damon's girlfriend drifted between a generic accent and a half-ass Southie accent depending on with whom she was in a particular scene. She is QUITE stunning, however. (by the way...at no time did I ever hear anyone in the film utter the immortal Southie phrase "wicked pissah") All nitpicking aside, this is an instant classic. Cast, soundtrack,and it's actually really funny in most scenes. Sometimes funnier than most comedies. I guess it goes without saying that Nicholson is in perfect form as the Whitey Bulger type "Frank Costello" He almost LOOKS like Satan. (Whitey could only HOPE to have as much charisma)

Location and supporting cast is spot on. I've seen so many films that are shot in Boston and it seems like the director or producer didn't do their homework in capturing the true flavor that is Boston, Massachusetts. Scorcese deserves an A+ in preparation as far as set and location.

A local radio host once said " Boston is all about TWO things...politics and revenge". It's also about the Irish mafia. To be quite honest, as violent as the movie is it may not even come close to the real carnage that has been reaped in Southie over the years.

I don't have any reservations about recommending this movie. I saw it the day it premiered so I wouldn't be influenced by any outside sources. It is destined to be a classic alongside such greats as GoodFellas, Casino, Scarface etc.

Be ready for a flurry of twists and turns at the very end of the movie. No spoilers here. You won't be surprised....well, that is, until the last 30 seconds of the movie. ENJOY!!!!!!

(ps Anybody have any idea of a way to get my daughter to break up with her boyfriend?...an aspiring Mass State Cop.....yikes!)

title: Good, but not as great as the original
review:
Infernal Affairs is such a fantastic movie, and I sort of groaned at first when I heard it was going to be REMADE in the US rather than just RELEASED here (theatrically, that is).

Then I found out Scorsese was directing and that got me interested.

So now, four years after the original, it's finally here. And it's very good, maybe even great - though I'll need to see it again to pass that judgment. In a way, that's really saying something right there because with the original my eyes were glued to the screen (which was only a six inch portable DVD player - pretty far from the 50 foot screen I saw The Departed on yesterday) and my spirit was soaring from the opening credits. The Departed lacks the breathtakingly beautiful flowing movement (camera work, editing, nuanced physicality of lead actors) of Infernal Affairs and replaces all this with grim, violent intensity. It's a very American, very Scorsese remake. There are great moments when it creates it own powerful, visceral sense of the pain that fills its characters. The Departed puts its focus much more on the painful consequences of lying to people and on the destruction that people who are lairs by necessity (because they have so much to hide) wreak upon their world. You can surely see the social/political message implicit in this - but sometimes I want a movie to be a sweeping emotional experience and not try to engage my political conscience.

title: Great film, but not his best job in director's chair.
review:
I really think Scorcese created a unique way of depicting criminals in unconventional forms , whether you are a police captain or a member of a mob family working double shifts. The story is real. It's modern, the writing is smart and the film lets you know in the opening scene that it's setting takes place a few years ago. But in reality, it's a story that takes place right now, present time to near future. There are hints of political jabs concerning levels of power now given to the local police departments and FBI and all other agencies of law enforcement for that matter. So the writing was smart and I was really never bored once throughout the entire 2 and half plus hours.

Now I'm not going to tell you what this film is about, just go see it. It's a modern cops and mobsters/Donnie Brasco/state of grace type film. The cast has all stars everywhere. This film has a B-movie feel to it, set wise, and firefights were OK, but nothing major..very little extras, very little car chases or anything else that looks expensive to produce. Most of the budget must of went to the cast. Starting off with Jack Nicholson. He was at his best here comically since Batman. He is great comedy throughout the film, and acting wise he does a good job at showing valence, and is believable as a mob boss. The show stealer in my mind was Leonardo DiCaprio. In my honest opinion, he overshadows everyone else in the film and that's saying a lot considering how good Damon was. The only good character development Scorcese paced well is the character Leo plays named Billy Costigan. I didn't care what happened to anyone else in the film. He was as emotional as anyone has ever gotten on film. It was almost as if other actors who were on screen with DiCaprio were intimidated by his overpowering acting. The other great performance that stood out was Baldwinn's character as a vulgar fast trash talking cop. He had me laughing throughout.

So great story, smart unpredictable writing, and top notch acting; What else does this film need? well, other the split screen time between Damon and DiCaprio kind of took away from good character development. Scorcese paced the movie in choppy manner, with cuts at inappropriate moments, and some scenes were just time fillers. He might win the Oscar this year, but its all politics.He deserved it plenty of times before, but not this one. Don't take it the wrong way though, this movie deserves at least 3 Oscars, one for DiCaprio, other for Screenplay, and perhaps a third for score. This movie had some pulsating scenes in it, due in part to it's great rock and roll trademark 70's Scorcese soundtracks.

The love story was OK, nothing like Stone and Deniro in Casino, or even Diaz and DiCaprio in Gangs of NY. But there is a subplot love story in the film. The story is about going crooked in life. Monsters could be anyone, and some are saved, some are only going to wind up dead. Every dog does have it's day. Scorcese will in March, when this film racks up some awards. 8 out of 10.

title: Great Movie ! ! ! !
review:
I am a big fan of Martin, and this film made me fall in love with his work all over again. To me a good sign of a movie is that as I am watching it, I get so caught up in it, I hope it never ends. Of course all movies must end, but I love a long ride.

This movie is not predictable, all the time I was watching it, I never had any idea if good or evil would prevail.

Great story, great cast, great editing, this movie tells a story in such a way that I haven't seen in a while.

Something else about the location filmed in Boston. It captured the city well without being a "travelouge", many other films show too much of a famous city, this film showed only the city you needed to see. My wife (a former resident of Boston) pointed that out to me.

Definitely the best movie of 2006. I'd go watch this movie tomorrow, as a matter of fact, I think I will.

Thanks Marty.

Steven Truitt spt@swbell.net

title: Excellent
review:
I saw the term "potboiler" applied to The Departed by some review. I thought the term meant "suspense", but m-w.com defines it as: a usually inferior work (as of art or literature) produced chiefly for profit.

M-W need to amend their definition: Pot full of water. Add plenty of rough chopped potatoes. Lots of salt. Burner on full. Now watch it come to boil slowly but surely. Let boil over.

Damn it's been a while since I've head some satisfying stew!!

Thank you, Mr. Scorcese, grandmaster chef extraordinaire.

Attempts to pad the comment with junk words can result in your account being blocked from future submissions, it warns! Screw you, I shout...

title: Great Remake of a Great Film
review:
Going into the movie I didn't know what to expect having seen Internal Affairs. But I can say that Martin Scorsese is one of the true great filmmakers of our time. I enjoyed the movie immensely and was impressed by how well the plot line moved from the Hong Kong environment to the Boston one. I am also glad to report that it is not a carbon copy remake of Internal Affairs as one poster would like you to believe. I think that this movie is maybe even a little bit better than Internal Affairs. I hate to say it but it has a few plot points that are different and I won't go into those now. But Martin Scorsese has done a wonderful job in directing this movie.

The acting is also wonderful in this movie. With what I think should be an Oscar winning performance for Jack. As he is great in almost every movie he is in but he has outdone himself here. It doesn't hurt that he has a great supporting cast. I know a lot of people have denounce Leo for not having any talent but I think he has redeemed himself for Titanic. But I think he has proved himself with time. If anything the worst actor in this movie is Matt Damon I found his performance was stale and he wasn't very likable unlike Andy Lau in Internal Affairs.Alec Baldwin gives somewhat of a comedic performance in this movie as does Marky Mark.I think that this movie should be Oscar worthy for sure and hope it finally gets Martin the statue he deserves.

title: Far from original, but a classic nonetheless
review:
Just left the theater, and for the first time in awhile, I feel like my money was well spent. Although parts of this film were predictable, the performance of every main character was so convincing that it didn't matter if I knew what was going to happen. DiCaprio & Damon can both hold their own w/ Nicholson, but Jack is the greatest and he proves why here. Wahlberg, Sheen & Baldwin were all superb in their supporting roles, especially the one formerly associated w/ the funky bunch. The last 20 minutes is like a kick in the gut to the audience, and will make you question who's side you were actually on. The ending was well worth the 2 hrs and 29 minutes of uncomfortable sitting. This movie receives my highest recommendation for the genre, and I think we will be hearing a lot more about this film come awards season.

Enjoy!

title: exciting
review: Its one of those movies that has you thinking but not a lot. I really thought it was good.Jack was amazing as always. Matt Damon was perfect for this role, looking like a good guy but good at hiding his dark side.And of course Leonardo DiCaprio who is one of my favorite actors really took the spot light. He really has become a leading man rather than a boy. He is so believable.I really thought his character had this undeniable charisma. there were also some other really great performances from the co-stars. Overall I thought it was a really well thought out film. Martin Scorsese doing what hes best at. He is always doing good films. Recently they have been unnoticed by many. But this is a classic to be placed beside a movie like Goodfellas. Maybe even something in the Oscar cards for Scorsese. One thing I like about this movie was that I didn't get distracted by anything. I could not. Bravo

title: A good return of the old Scorsese
review:
The Departed starts out with a scene that Scorsese does well. the mob boss walking through a shop, paying for other people things, and acting in charge of things. We soon meet the young Matt Damon character that grows up to be a cop that's in bed with the Irish mob. Then, we meet Leonardo DiCaprio's character, a cop who got kicked out of the police academy who gets a second chance to work against the mob. The story move right into story before you know it. Matt Damon's is soon a detective, with a kick ass apartment over looking Boston. For Leonardo, things are so smooth. Getting a chance to get at the Irish mob, he soon takes. When the mob boss, Jack Nicholson, asks Matt Damon's character to find out who the other cop is.

The story does one thing very well that original Chinese movie 'Infernal Affairs' did, also. The quick story pace. Of course Scorsese being Scorsese the story won't hang in a nothing scene. I love the differences from the original movie, and LOVED the fact that Scorsese didn't go through the Italian route. It was a very nice change, and a nice look back at what he was doing in the seventies and on. the movie provided a very well written story, and the movie was very well acted. This, I hope, will beat that Oliver Stone melodrama. 10 out of 10.

title: Violence, Language & maybe a bit over-clever
review:
I will start by saying if you are not a fan of very strong violence or very strong language, you should probably steer clear of this one. If you have seen any Scorsese movie before, you should know what to expect, but be warned this should be able to give goodfellas a run for its money on the cold blooded killings and swearing front.

I did like this movie a lot, but did have a hard time keeping up with it at times. There is A lot of people being undercover, switching sides and generally lieing to each other as to who's side they are on. Luckily it didn't get to the point of trying to be too over-clever (see oceans 12) but at times it was trying, and I feel the average viewer would have a hard time keeping up with this story.

Jack Nocholsons character reminded me a lot of Ben Kingsley's in Sexy Beast. A very intimidating and unpredictable man, who uses extreme violence and language on an everyday basis. And even though they both did not have much screen time (compared to some other major characters)I think everyone will agree they were both the best thing about both of these films.

Throughout watching this film, I couldn't help think it reminded me a lot of Michael Mann's action-drama "Heat". Both films used a lot of character development to make the shootout scenes that much more rewarding. Both used a mix of mellow and tense music to add extra depth to the scenes, and both used the entire first three quarters of the movie just as a warm up for the end when all the action took place, and you finally figured everything out.

I'm sure a lot of people will like the final 20 minutes a lot, I felt a bit like as there was so much time spent on developing thee plot and characters, Marty felt as though there wasn't much else left to do so just decided to kill everyone off. But I guess this was the way it turned out in the original, so I cant comment on that.

Overall I liked this film a lot. I think it should have maybe ended about 10 minutes earlier, as at one point near the very end I thought to myself "Most of the characters are gone, what is left to do"? I'm still deciding if it was my favourite of the year so far, but after 6 months or so waiting for the release, I think I can safely say I was not disappointed.

title: Absolutely great
review: This movie is amazing. I saw it today in London, and it blew me away, even more so as I was thinking about it, 2 hrs after I left the theatre. I was not a big Di Caprio fan beforehand, because I was let down with his performance in Gangs of New York, and the movie in general, but he more than makes up for it here. He is a real man now and his performance shows it. The rest of the cast, from Alec Baldwin, Martin Sheen, Jack, Damon, the beautiful shrink, and Ray Winston all deserve academy award nominations. Scorsese paints a masterpiece here. It is such a detailed movie that seemingly inconsequential details come back through the movie to explain certain scenarios, and that only an artist can do. This movie will become a true classic.

title: Goodfellas for our generation.
review:
I was too young to see Goodfellas in the theater but now I can imagine what that must have been like. As the movie opens with the Stones "Gimmie Shelter" you know you're in for a treat.

Scorseses last two films have been very good but after seeing The Departed in the theater my generation now knows what made him the directing legend that he is. Dicaprio grew up in this picture and finally delivered the performance that his reputation would you lead you to believe he had given many times before. Damon is in true "Good Will Hunting" form and Jack is well...Jack. It's hard for me to imagine another film due this year delivering better entertainment than this. In my humble opinion this and United 93 stand alone as the top two films of 06 so far.

title: Excellent flick!!
review: Typical Scorcese film: "Black," violent, lots of blood, twisting plots! If DiCaprio doesn't get an Oscar for this part, it will be a shame. If you remember him in a swell role in "Gangs of New York," you'll be amazed at how he tops that role in this film. And...I'm not a Dicaprio fan! Usually, when you see a flick loaded with stars, it's a pretty good sign that it's not worth seeing. Not so here! Nicholson is his typical scroungy hateful self. Great job on his part. Matt Damon, whom I absolutely do not like did a great job at being a worthless rat! One of my favorite stars is Mark Walberg. I was disappointed that he was given such a small role, but watch out for him in the end of the movie!!!!
